HEADLINE: Gene Tie to Male Violence Is Studied

BYLINE: By NATALIE ANGIER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21

 BODY:
Scientists have identified a tiny genetic defect that appears to predispose some men toward aggression, impulsiveness and violence, a discovery that is likely to rekindle the harsh debate over the causes of criminal and abnormal behavior.
Researchers emphasized, however, that the finding was thus far limited to a single large family, and that the inherited illness was likely to be quite rare in the general population. 
 Nevertheless, scientists said the discovery counts as a persuasive advance for human behavioral genetics, a field that has lately been in disarray as previous announcements of genes for manic-depression, schizophrenia and alcoholism have either been disproved or come under withering criticism.
In the new work, researchers from the Netherlands and the United States studied a large Dutch family with a history of erratic and often hostile behavior among some, but not all, males in the group. Those afflicted often react to the most mildly stressful occasions with aggressive outbursts, shouting at, cursing or assaulting the person they deem a threat.
 
Intelligence Found Low
 At other times, the men have committed arson, attempted rape and exposed themselves in public. In addition, their intelligence is on the low end of normal, with an average I.Q. of around 85 to 90.
The researchers have linked the abnormal behaviors to mutations in the gene responsible for the body's production of monoamine oxidase-a, an enzyme critical for breaking down chemicals that allow brain cells to communicate. The scientists do not yet know the exact mechanism of the disorder, but they propose that lacking the metabolic enzyme, the brains of afflicted men end up with excess deposits of potent signaling molecules like serotonin, dopamine and noradrenaline. Those surplus neurotransmitters in turn stimulate erratic, often hostile conduct.
"A human behavior like aggression is very complex," said Dr. Han G. Brunner, a geneticist at University Hospital in Nigmegen, the Netherlands. "But our study shows that in certain instances a biological factor clearly influences the behavior." Dr. Brunner is the lead author of the new report, which is appearing Friday in the journal Science.
Comparing the monamine oxidase-a genes in 5 afflicted and 12 nonafflicted males of the family, the scientists found a difference in only a single biochemical building block among the thousands that make up the gene, a type of defect called a point mutation. In each case, those who showed a predisposition to aggressive, impulsive behavior had the mutation, and those who did not show such symptoms lacked it.
 
Skin Cells Affected
 Biochemical analysis of the men's skin cells also showed a severe deficiency in the essential enzyme.
"Other studies have implicated biological and inherited factors" in aggression, Dr. Brunner said. "This is the first that actually pinpoints a specific gene and a specific mutation within that gene."
The gene is located on the X chromosome, which explains why only males, with their single copy of the X chromosome, can suffer from the enzyme deficiency. Women can serve as carriers of the genetic defect, but are themselves protected from its symptoms by their possession of a second, good copy of the gene, sitting on their second X chromosome.
The researchers do not yet know how many people worldwide may suffer from the enzyme deficiency, but based on other types of hereditary disorders, they estimate that defects in monoamine oxidase-a are likely to afflict no more than 1 in 100,000 people.
 
'A Rare Disorder'
 "What this paper does is give harder data to aggressive behavior in some people," said Dr. Emil F. Coccaro, director of clinical neuroscience research at the Medical College of Pennsylvania in Philadelphia. "But this is a rare disorder. It ain't the gene for all those people who are committing murder left and right."
Dr. Markku Linnoila, the scientific director of the National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism in Bethesda, Md., said: "This is an important step in understanding the biological determinants of human behavior. We learn by looking at extremes -- that's where the pay dirt is. Once you're able to make these kinds of findings, you look to see how it generalizes to the wider population."
Dr. Xandra O. Breakefield, an associate neurogeneticist at Massachusetts General Hospital in Charlestown and an author of the new report, cautions that even in a seemingly straightforward case like an enzyme disorder, the spectrum of the afflicted men's behaviors cannot be explained by a single genetic defect alone.
"Different members of the family behave differently," she said. "Some are functioning quite well, and one is married, has children and a job. Obviously how this syndrome is manifested as a behavior depends on many factors." She suggested that the finding could result in new therapies for the disorder, either drugs to help metabolize neurotransmitters, or a change in diet to prevent buildup of the chemicals.
 
Criticism of 'Aggressive Genes'
 Studies of the genetics of aggression and violence have fomented much acrimony among researchers and academics, some of whom see the research as disguised racism or attempts to reduce complex social and economic problems to a measurable blot on a laboratory X-ray. Last year a political uproar prompted the National Institutes of Health to cancel a conference scheduled to be held at the University of Maryland on the genetics of violence and criminal behavior.
Even Dr. Brunner emphasized that he and his colleagues had not set out to seek the genetic causes of aggression, but rather were responding to a request from a member of the Dutch family who already had done enough investigations on his own to conclude there was some hereditary abnormality at work in his bloodline.
Dr. Jonathan Beckwith, professor of microbiology and molecular genetics at Harvard Medical School in Boston and a critic of much research in behavioral genetics, complained that the latest study, like others before it, failed to define aggressive behavior in sufficient detail.
"It's been a long-term problem in this area, an insufficient characterization of the behaviors you're looking at," he said. "That's one reason why there have been so many announcements of genes that have later been retracted. There's often a lot less here than meets the eye."

HEADLINE: Amtrak to Cut Back Service On 3 Lines to Save $10 Million

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21

 BODY:
Amtrak announced today that it would reduce service on three passenger train routes and shut 15 ticket offices on Nov. 4. The cuts will save $10 million a year, it said.
The rail line is forced to cut service because it is not receiving an increase in Federal subsidies this year, as it requested, to offset declining ticket sales, said a spokesman, Howard Robertson. 
 These routes will be scaled back:
*The Pioneer, which has operated daily between Chicago and Seattle through Denver and Portland, will have only three runs a week west of Denver, departing Denver and Seattle on Monday, Wednesday and Saturday.
*The Texas Eagle, between Chicago and San Antonio-Houston, will run three times a week instead of daily south of St. Louis. The train that goes beyond St. Louis will depart Chicago on Sunday, Tuesday and Friday and San Antonio-Houston on Tuesday, Thursday and Sunday.
*The River Cities train between Kansas City and New Orleans will effectively be eliminated as Amtrak cuts out stops in St. Louis and Carbondale, Ill. Instead, Amtrak will provide nonstop buses between St. Louis and Centralia, Ill., that will connect with trains. Also, train service to Belleville, Ill., on the River Cities run will be dropped.
The rail line delayed a decision on eliminating three commuter trains on its Harrisburg-to-Philadelphia route. Amtrak is seeking financing from Pennsylvania.
Ticket offices will be closing in Delray Beach, Fla.; Pocatello, Idaho; Centralia, Ill.; Chillicothe, Ill.; Mattoon, Ill.; Fort Wayne, Ind.; Hattiesburg, Miss.; McComb, Miss.; Malta, Mont.; Southern Pines, N.C.; Devils Lake, N.D.; Amsterdam, N.Y.; Youngstown, Ohio; Temple, Texas, and Cheyenne, Wyo.
Trains will continue to stop at stations where ticket offices are being closed. Passengers with reservations can buy their tickets from the conductors on the trains for which they have reserved seats, but passengers without reservations would have to get their tickets in advance from a travel agent or at an Amtrak ticket office elsewhere.
The closings of these ticket offices, combined with a staff reduction at ticket offices in Johnstown, Pa., and North Philadelphia, will eliminate the positions of 33 ticket agents, Mr. Robertson said. "We will try where possible to put those people elsewhere," he said.
For further savings, Amtrak wants to eliminate 149 other positions this year but has not decided which ones, Mr. Robertson said.
Amtrak, with 25,000 employees nationwide, will get $351 million from the Federal Government this fiscal year, the same as it received last year but less than the $381 million it requested.
Amtrak revenues for the 1991-92 fiscal year were $1.3 billion, down from $1.4 billion the previous year. Figures for last fiscal year, which ended Sept. 30, have not been compiled.
The decline could be attributed to "everything from the recession, the airline deals, to the strike" against the railroad in July 1992, Mr. Robertson said.

HEADLINE: More Signs of a Productive U.S.

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
Contrary to a widely held view that the United States is an industrial has-been whose productivity in manufacturing has been surpassed in some other countries, a new study concludes that for manufacturing as a whole, the United States still holds a significant edge over the presumed world standard-setters, Germany and Japan.
The yearlong study -- by the consulting firm McKinsey & Company, together with three of the nation's top experts on productivity including Robert M. Solow, a Nobel laureate in economics -- combined research into nine industries with a wide array of available statistics. 
 While other studies have also found that the United States was still the world's productivity leader in manufacturing, the new study provides a more detailed look at individual industries.
Productivity, or output per hour worked, is the ultimate yardstick of an economy's competitiveness. It determines a nation's material standard of living as well as its standing among nations.
 
Explaining the Disparities
 Perhaps the most provocative findings concern the probable causes of the productivity differences that do exist. It concludes that in industries where the United States has fallen behind, the reasons have more to do with how goods are produced than with the skills of workers or the quality of technology.
"If the United States is lagging behind Japan in certain manufacturing industries, it doesn't appear to be because of the failure of our schools or technology," said Martin Baily, a University of Maryland professor, who helped direct the study. "We haven't put enough effort into organizing the workplace and designing products so that they are easy to manufacture."
Others versed in the field welcomed the McKinsey effort. "A couple of economists in some dingy room can cook up anything," said John A. Young, former chief executive of the Hewlett-Packard Company and chairman of President Ronald Reagan's Commission on Industrial Competitiveness. "This draws on McKinsey's incredible network of people in the field who can do a little sanity check on the numbers."
The study, a sequel to a McKinsey report last year that found that American service industries had a large productivity lead over the German and Japanese industries, challenges the view of some influential economists -- from Lester Thurow of M.I.T., author of "Head to Head: The Coming Economic Battle Among Japan, Europe and America," to Laura D'Andrea Tyson, chief of the Council of Economic Advisers -- who have argued that American manufacturing has been overtaken by German and Japanese industries.
"There's a lot of conventional wisdom swirling around here that's turning out, by and large, just to be wrong," said Bill Lewis, director of the McKinsey Global Institute in Washington, and a former Assistant Secretary of Energy in the Carter Administration.
The study also suggests that losing leadership in a particular set of industries -- cars, steel, consumer electronics -- does not preclude first-rate economic peformance or, for that matter, high living standards any more than a student with A-'s and B+'s would necessarily be less able than one who has a mixture of A+'s and D's.
"In the heads of a lot of people, there's a consumer-electronics theory of economic welfare," said Francis Bator, a Harvard University economist, who advised the research team. "It's nonsense."
The advice the report proffers runs counter to the conventional wisdom, and boils down to doing what the United States -- as opposed to Europe and Japan -- has already been doing: Where you lag, open your borders -- not just to imports, but to transplants; where you lead, set up shop in the countries of the laggards.
"You can make theoretical arguments about managed trade," Mr. Lewis said, "but the evidence that we found, for the first time, is that the more open you are, the more productive you become. On the U.S. side, the proof is the renaissance of the U.S. auto industry."
McKinsey's comparisons of individual industries show that the United States is by no means the most efficient producer of all products: Japanese output an hour is 15 percent to almost 50 percent higher in cars, car parts, machine tools, consumer electronics and steel.
Germany's productivity, which is half to three-fourths this country's in half a dozen industries from cars to beer, is equal to the United States' in steel and machine tools.
But these industrial powerhouses trail so far behind in some other industries -- packaged food in Japan, beer and cars in Germany -- that, measured in dollars of comparable purchasing power, the average Japanese or German factory worker produces $8 worth of goods in the time it takes an American worker to make $10 worth. The comparisons are based on case studies of nine industries that account for about a fifth of United States manufacturing.
In Japan, for example, a worker in the highly protected and fragmented food-processing industry -- which employs more workers than the auto, computer, consumer-electronics and machine-tool industries combined -- produces $39 worth of food in an hour, compared with an American counterpart's $119.
"What makes the Japan-U.S. comparison for manufacturing as a whole so much in the U.S. favor is that food production is such a large business in Japan and is so primitive," Professor Bator said.
 
Quality Beyond Technology
 The study suggests that a lack of leading-edge technology is less important than some suggest. Brewers in Germany, for example, are far less productive than Japanese or American beer makers. But the reason is hardly that the Germans lack the technology. The more efficient American and Japanese brewers use machinery imported from Germany.
Nor is lesser technology necessarily the difference in cars. General Motors, for instance, poured billions into robots and other glitzy technology, while Toyota and other Japanese manufacturers placed less emphasis on a high-tech approach and concentrated on how they trained, organized and motivated workers.
McKinsey's prescription for raising productivity -- to expose manufacturers to head-to-head competition with Japan, Germany or whoever is No. 1 in an industry -- raises hackles among American advocates of industrial policy.
The Europeans, said Stephen S. Cohen, co-director of the Berkeley Roundtable on the International Economy, "would be foolish to resist pressures to insulate themselves."
"They don't need more pressure," he added. "They don't have to take the same bloodletting"
But Professor Baily has a different perception. "We keep hearing policy makers say 'We've got to protect,' as if Americans got no benefit from going through all this pain and agony," he remarked. "Our industries today are in much better shape. Our view is that the evidence -- particularly from Germany, which hasn't allowed that kind of competition -- suggests that you should let the winners and losers emerge."
Copies of the report can be obtained from the McKinsey Global Institute in Washington by calling (202) 662-3141.

HEADLINE: Tokyo Journal;
Red-Light District, Fortunes Dimmed, Is Gloomy

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Oct. 21

 BODY:
When the Tokyo Metropolitan Government opened a big commercial complex this year next to a warren of peep shows, strip clubs and massage parlors known as Kabukicho, it was regarded as a cleansing shaft of light that would refurbish the hard-bitten area.
The new building had well-lighted plazas, a hospital, a large health club and a store that symbolizes the purer virtues of fresh air and good clean fun to Japanese as well as Americans -- L. L. Bean. 
 It was a noble idea, but the experiment in clean living is receiving a decidedly mixed welcome in this city's best known red-light district.
"It's too bright here now," moaned Isoji Mochizuki, manager of the tiny Hotel Villa Shinjuku, a "love hotel" along a once-dark alley where rooms are let by the hour. "People never come during the day and at night it's too lit up now. We're demanding that at least they plant some trees to block all that light."
 
Lamenting a Loss
 The looming complex is just one sign that all is not as it used to be in Tokyo's Tenderloin. The air is still redolent of stale beer most evenings, as hawkers in dark glasses cluster in the shadows, ready to pounce with pictures of doe-eyed beauties and promises of a good time.
Mercedes-Benzes with heavily tinted windows -- the calling card of organized crime groups, known as yakuza -- continue to patrol the alleys between the garishly appointed clubs and stalls selling freshly grilled eel and prawns.
But whether it is aggressive property developers, the growing fear of AIDS or, worst of all, an influx of foreign prostitutes and Asian gangsters, many Kabukicho die-hards are lamenting the loss of simpler times. It is coming as a rude shock that the underside of Japanese society is proving as vulnerable to the economic and political dislocations under way here as the Parliament and giant corporations.
"On the surface this has become a much more healthy place," complained Naoyuki Ogawa, the owner of American Crystal, a so-called private room massage club.
"But now you see people from the Taiwan mafia or the Southeast Asian mafia," he added. "The new competition has actually made this a more dangerous area. We've had more assaults on pachinko parlors and other shops. It's not like the old days when the yakuza believed in peaceful prosperity."
 
A Still-Thriving Industry
 Kazumi Suzuki, deputy head of the Shinjuku Police Precinct, the ward in which Kabukicho is situated, put it more bluntly. "It's almost all foreigners now engaged in prostitution," he said. "The customers are more and more foreigners, too."
Although prostitution is technically illegal in Japan, the "pink industry," as it is known, thrives in all its myriad forms in Kabukicho. There are clubs with booths where women fondle the customers and "soaplands," where men get a good scrub and other services.
While hard-drinking businessmen are the mainstays of the clubs, young people throng to the many cheap pubs. In the older alleys of closet-sized bars once favored by artists and writers, wandering musicians serenade patrons with accordions and traditional ballads.
The nearby Shinjuku train and subway station, whose many recesses fill up at night with homeless people, is as crowded at midnight as in the afternoon rush hour.
 
Keepers of the Peace
 Kabukicho is the successor to the famous old pleasure quarters of Tokyo -- once known dreamily as the "floating world" -- that have been an integral part of life here for hundreds of years. In the eyes of some, it is no less essential today, providing a safety valve for the white-collared minions in the pressure-cooker known as Japan Inc.
Even the gangsters in jade green or royal blue suits, who control the nights in this area of western Tokyo -- a stone's throw from the huge new city hall -- have long been accepted as keepers of the peace.
Mr. Ogawa proudly brandished his membership card to the new health club and said he was not among those who objected to the complex. It is called Hygeia, a play on a word incongruous in the area's sunless, cramped streets -- hygiene.
"Among my friends many wanted to join this club, but since it's in Kabukicho they wondered if the other members would be, you know, scary people," he said. "But it's mostly just ordinary salarymen."
Meanwhile, across the street sits the crumbling building that houses the Kabukicho merchants' association.
 
How the Change Began
 Change began in a small way in the early 1980's when a law was introduced requiring that clubs close at midnight. Not all do, but it meant that the area slowed down in the early morning hours, squeezing profits. As some clubs went under, fast-food restaurants moved in. Today, among the brightest lights in Kabukicho are those of McDonald's, Kentucky Fried Chicken and Haagen-Dazs.
The two-year-old recession and another law that took effect last year cracking down on the yakuza have put a further dent in business. On top of that has been the influx of other Asians, from Taiwan, China, South Korea and Southeast Asia.
Many came during the boom years of the 1980's, when Japanese shunned undesirable work, whether it was on road construction gangs or in massage parlors. The yakuza then began to import Asian women, at times forcibly and under brutal conditions. But without realizing it they opened the way for other Asian gangs, too. The result has been yet more competition for a shrinking pie.
Mr. Ogawa has sought to turn back the clock in his own way. His approach is stamped in big letters on the front door of his club, "Japanese Only!"
"That's so people can know it is safe," he said. "I don't want to sound like I'm prejudiced. I know some foreigners are wonderful people and that they don't have AIDS. But once we let one in I'm worried about how we would control things. My customers have to be comfortable."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Kabukicho is a strip in Tokyo where business hours start at dark and hotels rent rooms by the hour. The boom of the 1980's included Japanese shunning undesirable work and the opening in Kabukicho of Hygeia, left, a brightly lit complex with a health spa, a hospital and an L. L. Bean store. Now, the Tenderloin district is steeped in competition as the parlors compete for a piece of a shrinking pie. (Haruyoshi Yamaguchi for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Watching the Bottom Line, Investors Trim 8.94 Off the Dow

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY

 BODY:
Investors took most of their cues yesterday from reports of third-quarter earnings, creating small ripples throughout the stock market that failed to converge into big waves.
Most of the broad indicators zigzagged through the session in a narrow range, though a sharp drop in bond prices touched off a selloff of blue chips just before the closing bell. 
 Despite two snippets of favorable economic news, the market again seemed hesitant as investors warily considered the record gains of recent weeks. They shrugged off a cut in interest rates by the German central bank and a positive report on the economy from the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia.
 Instead, they scrutinized the balance sheets of companies like Computer Associates, which rose 4 7/8, to 38, after it said its profits jumped in the last quarter. Another strong performer was Tandy, which shot up 4 7/8, to 40 1/2, on news that its earnings were higher than expected.
"It really is a case of if you have the good numbers, you do well," said Dennis E. Jarrett, chief market analyst for Kidder, Peabody & Company. "The direction of the market in most cases was almost immaterial. People are cautious. They are not anxious to dive in."
 
Computer Stocks Benefit
 Declines in the blue chips -- particularly in the stocks of companies whose earnings are sensitive to the health of the economy -- were offset by gains among small and medium-sized companies, which had plunged earlier in the week. Computer, media and tobacco stocks were among the market's standouts, while telecommunications, transportation and chemical issues suffered.
The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 8.94 points, to 3,636.16. It had been mostly even in midafternoon, but then was hit by news that the Treasury's 30-year bond yield had shot up to 5.91 percent from 5.82 percent. Higher interest rates often hurt stocks because they make the return on bonds more attractive relative to equities.
 
Mixed Indicators
 Other indicators were mixed. The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks was down 0.71 point, to 465.36. The American Stock Exchange composite index was up 0.93 point, to 477.52. Ending a three-session losing streak, the Nasdaq composite index rose 3.03, to 771.28.
Big Board volume was 289.6 million shares, down from 307.2 million shares on Wednesday. Declining stocks outnumbered gainers by about 10 to 9.
Most active on the New York Stock Exchange was WMX Technologies, the waste-management company, which dropped 1/8, to 23 7/8. The stock plunged 4 7/8 on Wednesday after the company reported sharply lower third-quarter earnings.
Circus Circus Enterprises, which also fell hard Wednesday because of lower income, continued its decline, dropping 7/8, to 38 1/4. Philip Morris rose 7/8, to 52 3/4, rebounding from losses earlier in the week.
After reporting an earnings turnaround, Sears, Roebuck rose 1, to 59. Mobil was up 1/8, to 80 5/8, on third-quarter profits that rose 40 percent. American General was down 2 1/8, to 29 1/2, on heavy volume. It posted third-quarter income of 55 cents a share, down from 63 cents a year earlier.
Dow Chemical fell 2 1/2, to 56 3/8, on news that its profits had fallen 9 percent.
Technology issues again dominated the Nasdaq. Microsoft was off 1 1/2, to 79 1/2, on trading of nearly four million shares. Its earnings, reported Wednesday, were slightly better than expected, but analysts expressed concerns about prospective growth.
Apple Computer increased 2 1/2, to 30 1/4, and Intel rose 1 3/4, to 64 1/2.

HEADLINE: Washington Talk;
Dole Tries To Rein In President, But Slips

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ASHINGTON, Oct. 21

 BODY:
In foreign policy as in domestic policy, Senator Bob Dole of Kansas can play good cop / bad cop with President Clinton.
As a good cop, Mr. Dole has offered to work with the Administration to overhaul the health care system, and he helped orchestrate a compromise resolution on Somalia last week that averted a collision between the President and Congress. 
 But just as Mr. Dole spoiled Mr. Clinton's honeymoon with Congress by leading the filibuster that killed his plan to stimulate the economy, he offered another challenge this week by proposing a resolution that would have placed strict limits on the President's military options in Haiti. Only this time he misstepped.
As the Senate minority leader, Mr. Dole serves as Mr. Clinton's loyal "speed bump." But the Kansas Republican is also positioning himself for a possible third run for the Presidency. That means he must compete with Senator Phil Gramm, the highly partisan conservative Texan who is already crisscrossing New Hampshire, while trying to avoid the image that Democrats try to pin on him as the Darth Vader of gridlock.
"When running for President, the safe place is right of center," a senior Republican Senator said. "There's a lot of Gramm versus Dole in this."
Mr. Dole usually plays his balancing act with skill, but this week he stumbled a bit in his attempt to fine-tune the President's wavering policy in Haiti. On Sunday, without first consulting other senior Republicans, Mr. Dole announced he would introduce a resolution that would have obliged Mr. Clinton to seek an authorizing vote from Congress before deploying troops in Haiti.
The Dole proposal included a big loophole, by which the President could have filed a formal certification stating that American lives or national security interests were imperiled before invading the country. But Mr. Dole was clearly throwing down a challenge to the President's authority, saying that trying to restore Haiti's deposed President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, was not worth a drop of American blood.
The Republican leader found himself in the unfortunate position of being a general with too few troops, and he quickly backed off. He offered to negotiate with the White House, and in three days of talks he watered down his proposal into a weaker, nonbinding Sense of the Senate.
Before the Senate agreed to the resolution today by a 98-to-2 vote, Mr. Dole told his colleagues on the Senate floor that he was trying "to help the President of the United States." In an interview afterward, he said: "The President did get the message. I think it will be a cold day in July before American troops are sent there."
Mr. Dole and Mr. Clinton effectively struck a truce on foreign policy when they each agreed to support the compromise resolution on Haiti, as well as a similar resolution inspired by the Republican leader calling for but not requiring Congressional authorization for the deployment of troops in Bosnia.
But while White House officials praised Mr. Dole for his willingness to compromise, a number of Republican lawmakers found fault with the Senator's handling of the Haiti issue. Speaking on condition that they not be identified, they said he misjudged the sentiments of his Republican colleagues and proposed a constitutionally questionable resolution for what appeared to be political reasons.
The senior Republican Senator said Mr. Dole had "overcompensated" for his recent moves to the left in supporting Mr. Clinton on Somalia and backing the health care proposals of Senator John H. Chafee, the Rhode Island Republican who is seeking a compromise with the Administration.
Mr. Dole's positions on the two issues put him at odds with Mr. Gramm, whose approaches were more finely tuned to the majority in the Republican Senate caucus and to Republicans who vote in primaries.
The senior Republican , who is normally a strong supporter of Mr. Dole, expressed disappointment that after fighting off Democratic attempts to hamstring the foreign policies of Presidents Ronald Reagan and George Bush, Mr. Dole would now try to do the same against Mr. Clinton.
"Bob probably did not anticipate that people like me would object to his well-intentioned move on constitutional grounds," said Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona. Speaking of the original Dole proposal, he added: "If it had passed, it could have come back to haunt us. It would have set a dangerous precedent."
Expressing the view of several Republicans, Senator Conrad Burns of a Montana said, "You got to ask, How would I vote if my guy was in the White House?"

HEADLINE: CAMPAIGN TRAIL;
Ammunition in Tax-Rebate Scare

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY

 BODY:
With little warning, debate has been rekindled over New Jersey's homestead tax-rebate program -- a touchy subject with one of the most powerful groups in the electorate: the elderly.
Assembly Speaker Garabed (Chuck) Haytaian, a Republican, charged yesterday that the administration of Gov. Jim Florio, a Democrat, had either manipulated or mismanaged the distribution of this year's rebate checks and touched off what the Speaker described as panic and anger among thousands of elderly people. The tax rebates are sent annually to homeowners and tenants. 
 "It appears thousands of them have gotten homestead rebate checks in the mail but have been told they cannot cash them at the bank and if they spend the money, they will have to pay it back," Mr. Haytaian thundered during a news conference.
"A suspicious man might think the Governor mailed out the checks deliberately so they could yank them back at the last moment, infuriate senior citizens just days before the election and place the blame on Republicans," Mr. Haytaian said. "I think there is something sinister about the timing and the handling of the rebate checks."
Mr. Haytaian's accusations brought swift countercharges from the Democrats.
"Mr. Haytaian's motivation is painfully obvious," said the Assembly Democratic minority leader, Joseph V. Doria Jr. "He desperately wants to obscure the fact that they cut the rebate program last year and he wants to alarm senior citizens for political gain."
The dispute begin when the executive director of the State Office of Aging in Warren County, Mr. Haytaian's home, sent a letter to thousands of county residents age 65 or older, who only days before had begun receiving rebate checks. The letter advised them: "Don't cash your homestead rebate check!!!"
The letter cited a recent New Jersey Tax Court decision that certain groups of people were no longer eligible for the tax rebate: tenants living in government-subsidized housing, including developments for people with low incomes and the elderly, and tenants living in a dwelling that is exempt from property taxes.
Some bank officials, acting on their own, stopped honoring the rebate checks, and signs went up at numerous housing complexes and group homes for the elderly warning residents not to cash their checks.
 
Brady Endorses Democrats
 James S. Brady, the White House press secretary who was wounded in 1981 during an assassination attempt on President Ronald Reagan, went to New Jersey yesterday to endorse Mr. Florio and Democratic legislative candidates.
Mr. Brady calls himself a "staunch Republican" but said he supported Mr. Florio and the Democrats because of their positions on gun control and their defense of the state's ban on semiautomatic weapons.
Polls have shown that New Jersey residents overwhelmingly support the weapons ban, one of the toughest in the nation. But the polls also show that gun control is not one of the major issues in this year's election.
Nevertheless, Mr. Florio and the Democrats have pressed the issue and Mr. Brady's visit today was part of that campaign strategy.
Since he was wounded March 30, 1981, Mr. Brady has become one of the most outspoken advocates in the nation for gun control through his Washington-based lobbying organization, Handgun Control Inc.
 
Support From Black Clergy
 Mr. Florio picked up a much more significant endorsement yesterday from black clergymen who represent nearly 700 churches.
Both Mr. Florio and Mrs. Whitman had eagerly courted the Black Ministers' Council for its endorsement and had met with members of the group several times since September to explain their positions on minority judgeships, contracts, public education, employment and the economy.
"Our main priority was not whether the candidate was Democrat or Republican, but which candidate is best for our constituency," said the Rev. Reginald T. Jackson, pastor of St. Matthew A.M.E. Church in Orange and a spokesman for the council. "After hearing, reading and questioning the candidates we have concluded that for us, the best candidate is Jim Florio."
Both candidates have focused tightly on middle-class and suburban voters and avoided direct references to exclusively urban issues. The large urban centers, with mostly black populations, typically vote Democratic. But many blacks have talked of disappointment with Governor Florio over the relatively small number of minority appointments as judges and prosecutors.
Even though some ministers voiced concerns about Mr. Florio, Mr. Jackson said the council was more troubled by Mrs. Whitman's inexperience and platform, most notably her tax-cut plan and her advocacy of a school voucher program.
 
G.O.P. Assails Clinton Visits
 Haley Barbour, chairman of the Republican National Committee, weighed in yesterday with criticism that Governor Florio's campaign was not footing the bill for trips to New Jersey by President Clinton and others who had stumped for the Governor. "We want to make sure they play by the same rules as everybody else," Mr. Barbour told reporters in Washington, echoing complaints already made by Mrs. Whitman.
The chairman said he was particularly incensed by Attorney General Janet Reno's recent trip to New Jersey. "We have a tradition in this country that goes back at least a generation," he said. "The Secretary of State, Secretary of Defense and the Attorney General do not campaign."
The Florio campaign has insisted that most of the trips were for official business, and thus should not be paid for by the campaign. To underscore his point that the trips were blatantly political, Mr. Barbour showed a video tape of Roy Neel, the Deputy White House chief of staff, telling the Democratic National Committee recently that Mr. Clinton was traveling to New Jersey to help out Mr. Florio.

HEADLINE: Revolution in Lawyers' Fees: The Meter Is Being Shut Off

BYLINE: By MARGOT SLADE

 BODY:
It has been the bedrock of the lawyer-client relationship for decades: the billable hour. Lawyers have charged for their services by the hour, many with little inhibition about the number of hours accumulated, and clients have paid, often without a second thought.
But now the ground is shifting in response to increased competition among law firms and to diminished revenue among law firms and clients alike. And that shift, particularly in corporate law, has begun to bury the hourly rate. Cost-cutting alternative billing schemes are on the rise, and in some cases firms are even being forced to bid for corporate business. 
 The tremors of this change, first felt a few years ago, are now rippling through law firms from coast to coast.
 
Fixed, Capped or Contingent
 "Clients are talking about fixed fees, capped fees, fee estimates, contingent fees and discounts," said Blane R. Prescott, a partner with Hildebrandt, a management consulting company based in Somerville, N.J. "They want to see a budget, something that will give them a better idea in advance of what a law firm's services will cost. They want to discuss that budget and how it was developed."
Given a glut of lawyers and a dearth of clients, Mr. Prescott said, "clients are getting what they want."
Others who monitor the legal profession agree. Although there is no comprehensive national survey to buttress their view or to document the extent of savings for clients, "anecdotal evidence and our own recent, small-scale survey confirm the trend that we perceived: law firms increasingly moving to alternative billing approaches at clients' request," said Richard C. Reed, who is a consultant at Altman Weil Pensa, a Philadelphia-based legal management consulting firm, as well as chairman of the American Bar Association's alternative billing task force.
Those alternatives are a central element of an accelerating revolution, driven mostly by clients, in the way the nation's law firms do business. It is, industry analysts say, a cultural revolution that puts a premium on serving clients, not racking up hours, and on producing quality work, as clients define it: work that places an emphasis on timely performance, efficiency, risk-sharing between the firm and its clients, and the firm's willingness to discuss how cost estimates were arrived at.
Although the revolution is being powered by the muscle of corporations -- those Goliaths of law firm clientele -- some benefits are trickling down to David as well. Particularly in estates, trusts and other areas of family law, where the preparation of documents is increasingly automated, individual clients can frequently obtain services for a fixed fee.
 
Performance Criteria Change
 To clients, the sea change promises value for money. To law firms, it underscores efficiency as a requisite of long-term client relationships. And to individual lawyers within those firms, it brings a shift in performance standards.
In firms that embrace the new approach, partners are rewarded for their marketing and management abilities, "especially for their talent in pricing legal services and supervising legal projects," said Ward Bower, a principal at Altman Weil Pensa. And associates, he said, are "judged on how effectively and efficiently they serve clients, as against how many hours they record."
One benefit of all this is that an associate who is trying to balance family and career, for example, can be judged on something other than hours billed, said Peter D. Zeughauser, vice president and general counsel of the Irvine Company, a real estate development concern in Newport Beach, Calif.
The "down side," Mr. Bower said, is that as law firms turn leaner, they will need fewer lawyers; in the wake of vast numbers of layoffs that have already resulted from a weak economy, even more associates may be finding themselves out of jobs.
"Our object is to procure the right quality of legal services in the most cost-effective way," said David Grimes, vice president and director of administration in the legal department of the Bank of America. "And by 'quality' we refer to a law firm's ability to establish a relationship with us, to know us and the risks we are willing to take in any document or transaction, its willingness to work with our in-house staff and to work within a budget."
And what of firms that demur? "Frankly," Mr. Grimes said, "we don't use them."
 
$600 an Hour
 It was not always that way. Law firms long dictated the quantity, the quality and the price of legal service, and the price that many of them set was high: most recently as much as $500 or even $600 an hour.
The price had to be high, in order to cover the overhead generated by expansionist policies of the 1970's and 80's. To meet a swelling demand for their services, firms had gone on spending sprees, bringing in so-called "rainmakers" (partners with a knack for luring clients), hiring new associates, investing in technology and expanding not only into larger offices but also into other cities.
As their cost of doing business rose, firms compensated by increasing their billing rates and their hours, often by throwing hordes of young associates at a project and charging for the time of each. The legal industry called this "leveraging"; clients frequently called it overstaffing.
"Two things were central to making money then: how many hours you produced and how many people you could employ," said William C. Cobb, president of Houston-based W.C.C.I. Consultants, which specializes in strategic issues facing the legal industry.
 
Effect of Recession
 But law firm control of the legal services market was doomed, and, as a consequence, so was the unchallenged pre-eminence of the billable hour. By the late 1980's, the supply of lawyers was up but the amount of their business down, a result of a nagging recession and corporate clients' cost-cutting, especially through the increased use of in-house legal departments.
It was a buyer's market, and the buyers were balking at what they considered overstaffing of cases and high hourly fees.
In addition, some law firms hit up against what Mr. Reed, the A.B.A. task force chairman, calls the "productivity paradox."
"The advent of advanced technology, such as computers, minimized the number of human hours needed to generate legal work," he said. "Lawyers realized that if they charged only by the hour, they would earn less."
With revenue down, costs up and their profit margins squeezed, an increasing number of law firms have been developing alternative billing strategies. "And they are using market-based pricing -- based on the value a client is likely to place on a particular service -- rather than the time-and-materials approach of cost-plus pricing," said Mr. Bower, the Altman Weil executive.
What clients value, he said, are efficiency, on-time delivery, predictability of expenses and pricing that is competitive, even if that does not necessarily mean inexpensive. "There are, for example, 'you bet your corporation' cases," Mr. Bower said, "in which the situation is so severe that the client doesn't care what the legal work costs; all that matters is winning."
"In this sense, legal services are like health services," said Robert C. Buenger, marketing director at Bryan Cave, a St. Louis-based law firm with a diversified corporate practice. "Everyone wants managed health care to contain costs, until they get sick. Then they want the best care, regardless of costs."
 
Sharing the Risk
 Even these clients, however, may want to spread the risk of cost overruns and bad outcomes, Mr. Zeughauser said.
"Law firms are notoriously poor at forecasting how much it will cost to accomplish a particular task; they generally low-ball it," he said. "Capping fees and refusing to pay over a certain amount shifts that risk to the firm. Law firms are also bad at predicting the likelihood of a bad outcome, especially in litigation. Relying on a contingent fee, in which the lawyers profit from a good outcome and share in a bad one, shifts that risk, too."
To further contain legal costs, Mr. Zeughauser said, his company has forced competition for its business. "We've gone from one law firm, which supplied 90 percent of our legal services, to 35 firms," he said. "We've even invited law firms to submit bids on particular business." The result, he said, has been a saving of 25 to 75 percent in costs, depending on the given service.
No matter what alternative strategies they pursue, "what law firms should not do, if they want to survive, is play the part of the old buffalo hunters," said Mr. Cobb, the W.C.C.I. president. "When buffalo become scarce, buffalo hunters can come up with a better way of hunting, they can hunt something else, or they can nurture the buffalo they have. Buffalo hunters cannot sit in bars waiting for the buffalo to return on their own. They won't."

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
MOBIL CORP. (N)

 BODY:
The Mobil Corporation said yesterday that its 40 percent rise in third-quarter operating profit was the result of higher international oil production, strong margins in refinery operations, and increased sales of its petroleum products.
These gains, as well as a rise in natural-gas prices and increased oil production in Nigeria, more than offset a $4-a-barrel drop in worldwide crude oil prices, to the lowest level in five years. 
 Allen Murray, the company's chairman, commented, "Mobil had very good operating earnings, considering low worldwide crude oil prices and sluggish economic activity in several key industrialized regions."
He added, however, that the low oil prices and weakened demand would make a continuing rise in profit difficult for the company, the nation's second-largest oil concern. Mobil is based in Fairfax, Va.
Earnings from operations were better than analysts had predicted. Mobil said its net earnings rose just over 61 percent. Net income included a gain of $53 million, primarily from income-tax-rate reductions on deferred tax balances in Britain, Germany and Singapore.

HEADLINE: Tax-Credit Financing to Aid In Building Housing Units

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY

 BODY:
New York City should get enough money from a Federal tax-credit program to help build at least 6,000 new housing units for the poor over the next five years, housing advocates said yesterday.
Earlier this year a delay in Congressional renewal of the tax-credit program slowed scores of public-private housing projects throughout the city that had been depending on the money. But in August the program was made permanent as part of the Clinton budget package, paving the way, proponents said, for even greater participation from corporations. The program allows corporations to donate money toward a fund to build housing in exchange for reductions in their Federal tax bills. 
 Two organizations -- the Enterprise Foundation and the Local Initiatives Support Corporation -- plan to announce tomorrow that they will make a five-year, $300 million commitment to building low-income housing with the help of the tax-credit program. They estimated that the fund would be able to pay for 6,000 units, 1,000 more than in the previous five years.
 
Rebuilding Housing
 Acting as partners in managing the program with the city, the Local Initiatives Support Corporation and the Enterprise Foundation distribute the tax-credit money to local community groups. These groups, selected for their organizational skills and commitment to their neighborhoods, then develop the housing.
Since 1987, 35 corporations, including American Express, the Bank of New York, J. P. Morgan, Con Edison and Republic National Bank, have invested $201 million in the housing fund. The program has helped rebuild housing in Harlem, East New York in Brooklyn, and the South Bronx, in many instances serving as a catalyst for neighborhood revitalization.
So far, corporations have been donating at a greater rate than before, with $71 million having been pledged to the equity fund since the tax credit was made permanent in August. In 1988, the first year the tax credit was in operation, corporations contributed $22 million.
Paul S. Grogan, president of the Local Initiatives Support Corporation, said the Clinton Administration's decision to make the tax credit permanent has increased its attractiveness to donors.
"Making the tax credit permanent sent a message of stability to corporate investors," Mr. Grogan said. "In the past some corporations would not consider participating, or made very small investments because of the cloud of instability that hung over the tax credit when it had to be renewed each year."
Nationally, Mr. Grogan said, the tax credit is expected to result in the construction and rebuilding of from 120,00 to 125,000 units a year.
In New York, the tax-credit money will give a major boost to one of the city's most successful low-income housing production programs. Since 1987, the city's Department of Housing Preservation and Development has rebuilt more than 30,700 apartments, and the tax-credit money has paid for about some of the cost of rebuilding about one-third of these apartments.
Most of the units have been carved out of abandoned buildings the city has taken from owners because of tax delinquencies. Of the apartments rebuilt with tax-credit money, 30 percent are set aside as permanent housing for homeless people.
The tax-credit financing can also be used for operating expenses, social services and day care.
The two groups plan to announce the program with the Federal Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, Henry G. Cisneros, and a number of other prominent Democrats from New York and Washington.

HEADLINE: Blast Prosecutors Making Case, Shard by Shard

BYLINE: By RICHARD BERNSTEIN

 BODY:
A piece of a brake drum, some shreds of burned tire, a hinge with flecks of yellow paint, the twisted wreckage of a wheel, pieces of manifold and an alternator -- these were among the items displayed to the jury yesterday as prosecutors, testing the patience of the judge and risking losing the attention of the jury, continued, slowly and methodically, to build their case against the four men accused of blowing up the World Trade Center last Feb. 26.
The prosecution's theory, outlined in the opening statement of the chief prosecutor, J. Gilmore Childers, when the trial opened three weeks ago, is that the bomb was brought into the underground parking garage of the trade center in a yellow Ford Econoline van that had been rented three days earlier at a New Jersey Ryder rental agency by one of the defendants, Mohammed A. Salameh. 
 And so, for the last week, 20 agents from the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms, all of whom searched through the bomb wreckage at the World Trade Center, have testified so that surviving parts of the vehicle, or of the explosive device itself, can be put into evidence.
 
A Glacial Pace
 But so far none of the Federal agents, or any of the other 27 witnesses who have testified, have explicitly linked the scraps and shreds of metal and rubber to the yellow Ryder rental van. That fact, and the glacial pace by which the evidence is accumulating, led Judge Duffy at the end of yesterday's session to the rare gesture of advising the prosecution on how to get to the point a bit more quickly, presumably before the jurors' minds begin to go numb with the monotony of it all.
"I'm not running anybody's case," Judge Duffy said. "But might I suggest to the Government that what you do is get the guy in here from Ford or wherever and get him to say that all of this spells whatever it spells."
Despite his evident impatience, however, Judge Duffy overruled every objection made by the defense to stop the prosecution from introducing yet another shard, said to be from the Ryder van, or from showing it to the jury.
And so, during the course of the day, four witnesses, including three from the F.B.I. and one from the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms, were prompted by the prosecution to tell the jury what they or other members of the search teams found in the wreckage, and exactly where it was found.
 
Standard Courtroom Prop
 First up was David Symons, a nine-year veteran of the F.B.I. who said his job as a member of one of the teams searching through the rubble left behind by the blast was to tag the evidence found by other members of his team. Mr. Symons sat at the witness stand with a half-dozen pieces of wreckage arrayed in front of him, which he identified as a piece of a vehicle manifold, a piece of a flywheel, a generator, a pulley part and part of a pump.
The next witness, John Goetz, an Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms agent from the agency's Philadelphia office, examined a large number of other items that the prosecutor, Henry DePippo, wearing the pale yellow work gloves that have become a standard prop of the courtroom routine, pulled from a large plastic evidence bag.
There was a piece of tire, a piece that he said came from the steering mechanism of a vehicle, a latch from a trunk or a hood, part of a radiator, another part of a tire, and a piece of metal frame with the word "Ford" stamped on it.
The other witnesses produced additional, very similar evidence, leading Judge Duffy, at the normal midafternoon coffee break, to quip: "We're taking our break now because the coffee is hot. Anybody who's been watching will understand the need for that coffee."
What causes the proceedings to unfold at so glacial a rate is not just the prosecution's apparent determination to present what Judge Duffy grumpily called "every shard." It is not even the studied colorlessness of the prosecutors. It is the need to pass through the same series of steps which, taken together, produce a kind of humdrum courtroom choreography.
 
And Then the Gloves
 Each witness gives a bit of his background, especially his training in post-blast investigations. The prosecutors, taking objects out of plastic bags or battered cardboard boxes, ask each witness to identify each object. The witness then looks at pictures and affirms that they are "fair and accurate representations of the objects."
Next, the witness puts a small, round, colored sticker on a floor plan of the World Trade Center showing approximately where each object was found. By now, the floor plan, mounted on an easel, looks like something that might be found in a modern art gallery, with dozens of little splashes of yellow, green and red highlighting the gray background of architectural drawings.
Finally, Judge Duffy tells the jurors to put on their own pairs of yellow work gloves so the smaller pieces of evidence, and the pictures of the same objects, can be passed among them without danger of injury. The evidence makes its slow way to all 12 jurors and five alternates while the rest of the courtroom watches and waits, the defendants staring impassively ahead of them, Judge Duffy resting his head on his open hand, courtroom observers fidgeting.
Cross-examination also follows a similar pattern, with the defense lawyers generally trying to demonstrate that the witnesses do not really know what the shards of evidence really are, exactly who found them, or where they were found, and certainly that they do not know what vehicle or vehicles they came from.

HEADLINE: Critic of Weicker Joins Race for Governor

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Oct. 21

 BODY:
Comptroller William E. Curry Jr., a Farmington Democrat and a frequent critic of the Weicker administration, today announced his candidacy for governor.
Mr. Curry, 41, a former state senator, is the third Democrat to enter the race. Last month Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr., a Republican turned independent, announced that he would not seek a second term. Lieut. Gov. Eunice S. Groark, an independent who ran with Mr. Weicker, has decided to try to succeed him. 
 Mr. Curry has spent much of his political career challenging the political establishment and espousing liberal viewpoints. He said today that he wants to restore the electorate's faith in government. He contends that faith has waned as the state's economy slumped, crime increased and the quality of public schools deteriorated.
The two other Democratic candidates for governor are the Senate president pro tem, John B. Larson of East Hartford, and State Senator Richard J. Balducci of Newington, the former House Speaker.
On the Republican side, former United States Representative John G. Rowland, the party's gubernatorial nominee in 1990, is expected to make another run for the office. Secretary of the State Pauline R. Kezer, the only Republican to win a statewide office in 1990, also is considering a bid.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
CATERPILLAR INC. (N)

 BODY:
Powered by an 18 percent jump in domestic sales, Caterpillar Inc. reported yesterday that its third-quarter net income from operations was $96 million, far ahead of the year-earlier quarter's $5 million and the $50 million to $65 million generally projected on Wall Street.
Caterpillar also booked a $300 million after-tax benefit from settlement of a long-running dispute with the Internal Revenue Service and a one-time $36 million tax credit, lifting total net income for the quarter that ended Sept. 30 to $432 million. 
 The strong domestic performance by the world's largest construction equipment company offset a 3 percent decline in overseas sales, which account for roughly half of Caterpillar's business. Overall revenues, including those from financial services, grew to $2.85 billion.
Caterpillar said that the outlook for sales in North America and developing countries continued to brighten but that the recession in Europe and Japan was lingering.
Analysts said the third-quarter results pointed to expanding profit margins and growing domestic market share.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
A Skittish Market Sells Off Bonds

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The bond market sold off across the board yesterday as traders and investors worried about the possibility of faster economic growth and higher inflation.
But the lesson was not that interest rates are moving sharply higher. Nor was it that the economic fundamentals of sluggish growth and low inflation, which have underpinned this year's bond rally, have changed significantly. Rather, it was that the market will continue to be volatile and easily rattled, even by what are normally considered second-tier economic reports. 
 With long-term interest rates at the lowest level in 25 years, traders and investors have become cautious. Every day they wonder if interest rates have finally hit bottom. And they are vulnerable to any news that might make them reach that conclusion.
 
Three Waves of News
 Yesterday, the news came in three waves, though none was the kind of news that usually affects bond prices. Still, the price of the 30-year Treasury bond dropped 113/32 points, pushing up its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, to 5.91 percent from 5.82 percent Wednesday.
Among the news, the German central bank surprised most market analysts by cutting two key interest rates by half a percentage point. The Lombard rate fell to 6 3/4 percent while the more important discount rate dropped to 5 3/4 percent.
That made some people wonder if interest rates would start to fall even faster in Europe, which would mean that the recessions there could end much sooner than expected. That, in turn, could mean more demand for American exports, helping economic growth here, possibly sparking higher inflation. It was a long chain of reasoning linked by a lot of ifs, but it was enough to prompt selling when, as one trader said, "the bond market is looking for excuses to sell off."
John R. Williams, managing director of global economics at the Bankers Trust Company, said, "There is just a growing view that maybe the global economy is about to turn up a bit," though he added that he does not agree with this view.
A second factor was the surprising report by the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia. Its index of regional economic conditions jumped to 15.1 in October from 0.7 in September. Some analysts, like Raymond Stone, a managing director at Stone & McCarthy Research Associates in Princeton, N.J., believe this index gives a good hint of how the index of the National Association of Purchasing Managers will behave for October. Mr. Stone said the Philadelphia index points to a jump in the purchasing managers index to 53 or 54 in October from 49.7 in September.
He also said that the employment index in the Philadelphia index rose sharply, pointing to the possibility of an overall increase in manufacturing jobs in October, which would be the first rise in seven months.
"If it is a harbinger of stronger manufacturing growth it is something to worry about," Stephen Slifer, financial market economist at Lehman Brothers, said.
The last factor was new concern in the market that the October report for the Consumer Price Index will show an increase of three-tenths to four-tenths of one percent. The index was unchanged in September.
But the reason for much of that rise would be the adjustments made in the index to smooth out the regular seasonal fluctuations in prices, which means that the underlying rate would not be increasing. Still, given the tentative nature of the market right now, it was solely the prospect of a higher C.P.I number rather than the explanation on which many traders and investors focused.
The report that initial claims for state jobless benefits rose by 6,000, to 350,000, in the week ended Oct. 16 had little impact on the market, traders said. It was the second consecutive weekly increase and reflected applicants who were switching from an expired Federal program.
 
Treasury Notes
 The prices of Treasury notes also declined yesterday. The price of the 10-year note fell 24/32 as the yield rose to 5.32 percent from 5.23 percent the day before. The yield on the two-year note rose to 3.84 percent from 3.82 percent.
In the when-issued market, the two-year notes to be auctioned by the Treasury on Tuesday yielded 3.91 percent, up from 3.86 percent, while the five-year notes to be sold Wednesday yielded 4.74 percent, up from 4.67 percent.
 
Municipal Bonds
 In the municipal market, Goldman Sachs & Company won the competitive bid for $424.3 million of Florida Board of Education general-obligation bonds. The bond due in 2018 was priced to yield 5.17 percent, with an after-tax yield of 8.08 percent, while the bond due in 2023 was priced to yield 5.242 percent, with an after-tax yield of 8.19 percent at the top rate of 36 percent.

HEADLINE: Adventures in Daveland (and Not Just at Night)

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GRIMES

 BODY:
SOMETIMES television viewers begin to think of the characters they watch as real people. Psychologists have a term for this. The viewer, they say, has entered into a "parasocial relationship" with the figures on the small screen.
The psychologists do not have a term for what has happened to the people who work near the Ed Sullivan Theater on Broadway and 54th Street in Manhattan, the new home of "Late Show With David Letterman." 
 Like a Nebraska farm family that calmly enters a spaceship manned by aliens, the neighborhood residents, over the last several weeks, have given up their allegiance to normal, daily life and signed onto Letterman reality. They may seem to run businesses or work 9-to-5 jobs. But they are actually waiting for the rapture: the arrival of a Letterman crew and the five minutes of needling from Dave that will transform them, for Letterman watchers across the country, into fictional characters.
The guys at the Bagel Cafe on the corner of Broadway and 54th? Yes, they've been on the show. And Rupert Jee, manager of Hello Deli on 53d Street, took a standing ovation at center stage a few weeks back.
"Saw you on TV," said a woman waiting in line at the cash register on a recent afternoon. "You were great."
Mr. Jee thanked her.
"You're not going to be on the show tonight, are you?"
Mr. Jee thought it over. "Who knows? Maybe. You can't tell around here."
"Here" is Daveland, a tiny, very strange theme park that occupies, at the moment, Broadway between 53d and 54th Streets, and stores around the corners, heading west, on 53d and 54th Streets. The area runs on Letterman time. In the morning, tourists in twos and threes peer into the theater's glass doors. Some check out the stores that have achieved that special Letterman brand of fame: they've been ridiculed by Dave.
By noon, fans hoping to get one of the 50 standby tickets available every day line up on Broadway to be assigned a number, then disperse until later in the afternoon. At the same time, the first of 350 ticket holders begin lining up on 53d Street.
The curious can sample a new dish, polenta a la Letterman, at Il Teatro restaurant, or browse the Letterman Lizard Lounge in the Pet Department Store. At McGee's, a pub right next door to the theater, they can behold Dave's hat from the NBC days behind the bar. If they look across the street and upward, they can see "Hey, Dave!" signs in the office building at 1700 Broadway. (They can also enter the New David theater, but this is not an official stop on the Dave tour. It predates the show, and it shows X-rated gay films.)
Rock America, a souvenir store, has already become legendary. A Letterman camera crew wandered in during a recent show so that Mr. Letterman, back in the studio, could check out the merchandise, which included a $4.99 magnet with a photograph of Mr. Letterman in a University of Michigan T-shirt, as well as a T-shirt ($19) and sweatshirt ($44) with the "Late Show" logo in gold on a deep blue background, just like the theater marquee. (Mr. Letterman ignored the front window, which has a fake copy of The New York Times with the headline "Rock America Store Names David Letterman #1 Sexiest Showman in America!") In the end, Mr. Letterman ordered a photo I.D. card. Keumsoon Lee, the owner of the store, seemed to find this natural. "After all, he's a neighbor now," she said.
The store retains the name Rock America, but to millions of viewers it's really The Place Where Dave Bought His I.D. Card. Out-of-town visitors now wander into Ms. Lee's store to relive the experience.
"The goofier a person he can get to talk to, the more time he'll spend," said Hank Freid, the general manager of the Ameritania Hotel around the corner from the theater on 54th Street. "He spent a lot of time at the souvenir shop."
Mr. Letterman has also waved the magic wand over Academy Clothes, a tuxedo boutique that, like several other stores in the area, more or less signed onto the show without being asked.
In the doorway of the store is a list: "Top 10 Reasons to Shop at Academy Clothes." The reference is to a stock Letterman bit. The Academy's list, in full:
10. Free receipt with every purchase.
9. We give good tailoring.
8. All measurements are politically correct.
7. You'll like our material.
6. Our jackets are well hung.
5. Barneys is way across town.
4. No cover. No minimum. No MSG.
3. We'll teach you how to pronounce "cummerbund."
2. Free mambo lessons.
1. Dave window-shops here.
Despite Nos. 8 and 4, which show signs of effort, it's pretty clear that the writers of the show have not been moonlighting.
Fame can strike suddenly. On the show's first exploratory walk around the new neighborhood, the camera crew set up outside Academy Clothes. Bart Dadon, an owner of the store, stood in the doorway to watch what he thought would be a man-in-the-street interview. Suddenly, the camera swung in his direction and began to advance. He was the man.
From the studio, Mr. Letterman inquired about the merchandise. Mr. Dadon showed him a flashy sequined jacket. Mr. Letterman offered him $100 to wear it into the subway.
"I jumped at the chance," said Mr. Dadon. "And he made good on it, too." Mr. Dadon said he split the windfall with his tailor, Enrique Standard, whom he described as "my Ed McMahon."
The Letterman encounter has heightened Mr. Dadon's profile considerably. "I've done five radio interviews," he said. "There's been a tremendous response. People from as far away as Honolulu and Mississippi have stopped in here. I look forward to him picking on us for years to come."
 
Bids for Attention
 Neighborhood residents know that any one of them could be next. New Yorkers are not a shy people, and there are signs of serious struggle to gain Mr. Letterman's attention.
At 1700 Broadway, the office tower across the street, several windows have signs of the sort usually seen at baseball parks. One reads: "Hey Dave, Best Damn City, Best Damn Show, Best Damn Haircut."
"They're Meg wannabes," said Mr. Dadon, somewhat contemptuously, referring to Meg Parsant, who worked in the Simon & Schuster building across from the old Letterman show on NBC, and achieved celebrity when Mr. Letterman began calling her for on-the-air chats.
Some bids for attention show a little more initiative, like Il Teatro's polenta dish, for example, a tour de force that involves shaping polenta into tapered ovals that refer to the CBS eye and topping them with three seafood components in different colors: salmon Dijon (yellow), red snapper marechiaro (pink) and shrimp and scallop scampi (white).
"As succulent, tasty and sophisticated as the Late Show With Dave!!" read the letter that accompanied the polenta and assorted dishes that the restaurant sent over to the show soon after it was broadcast for the first time on CBS on Aug. 30.
The letter is displayed outside the restaurant in a glass case along with a thank-you note from Mr. Letterman.
"We expect that any day he's going to review us and put us in the show," said Steve Vucetaj, the maitre d'hotel. Mr. Vucetaj also mentioned that his business was up between 30 and 40 percent as a result of the show.
 
Improved Streets
 That's another reason to love Dave. Hello Deli now feeds Letterman crew members during lunch and after the show. In addition, the line for the show snakes down 53d Street, right in front of the deli. That has meant lots of drop-in traffic.
"This block totally changed," said Ms. Lee of Rock America. "We had problems before with thieves and robbers, even schoolkids who shoplifted. That's all stopped."
Most shopkeepers agree that things are looking up. More foot traffic means more customers, or at least potential customers. Wholesome Letterman fans now outnumber the louche characters who once found the area attractive.
McGee's now enjoys the patronage of Letterman crew members and many members of the studio audience, who pile in after the show is taped. People waiting in line often run in for a quick one.
"A lot of people in the neighborhood now think it's the place to be," said Martina Meegan, a bartender. "They all want to know: does he come in here, and what does he drink," she said.
Well, what does he drink? "He hasn't had anything to drink in 12 years," said Ms. Meegan, "but Paul Shaffer makes up for it. He drinks Remy."
Some customers put in bids on the Letterman hat behind the bar. (It's a baseball cap with the old "Late Night" logo.) Ms. Meegan has received offers in the neighborhood of $50. "I have one just like it at home," she said, "so if the price goes up, I may bring it in."
 
A Letterman Suite?
 Mr. Freid at the Ameritania does not mind taking credit for the economic upswing. "I think we had more of an impact than he did," he said. "Before we bought and renovated the hotel, it had a lot of undesirable people living in it, and people were afraid to walk on the street. I don't think the Letterman show would have moved here if we hadn't come in."
The Ameritania has been a little slow to capitalize on the proximity of the Letterman show. Its display of enthusiasm is limited to a tasteful blue-and-gold sign above the now-famous bagel shop that reads, "Ameritania Hotel Welcomes David Letterman Late Show." That's it. The hotel's clientele is almost entirely European, and it seems that the Statue of Liberty is higher on their list than Mr. Letterman.
There is no David Letterman Suite.
"Actually, that's not a bad idea," said Mr. Freid. "We could say something like, 'Laugh yourself to sleep with Letterman.' It's something to think about."
The Letterman boom has also given the more creative criminal types an opportunity. At the Pet Department Store, for example, a couple raced in and demanded 30 T-shirts with dogs on the front, saying that they were needed immediately for a photo shoot on the Letterman show. Eager to oblige, the store put together the order and then got stuck with a fake credit-card number.
Pro-Letterman feeling still runs strong at the store, however. In addition to creating the Letterman Lizard Lounge, an attractive corner with assorted reptiles in terrariums, the store has allowed its star poodle, Pupper, to do two promotions for the show, once wearing a Harley-Davidson jacket and motocycle cap with visor.
"We're also giving away a month's supply of dog, cat, lizard or fish food to any pet that can hold a Letterman cigar in its mouth long enough for a photo shoot," said Leigh Applebrook, the store's owner.
 
Not Everyone Is a Fan
 It's a fairly safe bet that Mr. Letterman will not be strolling into Santino Photo Electronic, a camera and electronics store a few steps away from the studio. The late-night show has many fans, but Sasson Elo, manager of Santino Photo, is not among them.
"Basically, I hate the man, O.K.?" he said.
The roots of Mr. Elo's enmity run deep, and in several different directions. First there's the snub. "We spent $400 to put out a banner welcoming him," he said, "and he never visits. That's rude."
Then there are the people in the line. "They're cheap," said Mr. Elo. "They don't buy." Even worse, he said, they get bored, come in his shop and waste the time of the salesmen.
Then there's the line itself. Mr. Elo hates it. It used to run in front of his shop and, he said, scared off customers. CBS has since moved the line from Broadway to 53d Street, which Mr. Elo concedes is an improvement.
It's not clear that a visit from Mr. Letterman would help at this point. "We're here 20 years," said Mr. Elo. "Who's Dave? Dave is nothing to us."
But he's everything to just about everyone else in the area. "They shot a guy from a cannon right on the street there the other day," said Mr. Jee at Hello Deli. "It used to be like a ghost town here. Now the job is more like play than work."
 
 
Getting Tickets
 To request free tickets to "Late Show With David Letterman," broadcast on CBS Monday through Friday at 11:30 P.M., send a postcard with your name and address to Tickets, Ed Sullivan Theater, 1697 Broadway, New York, N.Y. 10019. Tickets are available to those 16 and older.
Tickets to one of the tapings, held Monday through Friday at 5:30 P.M., are usually mailed within three months; if no response is received during that time, a second postcard should be sent. There is a limit of two tickets per request; ordinarily, requests for specific dates cannot not be accommodated.
Seating is on a first-come basis, and lines begin forming early in the afternoon. In addition, a number of standby tickets are available each day; numbers are issued at noon at the theater for the standby tickets, which are then distributed at 5 P.M.
 
Neighborhood Haunts
 New York's Letterman district is a small but glittering chip in the city's gorgeous mosaic. It occupies Broadway between 53d and 54th Streets, and curves westward for a half block at each end. Here are the principal cultural attractions.
 
ED SULLIVAN THEATER (1697 Broadway, near 54th Street). Home of "Late Show With David Letterman."
 
LONGACRE COPY CENTER (1691 Broadway, near 53d Street). Visited by the Letterman crew. Owner made a photocopy of her head for Dave.
 
McGEE'S (1699 Broadway, near 54th Street). See Dave's old hat behind the bar. Watering hole for the Letterman crew.
 
BAGEL CAFE (1707 Broadway, near 54th Street). Visited by the Letterman camera crew on Monday. Dave tried to convince two young women from North Carolina that he was carrying out a holdup by video.
 
1700 BROADWAY OFFICE BUILDING (at 54th Street). Note signs in windows designed to attract Dave's attention.
 
ACADEMY CLOTHES (1703 Broadway, near 54th Street). Visited by the Letterman crew. Note door with 10 reasons to shop Academy.
 
HELLO DELI (213 West 53d Street). Favored eating spot of the Letterman crew.
 
FLASH DANCERS (1674 Broadway, near 53d Street). Dave sent pizza to doorman.
 
SAN LEONE PIZZA (1678 Broadway, near 53d Street). Made and delivered the Flash Dancers pizza.
 
AMERITANIA HOTEL (1701 Broadway, at 54th Street). Put up the welcome banner over the Bagel Cafe.
 
IL TEATRO RISTORANTE (240 West 54th Street). Home of polenta a la Letterman.
 
SANTINO PHOTO ELECTRONIC (1693 Broadway, near 53d Street). Hates Dave.
 
ROCK AMERICA (1705 Broadway, near 54th Street). Photo I.D. store visited by the Letterman crew.
 
PET DEPARTMENT STORE (233 West 54th Street). Letterman Lizard Lounge, plus photographs in window of befuddled dog surrounded by Letterman-style cigars. WILLIAM GRIMES
