HEADLINE: Big Board's Open Positions on Short Sales Drop

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Even though stock prices are high and merger activity is strong, the number of shares sold short and not covered on the New York Stock Exchange fell this month, the Big Board reported yesterday.
The 2.8 percent drop, to 1.19 billion shares, came on the heels of a 12 percent rise in short interest in September, the biggest gain in recent years. 
 On the American Stock Exchange, however, sentiment that prices are at inflated levels grew stronger. The Amex said that short interest rose by 8.7 percent, to 100.9 million shares. The October total is the second-highest monthly short interest in the history of the exchange, surpassed only by the 104.5 million shares sold short in August.
The short-interest figures for both the New York and American exchanges covered trades during the month that ended on Oct. 7.
Short-sellers borrow shares and sell them. Much of the heavy short-selling reflects bets that share prices will decline, enabling the seller to repurchase the shares at a lower price, repay the lender and pocket the difference in price.
Some market averages on the Big Board, including the Dow Jones industrial average, posted modest declines during the period covered. But market participants said they were not surprised that short interest fell.
"My own reading is that interest rates have come down so much and there is so much money moving into equities that a lot of people who are typically fairly bearish at a time like this have to concede the market is strong," said Don Morken, a general partner at Genesee Investments in Seattle. "In that sort of a situation, you want to get out of the way, and unwind your short positions."
In addition to betting on a decline in prices, shorting is also used to speculate on the success of a merger involving stock swaps.
For example, The New York Times Company showed the largest increase in short positions this month, leaping by nearly 56 percent, to 9.26 million shares. In September, the company completed its purchase of Affiliated Publications, owner of The Boston Globe, for more than $1 billion, most of it in stock.
"To lock in a profit, arbitragers bought Affiliated stock and shorted the New York Times," said Susan L. Decker, a publishing and advertising analyst at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette in San Francisco.
Speculators used the same technique with shares in Merck & Company, which has agreed to acquire Medco Containment Services for stock and cash.
Short interest in Merck rose by more than 2 million shares this month, to 25.7 million shares, the largest short position of any stock on either the New York or American exchange.

SECTION: Section A; Page 29; Column 5; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 709 words

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
A President Like Us

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL

 BODY:
Like all Presidents, Bill Clinton is just a human being, the same as the rest of us. The trouble is that he is acting like it.
Most human beings are quick to take credit when things go well, wriggle out of responsibility when they go wrong, talk big, act small, try to bluff their way out of trouble and look put upon when cornered -- oh, the injustice of it all. 
 But we do not elect Presidents to be just like the rest of us. We want them to be better, stronger, wiser. When we are disappointed we go back to the booth in hope and belief, which are the grace and salvation of America.
In his conduct of foreign policy, on which American safety rests, Mr. Clinton is letting us down, and himself. The Administration weaves, rationalizes, blames everybody in range. The world notes every time.
The Administration is not heading for a crisis of confidence at home and abroad, but is already in it.
For weeks, I avoided writing those paragraphs. I hoped something would happen to prove them wrong or badly overstated.
I am not particularly solicitous about elected officials, but neither do I regard them as existing exclusively to provide journalism with daily targets. And like most Americans I am weary of failed or boring Presidents and want this one to make it.
But the Administration has become embarrassing. Mom, it was the U.N. that did it. Mom, that mean Secretary General is making faces at me. Mom, it was the American people, look how pale they get when American blood is spilled.
No. The U.N. did nothing that the U.S. did not approve in Bosnia, Somalia or Haiti. Washington acts as if it does not understand perfectly well that the U.N. cannot do anything important unless the U.S. agrees.
In Bosnia, I am against U.S. military intervention. But Washington arrived at that decision after avoiding the leadership responsibility -- to say yea or nay, without marbles in mouth or brain. It is still mumbling.
On Somalia, pretend it was U.S. troops who were the first to be ambushed and slaughtered, not Pakistanis. Pretend that the U.S. called for help, and Pakistan sent troops, who thereupon took casualties.
Right away the Pakistanis said they were not simply getting ready to pull out but meantime were not going to share street patrol duty with Americans. Would Americans still see Pakistanis as reliable allies?
(Speaking of credit: Henry Kissinger coolly saw the problems the new President was inheriting in Somalia and wrote them in his column before Mr. Clinton was even inaugurated.)
On Haiti, why did the U.S. even think of sending in soldiers armed only with sidearms to train thug "police" who itched to kill them? Why could not U.S. intelligence do better than send word that there was a one-in-three chance that goons would riot against the troops?
Mr. Clinton is giving cynics an ax-handle against his own decent human rights policy. Supporting human rights does not mean sending in the troops every time, or underarmed troops any time.
As for Americans, more than any nation they have been ready to bleed for others. But they are not morons and now ask why, how long, how much. In neither Bosnia, Somalia nor Haiti did Mr. Clinton tell them.
If Americans turn too inward, who encouraged them? A political hired hand hung that foolish and boorish sign -- "it's the economy, stupid" -- in his office. But it was his boss who hung it up over the whole country.
The Clintonians were right to support Boris Yeltsin, unless you prefer Pamyat or Communist hacks. In the Mideast they did not act as Arab apologists. But wisely they did not become more Israeli than the Israelis and question the Labor Government's risk-taking.
These intelligent decisions, however, do not override the belief in the U.S. and abroad that the Administration is confusing and ineffective on foreign affairs. That encourages enemies to close in for the kill and friends to feel sorry for Mr. Clinton -- both dangerous trends for any President.
He can still get himself out of the crisis of confidence. All he has to do is admit error, accept blame, take responsibility, quit behaving put upon, as if Americans were supposed to keep him happy, not the other way around -- altogether, just stop acting so damned human.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Can't We Afford a Little Music in Our Lives?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I went to see the Martha Graham Dance Company last week. The dancing was superb and this heightened my sadness and distress at having a third-row seat, perched above an empty orchestra pit, listening to the music pumped through a rather tinny sound system at New York's City Center. The music is an integral part of the dance and I find this state of affairs appalling.
At first I thought my reaction was the embittered response of a musician struggling to make a living in one of the many American orchestras that hover at bankruptcy's gate. But upon reflection, I think that any educated listener would respond as I did. 
 Without drastic changes in our priorities, the situation will only get worse. Music programs in the public schools throughout this country have been slashed to shreds. Last week in Albuquerque, N.M., voters overwhelmingly defeated a proposal to build a performing arts center, although the $10 million needed for construction was already in place, waiting. Now they have to figure out what to do with the money.
While Broadway grossed a record-breaking $327.7 million in 1992, the newly ratified contract for musicians working on Broadway has the potential to offer less work to musicians and raises questions about the future of live music in musical theater. It is more than a depressed economy we have to contend with in all these situations.
As both a performer and a listener, I have experienced wonderful excitement, chills and tingling up and down my spine at great moments in live performances. Never have I experienced this sensation from listening to a synthesizer or a stereo. Thrill seekers, unite: why should we deprive ourselves of one of life's greatest pleasures?
 
JENNIFER ADDAS
Albuquerque, N.M., Oct. 14, 1993

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

SECTION: Section A; Page 28; Column 5; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 338 words

HEADLINE: Can't We Afford a Little Music in Our Lives?;
New York Leads

 BODY:
To the Editor:
" 'Art' Is No Luxury" (editorial, Oct. 14) makes short shrift of New York State financing for the arts. 
 New York leads the country in state support for the arts. The New York State Arts Council's $26 million to local arts groups is more than six times the national average -- and an increase of 14 percent from last year. Beyond that, just this year, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo stepped in to rescue the New-York Historical Society, restoring its financial health while preserving its vast store of priceless art, artifacts and historical documents.
New York's Natural Heritage Trust was allotted nearly $11 million this year to finance organizations like the Guggenheim Museum, New York City Ballet and symphony orchestras in New York City, Buffalo, Syracuse and on Long Island. Our state and city university systems offer academic degrees in fine arts and performing arts to allow the talents of tomorrow to flourish.
The state budget includes nearly $230 million to help pay the salaries of the more than 10,000 music and art teachers in our elementary and secondary schools. And the state will spend $2 million this year to finance the Empire State Plaza Performing Arts Center and the New York State Theater Institute.
Certainly, the Council on the Arts has shared in the spending cuts that have been required since 1989 to keep the state budget in balance. Those cuts spanned the spectrum of government services -- from college financial aid, to health care for the poor and elderly, to layoffs and salary freezes for state employees.
Your linkage of arts financing to Governor Cuomo's efforts to retain the Yankees is odd. Like the arts, sports franchises contribute to our economy. New York City's Comptroller recently estimated that the Yankees generate $150.9 million in annual economic activity. What Governor Cuomo has proposed is an investment that would keep those dollars in New York City, rather than lose them entirely.
 
RUDY F. RUNKO
Director of the Budget
Albany, Oct. 15, 1993

HEADLINE: A Candidate's Colleagues Render a Mixed Verdict

SERIES: Giuliani: A Lawyer's Career -- A special report.

BYLINE: By DAVID MARGOLICKwith JANE FRITSCH

 BODY:
In picking their next mayor, New Yorkers will choose between an incumbent, David N. Dinkins, whose work they have watched for four years and a challenger, Rudolph W. Giuliani, whose professional career is far less familiar. But one group of New Yorkers would seem to know Mr. Giuliani best: the lawyers who have seen him work for much of the last 20 years.
They saw him develop as a young assistant Federal prosecutor in Manhattan and watched him during his short stints in private practice. Like everyone else, they remember him most vividly from his years as United States Attorney in Manhattan. 
 They remember the energy and enthusiasm he brought to 1 St. Andrew Plaza, where the United States Attorney works. But many also wonder whether he has shed some of the impatience and intolerance they say he displayed as a prosecutor, when he routinely described those who disagreed with him as "jerks" or "babies" or "dishonest."
Even Mr. Giuliani's longtime mentor, Harold R. Tyler Jr., a former Federal judge, is not sure what to expect from a Giuliani mayoralty, and has declined to endorse him. "I don't know whether being a good lawyer translates into being a good mayor," Mr. Tyler said last week. "He does love New York, but whether that will make him a good mayor is another question."
All but the most fervent of Mr. Giuliani's detractors in the New York legal community readily acknowledge his many strong points. They say that he is smart, energetic, hard-working, decisive, incisive, innovative and inspiring to those under him.
Conversely, all but his most fervent admirers note Mr. Giuliani's shortcomings. At times, they say, he can be overly zealous, self-righteous and thin-skinned, authoritarian and press-hungry and a bit provincial, thinking he shines more brightly by surrounding himself with loyal lesser lights.
Since leaving the prosecutor's office, Mr. Giuliani has gone into a kind of professional hibernation. Though affiliated with two large law firms hoping to cash in on his celebrity, he has practiced only sporadically, largely invisibly and not entirely happily. At each firm, he left behind many lawyers believing they had inadvertently subsidized his political career.
Instead of practicing law, Mr. Giuliani has spent much of the last four years preparing for his second run for mayor. While this miffed some law partners, Mr. Giuliani's friends say it broadened and deepened his understanding of people.
Richard Parsons, chairman of the Dime Savings Bank and perhaps his most prominent black supporter, described the old Mr. Giuliani as "not the kind of person who mixed a lot in the melting pot."
But Mr. Parsons added, "The process of trying to achieve office has broadened this man. He has a greater understanding of others and consequently of himself. He's blossoming as he grows older. He may be awkward with blacks, but he's initially awkward with a lot of people. It's just a matter of getting to know the guy."
Mr. Giuliani declined to be interviewed for this article. A campaign spokesman, Richard Bryers, said Mr. Giuliani would not cooperate because, he said, coverage of him in The Times has been consistently biased.
 
Making a Name
How to Become A Household Word
 Mr. Giuliani did for the office of United States Attorney in Manhattan what C. Everett Koop did for the office of Surgeon General of the United States: he made a prestigious backwater a household word. His predecessors, good and bad, Democrat and Republican, generally left little imprint on the public consciousness. The ever-conspicuous Mr. Giuliani, by contrast, was routinely and admiringly compared to Thomas E. Dewey and Eliot Ness.
Even those without law degrees could list the hit parade of those he had convicted: the Bronx Democratic leader Stanley Friedman and others in the Parking Violations Bureau scandal; Leona Helmsley; organized crime leaders in the "Pizza Connection" case; numerous insider traders on Wall Street. Vanity Fair called him "the most dazzling prosecutor in 50 years," whose life was "a crusade to coax, shame or force people into choosing good over evil."
But to lawyers of all political stripes, the verdict on Mr. Giuliani has always been far more equivocal.
Some, particularly those who have worked for him, shared the perception that he had compiled, as an assistant, Charles Carberry, once put it, 'the best record in law enforcement of anyone without a cape." Thomas Puccio, former head of the Organized Crime Strike Force in Brooklyn -- surely the only man Mr. Giuliani both taped (during the Parking Violations Bureau investigation) and invited to his wedding -- calls him Manhattan's best Federal prosecutor in 20 years.
Edward Little, who tried the Wedtech case, recalled how Mr. Giuliani authorized him to call Attorney General Edwin Meese, for whom they both worked, "a sleaze" in his summation, then backed him up when the Meese Justice Department threatened to discipline him for it. "Everyone thinks Rudy is self-serving and political and it just isn't true," Mr. Little said. "The guy is as straight as they come, an incredibly loyal and idealistic person."
Other alumni from the Federal prosecutor's office concede that he had early successes. But over time, they say, he became a self-promoter, someone who critics say called more news conferences than all his predecessors combined, who engaged in unseemly stunts like the episode in which he and Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato went undercover for a drug bust in 1986, who took credit for cases dumped in his lap or already under way, always looking to further his political ambitions.
"Giuliani focused all publicity on himself, and did so with unseemly intensity," stated a petition circulated four years ago by several alumni of the United States Attorney's office, including Michael Armstrong and Arthur Liman, along with Richard Uviller of Columbia Law School.
"Rudy is for whatever helps Rudy," said Gerald Lefcourt, a New York lawyer who battled Mr. Giuliani in the Parking Violations Bureau trial.
The critics share the sentiments of Edward Bennett Williams, the famed Washington lawyer who opposed Mr. Giuliani in an insider-trading case, who once described him as "consumed with raw power." His ambition struck Gov. Mario M. Cuomo upon first meeting Mr. Giuliani a decade ago. "Your friend Giuliani is looking for my job," Mr. Cuomo is said to have told the man making the introduction. (The Governor says he does not recall making such a statement.)
In 1989, an article in The American Lawyer based on interviews with 50 lawyers and judges said many perceived in Mr. Giuliani "an ambition so consuming that that which sustains it is embraced willy-nilly, that which does not directly feed it is neglected, and that which runs counter to it is earmarked for destruction."
E. Robert Wallach, whom Mr. Giuliani unsuccessfully prosecuted in the Wedtech case, once described Mr. Giuliani as engaging in "prosecutorial wilding": handcuffing and carting away three Wall Street traders, two of whom were later cleared; the prosecutions of Bess Myerson and Imelda Marcos, both of whom were acquitted; the prosecution and conviction of financial figures, later reversed on appeal.
Mr. Giuliani's admirers attribute many of these sentiments to sour grapes. "Let's face it, some of them are envious," Mr. Tyler said. "They tend to dislike prosecutors, particularly successful ones. I can't quite understand why, since a lot of criminal defense lawyers have never had it so good since he left."
Some admirers say that he must broaden his circle beyond the cadre of colleagues, nearly all white and male, adulatory and intellectually inferior to him, to which he has always cleaved. So sycophantic were his advisers at the United States Attorney's office that James B. Stewart, a former reporter for The Wall Street Journal and author of "Den of Thieves," once wrote that others in the office called them the "Yesrudis," as in "yes, Rudy" -- pronounced, according to Mr. Stewart, "with a Southern slave accent."
But Wendeen Eolis, a New York legal consultant and longtime friend of Mr. Giuliani's, called the charge "an old, outdated misperception." She said: "Rudy's key advisers have always been smart people, and he gives them not just responsibility but the authority to go with it."
 
Starting Out
Abundant Talent And Ambition
 From the outset of his career Mr. Giuliani gave ample evidence of the legal talent, charisma and drive that carried him to his present prominence. Less clear was the degree or direction of his political commitment.
He has said that he simply missed the political and social upheaval of the 1960's, and his classmates at New York University Law School, a crucible of antiwar and civil rights activity in the late 1960's, concur. "My recollection was that Rudy Giuliani was nowhere to be found on either issue," said Norman Siegel, the director of the New York Civil Liberties Union who now supports Mayor Dinkins.
Mr. Giuliani avoided military service, as did many young men of his generation, with a series of draft deferments. After law school Mr. Giuliani clerked for Federal Judge Lloyd MacMahon, to whom he grew very close. He then became an assistant United States attorney in Manhattan, graduating quickly from routine drug cases to chief of the narcotics unit.
At the age of 29, he took over police corruption cases, earning himself top billing in the book and movie versions of "Prince of the City." He experienced another flicker of fame in the 1974 conspiracy trial of Bertram L. Podell, a former United States Representative from Brooklyn. Rattled by Mr. Giuliani's grueling cross-examination, Mr. Podell called for a halt to the questioning and pleaded guilty.
As a youthful prosecutor he kept a photograph of the late President John F. Kennedy and his brother Robert on his office wall, and he voted for George McGovern in 1972. But he began to drift rightward shortly thereafter. He told Vanity Fair in 1987 that he had not felt safe with Democratic economic and foreign policy.
In 1975 Mr. Tyler, then Deputy Attorney General in the Ford Administration, hired Mr. Giuliani as an aide to help him oversee criminal matters. When Jimmy Carter became President in 1977, Mr. Giuliani moved back to New York and became a partner in Mr. Tyler's firm. Four years later, it was Mr. Tyler who recommended Mr. Giuliani, by now a Republican, for the No. 3 post in the Reagan Justice Department. The job thrust Mr. Giuliani into several disputes that, for the first time in his career, brought him unwelcome public attention.
The most notable disagreement came when he decided to drop bribery charges against four officials of the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, the Government's first major criminal indictment for illegal payments to foreign officials. The prosecutors handling the case, whom Mr. Giuliani did not consult, publicly expressed dismay at Mr. Giuliani's action. Mr. Giuliani excoriated them.
"As far as I'm concerned, we were watching a madman," one lawyer handling the case, Michael A. Lubin, told Mr. Stewart, a reporter for The Wall Street Journal. "It would have been a great videotape. He ranted and raved for a full 20 minutes. He just went nuts." Mr. Giuliani said at the time that his decision was correct.
During that time, Mr. Giuliani was also the Justice Department's point man on the issue of Haitian immigrants who had fled their country in leaky boats and reached Florida. The Reagan Administration, in a departure from usual practice, ordered the Haitians held at crowded, makeshift detention centers for months, sometimes years. In 1982, a Federal judge ruled for the Haitians but added that the Government had not engaged in discrimination.
In 1983 Mr. Giuliani, who had struck up a friendship with Senator D'Amato in Washington, was nominated by the Senator to be United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York. His mother opposed his taking the job, Mr. Giuliani has said, deeming it a step down. But citing his love for the city, Mr. Giuliani returned to New York.
 
Return to New York
Seizing the Day, Slaying Dragons
 When Senator D'Amato selected Mr. Giuliani, there was great apprehensiveness among his future colleagues.
Some, citing the McDonnell Douglas case, feared he would soft-pedal white-collar prosecutions. Others felt he had showed disrespect for the office he was about to lead by ordering staff cutbacks and forcing his predecessor, John J. Martin Jr., to hire Kenneth Caruso, a friend and now a campaign adviser, who had already been rejected by Mr. Martin's hiring committee.
Instead there followed a frenzy of activity and a surge in morale. So successfully did Mr. Giuliani use his influence in Washington to win turf battles with other Federal prosecutors that the skirmishing all but stopped.
"I didn't want to waste my time," said Edward A. McDonald, another former Federal strike force chief in Brooklyn. "I saw which way the wind was blowing. It was clear early on that Rudy Giuliani was anointed by the Republican powers that be to come up to New York, showcase his wares and run for political office."
Those who worked for Mr. Giuliani nonetheless depict him as fiercely nonpartisan. They say he urged them to follow the credo of an illustrious predecessor, Emory Buckner: "Figure out what the right thing is to do, then do it."
Critics charged that Mr. Giuliani's deputies, largely undersupervised as he spread himself increasingly thin, came to adopt what The American Lawyer called a "macho rah-rah-let's-crush-'em-like-bugs-because-they're-probably-criminals mentality." The office's approach brought criticism from some Federal judges, including many Republican appointees. One, John Sprizzo, complained from the bench of prosecutorial overkill.
 
'A Lightning Rod'
 Appellate courts came to subject some of Mr. Giuliani's convictions to searching scrutiny, and in several cases -- notably, those of executives of Princeton-Newport and GAF Corporation -- overturned them for errors that, some believe, they might have tolerated from someone else. "By making himself a lightning rod and making a big deal of his aggressiveness, Rudy lost the courts' confidence," said Gerald Lynch, a former prosecutor now at Columbia Law School. "The close calls tend to go with the Government, but the close calls did not go to Rudy."
No one epitomizes the bar's divided feelings about Mr. Giuliani better than Paul Curran, the United States Attorney in Manhattan in the early 1970's. Mr. Curran played a major role in Mr. Giuliani's advancement. Later, Mr. Curran represented Robert Freeman, one of the three handcuffed traders Mr. Giuliani went after and the only one convicted.
Mr. Curran called that episode "a fiasco," one that gave him pause about his former deputy. He is nonetheless supporting Mr. Giuliani's mayoral bid. "I think that overall, he did a good job as United States Attorney," he said. "He made some bad mistakes and he shot his mouth off too much, but he developed some good cases and had the guts to try a big case himself."
 
Eyes on the Mayoralty
Private Practice, Public Disputes
 Amid much fanfare in early 1989 the law firm of White & Case, eager to shed its stodgy image, hired Mr. Giuliani for a reported $650,000 a year (and his assistant, Dennison Young Jr., for almost $350,000). Some partners opposed the move. One had once represented Judge Hortense Gabel, the aged, ailing jurist Mr. Giuliani had prosecuted -- and, through her daughter Sukhreet, taped -- in the Myerson case. The American Lawyer asked why a firm would lavish $1 million upon "two strangers who basically intend to use the place as a meal ticket and a mail drop."
As the 1989 mayoral election heated up, the reticent firm paid a price for its acquisition, finding its carefully guarded client list picked over by rival politicians and the press. When the election was over, Mr. Giuliani returned to the firm but produced little business. The marriage of convenience having soured, Mr. Giuliani and Mr. Young quietly left the firm.
 
Looking for Glamour
 Mr. Giuliani, again with Mr. Young in tow, then went to another firm looking for glamour and new business, the firm now known as Anderson, Kill, Olick & Oshinsky, for a reported $500,000 a year. Though Mr. Giuliani immediately cost the firm at least one client -- Helmsley-Spear, Leona Helmsley's company, pulled its business within 24 hours -- he brought in others, including A.T.&T. and Willie Mays. (The former baseball player, according to his agent, loathes "egghead type" lawyers but found Mr. Giuliani "a regular guy" and considers him a friend.)
But according to some at the firm, he seemed bored with what he considered the tedium, lack of visibility and distastefulness of private practice. "How can people do this for a living?' he once asked a colleague. Another recalled how, during a conference call one Sunday, he fetched a television set and turned on a Giants-Vikings game. His happiest moments, one partner said, came on business trips, when star-struck strangers approached him at airports.
As his second mayoral bid heated up, Mr. Giuliani's productivity diminished. At a firm in which even rookie lawyers are privy to billing information, everyone knew the numbers: projected to bill 1,900 hours in 1992, he billed less than 178. According to Newsday, the firm paid him $294,000 that year. Last January, as the firm faced serious financial difficulties, two partners suggested in memorandums that he and Mr. Young be dismissed. Instead, the firm let go several more junior lawyers.
"He's definitely very self-centered and single-minded, without much of a conscience about protecting the institutions he joins," said Bruce A. Brown, who practices with the New York office of Phillips, Lytle, Hitchcock, Blaine & Huber. "If making this city the best city in America happens to coincide with his self-interest, he could be an excellent mayor."
The two took a leave of absence in May.
"We sure as hell did not make cash on Rudy," said Eugene Anderson, a founding partner of the firm. "If I had it to do over again, I'd be more realistic about politics than I was then. But I believe in experiments. And I think that over all, it was successful."

CORRECTION-DATE: October 23, 1993, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about Rudolph W. Giuliani's legal career misstated the views of Norman Siegel, the director of the New York Civil Liberties Union. Mr. Siegel is not backing Mayor David N. Dinkins in the New York City mayoral race; he has not endorsed any candidate.

HEADLINE: Plan Opens More Data To Public

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 21

 BODY:
In the clearest indication yet of the Clinton Administration's willingness to offer broader public access to Government information, the National Science Foundation is financing a project that will make corporate filings to the Securities and Exchange Commission available free via a computer network.
The decision to support the project, which will provide access to the S.E.C.'s on-line data base of financial data from America's public corporations, is a shift away from the Federal information policies under Presidents Ronald Reagan and George Bush. Those Administrations favored letting private companies sell printed and electronic versions of Government data. 
 Although the National Science Foundation project, which will be announced on Friday, is a test, it has broad implications for creating fast, inexpensive consumer access to public records of all sorts. The precedent could threaten the huge industry that has grown up to sell financial records, court cases and other public documents over services like Mead Data Central's Nexis and Lexis networks.
 
 
Available Over Internet
 The project will make disclosure of information from corporations accessible to anyone who has access to the Internet computer network through a modem or a direct network link. The Internet, a loose collection of computer networks that is administered by the National Science Foundation, is now routinely accessible from most university campuses and businesses.
"This is a priority for this Administration," said Michael Nelson, special assistant to the director of the White House Office of Science and Technology policy. "This is another indication of the Administration's commitment to make Federal information more available to the taxpayers who paid for it."
Internet access is rapidly becoming a feature of many commercial on-line computer services as well. Some 20 million computer users are connected to the Internet.
"This is a wonderful example of how the Internet might be used to provide access to Government information," said Marc Rotenberg, national director of the Computer Professionals for Social Responsibility, a Washington public interest group.
In June, the Office of Management and Budget announced that it was reversing previous Administration policy that had defined Government information as a commodity, often available for sale to private industry. The new policy encourages Federal agencies to make as much information as possible available to the public with fees as low as possible.
The project underscores how rapidly changing computer and network technologies are making it possible to offer low-cost access to Government information that has previously been available only on paper in libraries or electronically on mainframe computers that were difficult and expensive to tap into from remote locations. But increasingly, that mainframe data can be transferred easily to inexpensive work stations.
It also emphasizes the rapidly increasing scope of Internet as the forerunner of a national data highway that is expected to carry computer data, video and voice conversations beginning in the next century.
The project, financed with a $660,000 two-year grant from the science foundation, is being undertaken by the Stern School of Business at New York University and a small Washington company, the Internet Multicasting Service. They plan to make the Friday announcement.
Currently, the S.E.C. data base, called the Edgar Dissemination Service, is operated under contract by Mead Data Central. Mead acts as a data wholesaler, providing a variety of computer data feeds to the retail information industry.
 
Commercial Charge Cited
 Under this system, a retail information provider, like Mead Data's own Nexis service, charges about $15 for each S.E.C. document, plus a connection charge of $39 an hour and a printing charge of about $1 a page.
The only fees to use the S.E.C.'s data base under the science foundation's project would be for access to the Internet, for which pricing varies. Commercial access can be bought for as little as $2 an hour. But many college students now obtain Internet access as part of their tuition costs and many businesses buy a high-speed Internet connection that might cost the company hundreds or thousands of dollars each month but permits employees to share unlimited access to the network.
A legislative-affairs lawyer for the Information Industries Association, Ronald Plesser, said the industry would not oppose the project as long as the Government did not intend to restrict commercial publishing of Federal data.
"We have no problem with data bases being made available over the Internet," Mr. Plesser said. "But there has to be an interest in insuring a diversity of sources. We don't want a Government monopoly on the ownership and dissemination of Government information."
Representative Edward J. Markey, a Massachusetts Democrat who is chairman of the House Telecommunications Subcommittee has been pushing for greater public access to the S.E.C.'s Edgar Dissemination Service. He said today that he applauded the science foundation's move.
 
'S.E.C. Finally Gets It'
 "I've been trying to launch Edgar into cyberspace for the last year, and I think the S.E.C. finally gets it," Mr. Markey said, adding that he expected the project to stimulate the commercial market rather than hurt it.
The company involved in the project, the Internet Multicasting Service, is a nonprofit organization founded by Carl Malamud, an economist who developed computer technology for the Federal Reserve Bank. Mr. Malamud has also been instrumental in creating technology that is capable of broadcasting information including audio, video and data over the Internet.
He said the data would be delayed by a day, in contrast to the instant access that is provided by some on-line publishers for financial professionals. Under terms of the science foundation grant, the New York University researchers will buy raw data and reformat them so that they can be obtained over the Internet through Mr. Malamud's organization. Mr. Malamud said he hoped to have the new data base service operating by the end of the year.

CORRECTION-DATE: October 26, 1993, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on Friday, about a National Science Foundation project to distribute Securities and Exchange Commission data over computer networks, misstated the views of Ronald L. Plesser, a lawyer for the Information Industry Association. Neither Mr. Plesser nor the trade group has yet taken a position on the project.

International 3-6
 
CLINTON PLANS TO VISIT MOSCOW
President Clinton and President Yeltsin are to meet in Moscow in January as part of an American effort to support him in transforming Russia into a free-market democracy. 1 

U.S. IS SPLIT ON HAITI POLICY
The Clinton Administration appears to be at war with itself over policy toward Haiti as the C.I.A. battles with the State Department and the National Security Council in an effort to influence the policy. 1
 
The United Nations said a total embargo might be imposed on Haiti. 3
 
U.N. CHIEF VISITS SOMALIA
The United Nations Secretary General visited Somalia, provoking the first menacing street protests in more than two weeks. 1
 
THE TRIALS OF YASIR ARAFAT'S WIFE
For Soha Tawil, who was born a Christian but converted to Islam, coexistence with friends and colleagues of her husband, Yasir Arafat, the P.L.O. chairman, may be harder for her than coexistence with the Israelis. 1
 
ISRAEL EASES PALESTINIAN CURBS
Israel eased restrictions that have made it difficult for Palestinians in the occupied territories to enter Israel, but P.L.O. officials said the change did not go far enough. 5
 
LIBYAN ARMY REVOLT REPORTED
The Libyan leader appears to have put down a recent revolt by army units seeking to topple his Government, say Western intelligence reports and opposition leaders. 5
 
TROOPS KILL 25 IN KASHMIR VALLEY
At least 25 people were reported killed as protesters against Indian rule in the Kashmiri capital clashed with Indian troops who were enforcing a total curfew in the area. 6

With the number of drug-related slayings in the nation's capital steadily rising, Mayor Sharon Pratt Kelly asked President Clinton for authority to call up the National Guard to assist in policing the city. 1
 
BUYING FLU SHOTS AT THE GROCERY
A Cincinnati supermarket has been offering an unusual shoppers' special: flu shots. The response has been overwhelmingly positive. 1
 
PANEL SEEKS PACKWOOD DIARIES
The Senate ethics committee, investigating accusations of sexual misconduct by Senator Bob Packwood of Oregon, is demanding complete access to his private diaries. 7

Citing a technicality, the District Attorney in Austin, Tex., dropped indictments against Senator Kay Bailey Hutchison. But he vowed to bring the case to a new grand jury. 7

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Companies
Prudential Securities was flooded with telephone calls from customers throughout the country seeking details of the firm's agreement to repay investors who lost money on limited partnerships sold by the firm in the 1980's. Prudential agreed on Thursday to pay a minimum of $371 million in restitution to investors and fines to regulators for having misrepresented the safety and potential returns of real estate and energy partnerships. [Page 37.]
Lawyers said the most novel aspect of Prudential's settlement was its willingness to let investors file claims no matter how long ago they bought partnership interests. They said the absence of a statute of limitations may affect future fraud settlements. [37.]
Macy and Federated Department Stores settled their feud over Roger N. Farah, the Federated executive Macy appointed to revitalize its merchandising and lead it out of bankruptcy. [37.]
Kroger and other grocery chains and companies are providing customers around the country with flu shots at reduced rates in a program with the Visiting Nurses Association. [1.]
BankAmerica plans to eliminate up to 3,750 jobs to reduce expenses and lift earnings per share. [39.]
Computervision said it would cut 40 percent of its work force and it issued a bleak third-quarter earnings report. [39.]
Robert Siegel, president of the Dockers U.S.A. unit of Levi Strauss, was named chairman of Stride Rite. [39.]
 
International
The Clinton Administration is discussing with Congressional leaders whether the U.S. should enter into the North American Free Trade Agreement on an experimental basis, with a review after three years to check for layoffs or lower wages. [9.]
Brazil is being blocked from restructuring a $43.5 billion package of loans because the Dart family, which holds a quarter of the loans, does not like the terms. [37.]
Volkswagen plans to lay off more than a third of the workers at its troubled Spanish subsidiary SEAT and close a 40-year-old car manufacturing factory in Barcelona. [39.]
Trade talks between the United States and Japan, begun amid smiles by President Clinton and Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa last July, have bogged down in fundamental disagreements. [45.]
 
 Markets
Europe's major stock exchanges surged to record levels on investor hopes for economic recovery, one day after Germany's central bank cut two of its most important short-term interest rates and other nations followed with similar reductions. [37.]
U.S. stocks ended mixed after comments by Alan Greenspan curtailed a morning rally. The Dow gained 13.14. [38.]
Bond prices fell on Greenspan's upbeat remarks about the economy. The Treasury bond yield soared to almost 6 percent. [46.]
Oil prices sank to four-week lows amid signs of weak gasoline prices and ample oil supplies for the winter. [47.]
The dollar rose against major currencies as more European nations followed Germany's lead and cut interest rates. [47.]
 
 Your Money
Picking a mutual fund has gotten more complicated. As the number of funds has multiplied, so have the publications and services rating the performance of funds. [33.]
Those inheriting money from retirement plans must follow strict I.R.S. rules to avoid unnecessary taxes and penalties. [33.]
The tide may have turned for stocks of consumer product companies, especially food and personal-product makers. [33.]
People who want to adopt a child will need a lawyer to guide them through the complex and varied legal requirements. [34.]
A Long Island couple found that buying a vacant lot on which to build a house was no simple task. [34.]

HEADLINE: Qaddafi Reported to Quash Army Revolt

BYLINE: By CHRIS HEDGES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CAIRO, Oct. 22

 BODY:
Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi appears to have put down a rebellion by army units seeking to topple his Government in the last 10 days, according to Western intelligence reports and Libyan opposition leaders.
Western diplomats in Cairo and others interviewed by phone in London, Rome and Tripoli said that while details were sketchy it appeared that army units staged revolts in other military installations. 
 The largest rebellion apparently took place near the city of Misurata, on the Mediterranean coast 120 miles east of Tripoli, the capital. But uprisings may also have been staged at Bani Walid, a rural area 90 miles southeast of Tripoli, Brach and Tarhuna, they said.
"We have had reliable reports of large numbers of wounded and casualties in the hospitals," said a European diplomat who has seen reports from his embassy in Tripoli. "This seems to prove that some real fighting took place."
 
Nothing in the Press
 The state-controlled news media in Libya has made no mention of any disturbances, and Libyan officials reached by phone said there was no internal unrest.
But Western diplomats said there were reports of dozens of casualties, bombing raids against the rebel outposts by the Libyan Air Force, explosions at arms depots and purges of senior military officers.
The attempted coup would be the worst internal fighting in Libya since an uprising in 1986, just after the American bombing of Tripoli, by sections of the Libyan Army. The 1986 rebellion was crushed by units from Colonel Qaddafi's revolutionary guards, who were also involved in the latest fighting, Western diplomats said.
"People in the Government were quite rattled," a senior Western diplomat said. "Several old military hands appear to have taken part."
The reports of fighting come as the United Nations is considering whether to increase sanctions against Libya, including a freeze on its assets, because of its refusal to extradite two Libyans charged in connection with the bombing of a Pan Am jet that crashed over Lockerbie, Scotland, in 1988, killing 270 people.
 
Air Traffic Halted
 The United States, Britain and France have asked that the sanctions be broadened because of Libya's refusal to hand the men over for trial, but Russia is opposed. It fears such a step could prompt Libya to suspend payment on a $4 billion debt.
The new sanctions would also ban the sale to Libya of equipment used in oil refineries and transportation. Sanctions already in effect has halted international air traffic to Libya.
Libya is also under pressure to cooperate in a French investigation into the 1989 bombing of a French airliner in which 171 people were killed. French judicial authorities have issued arrest warrants for four Libyans, including Colonel Qaddafi's brother-in-law, in connection with the 1989 blast.
The international isolation has hurt Colonel Qaddafi's prestige, crippled the military because of a lack of spare parts and forced Libyans to travel by road to Tunisia or Egypt to take international flights. It has also damaged the tepid economic liberalization begun by the Government a few years ago.
The reports of the rebellion support recent statements by the National Front for the Salvation of Libya, an exiled opposition group, that spoke of a simultaneous uprising that included a revolt by 2,000 troops in Misurata.
Despite widespread discontent with Colonel Qaddafi's erratic and sometimes bizarre rule, Western diplomats have predicted he will only be overthrown by the army.
"He will be ousted in the same manner in which he took power -- by a coup," a Western diplomat who follows Libya said.
When the uprising took place is unclear, but most of the diplomats said they believed the worst fighting happened between Oct. 11 and Oct. 14. These diplomats contend that the Government carried out "numerous" executions of military officers and hundreds of arrests after the revolt.
There may also have been an attempt on Colonel Qaddafi's life on Oct. 13, diplomats in Cairo said.
Colonel Qaddafi, in a televised speech in Misurata last Sunday, four days after the supposed assassination attempt, spoke of "people who oppose the regime and who are to be punished by death."
"Treason is an abominable deed and those who commit it will go to the lowest level of hell," he said.
He went on to warn listeners to beware of "heretics" and those working for "the C.I.A. and other stray dogs."
Colonel Qaddafi, who has ruled Libya since 1969, governs a country that is dominated by powerful tribal leaders. The revolt may have been instigated by the Wurfala tribe, one of the country's largest, according to western intelligence reports.
Senior Egyptian officials contend that Colonel Qaddafi is unable to hand over the two former intelligence officers charged with being behind the 1988 bombing because at least one of them belongs to the Megraha tribe. Libya's second most powerful political leader, Abdel-Salaam Jalloud, is also a member of the Megraha tribe.
"Libya is not just Qaddafi," a senior Egyptian official said. "It is a tribal system. Jalloud has his own people, his own tribe, and the two people wanted for trial are his relatives. The Government fears that if the two men go to trial they will ask that Jalloud be investigated."

HEADLINE: Greenspan's Comments Trim Advance by Dow

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Stocks ended mixed yesterday, after comments around midday by Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, abruptly curtailed what had been an impressive rally.
Much of the session's action seemed to key on developments in the bond market, which rallied early and then sold off sharply once Mr. Greenspan told an audience at the National Italian-American Foundation in Washington that economic conditions were improving. 
 "The 50-mile-an-hour headwinds which hobbled the rate of growth have now come down to perhaps 20 or 25 miles an hour," Mr. Greenspan said.
The remarks, and the bond market's reaction, produced concern among stock traders that interest rates may have bottomed. Low rates have been driving this year's stock market rally. If rates start to rise, mutual funds may move out of stocks into fixed-income securities.
Before Mr. Greenspan spoke, the Dow Jones industrial average had risen about 40 points, to a new high of 3676.96. But selling in the afternoon trimmed the Dow to 3649.30, up 13.14, at the close. For the week, the blue-chip index was up 19.57.
Broader market averages did not do as well.
The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks fell 2.09, to 463.27. The American Stock Exchange's composite index was off 0.27, to 477.25. But the Nasdaq composite index, which was hammered earlier in the week, rose 1.40, to 772.68.
At 302.1 million shares, volume on the Big Board was very heavy and capped the third most active week in the exchange's history. For the week, volume totaled 1.53 billion shares.
"There is a lot of confusion, a lot of insecurity on the part of portfolio managers, who so far this year are looking at some very nice gains," said Edward P. Nicoski, chief market strategist at Piper, Jaffray & Hopwood in Minneapolis. "They are taking profits and moving into areas where prices are not so overheated on the hope that they might be the ones that will start moving up in January."
Among the best performing issues yesterday were cyclical stocks, which could do well if Mr. Greenspan is right about the economy.
Caterpillar, the heavy equipment manufacturer, jumped 4 yesterday, to 89 7/8, on good earnings and an upgraded rating by analysts at Merrill Lynch & Company.
Good earnings also helped shares of Cummins Engine, another Dow stock. The diesel engine manufacturer rose 3 1/8, to 87. And a strong third-quarter performance at United Technologies pushed its shares up 3, to 61 3/4.
The sharp selloff in the bond market hammered bank and other financial stocks and sent the Dow Jones utility average down more than 2 points.
Other market losers included Kimberly-Clark, which reported a drop in third-quarter net income. Its stock fell 1 7/8, to 51 1/2.
In Tokyo, stocks were higher. The Nikkei index of 225 issues gained 85.41 points, or 0.42 percent, to 20,264.93.

HEADLINE: CLINTON WILL VISIT YELTSIN FOR TALKS AT START OF 1994

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Oct. 22

 BODY:
President Clinton will meet Russia's President, Boris N. Yeltsin, in Moscow in mid-January as part of the Administration's campaign to support Mr. Yeltsin's struggle to transform his country into a free-market democracy.
The trip, announced today by Secretary of State Warren Christopher at a joint news conference here with Foreign Minister Andrei V. Kozyrev, is also evidently intended to enhance Mr. Clinton's standing as a statesman and divert the spotlight from the Administration's foreign policy setbacks in Bosnia, Haiti and Somalia. The Administration would clearly like to focus attention on its support for democratization in Russia, the foreign policy area where the Clinton Administration feels it has been most successful.
 
Separate Trip for Gore
 It was also announced in Washington that Vice President Al Gore will make a separate trip to Moscow, three days after the Russian parliamentary elections, scheduled for Dec. 12. 
 Administration officials like to point out that the American President has looked most like a statesman at the two summit meetings he has attended: a meeting with Mr. Yeltsin in Vancouver last April and the Tokyo gathering of the seven largest industrialized nations in July. After both meetings, Mr. Clinton's approval rating for his performance on foreign policy soared.
"It does remind everyone that our foreign policy is much broader than some of the issues we've been dealing with lately," the White House press secretary, Dee Dee Myers, said in Washington. She added that Mr. Clinton will spend eight or nine days abroad, attending the NATO summit meeting in Brussels on Jan. 10-11 and making other stops in addition to Moscow. The exact dates for the Moscow visit were not announced.
The trip will be Mr. Clinton's first to Moscow since the late 1960's when he visited when he was a Rhodes scholar at Oxford University during a Christmas break. "I've been there in January before," Mr. Clinton told reporters at the White House. "It's light about four hours a day. It shows you my timing."
Mr. Christopher told reporters that Mr. Clinton's visit was in no way intended to influence the outcome of Russia's parliamentary elections.
"I don't think my meeting with Yeltsin should be taken as anything but an endorsement of democracy and free-market reform in Russia," said Mr. Christopher, the highest-ranking American official to visit Moscow since Mr. Yeltsin dismissed the Russian Parliament and crushed a revolt.
During the news conference, Mr. Kozyrev endorsed an American plan, made public at a Defense Ministers' meeting of NATO this week, that would create a mechanism that could eventually lead to closer cooperation between NATO and the countries of the former Warsaw Pact. The American plan sets no schedule, however, for these former Communist nations to actually achieve membership in the alliance, something sought by Poland, Hungary, the Czech Republic and Slovakia.
 
Clear Differences
 In conversations with reporters accompanying Mr. Christopher on this trip, State Department officials have indicated that a clear difference of interpretation exists between Mr. Christopher and Defense Secretary Les Aspin, who made it clear at the NATO meeting that he had no enthusiasm for allowing membership of the former Communist states.
The difference was evident in a cable to NATO Foreign Ministers written by Mr. Christopher early in the week that expressed the need to support the eventual expansion of NATO at the January summit, senior State Department officials said. But despite Mr. Christopher's cable, the initiative has been widely interpreted in European capitals as intended to delay its expansion indefinitely.
"In our view, the summit should firmly open the door to an eventual expansion of NATO that would occur through an evolutionary process," Mr. Christopher wrote in a cable that was approved by the Pentagon and the White House.
 
Go-Slow Approach
 Indeed, Mr. Christopher stressed today that the composition of NATO would "not be changed lightly," and a senior official said that the process would take years.
Mr. Kozyrev praised the American initiative for its go-slow approach. "The thrust of this approach is quite correct," he said. "This is exactly what we've been saying here lately -- that states in Central and Eastern Europe and states of the former Soviet Union are entitled to become members of any organization, but there is no rush."
Mr. Kozyrev called the American approach "one of respect to every state and there is no attempt that is being made to leave Russia on the sidelines."
Mr. Yeltsin, apparently under pressure from his armed forces, sent a letter to President Clinton last month opposing an expansion of NATO to include former Warsaw Pact countries eager to join, like Poland and the Czech Republic. The letter, which was also sent to President Francois Mitterrand of France, Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany and Prime Minister John Major of Britain, added that any expansion that did not include Russia would undermine European security.
 
Trading Compliments
 Earlier in the day, Mr. Christopher flew by helicopter to meet Mr. Yeltsin at one of the Russian President's dachas, a hunting reserve about 80 miles northwest of Moscow.
Before their 45-minute meeting in a two-story solarium filled with tropical plants and stuffed exotic birds, the two men smiled for the cameras in a display of mutual boosterism.
"President Clinton sends his warmest regards," Mr. Christopher told Mr. Yeltsin. "He's full of admiration for what you're doing here, and he is enormously appreciative of your courage."
Mr. Yeltsin, who has been out of public sight for more than a week, returned the compliment, saying, "I have to say that of all the leaders of the world, President Clinton most steadily supports Russia, consistently, immediately and steadfastly."
 
Lenin as a Punchline
 A senior official, who briefed reporters on the condition of anonymity, said that after Mr. Christopher informed Mr. Yeltsin on the American proposal for NATO, Mr. Yeltsin raised his arms and called it "terrific" and "brilliant."
Mr. Christopher offered no criticism of Mr. Yeltsin's recent decrees, which have included the shutting down of some newspapers and the outlawing of several political parties.
In his meeting with Mr. Christopher, Mr. Yeltsin described the banned parties as "fascistic," senior American officials said. But he was also quoted as joking that democracy has progressed so fast that "the only thing that remains to be done is to bury Lenin."
Despite the obvious warmth, there were areas of discord. Mr. Christopher was unable to persuade Russia to drop its resistance to extending economic sanctions against Libya through the United Nations. The Clinton administration wants to punish the regime of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi for sponsoring terrorism, but Russia is concerned that sanctions will prevent Libya from paying $4 billion it owes Russia for weapons purchases.

HEADLINE: CAMPAIGN TRAIL;
Whitman, Aboard Bus, Is on Upbeat Roll

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY

 BODY:
Christine Todd Whitman, the Republican candidate for Governor, spent the last leg of her three-day, cross-state bus tour in Ocean County yesterday courting elderly residents for their votes, counseling teen-agers and entertaining a group of kindergarten students with a popular children's story.
"This campaign is about people, about jobs, about the future," Mrs. Whitman told a group of elderly residents of the Holiday City community in Berkeley Township. 
 At Toms River North Regional High School she was welcomed by students carrying her campaign signs, autograph seekers and sustained applause for her response to a question on abortion.
"I am pro-choice; I've always been pro-choice," Mrs. Whitman said. "It is a very personal decision between a woman and her physician and the Government should stay out of it."
On sex education, the Republican candidate told about 500 students who crammed into an auditorium for her visit that "abstinence is the only way to insure you don't get a sexually transmitted disease."
Mrs. Whitman began her day with a visit to the Sand Castle Early Childhood Center in Toms River, where she practiced a traditional bit of campaigning -- holding a baby as photographers snapped away -- and a bit of the unconventional -- settling on the floor in the midst of about 25 kindergarten students to read them a story.
Mrs. Whitman's selection was "The Little Engine That Could," the classic children's story of a small train engine that was able to pull a larger train up a mountainside while encouraging itself with the refrain: "I think I can, I think I can."
Asked if Mrs. Whitman, who is trailing Gov. Jim Florio by double digits in all the most recent independent polls, had selected the book for its symbolism, her media aide, Keith Nahigian, said the choice was purely coincidental.
"But maybe it's a sign," he said.
The bus trip that began Tuesday morning was packed with stops (and photo ops) galore: at diners, supermarkets, train stations, schools -- wherever voters, or voters' children, were likely to be found. As the bus rolled across the state, it provided a welcome sense of momentum to Republicans longing for their candidate to get moving in the polls.
Mrs. Whitman has little patience with those who find fault with the pace of her campaign.
"I've been doing this all along," she said yesterday at a Toms River stop.
The problem, she said, was the news media.
"They weren't looking at me over the summer," she said.
They have certainly been looking at her this week. At some stops, reporters, photographers and television crews were easier to find than plain ordinary voters.
Mrs. Whitman's travels also caught the attention and the attack of Mr. Florio, who was in Woodbridge yesterday to receive the endorsement of 40 owners of small businesses, or his speechwriters.
"I understand that Mrs. Whitman is finishing her bus tour today," the Governor said. "Anybody can get on a bus, but the question is, which direction is the bus going? Mrs. Whitman's bus is going backwards -- back to the trickle-down economics that nearly bankrupted the nation."
 
Florio's Best Friend?
 Perhaps it was inevitable.
Taro, New Jersey's death-row dog, has become an issue in the state's political season.
Gov. Jim Florio has his legal aides studying whether he has powers of canine clemency to save Taro from a court-imposed death sentence.
And yesterday the Bergen County Sheriff, Jack Terhune, got into the act.
Mr. Terhune, a Republican seeking re-election, suggested that the dog be spared, to spend the rest of its life in the county jail, where it has been impounded since March 1991.
Mr. Terhune denied any political pandering to dog lovers.
He called his life-in-jail suggestion more "cost-effective" than continuing to run up the legal expenses in the fight over the life of the dog, which is accused of biting the lip of a 10-year old girl in 1990.
Haworth's prosecution of the dog has cost its taxpayers $60,000 in legal fees. Lonnie Lehrer and Sandy Lehrer of Haworth, co-owners of the dog, say they have spent at least $25,000. The dog's food and upkeep costs at the jail for two and a half years have been about $18,000. Most of that expense has been for guards to walk and feed the animal. Sheriff Terhune said he would waive that fee if Taro is spared and charge only for the dog's food -- a cost that he projected at $9,000 if the dog lives another 10 years.
Mr. Lehrer scoffed at the idea of the dog's staying in the county jail forever. "That's not his life," he said. "He belongs to his family." Mr. Lehrer plans to appeal this week's ruling to New Jersey's Supreme Court.
Governor Florio's aides, meantime, say he wants to know his legal standing in the case. "His overall concern is we let the justice system continue to hear the case because he's in no position to intervene until a final decision by the courts takes place," said Audrey Kelly, a spokeswoman.

HEADLINE: Darts Clash With Brazil Over Loans

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
For the past couple of weeks, a high-stakes game of chicken involving one of America's wealthiest families and the Government of Brazil has animated what essentially is the final chapter of the Latin American debt crisis.
The dispute, which has Citibank and several other big banks caught in the middle, centers on a face value of about $1.4 billion in Brazilian loans held by the Dart family of Sarasota, Fla., which owns the Dart Container Corporation, a maker of foam containers and cups. 
 Those loans are part of a $43.5 billion package of loans that Brazil, the largest debtor in the developing world, and its major commercial bank creditors have been painstakingly working to restructure for nearly three years.
Now the plan is in trouble, even though holders of 95 percent of the debt have approved it.
That is because the Dart family, whose stake makes them the fourth-largest holder of the debt, have made it plain that they do not like the terms. As a result, Brazilian officials said they would not proceed with the closing of the transaction.
 
Not Small Players
 "This kind of problem is not new," said a trader who deals extensively in the debt of developing countries and spoke on the condition of anonymity. "But it usually occurs with smaller people. If the Darts had a smaller position, I think there would be an attempt to buy them out."
But the Darts are not small players. Indeed, other interested observers said they thought the family would ultimately choose to take a smaller profit on a revised plan rather than risk losing a great deal more if the financing package fell through.
Few people involved in the restructuring were willing to talk about it on the record because of its sensitivity. But they said that by the end of February -- when the plan was scheduled to close -- the Darts would probably blink, and go along with everyone else.
The Darts began buying the Brazilian debt in the rapidly growing secondary market for developing country debt about three years ago, when the loans in the form of securities were trading at a deep discount.
Prices have risen nicely since, but the Darts had kept their position secret until this spring, when it became clear that Brazil and the committee of banks negotiating the restructuring, led by Citibank, had agreed to alter the terms of the deal.
Under the original terms, the creditors were offered a menu of options to convert their debt.
Most chose to convert the securities into par bonds, which would give them the full face value of the loans but a lower fixed interest rate. The principal payment would be collateralized by United States Treasury bonds bought by Brazil with loans from the International Monetary Fund.
Another choice, and the one preferred by the Darts, was uncollateralized bonds. These bonds would be converted at full face value at an interest rate of 4 percent that would gradually rise to a fixed rate of 8 percent over six years. To make up for the lack of collateral, these bonds would pay the difference in interest between 8 percent and the current coupon in the form of more bonds, until the 8 percent ceiling was reached.
After receiving commitments, Brazil changed its proposal because the original restructuring plan, while lowering interest costs, did little to reduce its debt. But in requesting the changes, Brazil said reallocations should be on an "entirely voluntary basis."
Under its amended plan, Brazil asked the banks to convert at least 35 percent of the securities into a third alternative: deep-discount bonds. These would be securities converted at a discount to the full face value, thereby reducing Brazil's debt but with a floating interest rate. Like the par bonds, these securities would also be collateralized by United States Treasuries.
A committee of bankers agreed, as did most of the other creditors. But the Darts, who chose to place all their investment in the noncollateralized bonds, were less than thrilled, and lobbied against it. Between the time the original financing options were structured and Brazil came back with its new menu, market interest rates had fallen sharply. The Darts were opposed to being told they had to rejigger their options because the securities they had chosen were worth more.
 
An Impossible Deal?
 One possibility, some traders and bankers said, was that Brazil, would go ahead without the Darts, and then refuse to make interest payments on the Dart's holdings. That scenario would probably wind up in a courtroom somewhere.
"Nobody will permit the Darts to get a better deal than they get," said one portfolio manager with a smaller position in Brazilian debt. "They are being offered what everybody else is getting, so it's hard to see how they are being treated unfairly. But if they don't budge, then the deal becomes impossible."
Melissa Krantz, a spokeswoman for the Dart family, acknowledged that retaining a 100 percent interest in the noncollateralized bonds was the best possible financial result for her clients. But she added that if the Darts reduced their portion of noncollateralized bonds and took the 35 percent position in the discount bonds, as requested, Brazil would be out $73 million in up-front costs.
"We have tried to participate in a manner most advantageous to Brazil," she said. "We wish Brazil well. And Dart has not said it intends to stand in the way of the deal closing."

HEADLINE: U.S.-Japan Trade Talks Bog Down

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Oct. 22

 BODY:
Trade negotiations between the United States and Japan, begun in July with smiles by President Clinton and Kiichi Miyazawa, who was Prime Minister then, have bogged down in fundamental disagreements, according to participants in the talks.
The disagreements, which emerged in talks here over the last two weeks, indicate that the framework for further talks will not necessarily serve as the basis of a harmonious new economic relationship . 
 Rather, the problems seem to confirm the fears of some critics that the vaguely worded framework agreement, hastily drawn up and signed in July, would merely postpone arguments until later. Later is now.
Negotiators for both sides, however, said that talks were still in an early stage and that they anticipated completing trade agreements by the deadline -- next January -- in three sectors that were the focus of discussions in the last two weeks: automobiles and auto parts, insurance and government procurement.
"I don't think we are at a point in these negotiations where we can say there is anything unbridgeable," said Charlene Barshefsky, deputy United States trade representative, at a news conference today.
Negotiations are expected to resume next month in Washington.
The framework negotiations are not as urgent as some other issues that will soon test the Clinton Administration's attitude toward Japan.
The Administration has threatened to hit Japan with sanctions on Nov. 1 if no progress is made toward opening Japan's construction market to foreign companies. Another clash could come by mid-November over whether Japan will drop its ban on rice imports to facilitate an agreement in the Uruguay round of global trade talks under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.
Today, Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa moved to try to avert construction sanctions. He told a Cabinet meeting he would like to compile by the end of next week basic plans to introduce an open competitive bidding system for public works projects above a certain value. It is unclear, however, whether enough can be done by Nov. 1 to satisfy America.
For its part, Japan will withdraw from parts of the framework talks if construction sanctions go beyond barring Japanese construction companies from bidding for Federal projects, Sozaburo Okamatsu, vice minister of the Ministry of International Trade and Industry, said today.
In the last two weeks the United States has presented Japan with lengthy proposals for measures it should take to increase market access for foreign products in automobiles and parts, insurance, and government procurement of telecommunications and medical equipment.
American officials say they expect the share of foreign products in Japan's market to rise to roughly the same range as foreign market share in the other industrialized nations in three or four years. For instance, the Americans say, foreign companies have 5 percent of Japan's telecommunications market whereas foreign companies hold an average of 25 percent in the industrialized countries. Japan views such goals as targets and says it will not agree.
Japan also argues that some of the steps being requested by the United States are beyond the power of Japan's Government, while the framework is limited to "matters within the scope and responsibility of the Government."
It is believed for instance, that the United States is asking that Japan's Government undertake a consumer education program to dispel popular beliefs that American cars are too expensive or of low quality.
 
Who Should Explain?
 "Should explanations of U.S. products be made by the Government or by the companies?" Mr. Okamatsu of MITI asked.
Another big disagreement concerns wording in the framework agreement that the consultations "will take place under the basic principle of two-way dialogue."
Japan says this means the United States should also open its market where it is closed. The American Government, for instance, has never bought a Japanese supercomputer, even though Japanese manufacturers hold 40 percent of the European market, a clear sign that they make competitive products.
The United States maintains that although the framework calls for a dialogue it does not call for two-way market-opening measures and that the framework is clearly meant to address Japan's huge trade surplus.

HEADLINE: Yield on Long Bond Soars in Selloff

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The Treasury market continued its selloff yesterday after the chairman of the Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan, gave a mildly upbeat economic assessment.
The sharp drop in prices sent the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond soaring to just below 6 percent. 
 Mr. Greenspan's comments suggested to some investors that the Fed might lean toward higher interest rates to help keep a lid on inflation, which is aggravated by fast economic growth.
Some analysts said Treasury market investors used Mr. Greenspan's comments as an excuse to sell after growing jittery about owning bonds with interest rates at their lowest levels in more than two decades.
"Greenspan certainly was the nail in the coffin at the end of the day," said David Ader, a market strategist at Technical Data in Boston, a unit of Thomson Financial Services. "But this has been a very poor week in general for the bond market."
The price of the Treasury's main 30-year bond tumbled 29/32 of a point, while its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, soared to 5.98 percent, from 5.91 percent on Thursday.
 
'Headwinds' Have Abated
 Mr. Greenspan told a National Italian-American Foundation luncheon in Washington that the "headwinds" that had hampered United States economic growth -- debt accumulated during the economic expansion of the 1980's -- had significantly abated.
But analysts said Mr. Greenspan also remarked that the recent trend of widespread corporate layoffs was likely to continue, indicating a decidedly mixed view on the economy. This week, major drug companies and the BankAmerica Corporation announced thousands of job cuts.
The focus of the bond investors on news that is bad for the credit markets indicates how skittish they are about holding bonds after the phenomenal price rally of recent months.
That became clear on Thursday when a survey by the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia, normally viewed as a secondary economic report, contributed to a similar selloff. The survey of businesses in the mid-Atlantic region showed a sharp improvement in the regional economic conditions.
"Most fund mangers have been approaching the U.S. bond market with one foot out the door," said Robert Giordano, the director of economic research at Goldman, Sachs & Company.
Mr. Ader of Technical Data said the overreaction of the market was demonstrated by the concentration of the selloff in longer-term maturities.
The 10-year Treasury note, for example, lost 17/32 of a point, but short-term Treasuries posted losses of only 3/32 to 4/32 of a point.
The Lehman Brothers Daily Treasury Bond Index, reflecting price movements on bonds with maturities of a year or longer, tumbled 4.00, to 1,328.32.
Ordinarily, short-term securities would be most vulnerable to fears of higher interest rates, because the central bank uses short-term rates to carry out monetary policy.
Indeed, the discount rates on Treasury bills were relatively flat. The discount rate on three-month Treasury bills slipped one basis point, or hundredths of a percentage point, to 3.02 percent. The discount rate on six-month bills was unchanged at 3.13 percent. But the discount rate on one-year bills rose 2 basis points, to 3.27 percent.
In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds closed at 10520/32 , down 8/32 from late Thursday. The average yield to maturity was 5.40 percent, up from 5.38 percent.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Petroleum Continues to Fall As Supply Seems Adequate

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Oil prices sank to four-week lows yesterday amid signs that gasoline prices were weakening and that oil supplies would be ample to meet demand this winter.
On the Mercantile Exchange in New York, crude oil for December delivery fell 28 cents, to $18.07 a barrel, in the eighth trading session of the last 10 in which prices have declined. 
 November heating oil fell 0.56 cent, to 53.55 cents a gallon, and November gasoline dropped 1.04 cents, to 49.59 cents a gallon -- a five-week low.
 
Further Decline Is Seen
 Gasoline prices continued a recent decline from what many traders viewed as artificially high levels reached after the summer driving season.
Some oil analysts said they expected oil prices to continue falling next week in the absence of fear of higher winter heating oil demand or signs of a cohesive agreement by OPEC to restrain output.
"The market is giving out the clear signal that it is oversupplied," said Philip Verleger of the Institute for International Economics in Washington. "The barrel counters are wrong," he added, referring to some analysts' views of a tighter supply-and-demand picture. Domestic oil stocks are 327.1 million barrels, down 100,000 barrels from a year ago.
Unless cold weather hits the Northeast, the region where heating oil is used most, crude oil prices could fall below $18 a barrel.
"The short-term fundamentals don't look that good," said Victor Yu of Refco, predicting crude prices would fall to around $17.70 a barrel.
"It's still too early to say if the long-term downtrend has resumed," he said. "A lot of it will become a weather play." But some bullish traders said they remain convinced that oil prices would rebound once the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries shows it is holding the line on production.
"This is nothing more than a correction," one Texas trader said. "Why should I be bearish now when we've fallen about $1?The time to be bearish was $1 ago."
On other commodities markets, lumber prices soared, extending a six-month high. At the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, November lumber jumped the $10 limit, to $348.10 a thousand board feet, the highest price since mid-April. On Monday, trading will resume with $15 maximum price limits.
