HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Rises as Europeans Mimic Germany's Rate Cuts

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar rose against most major currencies yesterday as several more European nations followed Germany's lead of the day before and brought down interest rates.
In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 1.6755 German marks, up from 1.6667 on Thursday. 
 Gold prices fell. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for December delivery lost $1.50, to settle at $371.30 an ounce. The Republic National Bank of New York quoted a late bid price for spot gold of $370 an ounce, down $1.30.
Hillel Waxman, chief foreign exchange dealer at Bank Leumi Trust Company, said much of the dollar's gain yesterday was a continuation of Thursday's rally, set off when the German central bank, the Bundesbank, surprised financial markets by trimming two key interest rates.
 
Jumping on the Bandwagon
 Several other European countries including Belgium, the Netherlands, Switzerland and Austria, quickly matched the German rate cut. Yesterday, France, Spain and Ireland also cut rates.
Lower interest rates abroad tend to drive the dollar higher as investors shift money into dollar-denominated investments to capture higher yields.
"The primary engine behind this movement is the U.S. went into recession before Europe did and now we're coming out of recession and they're still in it," said Randolph Donney, director of capital market research at Pegasus Econometric Group.
European countries are bringing down interest rates to stimulate their economies, whereas market participants in the United States are wondering when domestic rates will rise. That, Mr. Donney said, creates a powerful environment for the dollar to move higher.
Aside from some profit taking against the yen, the dollar moved ahead yesterday for that reason, he added. It was trading late in New York at 108.05 yen, down from 108.35 on Thursday.
The British pound slipped to $1.4735 in New York, down from $1.4835 on Thursday.
Other late New York dollar rates, compared with late Thursday, included: 1.4755 Swiss francs, up from 1.4709; 5.8539 French francs; up from 5.8505; 1,613.00 Italian lire, up from 1,606.00, and 1.3043 Canadian dollars, down from 1.3105.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
BankAmerica Is Planning to Eliminate at Least 3,000 Jobs

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 22

 BODY:
The BankAmerica Corporation plans to eliminate 3,000 to 3,750 jobs in the next 14 months.
The cuts are necessary to reduce costs to bolster earnings per share, which have been constrained by the recession in California, Richard M. Rosenberg, BankAmerica's chairman and chief executive, wrote in a staff newsletter released on Thursday. 
 BankAmerica shares closed today at $43.25, down 25 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange.
Analysts said the relative lack of movement in the stock reflected the minimal impact the cuts would have on earnings, though the impact will be positive, and the fact that such cuts have been anticipated for some time. A BankAmerica spokesman said it had not been determined whether the cuts would result in a charge to earnings.
The job cuts, about half expected to be accomplished by attrition, represent the second time the bank has cut its work force since it acquired the Security Pacific Corporation for $4.4 billion in April 1992. In the first round, BankAmerica eliminated 20,000 jobs, shrinking its work force to 98,000 worldwide. About 12,000 people were laid off; the rest were moved into jobs opened through attrition.
"Although total net income increased considerably as a result of the Security Pacific merger, we have not yet begun to increase our earnings per share, which is the basic measure of how well we are performing for our shareholders," Mr. Rosenberg wrote in the newsletter to employees.
"We are facing a prolonged recession in some of our key markets, and heightened competition from both banks and nonbank financial institutions," he continued. "As a result, both our net interest income and noninterest income have been basically flat for the last 12 months, and we don't see the economic picture improving appreciably in the near future."
This week, BankAmerica reported that third-quarter earnings were $486 million, 2.1 percent more than the $476 million it earned in the comparable 1992 period. But earnings per share were lower: $1.19 a share compared with $1.22 a year earlier.
Mr. Rosenberg wrote that the job cuts are part of a larger cost-cutting program associated with the Security Pacific merger that the bank hopes will reduce its annual expense budget of $6.5 billion by $250 million. "As we continue our efforts to keep expenses in line with our revenues, we realize that we will have to reduce expenses still further between now and the end of 1994," he wrote.

HEADLINE: Health Insurance Costs Rise Less Sharply

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

 BODY:
Cost cuts by consumers and cyclical forces in the health insurance industry combined to slow the increase in health premiums last year, the accounting firm KPMG Peat Marwick reported yesterday, based on the results of a survey.
Health care premiums rose 8 percent from spring 1992 to spring 1993, compared with an 11 percent rise a year earlier. The latest figure was double the rate of inflation but was the lowest rate of increase since 1986-87. 
 One reason is the swiftness with which employers have embraced managed-care health plans, under which employees join health-maintenance organizations or preferred-provider plans. Last year, 58 percent of employers with 200 or more workers enrolled in such plans, compared with just 29 percent five years ago.
The survey indicated that President Clinton may now find it easier to promote his health care agenda.
"These modest rate hikes will continue over the next few years, and this is good news for Clinton's health planners, who need to predict the cost of future coverage," said James Buckley, head of group health consulting for Peat Marwick in New York.
Peat Marwick has also discerned a cycle of profits in the health insurance business since 1965. When insurance companies are profitable, increases in the premiums they charge are smaller two years later, Mr. Buckley said. When insurers suffer losses, premiums increase sharply two years later. According to the survey, the health insurance industry has been profitable for the last two years.
A spokesman for the Health Insurance Association of America said that the health insurance industry has averaged profits of a cent and a half on each dollar of premium collected. "The health insurance business is not that profitable," said Stephen Young of the association.
Referring to the President's health program, Mr. Buckley said: "To the extent that the budget assumed an increase greater than it's going to be, they will have over-accrued their health and welfare costs. A lot of his savings come from his slowing the rate of increase, and this will help."
But the President will have to move fast, before people get used to lower rates and the cycle changes again, Mr. Buckley said.

HEADLINE: Q & A

BYLINE: By Leonard Sloane

 BODY:

A Widow's Rights
 
Q I recently found out about a Social Security provision under which a widow can collect at age 60 if her husband was collecting benefits, if she is unemployed. Are the benefits I lost retroactive?
 
 ALICE MURRAY, Manhattan
A A widow is eligible for survivor benefits on the Social Security record of her deceased husband, as long as he was fully insured under Social Security at the time of his death and she was married to him for at least nine months. This duration-of-marriage requirement is waived if the death was accidental or occurred while the deceased was serving on active duty in the armed forces. 
 However, an application for a widow's benefits has no retroactivity. The rule is that it becomes effective in the month it is received by the Social Security Administration.
"There is, however, one exception to this," said Peter P. Di Sturco, New York regional director of the Social Security Administration. "If a death occurred in the month before the application was received, it can be effective with the month of death."
 
Capital Gains on Bonds
Q In 1984, bonds worth $100,000 were purchased for $65,000. They are now being called. Is there any way the taxes on the $35,000 gain can be spread out or deferred?
 
JOHN F. SHANLEY, Boca Raton, Fla.
A If the bonds were issued on or before July 18, 1984, the entire $35,000 profit would generally be taxed as a long-term capital gain when the bonds are called.
Under the 1993 tax law, though, you have the right to defer the recognition of the capital gain if you reinvest the proceeds in a specialized small- business investment company, which is licensed by the Small Business Adminstration to assist disadvantaged entrepreneurs.
Joseph N. Guariglia, a partner in McGladrey & Pullen, a New York accounting firm, said that "if the bond acquired at the market discount had been issued after July 18, 1984, the gain on the redemption would be taxed as ordinary income, to the extent of the accrued market discount on the bond, which could not be rolled over; the balance of the gain would be treated as long-term capital gain."
 
Zero-Coupon Bond Fees
Q Can zero-coupon bonds be purchased privately without cost or must they be purchased through a broker?
 
 EDWARD CAROLAN, Yonkers
A To buy zero-coupon bonds,you have to use the services of a brokerage firm or bank. Commissions are usually less than $50, with some brokers charging no fee on transactions of more than 10 bonds.
"An alternative to zero-coupon bonds is a mutual fund that has a portfolio structured to mimic a zero-coupon bond," said John Markese, president of the American Association of Individual Investors. As one example, he said, "the Benham Target Maturities Trusts with different maturities -- five-year intervals out to the year 2020 -- offer, in effect, a Government zero-coupon bond as a mutual fund."
Mutual funds, of course, charge management fees, with expenses deducted before determining net asset value.

HEADLINE: An Arts Center Takes Off Like 40,000 Honey Bees

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 22

 BODY:
With painstaking care, an artist has moved 40,000 honey bees from Oakland to the Center for the Arts at Yerba Buena Gardens, a new arts center in San Francisco that seeks to draw people out of their neighborhoods and into the city's center.
For the inaugural exhibition, which opened last week, the bees' hive was lowered the 20 feet from an open skylight to the gallery floor a little bit each day for a month to acclimate the bees to their new location. The center itself has been more than 25 years in the making, a laborious civic process that has involved five mayors, many financial problems (an early investor, Olympia & York, went bankrupt), several lawsuits and countless discussions among advisory committees in the last decade over what kind of art and performance to show. 
 The result is an eight-acre institution dedicated to multicultural and largely experimental art displayed in bright, shining buildings well served by public transportation. Coming during a recession, the center has been heralded by city leaders as the best thing to happen to San Francisco since the Golden Gate Bridge was completed in 1937.
"It is the nexus of the city," said Helen Sause, project director for the San Francisco Redevelopment Agency. "No one culture or community feels that it is solely theirs."
 
Innovative Design
 One building, the Center for the Arts Galleries, was designed by Fumihiko Maki, this year's winner of the Pritzker Architecture Prize. It resembles an ocean liner, with porthole-like windows, a flagpole that looks like a ship's mast and metal staircases. There will be no permanent collection in the three gallery spaces, which have 25-foot ceilings, but revolving theme-oriented shows and individual exhibitions.
The 755-seat Center for the Arts Theater, designed by the Manhattan architect James Stewart Polshek, looks like a giant, all-white Rubik's cube. Both buildings face a gently rolling five-acre open space (not long ago a parking lot) where people can sit and watch outdoor projections of the performances inside. Across the street is the new brick-and-granite home of the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art, which was designed by the Swiss architect Mario Botta. It is to open in 1995.
The neighborhood was once known as South of the Slot, a reference to the slotted tracks for cable cars on Market Street. The area has long been the city's underbelly and home to successive waves of immigrants. In the name of urban renewal, the city 25 years ago razed burlesque theaters, cheap motels and pawn shops to make room for two hotels, a convention center, parking lots and a sports arena that was never built.
The arts center now stands where the sports arena was meant to be. The switch was made, said Renny Pritikin, the center's artistic director for visual arts, "because of community activism to resist the brutal destruction of this neighborhood."
Residents filed suit in 1969 on behalf of the nearly 4,000 people who had been evicted, and it took nearly a decade before city officials met with neighborhood groups and worked out a plan for an arts center. The city set up an independent nonprofit organization to rent and maintain the buildings and oversee the programs. With $40 million from developers, the city paid the other half of the $82 million bill with bonds. The yearly budget of $4.5 million is to come from contributions, rentals (many to users of the convention center across the street) and ticket sales.
To reflect Northern California demographics, performances and exhibitions are to be steadfastly multicultural, mixing local, national and international arts. The policy has drawn some criticism. The choice of a 50-member Trinidadian steel drum orchestra to play at the center's opening last week was criticized by people who said a local group would have been more appropriate. But Baraka Sele, the center's artistic director for performing arts, dismissed critics of her international lineup of dance and music groups. "I program from the heart," she said.
With "In/Out of the Cold War," the exhibition in the arts galleries, Mr. Pritikin and his co-curator, Rene de Guzman, have also emphasized variety by gathering 32 black, white, Asian, Hispanic, gay and disabled artists to examine the end of the cold war through painting, kinetic sculptures, computer art, film and video.
Change is one of the show's themes: outsiders becoming insiders, life emerging from death. In one dark room, a carousel of military helicopters and winged angels goes around and around, creating an impression, with the help of a strobe light, that helicopters are turning into cherubs and back again. Also reflecting the life-from-death theme, an exhibit in another room, sealed off and viewed through plastic windows, shows live honey bees coming and going as they please through the open skylight. They are almost like unwitting performance artists as they dive to their hive in a real ox's skeleton on the gallery floor.
Many local artists and performers support the center's multicultural emphasis despite concern that the center could lose its local focus or that its approach might mean fulfilling racial quotas.
"San Francisco has a lot more artists than it has people to go to art," said Jon Raskin, a saxophonist who said he would like to perform in the theater. "This has the potential to help a lot of artists in the area."
A San Francisco photographer, Ira Nowinski, is to display his pictures of the white old men who once lived in the neighborhood at a show in 1995. When the old neighborhood was razed, he was upset, he said, but at least an arts center is better than an empty lot.
"When something terrible happens and there's a void, it's good to fill it with art," he said.

HEADLINE: Technology Will Force a Shorter Workweek;
Now, Get Past Politics

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The U.S. Senate passed a bill in the early 1930's calling for a four-day workweek to ease the terrible unemployment situation. The labor committee headed by Senator Robert Wagner endorsed this bill unanimously. If enacted, the legislation would have added eight million more jobs. It was fought fiercely by the Republican Party, the Manufacturers Association, conservatives and the usual so
called economists who relied on old economic theory. 
 The same types fight President Clinton's economic plan, give lip service to his health plan but are opposed to it. These same types lobbied against the 48-hour week, the 44-hour week and the 40-hour week, using the same scare tactics: reduction in work hours will ruin the country and bring severe depression. The country would go Socialist or Communist.
President Roosevelt was forced, under political pressure from the same groups, to ask his friend and supporter, Senator Wagner, to withdraw the bill, though many believed it would have passed by large margins.
I suggested in a 1967 newspaper article that the 32-hour week would help our then-severe recession. It received much favorable comment but was scuttled with the charge that the suggestion was Communist-inspired.
Perhaps now that the Communist bugaboo is behind us, in-depth consideration can be given to a plan I believe would erase our recessions, severe unemployment and the need to keep welfare costs so high because of unemployment. It could start at a slow pace. I urge the Secretary of Labor to study how such a law could be enacted to help lower- and middle-class citizens, who are the perennial victims of our recessions and depressions.
 
HARRY D. OFFENHARTZ
New York, Oct. 15, 1993
 
The writer was an editor with the Works Progress Administration in 1935 and a senior analyst with the Farm Security Administration, 1936.

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY;
Midway Plans To Fly Again From Chicago

BYLINE: By Adam Bryant

 BODY:
Midway Airlines, which operated from Midway Airport in Chicago for a dozen years until it halted service in 1991, plans to start up again this fall.
Its name and base airport will be the same, and its chief executive, Ken Carlson, was the founder of Midway in 1979, but little else has been retained from the original airline. Like many fledgling carriers, the new Midway, (800) 446-4392, is taking advantage of ripe market conditions -- including relatively inexpensive planes and a large pool of unemployed airline workers -- to fill a perceived niche. 
 That niche, Midway officials say, will be service to cities roughly two hours' flying time from Chicago. The airline plans to start flying between La Guardia Airport in New York and Midway on Nov. 15. Two more cities will be added before the end of the year from a short list of Boston, Philadelphia and Washington. And it hopes to lure business passengers with frequent flights, extra legroom, leather seats and lower fares than competitors.
The airline plans to fly roughly six round trips a day on weekdays between Midway and each of its destinations on new Fokker F-100 jets. It will offer a frequent-flier program that will enable the miles earned to be used on Midway or other airlines to be named later.
Midway officials acknowledge that in frequency of flights the carrier will fall far short of competitors like American and United, but said Midway planned eventually to approach those levels.
 ADAM BRYANT

HEADLINE: PERSPECTIVES;
Struggling to Lighten the Mortgage Debt on Co-ops

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER

 BODY:
THE circumstances of the co-op market have made a landlord -- small-time and probably temporary -- out of Michael Kollmer. In 1988 he and his new bride, Rachael Smith, bought a two-bedroom apartment in the 38-unit building at 622 West 114th Street, taking sponsor financing.
They were unable to sell it when Mr. Kollmer moved to New Rochelle in 1990 to be closer to a new job as a music teacher in Mamaroneck. This year the Kollmers, who now have two sons, bought a house in New Rochelle. They rent out the West Side apartment, absorbing a $150-a-month loss, the difference between the rent they receive and the carrying costs of the apartment. 
 "Some people who had to move out are losing $500 a month," he said. "They're hanging on by their fingernails."
But neither Mr. Kollmer nor other shareholders caught in afflictions of rent-regulated buildings that converted to co-ops in the late 80's are sitting on their hands. They are looking for ways to make their apartments more salable, which often means shoring up the fiscal structure of the building itself.
On West 114th Street, that may mean converting the building to a condominium. If that can be negotiated with the bank holding the mortgage and the sponsor, who still owns 14 apartments and gave financing on 11 that were sold, then potential buyers will find mortgage financing easier to come by. The negotiating parties would have to agree on the value of the units as condominiums in order to determine how much each co-op owner would have to pay to buy out the underlying mortgage on the building. Building debt in co-ops is paid off from maintenance payments to the corporation; in condominiums there is no building debt because buyers pay off the building's costs in the purchase price.
In Riverdale, shareholder efforts led to the negotiated prepayment of a loan, discounted by 10 percent, at the 178-unit River Terrace co-op at 2621 Palisades Avenue, which was done in a way that avoided an adverse tax effect. The co-op came away with $270,000 needed for capital repairs, said its lawyer, James Samson of the Manhattan firm of Bangser Klein Rocca & Blum.
And in New Rochelle, resident shareholders concluded negotiations with the new holder of the underlying mortgage on the building, which purchased it at a discount from the Resolution Trust Corporation, only last week. The residents negotiated a writedown that will keep the debt affordable and make the apartments marketable.
"The portion of the building's mortgage debt attributable to each unit should not exceed 35 percent of the value of the units," said Thomas W. Smith, of Smith Buss & Jacobs, the Yonkers law firm that represents the co-op board, citing guidelines that many lenders follow in underwriting building loans.
When the co-op sales market collapsed in 1989, some sponsors were unable to sustain maintenance payments to the building on unsold, renter-occupied apartments. But even when sponsors and resident owners are current, mortgage debt is often too high to keep apartments marketable.
WITH rates down, many co-ops, like other borrowers, have taken the opportunity to refinance. Possibly many more could than do. "They could buy a loan for cash and have another waiting to take its place," said Richard R. Pergolis, of the Manhattan mortgage-brokerage firm of Pergolis Swartz, which handled over 200 transactions last year.
"But a lot of them can't agree on anything," he said. "They all have a friend or an uncle or somebody who has an opinion. Everyone is going off in different directions."
Agreement among the shareholders is not the end of the problem, however. The New Rochelle co-op -- the 48-unit Stonelea Manor, at 110-120 Stonelea Place, near Interstate 95 in a neighborhood of older single-family homes -- is a case in point.
When the building was transferred to the co-op corporation, said Mr. Smith, the lawyer, it had a $1.3 million first mortgage with a savings bank within a $1.33 million five-year "wraparound" mortgage from the sponsor at a favorable rate. The size of the loan was based on potential value in vacancy sales at the then market values, the unfortunate practice at the time.
Eventually the Resolution Trust Corporation took over the bank and the loan found its way into a portfolio of loans sold at discounts to wholesale buyers. "We wanted to buy the loan ourselves," Mr. Smith said, and the building actually negotiated to do so. But in the end the co-op was surprised and disappointed to learn that it had been sold to an investment vehicle, Phoenix One Inc., which, through its agent, Strategic Resources Ltd. of Manhattan, buys nonperforming real-estate loans, restructures them and either holds them or resells them privately.
"We're taking a practical approach," said Paul Schack, president of the Phoenix Companies, based in Morris Plains, N.J., "which means we are looking at the economic realities of the home owners." The practical approach led to a solution last week under which the lender trimmed the mortgage balance to $1 million and the sponsor eliminated the wraparound loan, Mr. Smith said.
According to some specialists, mortgage debt should not exceed about a third of the vacancy value of the apartments, now considerably reduced from the level of the late 80's. More conservatively, others say that the debt level should be linked to the rental value of apartments, based on the market rental value of the already sold apartments and the actual rents of apartments still occupied by a preconversion tenant.
But in either case, debt cannot be excessive for the incomes of buyers in the area. Total housing debt should not exceed about 30 percent of household income. For co-op owners housing debt is a combination of payments on a co-op loan and the apartment's proportional share of the underlying mortgage on the building.
LENDERS, of course, are not keen on writing off debt while a loan is still performing. "It's a Catch-22," said Cynthia Wong, principal in Foray Capital Inc., a Manhattan financial advisory firm. "If there's a default on the loan, lenders will take a discount, but if the loan is good, how do you get them to do it?"
The co-op owner who paid $160,000 for an apartment a few years ago might be willing to accept, say, $130,000. But if the monthly maintenance is based on an exorbitant mortgage value in relation to market value, a buyer may have trouble getting a loan.
From the buyer's viewpoint, an apartment on the market for $130,000 with only $10,000 of underlying mortgage debt attributable to it may well be a better buy than an apartment selling for $100,000 that has $50,000 in mortgage debt attributable to it, Ms. Wong said. "The building is more stable," she said.
Stability is what the resident owners of Stonelea Manor in New Rochelle are looking for. Jon Forster, the 39-year-old treasurer of the board, found he had to give up a sales effort last fall because of lack of buyer interest. "We gave two open houses and no one came," he said. Had he been able to sell, he might have stayed with a job he took a year earlier in Pennsylvania. He commuted there, staying with family members during the week and returning home on weekends. Instead, he left the job for one in New York.
The present value of vacant apartments in the building is believed to be about $50,000 for a one-bedroom and $65,000 for a two-bedroom. Maintenance charges are about $400 a month for a one-bedroom apartment (about three-quarters of it paying off the building mortgage) and $550 for a two-bedroom. Without the negotiated settlement last week, maintenance would have risen at least 15 percent when the sponsor subsidy ran out, said Arlene Gordon Oliver, a lawyer and the board president.
"Right now the maintenance is affordable," she said. "We're trying to keep it affordable."

HEADLINE: Q and A

 BODY:

Forcing Officers To Pay Their Fees
 
Q. Our small four-unit condominium has a board president, who owns two condos and who has not paid his monthly maintenance fees for eight months. What can be done? . . . Angela Wynn, Spring Lake, N.J. 

A. According to Benjamin D. Lambert, a lawyer in Woodbridge, N.J., you have to review the condominium's governing documents. A potential remedy might be a reference that states that board officers must be in good standing financially to retain their positions.
Mr. Lambert also said you could sue in small claims court if the amount owed was less than $2,500 or in civil court if the amount was higher.
"At a minimum," he said, "have an authorized representative of the board file a lien with the county recording office for the amount owed."
 
Charges for Air-Conditioners
 
Q. Recently, I installed the air-conditioner in my rent-stabilized walk-up apartment. I got my landlord's permission to do so, of course. But in addition to my rent, I was asked to pay $5 a month just for having the air-conditioner. Does my landlord have the legal right to do this? . . . Dorota Wnuk, Manhattan
 
A. Yes. According to Lou Ganim, a spokesman for the New York State Housing and Community Renewal Department, which oversees rent administration in New York City, the landlord in rent-controlled or rent-stabilized building may legally charge $5 a month for eachair-conditioner even if the tenant pays for electricity and buys and installs the unit. He added that the charges, which are designed to compensate the owner for any potential damage to the building, were valid even if the air-conditioner was temporarily removed in the winter.
 
Do Proxies Add Up To a Quorum?
 
Q. At a recent shareholders meeting of our co-operative community, we had fewer members present than usual. But when we counted the proxies, we had a quorum.
Our bylaws permit voting in person or by proxy, but do not specify if members actually have to be present to constitute a quorum.
We conducted business, but now some members who were not present either in person or by proxy are asking for another meeting, stating that this one was illegal.
Do proxies count toward a quorum? . . . Sally Seymour, Spring Glen, N.Y.
 
A. According to Marc Luxemburg, a lawyer and president of the Manhattan Council of Co-operatives, a shareholders meeting is legal if there is a quorum in person or by proxy. "The people who didn't show up, they have nothing to complain about, as long as proper notice of the meeting was given," he said. "It's up to them to be there or have a proxy there."

HEADLINE: In the Region/Connecticut;
A Tourist Spot Where Shakespeare Once Reigned

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:
THE statue of Hamlet that broods amid the undergrowth outside the vacant state-owned Shakespeare Theater at Stratford-on-the-Housatonic may soon find itself in happier surroundings.
After years of searching, the Connecticut Economic Development Department, which is responsible for the 14.5-acre site, has found a development team it considers capable of creating a viable entertainment complex at the dilapidated theater center. 
 An ambitious project that will cover up to an additional 35 acres that are now privately owned was approved on Oct. 6. It will take 10 years to complete and cost about $95 million. Contracts for a low-cost lease between the state and the developers are expected to be signed in January.
The plans for the Stratford Festival Theater and Waterfront Village call for creating a tourist attraction that will eventually include a 64-room inn, a 230-room hotel, a marina, restaurants, shops, a waterfront promenade, an education program and perhaps a second, more intimate, theater.
Dropping its previous opposition to financial participation, the state has agreed in principle to contribute $7.5 million from a $60 million economic development fund for regional projects.
"The theater, which will continue to operate as a nonprofit company, is on the priority list of the 16-town Bridgeport region," said Robert Santy, Deputy Commissioner of the Economic Development Department.
The winning proposal among the three submitted was from Stratford Upon the Housatonic Inc., a partnership of Robert M. DelBuono Jr., a Stratford financial planner and real estate developer; Steven A. Wolff, head of a Fairfield arts consulting concern called AMF Planning and Research Corporation, and Scott Wilson, head of TLCR Architects of Boston, which has experience in theater design and renovation.
Mr. DelBuono and Mr. Wilson unsuccessfully participated in a similar competition last year as Brickhill-Burke Productions Inc. of New York. This year, their new partnership's successful plan was assisted by a group of theater professionals assembled to formulate the proposal and carry out construction and artistic supervision.
Among those professionals is Robert Orchard, director of the American Repertory Theater in Cambridge, Mass., who said: "We will develop projects at Stratford and bring our own Shakespearean and classic productions down from Cambridge for an annual 8-to-10-week season." In addition, American Repertory will bring in productions from abroad.
Also involved in rebuilding and equipping the theater are Jules Fisher Associates, Broadway lighting designers; Jaffe Holden Scarborough, sound engineers, and the Tishman Construction Corporation of New England, a division of Tishman Real Estate in New York.
Michael Price, director of the Goodspeed Opera House in East Haddam, Conn., and Judith Allen, director of the North Carolina Blumenthal Center for the Performing Arts, will continue to provide guidance in creating An American Playhouse, which will produce new and existing plays and musicals for performance at Stratford and on tour.
Founded in 1954 by members of the New York Theatre Guild, the theater, which operated only in summer, was to have been America's answer to England's Stratford-on-Avon and Canada's Shakespeare Theater. It attracted Katharine Hepburn, Helen Hayes, Maurice Evans and many other famous actors.
But by 1983 audiences had dwindled, and the theater closed. That year, the state bought the property, which had been foreclosed, for $1.3 million for use as a public park. An unsuccessful season in 1989 was its last.
RENOVATION of the theater, which is expected to reopen in 1996, and a 477-car parking lot will be the $18 million first phase of the development. This is to be followed by construction of the inn 100 yards away. "We may or may not build the inn ourselves," Mr. Wolff said.
The theater's lobby and restrooms must be expanded, dressing rooms must be added, scenery storage space and a loading dock need to be upgraded and enlarged. There is neither air-conditioning nor adequate heating. The electrical system must be replaced, and elevators will have to be installed.
"The building will be enlarged from 40,000 to 67,000 square feet," Mr. Wilson said, but the seating capacity will be reduced from 1,500 to 1,200 because of the reallocation of space. To achieve what Mr. Wilson called "a classy Connecticut look" rather than the existing pseudo-replication of the Globe Theater, fieldstone will be used on the exterior, complementing the building's millions of board feet of teak.
Before work can begin on an adjacent 5.4-acre parcel earmarked for the hotel and marina, asbestos and lead dumped by the defunct Raymark brake plant must be cleared. Officials at the Connecticut Environmental Protection Department and the Federal Environmental Protection Agency say that Mr. DelBuono, who owns the parcel, may have to undertake the cleanup himself. Under the law, owners of commercial property are responsible for removing contaminants, unless the original offender can be found. In this case, Raymark is in bankruptcy, limiting its liability.
The project, said Mark Barnhart, the City Manager, "will replace jobs lost by the downsizing of Sikorsky and Textron-Lycoming and create new long-term employment. We are very excited by the prospect of a major tourist attraction."
Some modifications in zoning regulations may be required to accommodate the new uses, possibly through a proposed theater district. A tax increment district is also contemplated, whereby a portion of taxes paid by the project's commercial operations would be reinvested in parking, sidewalks and business facade improvements in the theater district.
Construction and long-term financing, Mr. DelBuono said, "are being pursued with institutional and individual investors. Our construction schedule is conservative, with the timing dictated by financing."
Commercial development outside the theater site may not take place until 1999.
"We are delighted to have been chosen," said Mr. Wolff, one of the partners, "now the hard part starts."

GRAPHIC: Drawing: Rendering of renovated Shakespeare Theater in Stratford, part of a 10-year, $95-million development project. (Piatt)

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: The Four Seasons;
A Landmark Upheld

 BODY:
The New York State Court of Appeals ruled last week that the Landmarks Preservation Commission had acted properly in designating the fashionable Four Seasons restaurant a landmark. The 5-to-0 ruling, written by Chief Judge Judith S. Kaye, upheld decisions by the State Supreme Court and the Appellate Division. Those decisions rejected arguments by the restaurant's landlord, the Teachers Insurance and Annuity Association of America, that the designation would cause it economic loss because it would not be able to use the space for any other purpose.
The court also ruled that the commission was within its authority in giving landmark status to the striking interior architecture and furnishings, including the wide staircases, bronze railings, hanging sculptures, walnut bar, marble pool and ceiling panels. 
 The restaurant opened in 1959 in the Seagram Building, 99 East 52d Street. The commission designated both the building and the restaurant as landmarks in October 1989.
Marc P. Cherno, the landlord's lawyer, did not return a phone call. But a jubilant Laurie Beckelman, the commission chairwoman, said she was "especially pleased" with the ruling "as this is the first instance in which the highest court in the state has addressed an interior landmark designation."

HEADLINE: A SENSE OF PLACE

BYLINE: By Jay Romano

DATELINE: WASHINGTON TOWNSHIP

 BODY:
WILLIAM S. HAINES JR. leaned against a green pickup truck and gazed out across an expanse of cranberry bogs that stretched nearly a mile in every direction. The bogs -- a checkerboard of large rectangular fields enclosed by raised dams and flooded with water from nearby reservoirs -- were bordered in the distance by stands of pitch pine, oak and American white cedar.
"This is absolutely the best part of New Jersey," Mr. Haines said, describing Hog Wallow, a section of Washington Township in Burlington County that is considered by some to be the epicenter of the Pinelands. 
 "If you meet somebody from another part of the country and you say you're from New Jersey, they look at you with a kind of pity," said Mr. Haines, a burly, bearded 40-year-old. "But this isn't the New Jersey they're thinking about."
Looking toward the horizon, where the pine trees met a crystal blue sky, he said, "This is the real New Jersey."
The bogs account for about one-tenth of the 11,000-acre farm that Mr. Haines's great-grandfather started in the 1890's. The rest of the acreage is devoted to the shallow reservoirs used to fill the bogs and the pristine forest that insures the purity of the groundwater that courses through the Pinelands.
Mr. Haines, who earned a bachelor's degree in agricultural economics at Cook College of Rutgers University in New Brunswick, said that like his forebears, he plans on being a Pinelands cranberry farmer for the rest of his life.
"We've done this for a hundred years," he said while maneuvering his truck along the intersecting 12-foot-wide tops of the dams separating the water-filled bogs. "It's what we intend to keep on doing."
As a former first vice president of the New Jersey Farm Bureau, Mr. Haines has visited farms all over the state -- from Sussex County in the north to Cape May County in the south. And there is no place he would rather come home to than the family farm in Hog Wallow.
"I like the way it looks," he said. "I even like the way it smells," he added, alluding to the scent of the cranberry harvest.
The core of the Pinelands -- also known as the Pines, the Pine Barrens and the Pine Belt -- is a 650,000-are expanse of sparsely populated forested land that lies roughly within the triangle formed by Camden, Toms River and Atlantic City and contains communities with such unlikely names as Ongs Hat, Hanover Furnace, Friendship and Penny Pot. Traditional estimates place the population density of the area at about 15 residents per square mile.
"That's what I like about it," said Mr. Haines's father, William S. Haines Sr., 72, who still works the farm seven days a week. "It's the only place in New Jersey anymore that you can still be out in a real rural area."
The older Mr. Haines has lived on the farm since he was a newlywed 47 years ago. His wife died three years ago. And though his ZIP code is in Washington Township, his home is Hog Wallow in the Pinelands.
"I've got a place in Florida," he said, watching a team of workers harvest a bog topped with a floating layer of scarlet cranberries. "I never go down there much, though. I like it here."
The Pinelands were first settled by the Dutch in the 1600's. The settlers developed a brisk trade in timber, blueberries, glassmaking, ironmaking, shipbuilding and charcoal making. The area is most renowned, however, for its cranberry industry.
Pinelands cranberry farmers produce 4.45 million pounds of cranberries a year. As a result, New Jersey is now the third largest cranberry-producing state in the nation; only Massachusetts and Wisconsin produce more.
Most of the Pinelands, which covers about 22 percent of the state, is capped by a thick layer of sandy soil common in central and southern New Jersey.
"And underneath that nice sandy soil is one of the largest and purest aquifers in the country," said Terrence Moore, the executive director of the Pinelands Commission, a 15-member state panel that manages development in the Pinelands. The Cohansey aquifer, Mr. Moore said, contains more than 17 trillion gallons of water.
"We also have a number of endangered species," Mr. Moore said, explaining that in addition to "normal critters" like deer, muskrat, rabbits and beavers, the area also harbors corn snakes, timber rattlers, pine snakes and the Pine Barrens tree frog.
Some roads in the barrens cut poker-straight for miles through stands of tall pitch pine and cedar. Others, paved and unpaved, meander aimlessly through dense forest of dwarf pine and thickets of wild blueberry. It is not uncommon to drive for miles at a time and never pass a house, a driveway or even another car.
In 1978, the Federal Government designated the Pinelands a national preserve, creating the 1.1-million-acre Pinelands Preservation Area. The following year, the State Legislature, in response to the Federal act and concerned that encroaching development would irrevocably damage the delicate, pristine environment, passed the Pinelands Protection Act, strictly limiting construction within the preserve.
And while some farmers and property owners are opposed to the strict regulations -- they say that limiting development is a taking of their property without just compensation -- many inhabitants are happy that they won't be finding a shopping mall in the middle of a national preserve.
"They're letting too much building go on in the Pinelands already, I think," said Pearl Thomas of Southampton Township, who has lived in the area for all of her 71 years. "They want street lights; they want this; they want that. The people moving in want everything to be like it was where they came from. Most of them think cranberries grow on trees."
Mrs. Thomas was sitting in the temporary trailer office for this year's Cranberry Festival, an event held last weekend that drew more than 25,000 people.
"Years ago, people minded their own business," Mrs. Thomas said. "You could walk away from your house and come back and find it all there. You could trust your neighbors. Now, we're under lock and key."
Notwithstanding her concern for overcrowding and security, Mrs. Thomas said she could not even imagine living anywhere else.
"I was born and raised here," she said. "I'm not the outsider."
The folklore of the Pinelands paints its early inhabitants in less than flattering terms. In the early 1900's, one governor even suggested that its residents be segregated from the rest of the state because they led "lawless and scandalous lives."
The people of the Pines today, though, are generally well-educated, law-abiding, hard-working citizens. They love their land, cherish their privacy and seem to possess a contentment with their way of life that is rare in modern times and modern places.
Even some who do leave for what appear to be greener pastures eventually return.
"When you go out and see what everyplace else is like, it gives you perspective to see what you already have," said Mary Ann Thompson, chairwoman of this year's Cranberry Festival.
Ms. Thompson, a lawyer who worked for the United Nations and who has taught at the Rutgers Law School in Newark, has lived in New York, Atlanta and Washington, and has traveled extensively abroad. She returned to her home in Vincentown, a village with a total of eight streets, in the late 1970's.
"Now, whenever I talk to someone in the 201 area code, they think we're hicks," Ms. Thompson said.
But isn't a community with eight streets a bit quiet for a person with such cosmopolitan credentials?
"If it's too quiet, I can always go someplace where it's noisy," Ms. Thompson said. "That's one great thing about New Jersey. We're next to everyplace else that's noisy."

HEADLINE: At Work;
Will These Contract Talks Fly?

BYLINE: By Barbara Presley Noble

 BODY:
OBJECTIVE reality is the uninvited guest to virtually any labor-management negotiation, but rarely more so than in the current lengthy dispute between American Airlines and one of its unions, the 21,000-member Association of Professional Flight Attendants. Perhaps Srinivasa Ramanujan, the late Indian mathematical genius, could untangle the airline industry's wizardly compensation formulas and arrive at a kernel of pure truth.
Mere mortals wait in vain for any fact, factoid or fact-ette to stand up and bark. Are flight attendants still getting the shaft a decade after they made concessions, including allowing the company to impose its two-tier wage system, to save their jobs and, supposedly, the airline? Or is American a benevolent employer, simply seeking flexibility to allow it to compete in what every American man, woman, child and kitty cat by now agrees is a killer industry? 
 One thing is clear: those divergent views must soon converge. The flight attendants' contract with American Airlines became amendable last December. The airlines are governed by the National Railway Labor Act of 1926 and its agent, the National Mediation Board. The board's mandate is to keep any parties in a transportation industry dispute at the bargaining table until they resolve their differences, in effect extending contract deadlines, or they hit a wall.
Late last month, the board declared American and the attendants' union at an impasse. The dispute entered a 30-day "cooling off' period, during which the parties are supposed to go to their corners and come to their senses. The sides more typically continue making offers quietly while lobbying for advantage. Tomorrow everyone returns to the table in Washington to try to reach an agreement before the cooling off period ends on Friday. Meanwhile, the union has thrown up information picket lines at airports in 15 cities and has called a strike for "on or before Nov. 22," just as the Thanksgiving transmigrations begin. The company has canceled November vacations and issued a pamphlet to the attendants, entitled "What Happens to Me If the A.P.F.A. Calls a Strike?" Permanent replacement is not threatened for those who join the strike, but neither is it excluded.
The problem is how to judge the competing claims: Flight attendants have suffered a 40 percent decline in real wages since making heavy concessions in 1983, says the union. No, real wages have risen by 32 percent, says a spokesman for the AMR Corporation, American's Dallas-based parent. The carrier can afford to loosen its grip on the budget strings, the union says. "American Airlines isn't going broke," A.P.F.A. president Denise Hedges told a news conference in Dallas on Wednesday, shortly after AMR reported third-quarter earnings of $118 million, compared with a $100 million loss in the same quarter last year. "Insufficient but a step in the right direction," grumped Robert L. Crandall, AMR chairman. Changes in benefits would in effect reduce wages, says the union. Changes in benefits bring attendants into line with other work groups, says the company. And on and on.
American contends it is not asking from the flight attendants anything not already in place at other airlines -- for changes, in other words, it views as necessary to improve its competitive position. "We are the only major airline offering wage-scale increases," said Al Comeaux, a company spokesman. "We are not asking for any work-rule efficiencies that other airlines don't have."
The jackrabbit of the airlines race now is Southwest Airlines, also of Dallas, one of the few success stories in an industry that hit a sinkhole in the late 80's and has only just started to climb out. "Our costs for aircraft and gates are the same as Southwest," Mr. Comeaux said. "The one cost that's more controllable, more variable, is labor."
The union points out that Southwest runs a different and cheaper show, a system based on short hops with quick turnarounds and limited in-flight service. It especially galls the attendants that American is rated first in service but sixth in salary. The domestic pay scale now ranges from $14,988 for an entry-level attendant to $32,745 for someone at "max out," or step 14 -- 14 or more years of service. Under the company proposal, the maximum would rise to $36,430 in four years. The union wants "industry leading" wages, which could range anywhere from a tenth to a third higher than the current scale. The median salary is now $23,000, the average $25,000. Attendants, the union is quick to point out, are not Barbie dolls looking for adventure, who can sacrifice salary for travel privileges, but women and men trying to make a living and a career out of flying. "I was hoping this year to gross $20,000," said Diana Dunn, a union strike administrator who is entering her sixth year at American.
PERHAPS even more important than salary, however, is the gap between the union and the company on staffing planes, now a contractual issue the company would like to control. For example, the Federal Aviation Administration requires a minimum of three attendants on 727 flights. The union contract requires four. "On a late-night flight, with no meal, we still have to have four," AMR's Mr. Comeaux said.
The attendants are worried that if the airline begins tinkering with the schedules they now bid for on the basis of seniority -- and can count on roughly a month in advance -- eventually they will be reduced in effect to reserve status. They envision sitting by the phone, waiting for the company to call -- an efficiency for the airline, but a nightmare for anyone who wants a life. "The quality of work life changes dramatically," said Robert Clayman, the union's chief counsel. "It's equivalent to a speedup on an assembly line."
There is also resentment that the company wants to curtail the juggling schedules to extend vacation time, which for about two-thirds of attendants doesn't exceed 14 days until for their 11th year. The company says, indeed, it once encouraged its workforce to do that, but can no longer afford it.
Airline negotiations frequently reach the very edge of the precipice before the parties make a deal. The union appears to be more unified and better prepared than it was in 1987, when the last contract was forged, and the stagnant wider economy hasn't improved anyone's mood. But the betting is that both sides have too much at stake to jump.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
For Clinton, A Place on the Bottom Line

BYLINE: By Steven Greenhouse

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
AS a self-proclaimed New Democrat, President Clinton has tried to show that he has a warmer heart toward business than the Democrats of old. Notwithstanding corporate America's traditional skepticism toward Democrats, executives have been willing to give Mr. Clinton a hearing, but the bottom line is what his policies will mean for their companies' bottom line. On that, the jury is still out.
With an eye to helping business, Mr. Clinton has vowed to speed up growth, remove trade barriers and cut corporate health care costs. He has also pushed through a deficit-reduction plan, which his aides assert has gone far to push down long-term interest rates. All this, the Administration vows, will fatten profits. 
 But corporate America wishes it could be half as confident. Where Mr. Clinton boasts of deficit reduction, many executives see an increase in the corporate income tax rate to 35 percent, from 34. Where Mr. Clinton promises lower corporate medical bills, many companies are seeing red about requirements that they buy health insurance for all employees.
"Many of the Administration's economic policies either already have increased or will most likely increase the cost of doing business," said Edward Yardeni, chief economist at C. J. Lawrence.
To be sure, some companies will see fatter bottom lines as a result of Mr. Clinton's policies, while others will see leaner ones. But if businesses as a group can rejoice about anything that has happened on Mr. Clinton's watch, it is the plunge in long-term interest rates (although the Federal Reserve certainly shares the credit). Not only has this reduced the cost of borrowing, but by helping push up stock prices, lower rates have encouraged many companies to issue stock to replace their debt.
"In these ways, lower rates are reducing the cost of doing business," said Robert G. Dederick, chief economist for the Northern Trust Company in Chicago. By some estimates, lower rates could increase profits -- which stood at $282 billion at an annualized rate in the second quarter -- by $15 billion to $20 billion a year. Mr. Dederick forecasts an increase of 11 percent this year and 12 percent next year, compared with 7 percent in 1992.
Arguably the biggest effect Mr. Clinton will have on profits will turn on the effect he has on overall growth. If the tax increases that take effect next year crimp consumer and business spending, the economy could droop again, and profits along with it. But if low interest rates produce an unexpected surge in spending and investment, the economy and corporate profits could make a surprising bound upward.
What will all this mean for stocks? Perhaps, not very much.
One view, from Laurence H. Meyer, who runs a St. Louis consulting firm, is that so long as long-term rates stay low, the stock market won't sag, despite concerns that it is overpriced. And unless growth zooms unexpectedly above 3 percent, don't expect much of a rally either.

HEADLINE: Business Diary: October 17 - 22

BYLINE: By Hubert B. Herring

 BODY:

COMPANIES
 
Ever Get Burned by a Fast-Talking Broker? Now, Some Justice
Who says the small investor can't get justice? Who says you're out of luck when your broker assures you something's safe and you lose your shirt? Last week the little guy scored big when Prudential Securities agreed to pay $371 million to settle charges that it defrauded 400,000 investors. Part of that is fines, but the bulk of it -- $330 million -- will go to investors who can prove they got false promises or were otherwise cheated. (If, eyes wide open, you took a flier on a high-risk limited partnership and lost, forget it.) In 1989, Drexel agreed to shell out $650 million, but that was big-game stuff involving institutional investors; this is the largest settlement ever involving the mistreatment of, say, retirees who see modest nest eggs hacked away by fast-talking brokers. And it may get even bigger: Prudential, which made $1 billion on limited partnerships, must pay all claims -- no limits, no statutes of limitations. 

QVC Knocks Louder on the Door
It's called a tender offer, but tender it's not. It means the gloves are off. Last week QVC, ignored by Paramount's board even after coming courting with $9.5 billion in roses, got more aggressive by making an $80-a-share tender offer to stockholders for 51 percent of the company. The rest would be QVC stock. The total offer remains at $9.5 billion, but that's a lot more cash than anyone's mentioned yet. So where does that leave Viacom, the rival suitor? For now, with $7.5 billion in wilted roses in its hand.
 
A Shrinking Drug Industry
The drug industry's headache is getting worse. Big health care groups are flexing their buying muscle, and the Clinton plan includes sanctions to punish drug makers for high prices. A result: Drug makers have been shedding workers right and left. Last week Upjohn, Pfizer and American Cyanamid announced plans to cut a total of 7,000 workers. New York and New Jersey will surely feel the pain, because that's where a lot of the jobs are. Upjohn had the added problem that patents on two of its drugs -- the anxiety treatment Xanax and the insomnia remedy Halcion -- expired last week. But that's small consolation for the about-to-be-jobless who find themselves anxious and sleepless.
 
Mr. Sculley Knows Best?
Maybe John Sculley knows something we don't. After heading Apple Computer for a decade, he's got one of the heftier high-tech resumes. So you'd think that when he picked up the help-wanted ads after leaving Apple, he wouldn't head for a little company facing a spate of lawsuits alleging stock manipulation. But that's what he did last week, signing on as chairman and chief executive of Spectrum Information Technologies, which controls patents linked to wireless transmission of computer data. Spectrum's shares soared in May after a deal with A.T.& T., but then quickly drooped. But maybe Mr. Sculley does know something. Investors clearly think so. The magic of his name suddenly made Spectrum nearly a quarter of a billion dollars more valuable.
 
Citicorp on the Mend
Citicorp was in bad trouble several years ago, and one big culprit was commercial real estate loans. But it's been chipping away at that problem, and last week it said quarterly income had more than tripled, to $528 million. Citicorp stock didn't react much, but of course the shares have already more than tripled in two years.
 
Stew Leonard Gets His Bill
Stew Leonard has always done things big. His Connecticut stores rewrote all the rules, selling vast quantities of dairy goods and produce basically by putting on a continuous circus. So it's not surprising that when he turned his agile mind to something less wholesome, he'd dream up what's been called the country's largest computer-driven tax-evasion scheme. He doctored revenues, and the spare cash -- tens of thousands of dollars at a clip, $17 million or so in all -- would be put in suitcases and whisked off to St. Martin. Last week he paid the price, as a judge sentenced him to more than four years in prison and fined him $947,000. At the store, the show goes on.
 
A Whopper, Hold the Ads
This is what the fast-food customer is really saying: "A double order of your ads, please, and a burger and fries on the side." In the huge American fast-food derby, image is the main dish, so it's no wonder the big chains rack their brains for the right advertising. Some get it right, some just can't seem to. Which brings us, of course, to Burger King. Remember the "Herb the Nerd" ads? O.K., you'd rather not. Remember "We Do It Like You'd Do It"? Grammar aside, just try saying that three times quickly. So again last week, the chain's share of that golden market slipping, the frantically revolving door of Burger King ad agencies turned again. The company started hunting for a new agency for the bulk of its domestic advertising, lately handled by D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles. Brace yourself for the next inspiration.
 
INTERNATIONAL
 
Nameless Cash? Lloyd's Accepts
It was so very British. To really be able to put your nose in the air, you had to take part in the odd ritual of putting your fortune, down to your kitchen chairs, behind Lloyd's of London. Upper-crust investors, quaintly called "names," had no limit on what they could lose -- a high-risk game seen as jolly good fun. Because of course one didn't lose with Lloyd's, one just kept making a respectable income. Until recently. A few years ago, amid billions in losses, the whole jolly game came crashing down, and a lot of "names" saw the fortunes of generations wiped out. So last week Lloyd's dumped a three-century tradition and allowed institutional and corporate investment.
 
An Auto Show for a New Japan
Japan's auto industry has come of age, and it's not happy about it. For in this industry, coming of age means you don't keep growing year after year. As Detroit well knows, it means mixing good years with bad. Japan's sobered car makers had a coming-out party of sorts last week, a Tokyo Motor Show more subdued than usual. There was talk of fuel conservation, safety and "ecolution" (a mix of ecology and evolution). "But they are not talking about the market," one analyst said. "It's almost like they want to hide the problems." But then again, their problems pale next to those faced by Detroit a few years ago.
 
Economics Saves Chernobyl
It's apparently one more price to be paid for the Soviet breakup. Almost everyone wants the Chernobyl nuclear plant closed: American experts cite numerous safety flaws, and Ukraine's 1991 decision to scrap it this year was applauded by the plant's neighbors. But Ukraine has budget deficits and needs energy badly -- nuclear power accounts for 35 percent of its electricity -- and it owes Russia $2.5 billion for oil and gas. So last week the Ukrainian Parliament changed its mind, voting to keep it open. That leaves the rest of the world, remembering the 1986 disaster, with an awful lot of crossed fingers.
 
Cheering Germany's Rate Cut
Germany cut its key interest rates again, and all of Europe celebrated. Stock markets in London, Frankfurt and Paris hit all-time highs on Friday, as investors bet that the rate cuts would give a much-needed lift to Germany's economy -- and thus Europe's.
 
ECONOMY
 
A U.S. Blessing on Recycling
This nation is rapidly becoming committed to recycling, but the flip side of the equation doesn't work yet. Americans are dutifully putting so much paper in their recycling bins that it's piling up in warehouses. That's because the market for used paper is so weak. So in a move to hasten the completion of this cycle, President Clinton put pen to (recycled?) paper last week, issuing an executive order requiring Federal agencies to buy paper made from at least 20 percent recycled fiber by the end of next year, and 30 percent in five years. The Government buys less than 2 percent of the country's paper, but Mr. Clinton wants to send a message to states and cities. The paper industry was skeptical, voicing concern that paper-mill operations would be disrupted, but environmentalists called it a victory, with one saying the order would save more than a million trees. We could, of course, just use less paper (this page excluded, naturally).
 
Pecking at the Health Plan
President Clinton knew his health plan would have enemies, but he was also counting on a few friends, like the National Association of Manufacturers. This group mainly represents companies that provide health coverage, and would benefit in not having to compete against lower-cost rivals that do not. The plan, though, "is too ambitious, and must be dramatically scaled back," said Jerry J. Jasinowski, the group's president. But Mr. Clinton is not going to settle for bits and pieces on this one; he wants to fix the health mess, now.
 
Collider Collides With Congress
Not many people understand the Superconducting Supercollider. Is it tomorrow's science or yesterday's sinkhole? Physicists talk of crashing protons at nearly the speed of light. But Congress saw a 10-mile hole under the Texas plains, a hole that's already cost $2 billion. The total cost is now put at $11 billion, more than twice original estimates. Last week, after much hemming and hawing, it pulled the plug. "A sad day for science," one backer said. But the day was won by those who said there just wasn't enough money.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Lloyd's building in London. (Jonathan Player for The New York Times); Toyota's new Celica.

LENGTH: 1521 words

HEADLINE: Feeling the Bumps in the Road At the Tokyo Auto Show

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
IN 1985, visitors to the auto show here were treated to a preview of Honda's new Accord, a car that crossed the Pacific and outsold all American models for three years running. The 1989 show marked the first sighting of Lexus, the Toyota luxury sedan that displaced Cadillacs, Mercedeses and Jaguars from garages of the wealthy.
The once-obscure Tokyo Motor Show, held every other year, had suddenly become a gallery for the dynamic imagination of Japan's auto industry, whose creations provoked nightmares from Detroit to Turin. 
 But a visitor to this year's show, which opened to the public yesterday, could see how that nightmare has become less frightening from an American point of view. With Japanese sales slumping at home and abroad -- a result of the country's recession, a soaring yen and Western retaliation in the form of savvier car design and improved quality -- this year's exhibits are heavy on future technology but light on dramatic new models likely to be sold soon in the United States. Japanese auto makers, to save money, are introducing new models more slowly than during the salad days of the late 1980's.
Still, a close examination of the exhibits suggests that the car companies already are gearing for better days. They evidently are sure that consumers will buy -- and governments will mandate -- cars that pollute less, consume less energy, are easier to recycle and minimize safety hazards. And despite the strong yen, the Japanese are finding ways to cut costs so new technologies will be affordable. For example, Toyota's just-released annual report, which is handed out at the company's exhibit, brags that engineers are saving money by the once-unthinkable practice of using some parts from last year in next year's models.
Specifically, the report mentions mirrors that can be used on a number of models, thereby saving the development cost incurred each time a new one is designed.
The money Toyota saves on new mirrors and the like can be spent toward further development of the EV-50, an experimental electric passenger car on view at the show here. Under California law, by 1998, 2 percent of sales in that state by the biggest-selling auto makers, including Toyota, Honda and Nissan, must be of vehicles that are virtually emission-free.
"The EV-50 is the most important car here, though the company isn't happy about selling electric cars because our engineers say they don't work very well," said James Olson, senior vice president of Toyota's United States sales subsidiary. Powered by lead acid batteries, the four-seater can reach a top speed of just 72 miles per hour, and it has a range of about 155 miles before recharging, which can take several hours.
(Toyota kept one crucial new car, called Avalon, under wraps in a studio. The auto maker earlier this month announced it will build the six-seat sedan, which replaces the Cressida, in its Georgetown, Ky., plant in 1995. The car will sell in the United States for about $30,000. "Boring," was the description of one Toyota executive of Avalon's looks. "But I'm too young to be a typical buyer.")
The Mitsubishi Motors Corporation has addressed the electric vehicle's problem of limited range and power with ESR, a prototype of a "hybrid" car that is powered by batteries but also has a small, efficient, low-polluting gasoline engine. The car runs on its batteries alone or in conjunction with its engine, which doesn't directly power the car but instead is used to charge the batteries.
With the engine giving a boost to the batteries, the ESR claims a range of more than 620 miles and a top speed of 125 m.p.h. -- superior performance among prototypes developed to comply with California law. The ESR, Mitsubishi believes, could meet California's strict emissions requirement, but for now the company does't plan to use the car's hybrid technology. Instead, it is considering a number of other options, including a different electric car on which it is working.
For the here and now, Mitsubishi displayed a retracting hardtop version of its 3000 GT sports car to be sold within a year in the United States, built in Long Beach, Calif., jointly with the ASC Corporation of Southgate, Mich. With the touch of a button, the metal and glass roof deployed and retracted smoothly into the trunk -- while gawking viewers snapped pictures furiously.
The Mazda Motor Corporation alone has staked its bet on hydrogen, rather than electricity, as the nonpolluting energy source that can satisfy environmental concerns. Mazda's HR-X2 prototype claims significantly better range, almost 150 miles, than an earlier hydrogen prototype shown two years ago. One reason the range is still modest is the weight and bulkiness of the equipment needed to safely carry hydrogen, which has an explosive nature. But in terms of speed and acceleration, the HR-X2 performs much like a normal car.
Unlike almost every other combustible fuel, hydrogen does not produce carbon dioxide, which is blamed for contributing to the greenhouse effect and global warming. Burning hydrogen yields water. How an infrastructure would be built to produce and distribute large amounts of hydrogen for drivers remains a mystery, but Japan's Ministry of International Trade and Industry plans to study the possibilities.
THE HR-X2's body is made of liquid-crystal polymer, a light and easily recyclable material. Mazda thinks the polymer is sturdy enough to pass crash tests. Moreover, the body swiftly detaches from the HR-X2's metal suspension so its components can be sorted upon retiring the vehicle from operation and disassembling it. European countries, Japan and some states are considering tough regulations that eventually may make crushing or shredding entire cars prohibitively expensive.
Responding to what it hopes will be more immediate market forces, Mazda unveiled a chic-looking, conventionally powered luxury sedan called the Eunos 800, which soon will appear in American showrooms as the Mazda Millenia. The Eunos 800, meant to compete with Acura, Lexus and Infiniti, is a remnant of Mazda's ill-fated Amati line of luxury cars. Amati was to have been a separate franchise, but it fell to the ax in 1992 due to the high yen and sagging sales of Japanese luxury models.
THE Honda Motor Company showed its EVX electric car, a version of which it is nearly ready to produce. The headlights are designed to use just a tiny amount of power, and solar cells mounted on the vehicle's roof can recharge the batteries a bit when the sun is out.
But Nobuhiko Kawamoto, Honda's president, voiced skepticism similar to that expressed by other auto executives. "I don't think it will pay as a business," he told reporters. In other words, he said, Honda and others must be ready to bear the expense of electric vehicles if they want to stay in business in California.
Honda's FSR (for "future safety research") prototype embodies features that Honda engineers believe may appear in cars around the turn of the century. Headlamps that move and cameras on the nose improve visibility on blind curves and at intersections. Reflective paint on the body makes the car more visible at night, particularly from the side. In Japan the single biggest category of traffic fatalities involves pedestrians, so the research is especially relevant here.
Subaru, the brand name used by Fuji Heavy Industries, brought a few perky prototypes to the auto show, but the only car that mattered greatly was an actual model for sale, the new Legacy. The car resembled most other Japanese sedans of its size, except for a distinctive scooped-out portion onits hood.
Fuji lost more than six billion yen in the fiscal year ended March 31; that's $50 million at the rate of exchange then in effect. Without improved United States sales from its new Legacy, most analysts say, Subaru has little chance of hanging on as an independent auto maker in the crowded North American market. In the Japanese tradition, Subaru may well be forced into an arranged marriage with a larger, less financially strapped Japanese car maker.
The problem is that many Japanese car makers are now financially strapped, while many Western auto makers are on the comeback trial.
That shift in fortunes has had an impact on the status of the auto show itself. Executives from the West used to arrive here, filled with anticipation and dread, to discover what new bombshells would explode in their faces. But now, "the focus point again is Detroit," said Koichi Amemiya, president of Honda sales in North America.
Indeed, these days Japanese executives are traveling to shows in the United States and Europe with just as much anticipation and dread as their American counterparts felt upon arrival here not long ago.
The most talked-about car to debut in a show this year was not a Honda or a Toyota. It was Chrysler's Neon subcompact, which grabbed the spotlight last month -- in Frankfurt. The Neon, which is designed to compete directly with small Japanese cars, isn't even on view here this week, because Chrysler at the moment has no plans to sell it in this country.

(The New York Times); The Honda FRS is loaded with high-tech safety features. (Shizuo Kambayashi for The New York Times)
