LENGTH: 1582 words

HEADLINE: Profile: Kenneth Stone;
His Message for Mom & Pop: There's Life After Wal-Mart

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER

DATELINE: MERRILLVILLE, Ind.

 BODY:
IN the late 1980's, after spending more than a decade helping Iowa towns and businesses cope with change, a rising tide of phone calls and speaking invitations alerted Dr. Kenneth Stone that he might have the best data in the nation on what happens when Wal-Mart and other mass merchants move into a community.
Since then, the mild-mannered 57-year-old Iowa State University economist has diligently accumulated something even more precious: insights into how local retailers can survive -- even thrive -- when Wal-Mart and its competitors, like Kmart, the nation's No. 2 retail chain, roar into town. 
 Now, as mass merchants expand across the landscape, Mr. Stone is being run ragged. Although admits that he lacks stage presence and a gift for gab, audiences, like the lawn and garden shop owners who recently came here to northwest Indiana to hear him, can't get enough of him. "What's fascinating about all this is that a lot of people say they have come back to hear me two or three times, even though I think I am a boring speaker," Mr. Stone said.
That demand certainly won't taper off as long as he does so little to capitalize on his sudden renown. The ride from obscurity to guru status has made Mr. Stone richer than he ever imagined, but not nearly as wealthy as he could be. By hanging on to his job as a state extension economist, Mr. Stone is committed to working free within Iowa. And when he uses his free time for outside consulting, he sticks to a standard fee of $1,000 plus expenses, a fee that is laughably modest on the business consulting circuit. Although Mr. Stone said he plans to experiment with variable fees, he is determined to stay available to small communities and groups for whom even $1,000 is "a stretch."
Typically, Mr. Stone starts his talks with a broad perspective. Here, he told the garden shop owners they were seeing the "over-storing of America," citing not just such mass merchants as Wal-Mart, but shopping clubs and "category killer" chains like Toys 'R' Us. "The reason I pick on Wal-Mart is that they are leading the way," he said.
In truth, Mr. Stone does not so much pick on Wal-Mart and its rivals as pick over their strategies and use them as lessons. Some advice comes in the form of admonishments to learn what works, like staying open on Sunday. Some advice centers on how to cooperate with mass merchants, like signing agreements to service equipment they sell. And some comes down to blunt warnings, like don't try to undercut their price on items like disposable diapers or toothpaste unless you are located far enough away that they are not routinely checking your prices.
One key to Mr. Stone's appeal is that he persuades audiences that he has thought about their individual concerns. Here, for example, instead of simply saying it is important to carry product lines that Wal-Mart overlooks, he mentioned bonsai trees and other specifics. And he talked about Kmart, which has been emphasizing lawn and garden products.
Mr. Stone has delivered similar pep talks to tire and carpet makers, newspaper distributors, hardware shops, eyeglass retailers and grocers. He has done it in Iowa towns so small they barely appear on maps, and in cities as large as Oakland, Calif. He has traveled to every state except Delaware in the last five years.
In recent months, with Wal-Mart, based in Bentonville, Ark., headed toward the New York City region, Mr. Stone has spoken to New York-area grocers at the Tavern on the Green restaurant in Central Park, to rural retailers and community leaders from New York, New Jersey, and Pennsylvania at a meeting in Middletown, N.Y., and on Long Island.
The eldest of seven children who grew up in St. Marie, an agricultural hamlet in southeastern Illinois, Mr. Stone recalls suffering "unbearable shyness" when he began speaking publicly. He seems to have as many anecdotes as Wal-Mart does products but, faced with an audience, he tells them sparsely, building toward conclusions rather than punchlines. In a story used to underscore the value of good labeling, he simply said he had never realized Wal-Mart catered to elderly shoppers by making price labels large enough to read without bifocals until he absentmindedly left his glasses in the car on a recent visit to an outlet in Iowa.
Mr. Stone may not entertain audiences, but his data often surprise them. Wal-Mart and the other discounters, for instance, attract more high-income customers than is commonly believed. They have begun to offer better service too, using such tactics as hiring horticulturalists for their lawn and garden sections.
While discounters are zealous about setting bargain prices on several hundred items, there are tens of thousands more whose prices are similar to -- or higher than -- those of smaller retailers. And although everyone realizes the mass merchants are growing, the magnitude of this still stuns many people when Mr. Stone lays it out for them.
THE centerpiece, of course, is Wal-Mart, which grew from $1.2 billion in sales in 1980 to $55.5 billion in 1992. "This company has a good chance of becoming the biggest business in the United States," Mr. Stone said.
Still, the secret of Mr. Stone's success is that his data give him the ring of authority. That aura is reinforced by his bearing, which includes traces of a military career that took him on two tours of duty in Vietnam. And his talk reflects the years he worked as an engineer in the military industry before seeking a Ph. D. in agricultural economics at the University of Illinois.
"He reaffirmed a lot of things we knew we needed to know," said Steve Tholen, whose family owns the Tholen's Landscape and Garden Center stores in Kankakee and Boubonnais, Ill. With 35 employees and just $1.7 million in revenues, Tholen's now finds itself within a few miles of a Wal-Mart, a new Super Kmart, Venture, Target, three big home-improvement chain stores and three lumber yards, all of which are aiming at parts of Tholen's business.
Mr. Tholen and his wife, Nancy, said Mr. Stone persuaded them that they had to spend more time checking competitors' prices and more time and money training employees to offer customers expert advice.
Dr. Stone's favorite testimonial came from a hardware shop owner who came up to him after a meeting in Denver and said an earlier talk by Mr. Stone had saved his business. The shop owner had been planning to quit when a Wal-Mart opened nearby but, after hearing Mr. Stone, he sought and won a contract to service power equipment sold by the discount giant. He ended up with higher total sales, Mr. Stone said.
Mr. Stone has mixed feelings about the thank-you message that Emily Teller of Westford, Mass., left on his answering machine last month. She thanked him for the contacts he provided and the role his research had played in helping her and other community activists block an attempt by Wal-Mart to open in their town.
That research is not entirely unfavorable to Wal-Mart. It shows that the original wave of expansion actually broadened the shopping region of many towns, helping to bring new customers to local merchants. For some stores, the added customers offset business lost to Wal-Mart. Increasingly, though, the chains are making sure fewer people must travel long distances to get to them, leaving local retailers to fight it out with the discounters.
Mr. Stone is delighted if such data help persuade communities not to grant discounters tax abatements, but he does not want his work to be used to impose artificial restraints on the mass merchants' growth. Indeed, Mr. Stone said he has no qualms about sharing retail trade data with chains seeking good locations in Iowa. And he has no sympathy for local merchants who are unwilling to work harder and smarter when competition picks up.
Wal-Mart is among those impressed by such evenhandedness. "As near as I can tell, Dr. Stone tells people facts about Wal-Mart, about retailing and about their business, and lets the chips fall where they may," said Donald Shinkle, Wal-Mart's chief spokesman.
MR. STONE did not see anything momentous brewing in 1988, when he published research on the impact of Wal-Mart's arrival on some small Iowa communities. He had been beavering away at the obscure task of studying the economic decline of rural communities since getting his Ph. D. in 1976.
By taking advantage of Iowa's sales tax reporting system, which churns out data from the state's 856 towns and cities by retail category, Mr. Stone built a unique data base to study Wal-Mart's impact, and mass retailing trends in general. Once word of his studies got around, journalists, retailers and economic development officials around the nation began calling Mr. Stone.
"It's been quite a run," he said. He credits the consulting income with putting two sons through college and helping him and his wife, Janis, an Iowa State researcher, put away more retirement savings. But they have not moved from the house they have lived in for 16 years. Until recently, Mr. Stone had always felt that demand for his insights was about to peak. Now he expects to have more business than he can handle.
Why not hire an associate, as have many successful consultants? Mr. Stone says it would be appealing to have more time for research, but he has already turned down several offers from retail executives and others to work with him. "I have too difficult a time coordinating myself to take anyone else on," he said.

Jedd Wolchok and Karen Popkin

 BODY:
Karen Elizabeth Popkin, the daughter of Sam and Marilyn Popkin of Toledo, Ohio, was married last evening to Dr. Jedd David Wolchok, a son of Harold and Elaine Wolchok of Grymes Hill, S.I. Rabbi David Katz performed the ceremony at the Princeton University Chapel in Princeton, N.J.
Ms. Popkin, 27, is keeping her name. She is a medical secretary at New York University, where she is also a master's degree candidate in music therapy. She graduated summa cum laude from Ohio University. Her father, now retired, was an inspector at AMC/Renault in Toledo. Her mother is a tax preparer in Toledo for H.& R. Block Inc. 
 Dr. Wolchok, 28, received a Ph.D. in microbiology from N.Y.U., where he is also pursuing an M.D. He graduated from Princeton.
His mother teaches the second grade at Public School 170 in Brooklyn. His father, a professor emeritus of economics and labor relations at New York City Technical College, is the executive assistant to the president of Local 144 of the Hotels, Hospitals, Nursing Homes and Allied Services Union in New York.

HEADLINE: ABOUT CARS;
Volkswagen Introduces A New Golf And Jetta

BYLINE: By Marshall Schuon

 BODY:
THE first new import to live in our driveway was a Volkswagen Rabbit, a tomato-red '77 model that we loved dearly. Actually, the car belonged to my wife, and it was the first new car that she had bought on her own.
The interior was black, and it packed an incredible amount of room into a small, square package. We took the car camping, and we used it for all the usual family trucking. It was thrifty and it was terrific. 
 Those were the days, of course, when VW was synonymous with success, coming off its long run with the Beetle. They were the days before the company somehow gave away its seemingly invincible role as America's favorite overseas visitor.
I have always thought that a big part of VW's problem was the success itself -- its dealers here simply became too fat, too arrogant. In any case, it is a long, sad tale, and the only reason for bringing it up now is that another "Rabbit" has come for a brief stay.
The name long ago changed to Golf, which was what Rabbits had always been called in Germany, and the new vehicle is a Golf III GL. It is a pretty metallic turquoise, and it is one of the very few 1993 models that Volkswagen has managed to get into the country this year.
Introductions of the four-door Golf III hatchback and its semi-twin, the Jetta III sedan, were delayed for almost a year because of labor troubles and production problems in Puebla, Mexico, where the cars are built. Dealers have had few to sell, and as of September sales had plunged 44.7 percent from 1992.
The company's share of the market has also shrunk to an almost invisible 0.32 percent, and the dealers have been kept in business through company subsidies. Now, though, the '94 cars are coming, and a steady flow is expected. The new compacts are basically the same as the '93 tester -- but with the important additions of standard dual air bags and optional antilock brakes.
Prices will rise $600 because of the air-bag installation, and that means a base sticker for the Golf of $12,500. The Jetta, which has the same interior but adds some standard niceties, will start at $13,725. Air-conditioning, updated with an environmentally friendly refrigerant, is an $850 option, and a new four-speed automatic transmission is optional at $875.
No price has been announced for the antilock brakes, which will come early next year, along with a two-door version of the Golf and a hot Jetta sport sedan offering a 172-horsepower V6 and traction control.
For the moment, though, all Golfs and Jettas use a 2-liter four that sends 115 horses to the front wheels through a standard five-speed stick. Economy is about 24 miles per gallon, city, and 31, highway, and the 14.5-gallon tank means a trip-range of 450 miles between fill-ups.
The new Golf still looks a bit like that long-lost red Rabbit, but it is far rounder -- and smoother and more rigid than the previous Golf as well. It has a body-colored grille, teardrop headlamps and a wider stance. Bumpers, too, are the same hue as the body, and there is a low liftover at the rear, making it easy to load cargo.
And cargo, human and otherwise, is what the little Volkswagen has always been about. The hatch rises on twin gas struts to reveal a "trunk" that will swallow 17 cubic feet of whatnot. That is 3.6 cubic feet bigger than the trunk of a Lexus LS 400 and 3.7 cubic feet more than you get in a Honda Civic hatchback.
Further, the rear bench folds flat, generating a gigantic 41 cubic feet of space. With the seat in place (and, incidentally, it is backed with sheetmetal to protect against objects flying forward in a crash), the new Golf carries four in comfort.
Headroom is good, front and rear, even allowing for the space taken up by the tester's optional $575 flip-or-slide sunroof. The interior is done in vinyl and cloth, and the front buckets offer good support, with long lower cushions and fully reclining backs.
The restyled dash is gently rounded and softer than in the past. Controls are easy to use, and there are dual cupholders at the front of the center console, with a single cupholder folding out of the rear.
Gauges include dials for fuel and temperature, with a large tachometer and an amusingly optimistic 140-m.p.h. speedometer. Performance, though, is all that can be asked, given the car's weight, which is 2,500 to 2,700 pounds, depending on the model and equipment.
On the road, the Golf is solid, even a bit stiff in the Teutonic tradition, but it is quiet and comfortable, with good acceleration and handling that has been enhanced by the wider stance.
For the driver, it is fun -- and it is odd as well. For instance, it might be expected that an economy car would have only rollup knobs for the windows. And the lack of power adjustment for the seats and the sideview mirrors is no surprise.
But then both Golf and Jetta have a central locking system that even buttons up the fuel-filler flap. And there is also a luxurious tinkling chime to warn if you open a door and forget to take your keys.
There is some confusion here about where Spartan ends and upscale begins. As I recall, however, Volkswagens were always a bit quirky. Maybe the company really is on the way back.

HEADLINE: GARDENING;
From Tulipmania to a Glory of Spring

BYLINE: By JOAN LEE FAUST

 BODY:
THERE is still time to plant hardy spring-flowering bulbs. But the opportunity is fast dwindling since the bulbs must grow roots before the ground freezes. It is these roots that absorb the soil's moisture, which in turn pushes up the leaves and the stems that support the flowers.
Tulips will probably take top priority this year, in celebration of their 400th anniversary. To mark the event, the Netherlands begins a yearlong tulip quadricentennial. The country, the center of an industry that propagates more than 3,500 tulip hybrids and species that are planted in gardens all over the world, has long been noted for its beautiful tulips and its vast bulb-growing fields are indeed a sight to be seen. 
 The Netherlands was home base for that era known as Tulipmania, when bulb prices eventually bankrupted many private fortunes. History records show that one tulip bulb was priced as high as 3,000 Dutch guilders or about $1,500.
Records also show that shortly thereafter a single bulb was sold for 4,500 guilders or $2,250 plus a horse and carriage. But prices have settled down and today tulip bulbs are about 50 cents each.
The bulb-selling craze or Tulipmania traces a fascinating record through history. The so-called father of the tulip industry was believed to be Carolus Clusius, an elderly botanist at the University of Leiden. He planted his handful of bulbs there in a garden in 1593.
Little did Clusius know what he had started. The Dutch populace had never seen tulips in bloom. The new flowers caused a sensation in the 17th century and soon became the rage. Those who could afford the flowers flaunted them as symbols of power and prestige. Demand for the bulbs accelerated to a fever pitch and growers were even selling futures on bulb crops that had not yet been harvested. The craze continued until 1637, when the market crashed and Tulipmania came to an abrupt end.
The original bulbs and seeds that Clusius planted came from Ogier Ghiselain de Busbecq, the Hapsburgs' ambassador to the Ottoman Empire. At the time of his ambassadorship, de Busbecq gave his collection of tulip bulbs and seeds to his friend Carolus Clusius. At the time, Clusius was prefect of the Imperial Garden in Vienna. By the time he returned to the University of Leiden, Clusius had already been experimenting and cross breeding tulips.
Although many at first thought that the tulip originated in Turkey, it is now felt that the tulip originated farther east, in the steppes of Armenia, Persia and the Caucasus. The tulip then spread to the region around the Black Sea, throughout the Mediterranean area and possibly even into China.
Many of the early wild tulips are called species tulips or botanicals in bulb catalogues, and they are sold to gardeners today. The tulips are small and delicate, as found in nature, and have not been bred or hybridized. They are delightful to grow and well worth having.
It is now believed that as early as 1000 A.D. the Turkish populace was starting to cultivate tulips. The flowers were favored in the courts of Suleiman the Magnificent, who was Sultan of the Ottoman Empire from 1520 to 1566, and it is thought that Ambassador Busbecq first saw the tulips during one of his visits to the Court of the Ottoman Empire.
One of the curious things about the earlier tulips was the unusual mottled appearance of the flowers. They were shorter in stature and had two-tone mixed colors. Since they were featured in so many of the paintings of the Dutch masters, these tulips became known as the Rembrandt tulips.
When researchers delved into this peculiarity, they found that the mottled effect was not in the breeding, but was caused by the mosaic virus. Sale of diseased tulip bulbs is no longer permitted. However, the unusual patterns have now been duplicated in healthy tulips and the Rembrandt tulip look-alikes are available for sale.
Some of the modern tulips to look for are Union Jack, Cordell Hull, Shirley and Sorbet.
Another plus for modern research has been the formation of the Royal Dutch Bulb Growers Association, which maintains the industry's standards. There is also a living museum of bulb flowers maintained in the town of Limmen. Plantings there by the Hortus Bulborum preserve the gene pool used by the modern bulb hybridizers. The museum also has one of the original hybrids of Clusius, Duc van Tol, which he developed in 1595.
It has been estimated that American gardeners will plant as many as 270 million tulip bulbs this fall. One advantage for all bulbs is that these spring glories can often be planted where summer flowering plants cannot, because the trees' canopies provide too much shade.
Spring-flowering bulbs like the tulips will bloom long before the trees leaf out.

HEADLINE: Reduce Oil Imports Before the Next Crisis

 BODY:
To the Editor:
It is particularly distressing that not only have we forgotten the lessons of two oil embargoes and the Persian Gulf War but also that we are still paying their economic price ("After 20 Years America's Foot Is Still on the Gas," The Week in Review, Oct. 17). Although we complain about automobile imports, the importation of oil costs us twice as much and is the biggest item in our negative balance of trade. 
 One of the only real successes in getting off oil in the last two decades has been in the electric utility sector, which since 1973 has reduced its use by a million barrels a day. This has been achieved through the construction of new coal and nuclear plants, which accounted for almost all new electrical capacity.
Yet even in this area we are still in jeopardy of returning to significant oil use. A large fraction of the old oil-fired plants have been modified to burn both natural gas and oil. The new wave of natural gas-fired plants now being built will be able to burn oil as well. Thus any sharp runup in gas prices or problems in the pipeline system could trigger large-scale increases in the consumption of imported oil to generate power.
A long-term solution to the oil import problem lies in more efficient vehicles, for which there can be no choice but to use liquid fuels, and the use of our vast domestic sources of coal and nuclear energy for power generation. Now is the time to make these investments while no crises loom and while energy prices and interest rates are relatively low.
 
THEODORE M. BESMANN
Research Group Leader, Oak Ridge National Laboratory
Oak Ridge, Tenn., Oct. 19, 1993

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

INDUSTRY: NAICS 213112 OIL & GAS INDUSTRY (90%);

HEADLINE: THE NATION: Season of Fear;
Polititians Feel a Crime-Induced Chill in the Air

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
IT could be your next-door neighbor describing her fear for the safety of her teen-agers when they leave the house on weekend nights -- but it isn't. It's Christine Todd Whitman, the Republican candidate for Governor of New Jersey, looking squarely into the camera as she tries to convince voters that she is not soft on crime, as Gov. Jim Florio would have them believe.
"As Governor," she says in a new campaign ad, "nobody will be tougher than me on drunk drivers and criminals, especially those who prey on women and children." 
 Mrs. Whitman did not have to emphasize her point with the usual campaign-season props of bloodied bodies and blaring sirens. People are already afraid.
Crime, always a potent political issue, has taken on a chilling new character for many Americans. In the public imagination, hard-core criminals can no longer be expected to simply rob and kill; they now seem to carry out their deeds with unparalleled wantonness, even exultation, and the criminal-justice system, when not directly part of the problem, hardly seems up to the challenge.
Many recent episodes are feeding the fear: There was the Mayor of Washington, D.C., Sharon Pratt Kelly, on Friday asking President Clinton for authority to call out the National Guard to combat the city's soaring homicide rate. There was the Reginald Denny beating case, which ended in Los Angeles last week with convictions of his assailants, but not on the most serious charges against them -- despite what to many people was damning videotaped evidence of brutality against the truck driver followed by a jig of glee. (Details of the verdict, page 2.) There was the police beating of Rodney King before that, and the initial acquittals of the officers that touched off the Los Angeles riots in the first place. There were the highway killings of foreign tourists in Florida, and the torching there of a black tourist from New York (bringing life sentences for his assailants last week). There was the roadside murder of the father of the basketball star Michael Jordan. Carjackings. The list goes on and on.
Like Mayor Kelly, politicians around the nation, many with an eye to Election Day a week from Tuesday, are responding to the perception that violent crime has sped out of control and that the criminal-justice system in many cases has broken down (witness the recent hearings on police corruption in New York City).
Last week Attorney General Janet Reno pointedly placed a large share of blame on television, warning industry executives that if they didn't tone down televised violence, the Government would compel them to.
In gubernatorial races in New Jersey and Virginia and in mayoral races in New York, Detroit, Miami and other cities, the heightened debate over crime has brought to the fore not so much new remedies but age-old tensions between Republicans and Democrats: Do you lock up more offenders? Hand out stiffer sentences? Or should the priority be getting guns off the streets?
 
Gun Control Gains Favor
 As the New Jersey race illustrates, the Democrats have the potential to make the issue their own as the National Rifle Association loses clout and as voters favor measures like the ban pushed through by Mr. Florio on certain semiautomatic weapons. Paradoxically, Republicans used to point to Democrats' support for gun control as evidence that they were soft on law and order. A test for Democrats in Congress is whether, after years of failed efforts, they can pass a strong anti-crime package this year.
Inescapably, the debate over crime has been complicated by the issue of race. The revulsion over the Los Angeles riots helped the election of Mayor Richard Riordan, a self-described law-and-order politician and the first Republican to hold that office in a generation. In the mayoral race in New York, there are tensions over whether the tough-on-crime stance of Rudolph W. Giuliani, the Republican challenging Mayor David N. Dinkins, is a subtle appeal to prejudice.
"We've seen a difference in the nature of crime -- a bravado where you've got juveniles who have no fears," said Charles M. Oberly, the Attorney General of Delaware who is running as a Democrat for Senate next year. "It's an expedient political issue: What else do you tell people when you can't get them jobs and you've got an economy that's stagnant? So there's fear-mongering going on, and the public is ripe for it."
While the nation's overall crime rate dropped slightly in 1992 -- the first time it had not increased in eight years -- the most violent crimes, especially rape and aggravated assault, continued to rise, according to the F.B.I.'s Uniform Crime Report.
In politics, in any case, it is perceptions that count. So as people buy up burglar alarms in record numbers, they say in surveys that they feel less safe, even in their own homes, than ever before. In a poll conducted last April by L. H. Research for the Harvard School of Public Health, 94 percent of Americans said crime had gotten worse in comparison with the time they were growing up.
Mark Melman, a Democratic pollster, said crime is the No. 1 issue for mayoral candidates he is advising this year in Seattle and New Orleans, but not because crime is on the rise. "The real crime rate and peoples' perceptions are two different things," he said.
Already, Democrats are upbeat about their fortunes. Recalling that Mr. Clinton got a standing ovation when he mentioned the crime issue at a dinner for Senate Democrats, Don Foley, the executive director of the Democratic Senatorial Campaign, said: "That's something I didn't expect to see from a Democratic audience in my lifetime." As the Democrats grow more comfortable with the issue, Republicans seem increasingly uneasy. Just as they moderated their opposition to abortion four years ago, many are changing tack on gun control now. Gov. William F. Weld of Massachusetts, a Republican, reversed himself last month and proposed some of the most stringent gun control laws in the country.
Yet many Republicans are still torn over how best to shore up their reputation for toughness on crime. Haley Barbour, the Republican Party chairman, echoed the Democrats' dire concerns about crime, but made clear that a call for gun control was not part of his pitch.
"In some parts of Washington, D.C., people say they are afraid to go out of their houses," he said, dismissing the city's gun control law. "And they know that the only way that you're going to do something about that is to have sure and severe punishment to violent criminals."
Stuart A. Scheingold, a professor at the University of Washington who specializes in crime and politics, has little patience for candidates who are talking up crime. "This is all symbolic," he said. "But everybody's avoiding the really tough issues of addressing the fundamental social conditions that are breeding this."
As an example, the much-promoted Clinton crime bill, which would extend the death penalty to 50 crimes, has been criticized as a rehash of a proposal by President Bush.
For now, many politicians are doing little more about crime than making commercials. In a spot strikingly similar to Mrs. Whitman's, Mayor Norm Rice of Seattle, a Democrat, strolls through a residential neighborhood, assuring voters: "I hear you. These are our streets. And we must take them back."

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Promoting Home-Grown Ideas for Cleaner Air

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
BURTON TRIBBLE came from Kansas to the nation's capital last week to volunteer the services of his 3,000 swine for the Clinton Administration's war against the greenhouse effect.
At the White House, Vice President Al Gore cited the hog farmer as an example of what business can do to cut the emissions of gases that trap the sun's heat within the atmosphere, possibly raising the earth's temperature enough to do serious environmental damage in years to come. 
 The United States signed a treaty last year pledging to reduce greenhouse gas emissions to 1990 levels by the year 2000, and the Administration last week produced a plan that calls for achieving the goal primarily through voluntary efforts and profit incentives rather than strict new regulations.
So what can a hog farmer do about it?
At the Tribble spread near Nortonville, Kan., the pollution takes the form of methane rising from a 20-foot-high tank where a slurry of pig manure ripens until it is used as fertilizer. Mr. Tribble wants to spend more than $100,000 installing a lid on the tank and other equipment to capture the methane and burn it for heat and electricity. He estimates that he will halve his energy bills and pay for the investment in less than five years.
It is not a terribly novel concept, but neither is it widely practiced on American farms, and Mr. Tribble said he has been having problems with the idea when he takes it to the bank.
"I am finding a major problem finding financing," he said. "Hogs have a stigma."
The Administration hopes to help with an inexpensive program of technology assistance, education and publicity, pushing projects like Mr. Tribble's into operation at about half the 3,000 or so swine and dairy operations where it makes economic sense, and capturing an estimated 1.5 million metric tons of methane without costly regulations or subsidies.
That would be one step among dozens -- involving utilities, forestry, home appliances, landfills and manufacturing plants -- that are expected to reduce net emissions of greenhouse gases, principally carbon dioxide, methane, nitrous oxides, and hydrofluorocarbons, by 109 million metric tons in the next seven years.
Much of that reduction might happen with or without a national plan, since, like Mr. Tribble's methane plant, they are expected to pay for themselves. The Administration estimates that the private sector will invest $60 billion between 1994 and 2000, recovering every penny in reduced energy costs in that period, and saving $200 billion in the following decade.
Already, 50 utilities have signed letters of intent promising the Energy Department that they would cut greenhouse gas emissions, mostly in the form of carbon dioxide, even though no Federal law requires them to do so.
But increasingly, state utility commissions are requiring power companies to take pollution into account when making investment decisions, and are rewarding companies for investing in conservation.
Conservationists have applauded this thinking, which is what allows utilities to subsidize consumers who buy low-energy light bulbs, or to lend money to homeowners for efficient furnaces or insulation. The plan also relies heavily on encouraging efficient lighting in commercial buildings and efficient machines in factories.
 
It's Cheaper Overseas
 But environmental groups find some parts of the plan disturbing, especially those that encourage polluters to scour the world seeking cheap ways to reduce emissions, instead of taking more costly measures closer to home.
The concept is called "joint implementation," an approach that rests on the fact that greenhouse gases do their damage globally no matter where the emissions come from.
As an example, several American utilities are examining an investment in the town of Decin in the Czech Republic, where apartment houses are heated by plants burning environmentally dirty brown coal. The town cannot afford to tap into nearby natural gas pipelines, but if an American utility foots part of the bill, the reduction in emissions could be much cheaper for the utility than similar results in Wisconsin or New York.
Some environmentalists also worry about the plan's reliance on forests as storehouses for carbon absorbed by trees from the atmosphere. About 9 percent of the so-called "reduction" in emissions in the plan comes from expanding forests, as utilities and other producers of carbon dioxide are encouraged to plant trees.
Of course, the environmental movement favors forest preservation, but not necessarily trading trees for coal and oil. Unused fossil fuels like oil will store carbon for millions of years; trees die relatively soon, and then return their carbon to the air. "The best way to store carbon is in a dead dinosaur," said Dan Becker of the Sierra Club.
All the numbers being bandied about, and the Administration's optimistic talk about fighting the war with an all-volunteer army, mask considerable uncertainty over whether the goal will in fact be achieved.
If the economy grows 0.5 percent a year less than the Administration assumes, carbon emissions, mostly in the form of carbon dioxide, could be 29 million metric tons less than the plan predicts, the Administration estimated. If oil prices stay flat until the year 2000, carbon emissions could rise 16 million metric tons more than predicted.
On Monday, the Energy Department will publish its first comprehensive inventory of greenhouse gas emissions, up to 1990. It will show that carbon dioxide emissions grew at an annual rate of 1.4 percent between 1985 and 1990, well below the rate of growth in the economy. Calvin Kilgore, a department official, said the economy was becoming more energy efficient on its own. And that, of course, was happening before global warming rose to the top of the national environmental agenda.

HEADLINE: IDEAS & TRENDS;
We Are the Wired: Some Views On the Fiberoptic Ties That Bind

BYLINE: By GEORGE JOHNSON

 BODY:
SOMEDAY, the visionaries tell us, we will be able to communicate with just about anybody by sending an electronic message; no matter where they are, the bundle of bits will find them. On the information superhighway, the literature of the world and the videos, too, will be just a point and a click away. So will anyone we want to hear from.
Someday, perhaps, but not yet. When we asked four writers to give us their visions of the information future, the science writer James Gleick communicated with us entirely through the Internet, the loose confederation of computer networks that serves for the time being as a kind of two-lane blacktop for exchanging information. But then Mr. Gleick, who is building an access ramp to let common folk use the Net, is an old hand at this. (Getting his words from the Internet and into our own computer proved a little trickier.) 
 We reached Bill McKibben, whose book "The Age of Missing Information" involved watching an entire day of television -- every minute broadcast by a staggering 103 channels -- by sending a fax to him in the Adirondacks. He faxed us back, but then we had to retype his words into the system. We had to resort to primitive telephone calls to contact the novelist Robert Coover, who runs a hyperfiction workshop at Brown University, and the cultural critic Neil Postman, author of "Technopoly" and "Amusing Ourselves to Death." Mr. Postman replied by fax, Mr. Coover through the Internet. Finally, we faxed the replies to Robert Zimmerman, in North Carolina, who sent the artwork by modem. GEORGE JOHNSON
 
 
Robert Coover
Stringing Together The Global Village
 Digital convergence is not a futuristic prospect or a choice to be made among other choices; it is an onrushing train. The digitalization of all forms of information (including the transmission of sensations) has proven itself to be accurate, economical, ecologically wise, universally applicable, easy to use, and fast as light.
Digital convergence is also radically disruptive: to communications systems, to the knowledge and entertainment industry, to human life in general. Ownership, whether of the information itself or of the means of its transmission, is highly problematic and potentially an explosive political and economic issue, one perhaps to be fought out, not on the streets, but on the nets, where rebellion and sabotage and telecom-baron wars can be as fatal as a bomb. And, if it is not clear who owns what in digitalized hyperspace, it is also not clear, beyond the sale of hardware, just where the profits are. Early developers of this new communications arena are hoping to turn it into a vast worldwide marketplace and to take their cut by renting stalls, as it were, but exclusive access has never been a principle of the ether, home of the computer nets. If telephony and cable put a lock on the hard-wiring, watch for pirate satellite ships.
Will everyone have equal and universal access to this magical new realm? No, they will not. But the gap between haves and have-nots, already almost unimaginably vast in our time, will not necessarily widen. Digitalization, like the Gutenberg technology before it, has so far had a democratizing effect on cultural exchange, greatly empowering the individual user, and it is easy enough to learn that small children can make full use of it. It can spread as rapidly as there is human will to do so. Making it more universally accessible is a contemporary political issue in the way that rural electrification and telephone line laying were earlier in the century. Certainly it is the new standard by which literacy must be judged, and for a time whole nations, but perhaps for government elites, will in effect be made newly illiterate. They need not remain so: this is easier to overcome than hunger or drought. New tasks for future Peace Corps: wire up the global village.
 
 
Bill McKibben
The Data That Are Thrown Away
 Many times this week, in the hoopla about the mergers paving the way for a marriage of phone and cable, I've heard happy salutes to the coming "information superhighway." The phrase -- beloved of the President, too -- seems instructive to me. For what is a superhighway? It is fast, and this technology will surely be fast. But it is also flat, uninteresting, repetitive.
A path provides you with immense amounts of information about a place -- walking it you feel the topography, the weather. You have time to look at what's around you, to talk with anyone you meet. Even a back road -- a blue highway -- offers lots of information, leaves you with some sense of the country you've driven through. But a highway makes sure you can't even stop at a restaurant that might serve something local.
So with the communications superhighway, I think. Five hundred channels sounds wonderful -- but the 500 channels, and the electronic bulletin board, and the CD ROM Louvre, will still be showing the same narrow band of human experience, the only parts that can come across a screen. Vast amounts of information -- the kind one gets from contact with other human beings or with the natural world or with live performance or with one's own navel -- remains beyond even the fiber-optified magicians.
I suspect that our saturation with information we don't need, with noise that increasingly rattles us, will begin to pall, that we will come ever more to resent the time it steals from our lives. Very few people anymore want a real superhighway through their neighborhood, and perhaps it will someday be the same with megatube.
 
 
James Gleick
A Frontier That Is Building Itself
 Excuse me, wait just a second . . . yes, I thought so! My television set is still sitting there all by itself in the kitchen, and I have to turn it off, not on, when the telephone rings. And my computer is somewhere else altogether.
Telephone companies and cable-television companies may not be able to keep their hands off each other, but blending our actual telephones and televisions will surely require a lot more than F.C.C. approval. The video side of the information superhighway is a one-way street and will remain so for a long time -- even if interactive boxes someday do let us send a few bytes' worth of nay votes up the line toward Geraldo.
Yet the real information superhighway has already taken shape, almost behind our backs, with startlingly little real planning and with only the most accidental assistance from Government policy makers and the telecommunications companies. The global Internet -- somehow lacking a mergers and acquisitions department, not to mention a board of directors -- has suddenly become the most universal and indispensable network on the planet.
It's a wild frontier, befitting its origins -- amorphous, unruly, impolite and anarchic. It's like a television station without programmers or a newspaper without editors -- or rather, with millions of programmers and editors, a lot more opinionated than polished. Like it or not, in a time seemingly dominated by giant communications empires, the amateurs may hold the key after all.
Now if I can just find the batteries for my remote control. . . .
 
 
Neil Postman
Buried in a New Kind of Garbage
 In the 19th century, beginning with the invention of telegraphy and photography in the 1840's, humankind attacked the problem of how to get information to people fast, conveniently, in various forms and in great quantities. It took about a hundred years to solve that problem satisfactorily, but in the process new and unprecedented difficulties were created. Information, once a valued resource in solving problems of our material and psychic worlds, became a cheaply available commodity, to be bought and sold. What was important was mixed with the trivial.
The connection between information and action was severed as people came to know of many things about which they could do nothing. The flood of information undermined and seemingly made irrelevant traditional sources of authority. A sense of what things mean was lost as information poured in from uncountable sources, directed at no one in particular, in unassimilable quantities. We moved from a culture burdened by information scarcity to one burdened by information glut.
The fact is that information has now become a form of garbage. We don't know what to do with it, have no control over it, don't know how to get rid of it.
In the face of this, we propose to spend billions on a super-information network. To do what? Instead of 60 TV channels, we'll have 500, maybe a thousand. We'll have access to more entertainment, more sports, more commercials, more news -- faster, more conveniently, in more diverse forms. We will, in other words, flood our lives with that from which we are already drowning. This is supposed to be our response to the challenge of the 21st century. It is, in fact, a looking back, not ahead; a 19th-century solution proposed by information junkies who have no sense of purpose and meaning, and who require distractions from confronting their emptiness.

HEADLINE: THE WORLD: Following a Tough Act;
Bhutto Gets Another Chance to Get It Right

BYLINE: By EDWARD A. GARGAN

DATELINE: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan

 BODY:
BENAZIR BHUTTO, a gauzy veil draped over her hair in a gesture to Islamic modesty, smiled slightly last week when the speaker of Pakistan's Parliament announced that she had won a majority of votes to regain the prime ministership she lost three years ago, when she became the first woman to lead an Islamic nation.
It was a moment of victory for Ms. Bhutto. She had prevailed over her political nemesis, Nawaz Sharif, the man who succeeded her and who she said had conspired with the country's powerful army and President to oust her from office. Moreover, she had regained the power that she feels is rightfully hers, not only by popular acclaim but by birth as well. Far less clear, however, is what her victory means for Pakistan. 
 Ms. Bhutto's 20-month first tenure was notable mainly for her failure to grapple with the country's grievous economic decay. At 40, she is a bit older and perhaps wiser now. This time, however, she follows a tough act that could point up not only her inadequacies but those of all of Pakistan's politicians and the political system tainted by class and money in which they operate.
The tough act is Moeen Qureshi, a former World Bank vice president who was appointed interim Prime Minister for three months to break a paralyzing constitutional crisis. In his brief tenure, he dazzled Pakistanis and much of the world with a blizzard of laws and initiatives aimed at ridding the nation of endemic political corruption and economic mismanagement.
Many Pakistanis doubt whether Ms. Bhutto, steeped in the hurly burly of the nation's politics, can equal the accomplishments of Mr. Qureshi, a political outsider beholden to few. A public opinion poll conducted the week before the national elections found that 85 percent of those polled wanted Mr. Qureshi, though unelected, to remain in office. With the laws pushed through by Mr. Qureshi set to expire after four months, many wonder in fact whether Ms. Bhutto will preside over their undoing.
When she was first elected Prime Minister in 1988, Ms. Bhutto's victory reclaimed the office held by her father, Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, until he was toppled in 1977 in a military coup and later executed. But her father's legacy gave the young Ms. Bhutto neither the stature nor the power to confront the hostility of the army and Pakistan's authoritarian President, Ghulam Ishaq Khan. When she was dismissed for corruption and incompetence, the first charge never legally proved, the latter a matter of opinion, she left office with the country in dismal shape. She had introduced no legislation of import, done more damage than benefit to the economy, ignored the plight of the country's women and presided over the collapse of relations with the United States.
Pakistan is crushingly poor and illiterate, dominated by two elites, the landed aristocracy from which Ms. Bhutto hails and an emerging urban business class represented by Mr. Sharif. The landed gentry's sense of deserved destiny clouded Ms. Bhutto's first administration and poses questions about what she will do now. "If you were to go by the past history, she won't do much," said Paula R. Newberg of the Carnegie Institute of International Peace. "But this time, she can't say, 'The royals won't let me rule.' This time it's up to her. She has to show leadership in political and economic terms."
 
Shaking Things Up
 In a sense, Ms. Bhutto's task is far easier now than it was in 1988 because Mr. Qureshi, ignoring politics, has laid the groundwork for economic recovery.
He was sworn into office last July after prolonged political and constitutional turmoil -- instigated in no small part by Ms. Bhutto herself -- in which the President dismissed Prime Minister Sharif, the Supreme Court reinstated him and nobody knew who was in charge. While overseeing the transition to a new elected government, Mr. Qureshi expanded his mandate to initiate sweeping reforms. He devalued the country's overvalued rupee, moved to free the Central Bank from political influence, introduced the first tax on large rural landowners (Ms. Bhutto's allies), ended capricious government spending and went after loan defaulters, including Ms. Bhutto and her husband. He also increased prices on subsidized commodities and utilities, measures that would be difficult for any elected government to enact.
Despite Mr. Qureshi's labors, Ms. Bhutto's instincts appear to be getting the better of her. A politician who invariably runs on populist platforms, Ms. Bhutto now seems inclined to review some of her predecessor's policies, in particular the agriculture tax, which for the first time imposes taxes on the wealthy land-owning classes. In an interview, she also expressed her dislike for the devaluation of the rupee, an action that has made the foreign goods consumed mostly by rich Pakistanis more expensive even as it will boost Pakistani exports abroad in the long run.
But her Government could well face its toughest questions over social and educational reform. More than 75 percent of Pakistanis are illiterate; among women, the rate runs to 90 percent. Women are subject to discriminatory laws -- rape victims are often jailed for adultery -- and are barred from much of social life. When pressed in an interview as to what she would do about illiteracy and the condition of women, Ms. Bhutto's concerns seemed focused on the elite. The new Prime Minister spoke about the need for women's universities rather than the necessity for compulsory primary education, a key to broad-based economic development, according to most developmental economists. She spoke about allowing women to become pilots for the national airlines rather than bringing women out of purdah, the culturally and religiously imposed quarantine for women practiced in much of rural Pakistan, where 70 percent of the country's 121 million people live.
And Ms. Bhutto too faces the stringent economic and military sanctions imposed against her country because of its nuclear weapons program. In her first speech, she made it clear that while she wanted to improve Pakistan's relations with the United States, she would not tamper with the nuclear program.
Arif Nizami, the editor of the Lahore-based newspaper The Nation, was in Islamabad for Ms. Bhutto's swearing-in, watching her ascent to power with a mix of expectation and resignation. "I think she has a working majority," he said of her coalition, which includes independents and splinter parties. "But do I think she'll be able to do anything radical? No I don't."

HEADLINE: IDEAS & TRENDS: A Genteel Conspiracy Theory;
Is It Just Possible That Ford Wants to Beat G.M.?

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET

DATELINE: DETROIT

 BODY:
TO hear normally buttoned-up auto industry analysts sound like conspiracy buffs surveying the grassy knoll, ask them this: Is the Ford Motor Company quietly trying to overtake the hobbled General Motors Corporation and become the No. 1 automaker in the United States?
Odd that the question should have to be asked. In other industries, companies like Pepsi, Avis, Apple and United make no bones about their eagerness to knock off the big guy. But one of the peculiar aspects of relations among the Big Three automakers is that they are publicly quite genteel. Perhaps because they focus their hostility on the Japanese, no one here talks much about crushing the domestic competition and becoming No. 1. 
 Ford itself is coy. "It's not a goal," said chairman Harold A. Poling. "I never think about it."
But, muddying the waters a bit, he said the company did want to keep increasing its market share while staying profitable -- a modest strategy that, if successful, would of course end in utter domination of the world.
"We don't write it on the wall, we don't talk about it and we frankly don't think about it," said Alexander J. Trotman, who is to replace Mr. Poling next month. Then he too opened the door a crack, saying: "I think it's a possibility."
Such comments have spawned opposing camps of conspiracy theorists, some believing that Ford harbors a secret yearning to dance on G.M.'s grave, others convinced that it is resigned to playing Sancho Panza no matter how quixotic G.M. gets.
"It's a 60-year tradition," said Sean P. McAlinden, a research scientist at the University of Michigan's Center for the Study of Automotive Transportation. "It's almost profane to break it -- they're almost afraid to."
The question is of more than intramural significance. G.M. traditionally filled the leader's role: setting prices, lobbying the Federal Government and expanding the market by inventing new products and new ways to sell them. Now no one does.
In sales, Ford has been coming on strong. G.M. has dropped from controlling 43 percent of the domestic market 10 years ago to controlling 33 percent now. The Japanese sopped up much of what it spilled, but Ford gained more than they collectively did. It went from controlling about 20 percent of the market in 1983 to controlling about 25 percent now.
G.M. is still struggling to bring out cars that will sell not because they are cheap but because they are good. Meanwhile, Ford produces five of the 10 top-selling vehicles in the U.S., including No. 1 car, the Taurus.
With a strong yen making Japanese vehicles pricier, Ford is the best positioned to take advantage of G.M.'s weakness. In the 1980's, G.M. invested billions in plants it didn't need, and is now struggling to shed excess capacity and tens of thousands of workers. Meanwhile, Ford was learning to operate its old plants more efficiently. By some estimates, Ford assembly plants are now about one-third more efficient than G.M.'s, which may make Ford the lowest-cost car producer in the world.
"When you're the low-cost producer, you're in charge," Mr. Poling said.
As Ford has increased its market share, it has also stepped into some leadership roles. Today its chairman, not G.M.'s, leads the Big Three's Washington lobbying on issues like health care and trade. And it was Ford, not G.M., that the United Automobile Workers picked this year to negotiate with over a new contract; the first contract usually sets the pattern for the industry. (Quite cleverly, some analysts say, Ford took the chance to negotiate pension and lay-off benefits that would significantly raise G.M.'s labor costs without much affecting its own.) And Ford reintroduced the color green into the automotive palette.
Moves like those convinced some analysts that, if Ford executives could be injected with truth serum, they would admit that they'd chew off a limb to become No. 1. In fact, a few of them have been caught in what in Detroit passes for pretty wild talk: they have speculated openly about selling more trucks than G.M.
"That's what they want -- they want to be the best in the world," said Wendy Beale Needham, an analyst with Smith Barney Shearson in New York. "They feel that G.M. is weak, and it is. They see this as an opportunity to go in and get as much market share as they can and hurt G.M."
But opposing theorists argue that being No. 1 carries burdens that Ford wants to avoid. In the first place, it would have to make a huge new investment in assembly plants to seize much more market share. Also, the industry leader attracts much more media and government scrutiny. Had Ford been the leader in the last couple of decades, for example, it would have been blamed for the industry's sloth about installing seat belts and air bags, and for its failure to produce a pollution-free car.
Also, the leader is expected to bear the costs, as G.M. once did, of doing the lion's share of the industry's research and development.
Perhaps G.M.'s most significant role as industry leader was to expand the market. When Ford was last indisputably No. 1, Henry Ford's notion of satisfying consumers' needs was to offer everyone one car -- the Model T -- in one color, black.
G.M. seized and consolidated leadership in the industry by not just meeting but creating needs: introducing the annual model change to keep customers hungry and diversifying its vehicles to suit every customer. G.M. economists began setting prices; G.M. lobbyists pushed for the dismantling of public trolley lines.
Ford has taken steps to expand the market. It has led the way on leasing, perhaps the most significant market innovation by the Big Three in recent years.
And, perhaps learning from Henry's mistakes, it has gingerly broken new ground on styling. A few years back, it began slapping the color green on some cars. The industry held its breath.
It worked. This year, by the way, look for purple.

HEADLINE: Giuliani Campaign Theme: Dinkins Isn't Up to the Job

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
The New York City mayoral candidates have tried to frame their contest in many terms, from who would make the better healer to who would be tougher on crime. But for Rudolph W. Giuliani, one argument has emerged again and again: that Mayor David N. Dinkins is simply not up to the daunting task of managing a complex city.
"It is patently clear that he can't manage a riot, he can't manage a boycott, he can't manage a budget, and he can't manage a campaign to keep it even vaguely in compliance with the law," Mr. Giuliani said last week, summing up in campaign hyperbole what even Mr. Dinkins has acknowledged were missteps in handling problems including violence on the streets and raises for the city's union workers. 
 For his part, the Mayor has been at some pains simply to prove his bona fides, repeating over and over that he has balanced four municipal budgets in tough economic times, something that may count as an achievement but that is also required by law. Indeed, by the account of all but his most ardent supporters, Mr. Dinkins's record has been decidedly mixed, albeit in the face of the deepest local recession in decades.
Official reports have found that the Mayor was strikingly unaware of the extent of anti-Jewish violence in Crown Heights and of the feuding among his own top aides that led some of them improperly to favor a competitor for a $150 million contract to collect parking fines. In the same week in October 1990, he granted teachers a substantial raise, proposed record police hirings and then threatened 15,000 layoffs.
Mr. Dinkins favors a management style that delegates heavily to his cabinet of deputy mayors, but he has often failed to stop public feuding among them, producing policy deadlock. His own commissioners have found him so inaccesible that they organized informal meetings of their own to discuss city problems. He routinely runs an hour behind schedule for daily events and sometimes arrives appearing to be ill briefed and unable to cite specific examples to illustrate his points.
"Competence" is an elusive political notion, at once the bare minimum that citizens should demand from public officials yet, in an age of diminished expectations and intractable problems, a stand-in for an amalgam of other qualities from "leadership" to "innovation" to "originality." As a slogan, it has had mixed success. It worked for Edward I. Koch in his first run for the mayoralty against Abraham D. Beame (who had presided over the city's near bankruptcy) in 1977, but then fell flat for Michael S. Dukakis in his quest for the Presidency against George Bush (who inherited the Reagan mantle) in 1988.
This year, it has struck a particular chord, because Mr. Giuliani is not merely arguing that he is competent but that Mr. Dinkins isn't: an unusually harsh charge, possible only because of the strong public perception of blots on the Mayor's report card.
Mr. Giuliani also likes this argument since it tends to steer the debate away from sensitive and potentially divisive questions of race, ethnicity and outlook into a motherhood issue that no one could be against raising. He has made it in television commercials, attacking Mr. Dinkins for a litany of lapses, beginning with his failure to file income tax returns for four years two decades ago.
 
Freighted With Overtones
 But the question of competence is also freighted with overtones and disagreements on terms. Competent compared with whom? Based on what standards? Competent in the face of what vicissitudes? More or less competent than a challenger who has not done the same job?
"I would never call the Mayor incompetent as a manager or steward of the city's fiscal and human resources," said Raymond D. Horton, president of the Citizens Budget Commission, a nonprofit group financed by business that monitors the city's fiscal affairs, and that has been among Mr. Dinkins's sharpest and most persistent critics. "I would say that in the scope of New York City mayors, he is very much in the tradition."
"Mayors have lost a lot of control over the political process, to the State Legislature, to the unions, and to structural financial stresses that can only be addressed by the state and Federal governments," Mr. Horton added. "Is there room for improvement? Obviously, yes. If he were re-elected would he do any better in a second term, or could Giuliani? Those are the questions."
Mr. Horton said the Mayor's biggest failing was that he had not used hard times to persuade fellow politicians or the public to change the way the city does business, to win productivity improvements from the labor force to save money "except in bits and pieces."
It is precisely by this standard that Robert F. Wagner Jr., a former Deputy Mayor and the son and grandson of legendary New York politicians of the same name, contends Mr. Dinkins has failed.
"I would be less extreme than Rudy," said Mr. Wagner, who recently endorsed Mr. Giuliani. "But I think the last three and a half years have been characterized by a lack of leadership and a lack of hope for the future of the city. Certainly, David conveys a picture of decency and concern, but not of leadership. It's more than competence. It's leadership, in terms of being able to rally people, to manage, to inspire."
In some ways, Mr. Dinkins has never recovered from three episodes in his first year in office that left the distinct impression that he was overmastered by events. The first was the black-led boycott of a Korean-owned grocery in Brooklyn, which the Mayor sought to end by mediation.
The boycott began over allegations that the merchant had struck a black customer. Mr. Dinkins, who respected the boycott tradition of the civil-rights movement, was reluctant to inflame passions by seeming to take sides, and mediation tactics had resolved a similar boycott at about the same time. But he now acknowledges that some protesters were simply racist and "did not want a resolution.
Next came a spate of highly publicized violent crimes, to which Mr. Dinkins reacted with such apparent equanimity as to prompt a chorus of criticism that culminated in a front-page headline in The New York Post: "Dave, Do Something." What the Mayor did was delay for months while the Police Department completed a study of its staffing needs.
Ultimately, Mr. Dinkins proposed the largest police hiring program in history (and won special taxes to finance it, deferring other social spending programs). But he did so in the same week that he granted the teachers' union a 5.5 percent annual wage increase, setting a costly pattern for other workers just as the depth of the city's fiscal problems was becoming clear.
These events formed a picture of a City Hall out of control, and of a Mayor who took too few actions too late, an image that repeated and unchecked feuding among top aides did little to dissipate. Meantime, the Mayor cobbled together a budget that cut some of the very services he had campaigned to protect (library services, parks, education).
Finally, in August 1991, three days of violence between blacks and Jews in Crown Heights produced public disorder that the city had not seen in years, and a state report this summer found that the Mayor had shown a lack of awareness of the depth of the violence and failed to order the police to take prompt action.
Having made concern for the homeless a centerpiece of his campaign, Mr. Dinkins has largely failed to make any headway against the problem. Spending on shelters for families has almost doubled and the number of families sheltered has risen to 5,600 from 3,700, more than 1,000 of them still in the kind of welfare hotels he once scorned as inhumane.
Having seen budget problems dominate his entire first term, the Mayor this year broke his vow to grant union raises only in exchange for productivity increases, and now faces the prospect of a budget gap of several hundred million dollars in the fiscal year that ends in June and of more than $1 billion in each coming year.
Having rejected some of the advice of a panel of outside experts he commissioned to recommend solutions (like tolls on the East River bridges) two years ago, he has now commissioned a similar study by a new panel that includes one of the same members, whose report is not due until after Election Day.
All that said, as the Mayor likes to point out, "At the margin, we have done some things." Reversing his earlier policy, Mr. Dinkins has now moved to expand library service to six days a week for the first time since 1947, opened new neighborhood health clinics and public schools as after-hours community centers, and presided over a general decline in reported crime.
"Competence is entirely a fair issue to raise," said Borough President Ruth W. Messinger of Manhattan, one of Mr. Dinkins's most articulate defenders. "Giuliani is lobbing these tomatoes when they might well be thrown at him. The Mayor, amid tough times, has tried to steer a course, find a way, pull people together, get bills passed, squeeze out a new program. If Rudy Giuliani ever has specific answers, they strike most people as too facile to be believed."
At the same time, Ms. Messinger acknowledged, the Mayor often "couldn't do enough to make people feel as hopeful about their futures as everyone would want."
"This is an administration that because of tough options and the Mayor's style, has made a commitment to being deliberative," she said. "Very often, that doesn't please anyone."
The Mayor's style is often compared with that of Mr. Wagner's father, who in his years as Mayor was a phlegmatic presence at City Hall for three terms ending in 1965, and who was well known for temporizing so long in the face of some problems that they went away or diminished sufficiently to get him off the hook.
"There are definite similarities in personal qualities," Mr. Wagner said. "Probably my father's leadership style was more appropriate to the time in which he held office. But he was much more focused and informed. Even if my father chose to avoid eight of nine problems, he was aware of them and abreast of them."
This election will undoubtedly turn in part on whether voters believe Mr. Dinkins has been.

HEADLINE: VOTING IN CANADA CAN AFFECT NAFTA

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TORONTO, Oct. 23

 BODY:
If the Liberal Party leader, Jean Chretien, becomes Canada's Prime Minister, as is expected in general elections on Monday, the Clinton Administration could face new problems over the North American Free Trade Agreement as a vote nears on the pact in the American Congress.
In 1988 elections, the Liberals, under John Turner, vowed to tear up an earlier free-trade accord with the United States. Under Mr. Chretien, 59, a shrewd, folksy, pragmatic Quebecer who held high office in earlier Liberal Governments, the position on the broader accord with the United States and Mexico is more moderate. 
 The Liberal platform, and Mr. Chretien, have said that the pact would be canceled only as a last resort. But to placate the left wing of his party, Mr. Chretien says he wants a new round of negotiations to win greater protection for Canadian exporters.
"He's an old political animal trying to accommodate everyone, but renegotiation is a delicate business," cautioned Tom Velk, co-director of the North American Studies Program at McGill University in Montreal. The party's robust left wing draws much of its strength from antagonism toward the United States.
Should negotiations be reopened, Congress could demand concessions in return, like an end to the protections that Canada now enjoys for its cultural industries -- magazines, books, television and films. "It could be messy in the short term," warned Peter Morici, director of Canadian studies at the University of Maine.
 
Third and Fourth Parties
 In the latest opinion polls, Mr. Chretien's Liberals, showing strength particularly in Ontario and the Maritime provinces, stand a good chance of winning at least a plurality in Parliament and Mr. Chretien of becoming Canada's 20th Prime Minister.
But the polls also show heavy backing for two smaller parties, the separatist Bloc Quebecois, which is likely to sweep Quebec, and the Reform Party, a populist group powerful in the west.
The Progressive Conservatives, who have governed Canada for the last nine years, have stumbled politically -- reflecting popular disaffection over unemployment, budget deficits, credibility problems of those in office, and a series of campaign gaffes by Prime Minister Kim Campbell. She inherited the job from Prime Minister Brian Mulroney, and is facing her first test with national voters. The personal popularity of Mr. Mulroney, who resigned in June, had been the lowest of any Canadian leader this century.
The Tories' popularity has hardly improved since. A Gallup poll released on Friday showed the Liberals supported by 44 percent of decided voters, a level of approval that usually translates into a majority in Parliament. The Reform Party was backed by 19 percent, and the recently governing Conservatives were down to 16 percent. The Bloc Quebecois, running candidates only in Quebec, had 12 percent. Half of those in Quebec who had made up their minds backed the separatists. The poll, taken Oct. 17-20, had a margin of error of 3.1 percentage points.
The strength of the regional parties could mean new pressures on Canadian federalism and again make Canada without Quebec a political option.
 
Pro-U.S. and Practical
 Although Liberal Governments in recent times have tended to be more adversarial than Conservative Governments in relations with the United States, Mr. Chretien leans to the more conservative side of his party and is considered unlikely to seek significant changes in relations with Washington.
He is a down-to-earth practical politician in the mold of politicians from small towns in the United States -- Mr. Clinton, for instance. Both share a belief in activist government.
The 18th of 19 children, Mr. Chretien used law school to cut himself away from small-town Quebec. He held Cabinet posts under Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau, and like Mr. Trudeau, strongly opposes Quebec separatism.
Charles F. Doran, director of the Center of Canadian Studies at Johns Hopkins University's School of Advanced International Studies, said Mr. Chretien would be "the most experienced of any politician to come to the prime ministership in my memory."
On Nafta, Mr. Chretien says he wants to talk with Mexico and the United States about a common code to define unfair trade practices to prevent Canadians from being targeted by Washington. Over the last year, the United States has used its trade laws to hit at exports of Canadian lumber, steel, pork and wheat. Duties are often set from the belief of American authorities that Canada uses unfair subsidies to increase sales.
During the election campaign, the Conservatives have derided as unrealistic the call for new negotiations, and Mr. Chretien has remained ambiguous about his specific aims. Neither the United States nor Mexico has indicated any willingness to reopen talks, but working groups could be set up to study the Liberal demands, a possible diplomatic way out of the imbroglio.
