HEADLINE: Questions Raised About Children in Attic

BYLINE: By ROBERT HANLEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Oct. 22

 BODY:
When detectives arrived at the home of Anthony and Shirley James on Oct. 8 after questioning two of the couple's six children in a shoplifting case, they found what they called clear-cut signs of abuse. The attic where the children stayed was like a virtual prison, they said, with only two small mattresses for four people, and there was no heating except for a chimney stack that the children would gather around for warmth.
But after a flurry of media reports about the case, family members and the couple's lawyer say that the real victims in the case are the parents. They say the Jameses opened their home to five adoptees, bringing them up in a loving manner. By their account, the children, caught shoplifting, wove a false tale for the police in order to avoid punishment. 
 "I think an injustice has been done," said Mr. James's mother, Hyacinth, a 58-year-old church minister in Far Rockaway, Queens. "It's tearing me up -- the degradation. We're a big family. Our family has been crushed, crushed to death. I just hope to God that this truth will break." Her son and his wife have refused to comment, on the advice of their lawyer, Joseph Contaldi.
Since the arrests, Englewood's Superintendent, Dr. Henry Oliver, and his aides have been poring over the children's files, trying to determine whether the home instruction program the children were in complied with New Jersey's education law.
 
Police Back Abuse Account
 For their part, Englewood detectives say that they believe the children's accounts of abuse, and that the children were apparently left in the attic as a way to keep them in line.
"The mother and father were disciplinarians, and this is how they disciplined them," said Detective Joseph Udina. "This is their way of life."
He and his colleagues in Englewood's youth bureau say they had never encountered the four children until the night of Oct. 8. While Mr. and Mrs. James were out for dinner with their two other children, an adopted girl of 12 and their biological son, 8, two of the children, a girl, 15, and a boy, 11, were caught stuffing bagels, bologna, candy, crackers and other food into book bags at a Shop Rite supermarket in a new mini-mall just off Palisades Avenue, said Detective Frank C. Jones.
The two children were taken to police headquarters on shoplifting charges. Detective Jones described them as frantic and hysterical at the thought of being returned home, and said that they told him that all four had been left locked in the attic when the parents left for dinner. The two caught shoplifting said they had escaped by prying open the lock bolt with a coat hanger and had taken the food because they were hungry.
 
Boy, 10, in Diapers
 Detective Jones said he returned to the home about 11 P.M. with the children and found the oldest child, a 16-year-old girl, sleeping on a mattress in the attic and the youngest, a 10-year-old boy, asleep on the floor in diapers. There was no bathroom accessible from the locked attic, the detective said.
The only furnishings he saw in the room, which measures about 30 feet by 12 feet, were two twin-sized mattresses on the floor, Detective Jones said. He said there were no lights, desks, tables or dressers in the room. In later questioning, the children said the room was sweltering in the summer and cold in the winter. The only heat in it, Detective Jones said, radiated from the house's main chimney, which passed through it.
The children told detectives they had to eat in the basement, away from the rest of the family. The two boys, Detective Jones said, told how they were often hit for taking food from the refrigerator and were allowed outdoors only when the Jameses' 8-year-old son wanted to play with them outdoors.
"They were kept in the attic most of the time every day," the detective said.
 
Police Version Disputed
 Mr. James's mother and his lawyer, Mr. Contaldi, denied the police version of life in the home. Mrs. James insisted the children had access to all the rooms in the house, to the refrigerator and to the above-ground pool and its deck in the backyard.
She said she visited the family here last summer for a cookout and the four children were teaching their mother to do a new dance. She described the attic room as a bedroom, with a television and Nintendo game, a smoke alarm, a lamp and a table, and beds, although she wasn't certain how many.
Furthermore, she said the children shoplifted and sometimes stole money from their parents. They had trouble getting along with peers, and for that reason, she said, all six children were taken from Englewood schools and taught at home by their mother.
Mr. Contaldi, the couple's lawyer, scoffed at the authorities' depiction of the attic as a prison. "It was a bedroom," he said. "We will blow that right out of the water -- that they were locked in the attic all the time."
 
Spanking 'Not a Crime'
 Mr. Contaldi did not dispute the charge that their father had hit the 10- and 11-year-old boys with a belt.
"At one time or another, most people have spanked their kids," he said. "It's not a crime. Corporal punishment is allowed. It's always a question of degree. It certainly cannot be excessive or cause harm to the child. They never needed any medical attention."
After the children were taken from the home, medical examinations found no serious physical ailments, the authorities say. The four children are now in the custody of New Jersey's Division of Youth and Family Services, which investigates cases of abuse and neglect of juveniles. On Oct. 13, a day after their arrests, the Jameses appeared in New Jersey Superior Court on charges of endangering the welfare of the children. They were released in their own recognizance on $10,000 bail each by Judge Arthur Minuskin.
The Bergen County Prosecutor, John J. Fahy, is preparing the case now for presentation to a grand jury. He and his aides have declined to comment on the issues.
 
Home-Teaching Inquiry
 Dr. Oliver and school officials here are trying to determine whether the Jameses complied with New Jersey's Compulsory Education Law. It requires that parents of children between the ages of 6 and 16 insure that the children attend either public or nonpublic schools or instruct them at home with a curriculum that is the academic equivalent of their grade level in a school. Such a home plan must be reviewed and approved annually by a school district's superintendent and board of education.
Dr. Oliver said this week that the Jameses did not have an approved home-study program in place. He said the children were withdrawn from Englewood schools in 1991 and 1992, and school officials learned that some of the children had attended a parochial school for a time and schools out of state.
Mr. Contaldi, the couple's lawyer, said Mrs. James was teaching all the children at home with an educational packet provided by the Calvert School, a private school in Baltimore. He said he did not know when she had started the home instruction or how many hours a day she taught the children in the house.
Besides taking custody of the four children, New Jersey has also taken control of the monthly subsidies the Jameses had received for each of the children under a federally run program for "special needs" adopted children deemed "hard to place," either because of a physical or emotional handicap or because they are older or are siblings.
 
Subsidies From New York
 The monthly subsidies are $579 for the 16-year-old girl, who was adopted by the couple in 1984 in New York City; $475 for the 15-year-old girl, and $489 for each of the two boys, officials close to the case said. They and the 15-year-old are natural brothers and sisters and were adopted in New York in 1987.
Mr. James is currently unemployed. He had worked as a manager of security guards but was laid off five months ago, Mr. Contaldi said. He declined to identify the former employer.
The family moved from Queens to their home on Howland Avenue here in early 1988, but New York continues providing the subsidies, New York officials said.

HEADLINE: U.S. Offers Help to Russians to Insure the Elections Are Fair

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Oct. 23

 BODY:
As part of its campaign to support President Boris N. Yeltsin in his efforts to change Russia, the United States offered technical help today to try to insure that parliamentary elections in December are free and fair.
"Our efforts -- if we are asked -- would focus on the nuts and bolts of free elections, from voter education to poll-watching," Secretary of State Warren Christopher said in a speech to the Academy of the National Economy. 
 To avoid the impression that the United States was endorsing Mr. Yeltsin or his faction, Mr. Christopher added, "As in all countries where we support the electoral process, any assistance we would mobilize in Russia would be politically neutral, nonpartisan and available to all participating parties and groups."
But the Clinton Administration has gone out of its way to support Mr. Yeltsin in his recent political crisis, and Mr. Christopher sounded much like a politician passionately endorsing a candidate at a campaign whistle-stop, exhorting his audience to take its future into its hands and vote for democracy.
 
Cost Could Be $10 Million
 The United States has prepared what a senior Administration official called "a fairly comprehensive plan" for the Russian parliamentary elections in December and the presidential election in June.
Four American nongovernmental organizations, including three associated with the National Endowment of Democracy, would sponsor projects in political training in about a dozen cities. The United States could also train observers who would monitor campaign practices and voting practices on the day of the elections and train editors to make news coverage more objective and sophisticated.
Mr. Yeltsin and Mr. Christopher briefly discussed the plan, which would probably cost the United States Government at least $10 million, during their 45-minute meeting on Friday, a senior Administration official said.
In his speech today, Mr. Christopher said that over the long term the United States was committed to helping Russia reform its judiciary, develop political parties and offer training programs in public administration to strengthen its democratic institutions.
Vice President Al Gore will visit Russia a few days after the parliamentary elections on Dec. 12, and Mr. Clinton will visit after a NATO summit meeting in Brussels in January. Senior Administration officials said today that Mr. Clinton might spend eight or nine days abroad on a trip that could include stops in Central and Eastern Europe and other countries of the former Soviet Union in addition to Russia.
 
'Extraordinary Times'
 As the site of his speech today, it was no accident that Mr. Christopher chose the institute founded by Yegor T. Gaidar, one of Mr. Yeltsin's Deputy Prime Ministers and the staunchest advocate of radical economic reform. Mr. Gaidar also heads Russia's Choice, the largest pro-Yeltsin bloc running in the election.
"I know that many of you may be tired of politics," Mr. Christopher said. "But I will ask of you what Bill Clinton asked of young Americans when he ran for President last year: do not let your healthy skepticism harden into cynicism, and do not let the promise of change wilt into apathy."
One of those in the audience, Anna Lysenko, an associate professor of international economics trained at Harvard University and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, said: "It is very nice that he came to our academy. We appreciate that he's totally supportive of Yeltsin's decision, even though some innocent people lost their lives."
Mr. Christopher's speech was the Administration's strongest explanation for its decision to stand by Mr. Yeltsin and his moves to abolish Parliament and then use force to crush the violent revolt against him. "The United States does not easily support the suspension of parliaments," he said. "But these are extraordinary times. The steps taken by President Yeltsin responded to exceptional circumstances.
"The Parliament and Constitution were vestiges of the Soviet Communist past, blocking movement to democratic reform. By calling elections, President Yeltsin was once again taking matters to the Russian people, to secure their participation in the transformation of Russia."
 
A Visit to Kazakhstan
 Mr. Christopher, who flew to Kazakhstan after his speech for meetings Sunday with President Nursultan A. Nazarbayev and other officials, portrayed the Russian political struggle of the last few weeks as the forces of Yeltsin the good Democrat against the desperate, doomed forces of reaction and repression.
"When those demagogues at your White House waved the hammer and sickle in the name of democracy," he said, referring to the Parliament building, "you saw the hypocrisy. When you heard the defenders of the old system calling for 'renewal,' you knew they meant a renewal of stagnation and a betrayal of Russia's youth. And you had the nerve to chase away both the gaunt specter of the Soviet past and the new extremists who wanted to win with bullets what they could not win with ballots."

HEADLINE: Roof Collapses in Harlem Building, Injuring 6 People

BYLINE: By EMILY M. BERNSTEIN

 BODY:
The roof of a city building being rehabilitated for temporary housing for the homeless collapsed yesterday morning in Harlem, taking five workers down with it and injuring a passer-by.
A spokesman for the Buildings Department said the contractor, A.H.A. General Construction of Brooklyn, had violated city policy by not applying for a special permit to work on the weekend. The company also did not inform the City Housing Authority, which manages the site, that it was working, so the engineer and construction manager who usually monitor safety were not at the site, the department said. 
 Workers were trying to remove the roof of the five-story building at 356 124th Street, just east of Morningside Avenue, when the roof caved in and fell to the first floor. Five men on the roof fell, with three trapped under the rubble. Two were taken to the St. Luke's-Roosevelt Medical Center, where a spokeswoman said one was in critical condition with several fractures and the other was in fair condition.
A passer-by was also taken to St. Luke's, where he told doctors that debris hit him on the foot. Three workers were taken to Harlem Hospital, where they were listed in stable condition.
Today a demolition crew is to take down a wall that lost its supports and other parts of the building. The crew will use a crane to try to preserve as much of the building as possible, as well as Nos. 352 and 354, which are also part of the project and are connected to the damaged building.
Because of the collapse and demolition the Buildings Department has removed people from three adjacent buildings on Morningside Avenue, including the back of St. Luke Baptist Church. Thirteen families, with a total of 28 people, left their homes for a day or two.
 
Entrance Through Basement
 When rescuers arrived at 356 124th Street after receiving a call at 9:25 A.M. they had to enter the building from the basement and crawl up to the first floor to try to dislodge the trapped workers. One worker's boot was caught, and police officers and firefighters eventually cut open the boot and pulled the worker's fractured leg from the debris.
"He was yelling in Spanish, complaining about the pressure on his leg," Officer Juan Gonzalez said. "I was talking to him in Spanish, trying to get him to calm down."
As the roof fell it pulled down supports on a wall, and sections of the wall started falling on the rescuer. "It was pretty hairy in there," Officer Donald Costleigh said. "You could see that there was just one beam holding up two walls up there. If that beam would have given up the whole thing would have collapsed."
Mayor David N. Dinkins stopped at the site, put on a fire hat and rode a crane boom to survey the building. "From a layman's eyes that building is very dangerous," Mr. Dinkins said after viewing it for five minutes. "Obviously if a shell isn't sufficiently stable it has to come down, and that's got to come down."
 
'Ways to Do Things'
 Mr. Dinkins said he wanted engineers from the Buildings Department to inspect the other buildings in the project to determine whether they were sufficiently stable for work to continue.
A spokesman for the department, Vahe Tiryakian, said inspectors at the scene had told him that the building where the roof collapsed appeared to be stable. He said it appeared that the workers had not shored up the roof sufficiently before working on it. "It's very hard for a building to be in such unsafe condition that you can't do safe work in it," he said. "But there are acceptable ways to do things."
The Human Resources Administration is rehabilitating the buildings, with the Housing Authority overseeing the work, which began in June.
A construction worker who was on the roof when it collapsed, Jerome Garbutt, said that he saw that the roof was caving in and that he warned the other workers, who did not listen. "I could see this thing was going to drop in, but they wouldn't believe me," said Mr. Garbutt, who had been at the project about three weeks. "So I stepped back away from it. Just as we stepped away it fell. It felt like an earthquake. Everything was shaking."
A foreman at the site, Ricky Winfield, had just stepped out of the building to go to a trailer when the roof collapsed. "There was a big noise," Mr. Winfield said, "and then a lot of dust and a lot of people screaming."
Mr. Tiryakian said the Buildings Department did not have records on general contractors because the city did not license them. But he said the Mayor had recently proposed a bill to require general contractors to be licensed and to have licensed people at construction sites at all times.
"We feel this is an important bill, because it would give the city greater leverage than we have now to control this kind of work through licensing," Mr. Tiryakian said. "Perhaps what happened today proves this kind of legislation is necessary."

Five men fell from the roof and three were trapped under the rubble. Fire Department rescue workers retrieved the victims, all of whom were listed as stable. (Lee Romero/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: CAMPAIGN TRAIL;
Florio Faults Whitman on Spending

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY

 BODY:
Gov. Jim Florio's campaign, which has spent part of the last two weeks defending itself against complaints of election law violations, has leveled accusations of its own against the campaign of his Republican opponent, Christine Todd Whitman.
The Florio campaign on Friday filed two complaints with the State Election Law Enforcement Commission asking that Mrs. Whitman's campaign be forced to pay for two brochures distributed in recent weeks by some of her supporters. 
 According to the Florio campaign, a brochure advocating Mrs. Whitman's economic plan was paid for by the re-election campaign of State Senator Gerald Cardinale, a Republican from Bergen County, and distributed at a fund-raiser for the gubernatorial candidate in Hackensack on Oct. 4. The second brochure was mailed by a Jersey City group known as Citizens for School Choice Inc. and it was in support of a school voucher program being pushed by Mrs. Whitman and Jersey City's Republican Mayor, Brent Schundler.
The Governor is alleging that the brochures violate the election law because they directly benefit Mrs. Whitman's candidacy and they therefore should be considered a campaign expense.
Mrs. Whitman argued that her rival's campaign should pay for visits that President Bill Clinton and members of his Cabinet made to New Jersey over the last six weeks. Mr. Florio has said the visits were official, but Mrs. Whitman has insisted they were political and intended to aid the Governor's re-election campaign.
She also has accused Mr. Florio's campaign of prematurely and illegally spending $225,000 in general election funds two months before the June 8 primary election.
An Administrative Law Court judge last week dismissed the complaint on the Oct. 8 visit by President Clinton, but there has been no ruling on the other complaints.
 
A Halloween Fright
 Go ahead, Governor Florio told a senior citizens rally in East Orange yesterday, spend the state's freshly printed homestead tax-rebate checks, and don't be frightened by Republicans.
"If you got the check, cash it," he admonished about 200 elderly people gathered in a gym at Upsala College. "Enjoy the money and put it to good use." Republicans, including his opponent, Mrs. Whitman, are creating anxiety by going around and telling people the checks were not good, the Governor said.
"Halloween is coming up, I know," the Governor said. "But it's not time to be out scaring people."
Two days ago, Republicans were accusing the Florio Administration of bungling distribution of this year's rebate checks and creating panic among thousands of elderly waiting for the checks, which can amount to up to $500 for low-income people. The Assembly Speaker, Garabed (Chuck) Hayataian, suggested that the Florio administration had deliberately mailed checks to residents ineligible for them and then ordered them to be returned or not cashed and would then blame everything on Republicans.
The administration's timing for distribution of the checks was "sinister," Mr. Hayataian said.
The rebate flap arose after the administration mailed thousands of rebates, perhaps up to 50,000, to residents who were ruled to be ineligible by a state Tax Court last November because they lived in housing that is government subsidized or tax exempt. The ruling was made after the state's income tax booklet, which contains rebate applications and eligibility criteria, had apparently already been printed.
Few of the seniors who listened to Mr. Florio today seemed perturbed, befuddled or anxious about the checks.
"All politics," said James Dennis of East Orange. "Mine's already cashed and in the bank."
Ditto for Mrs. Verner Baker. "If it's a check and it's got my name on it, then I'm going to cash it and spend it, which I did," she said.
On Friday, Mrs. Whitman told residents at a senior citizens complex in Berkeley Township that, if elected, she would spare the elderly any more worry about the rebate checks. Simply mail them out in July, as they were in the late 1980's, instead of sending them on the eve of an election, Mrs. Whitman said.

HEADLINE: NOTEBOOK;
In the Coming Free-Agent Market, It Could Be a Whole New Ball Game

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TORONTO, Oct. 23

 BODY:
This is the off season that clubs are supposed to retard their rush to put free agents on the Forbes 400 roster. Television revenue will be slashed drastically beginning next season, small-market clubs say they won't spend because they are hurting badly, and large-market clubs say they have to trim their payrolls or at least practice their version of fiscal responsibility.
Owners have made similar noises in the past, but their promises -- or threats -- have often turned out to be empty and the players' pockets full. In other words, watch their actions; don't listen to their words. 
 A new element could be introduced into this free-agent season. One general manager even wondered out loud if it is something the Players Association has thought about as one reason to agree to the three-division format.
"There could be a hidden element in it that the association maybe recognizes and we are slow to recognize," the general manager said. "With the illusion that you're one player away, you may have a lot of clubs overreacting this winter. That perception may exceed the reality. A club could take the short-term view of trying to grab the brass ring."
 
A First-Time Champion
 He especially had in mind the teams that would play in the four-team divisions. Under the proposed new alignment, for example, the American League West would have four teams, two of which have never won a division championship.
The Texas Rangers and the Seattle Mariners, the general manager said still wondering out loud, would have the opportunity to win for the first time, playing in a division with Oakland, which finished last this season, and California, which faded into oblivion as the season progressed.
The Rangers finished second in a seven-team division this season, falling short primarily because of a lack of pitching. They haven't shown a penchant for spending lavishly on free agents, particularly with George W. Bush Jr. operating the club, but what if they decide to seize the moment and make a quick and expensive strike?
"Nope," Tom Grieve, the Rangers' general manager, said, quickly squelching that thought. "I think our feeling going into the winter is that we would do exactly the same thing even if there hadn't been realignment. To go out and try to do more or less because there's less competition doesn't enter into the equation. We'll make a sensible off-season plan based on the economic situation and the team we have, and try to be as good a team as we can be under our own parameters and our plan."
Although Grieve rejected the notion that the Rangers would do anything rash, they will have money to spend. They are anticipating a significant increase in revenue from their new park next year and they have money freed up by Nolan Ryan's retirement and their decision not to exercise options in the contracts of Charlie Leibrandt, Craig Lefferts and Bob Patterson.
The Rangers have two primary tasks: sign Rafael Palmeiro and solidify their pitching staff. That means finding a starting pitcher or two and shoring up the bullpen.
"One of the keys is whether we can sign Palmeiro," Grieve said. "We're going to make a strong effort to do that. We've made him a very competitive offer. But logically so, he'll look at the market and determine his value. I don't think we could make him an offer that would keep him from looking at the market. We'd like him to stay here and I think he'd like to stay here, but we'll see."
Palmeiro, who was offered five years for about $25 million, will be one of the most glamorous free agents available. His .295 batting average, 37 home runs and 105 runs batted in elevate him into that position. The Rangers had a formidable offensive machine this year in Palmeiro, Juan Gonzalez and Dean Palmer.
On the pitching end, the Rangers seek a fourth starter who can pitch between 180 and 200 innings and join Kevin Brown, Kenny Rogers and Roger Pavlik.
"We have some kids in our farm system," Grieve said, "but we would prefer to find a fifth there, not a fourth and fifth. We also need to retool our bullpen like a lot of teams do. If we can improve our pitching, we feel we have a good chance to win."
 
Still a Proposal
 The Rangers will have a better chance to achieve that aim in their proposed four-team division. The problem is, the three-division format remains just that -- a proposal. The clubs and the union have not reached agreement, and the method of determining post-season player shares remains the major obstacle to an agreement.
A couple of months ago, both sides said they had only a "small window of time" to change the division alignment and playoff system for next year. Now they say they still have time. The pane apparently has become larger.
But if any clubs plan to base their off-season strategy on next season's format, they will soon have to know what it is.
 
An Unhappy Henderson
 From the day -- Nov. 28, 1989 -- that Rickey Henderson signed a $3 million-a-year contract, he has been unhappy with it. He shouldn't expect to be any happier with the offers he will receive as a free agent this off season.
Sore hands or not, Henderson has not put himself in a potentially lucrative position by hitting .215 for Toronto the last two months of the season, then .120 in the league playoff. His bat stirred slightly in the World Series after a 1-for-6 start, but he will be 35 in September and not even George Steinbrenner is very likely to be seduced by Henderson at his most motivated.
Nevertheless, Henderson has taken steps to secure the big contract he has wanted for four years. He has hired as his agent Dennis Gilbert, who in the last two winters gained the richest free-agent contracts for Bobby Bonilla and Barry Bonds.
 
A Lack of Stars
 The group of players who can begin filing for free agency tomorrow is not as star-studded as the 1992 class. No Barry Bonds, Joe Carter, Kirby Puckett, Mark McGwire, Ruben Sierra, Greg Maddux or David Cone, who signed seven of the dozen richest contracts ever.
Standout eligibles among hitters this year are Rafael Palmeiro, Will Clark and Andres Galarraga, followed by Tim Raines, Harold Baines and Robby Thompson, then Tony Fernandez and Luis Polonia. Also on the list is Howard Johnson of the Mets.
Pitching is thin, too. Most intriguing is Mark Portugal, who blossomed belatedly but at a time most propitious for him. The right-hander, who will be 31 years old Saturday, will make millions because of his 18-4 record and 2.77 earned run average with the Astros. Sid Fernandez, Dennis Martinez and Tim Belcher follow on the list. Lee Smith heads the available relief pitchers.
Several players will learn or decide soon about their status. The Philadelphia Phillies, for example, have until Nov. 1 to exercise their 1994 option on Lenny Dykstra's contract. At $2.6 million, he will be a steal. The Toronto Blue Jays, on the other hand, will notify Jack Morris two days after the end of the World Series that they will buy out his option year for $1 million rather than pay him a $5.15 million salary.
Otis Nixon controls his own future. He must tell the Atlanta Braves by two days after the Series if he wants their $2.5 million salary for next season or if he wants to be a free agent. He most likely could do better elsewhere, like in left field for the Mets.
 
Hershiser, the Hitter
 With so much attention focused last week on pitchers' hitting in the World Series, it should be noted that Orel Hershiser of Los Angeles had by far the highest batting average among pitchers this season, .356. Hershiser had more hits (26) than teammates Darryl Strawberry (14), Mike Sharperson (23) and Carlos Hernandez (25).
Following Hershiser were Jose Rijo of Cincinnati, .268, and Bill Swift of San Francisco, .263. HEADLINE: Health Reform and the Lawyers

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Harlan R. Ribnik, in "Health Reform? How About Lawyers?" (Viewpoints, Sept. 26), asked why lawyers aren't being asked to donate their services to the poor. Dr. Ribnik will be glad to know that lawyers are in fact being asked to do just that, and are responding in large numbers. 
 Volunteer lawyers in New York City provide counsel in housing court, handle basic legal matters for persons with AIDS, represent children in Family Court and represent victims of abuse and discrimination seeking protection. They help nonprofit organizations with corporate, tax and real estate issues and work on low-income housing and economic development transactions. In all, New York City's lawyers donated about $100 million in legal services to the poor last year -- none of it tax-deductible. That's pretty impressive.
 
ALLEN R. BROMBERGER
New York, Oct. 4
 
The writer, an attorney, is executive director of Lawyers Alliance for New York, a pro bono program for lawyers in New York City.

Legal Services of Eastern Missouri, a nonprofit organization, serves approximately 20,000 poor people a year with their civil legal needs. The majority of our clients are women with children, many of them in need of protection in domestic violence matters. HEADLINE: Tax-Cut Backlash Swelling in California and Oregon

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SEATTLE, Oct. 23

 BODY:
The tax revolt has come full circle on the West Coast, where two states are trying to make up for revenue they lost in earlier tax rollbacks, while another may pass sweeping restrictions on how government can raise money.
When residents of Washington, Oregon and California vote on pocketbook initiatives on their November ballots, they may send out a mixed message. 
 These tax measures are getting the most attention in an off-year election that features only a handful of other ballot measures in the election on Nov. 2 on such normally high-profile issues as gay rights and term limits.
There are two tax revolt measures in Washington State. One, backed heavily by the tobacco and liquor industries, would repeal levies imposed this year to help pay for this state's fledgling health care plan covering all residents. The other measure would limit the growth of state taxes to the rate of inflation and the growth of the population.
 
Strange Political Alliances
 The two proposals have made a mess of normal alliances. The coalition opposing the rollbacks includes Bill Gates, the billionaire founder of Microsoft; a former Republican Governor, and teachers. Those organized to repeal the taxes include citizens' groups egged on by radio talk show hosts, cigarette and liquor companies and conservative Christians. .
The proponents of both measures say they were necessitated by the refusal of the state government, controlled by Democrats in both houses and the governor's office, to cut spending enough in this year's legislative session.
Voters in Oregon and California will decide if they want to raise taxes, in large part to recover from blows their states took after voters adopted tax restrictions.
Oregon's measure -- on the ballot on Nov. 9 -- would impose the state's first-ever sales tax, a 5 percent levy on most goods. Previous ballot measures to impose a sales tax failed, but now state officials say their schools and major institutions are in terrible shape because of the severe property tax cap that was narrowly approved in 1990.
California, which started the nationwide tax revolt in 1978 with its Proposition 13, has placed two measures before the electorate that would make it easier to raise taxes for schools and public safety.
The California ballot also includes the nation's most comprehensive attempt yet to set up a voucher system for children attending private schools. But Proposition 174, which would allow every one of California's nearly 6 million school children to receive $2,600 in tax money to help pay for tuition, has been declining in popularity in recent polls and is expected to fail by a wide margin.
 
Limited Vote on Term Limits
 Elsewhere around the nation, the term limits movement is taking a breather this year; Maine is the only state that will vote on whether to limit terms of state office-holders. New York City also has a proposal that would set term limits for local officials. Over the last four years, 16 states have approved limiting the terms of state and Federal office holders.
Gay rights is on the ballot in one city, Cincinnati, where voters will decide whether to repeal a city ordinance that protects homosexuals from discrimination.
In this state, an initiative to make life in prison without parole mandatory for people convicted of three consecutive felonies has received a great deal of outside attention and is expected to pass. Washington's Initiative 593, a measure called "Three Strikes and You're Out," comes at a time when the public's tolerance of violent crime appears to have reached its limit.
The initiative gathered more than 300,000 signatures, many more than needed to qualify for the Nov. 2 ballot. Opponents say it would crowd the prison system with thousands of aging felons, and it would make a mockery of the state's sentencing guidelines.
It would mean that any person convicted of a third felony in a category labeled "most serious" would go to jail for life without chance of parole. Qualifying offenses would include vehicular homicide, rape and molesting a child, but they would not be applied to juvenile crimes. Backers of the initiative, pointing to statistics showing that the majority of violent crimes are committed by 10 percent of all those arrested for such offenses, say the measure would target a group of repeat offenders and put them away for life.
 
Boosted by Talk Radio
 Beyond the judicial ramifications of the measure, Initiative 593 is noteworthy because it is one of three Washington State initiatives that have benefitted from nearly nonstop promotion by KVI, a Seattle talk radio station with conservative hosts.
Taking over a role that normally would have been handled by this state's Republican Party, KVI has served as the leading booster and organizer of the tax revolt and anti-crime initiatives. Particularly in the tax rollback measures, the radio station took initiatives that had been conceived by leading state Republicans and made them the centerpieces of the listening day. The audience was told where to go to sign initiative petitions, and it was bombarded with an endless litany of horror stories about state government excesses.
But voters, while initially embracing the tax restraint measures, now seem more cautious. Polls show that there is a huge pool -- more than 30 percent in some cases -- of undecided voters.
Recently, Mr. Gates, who was listed this month by Forbes as the second richest American, broke his longstanding silence on political issues and came out against the tax revolt measures in his home state. Mr. Gates said they would be "bad stuff" that would hurt the state's schools and ultimately effect the area's economic competitiveness. He has joined former Gov. Dan Evans, a popular three-term Republican, who is leading the opposition.
 
Taxes Being Phased In
 One of the tax measures, Initiative 602, has been financed in large part by tobacco and liquor interests. They are fighting the increases in cigarettes and alcohol, which are being phased in, that were set up to pay for the health care of nearly 200,000 Washington residents who currently lack coverage.
The other measure, Initiative 601, calling for the growth of state expenditures to be limited to the rate of inflation and the growth in population, would require people to vote for any tax that exceed the limit.
"Opponents of 601 don't think the people are intelligent enough to decide whether future taxes are really needed," the supporters wrote in the Washington voters' pamphlet. "They want us to trust politicians who consistently refuse to control spending."
These initiatives are part of the trend toward taking away the taxing power of elected representatives and turning it over to the electorate.
"The new wave for the tax revolt is to require voter approval for any new taxes," said David Keating, executive vice president of the National Taxpayers Union, based in Washington, D.C. He said two states, Colorado and Oklahoma, had passed such legislation, while several others are considering it for next year's ballot.

HEADLINE: Substance Abuse Is Blamed for 500,000 Deaths

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23

 BODY:
The widespread use of cigarettes, alcohol and drugs is killing more than 500,000 Americans a year and generating a host of social problems, including street crime, homelessness and gang violence, a new study says.
Unless Americans stop abusing these substances, efforts to hold down soaring health costs are doomed to failure, the study's sponsors warned in a report made public on Thursday. 
 Three dozen organizations representing the nation's doctors, lawyers, employers and educators responded to the report with a call to make the prevention and treatment of substance abuse a top national priority.
The study, which was sponsored by the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation and conducted by researchers at Brandeis University in Waltham, Mass., estimated the total economic cost of smoking, drinking and drugs at $238 billion in 1990 alone. Alcohol abuse accounted for $99 billion of those costs; smoking, $72 billion, and drug abuse, $67 billion.
 
Strains on the System
 Joseph A. Califano Jr., president of the Center on Addiction and Substance Abuse at Columbia University, said the habits outlined by the report were "destroying families, driving up health care costs, overwhelming the education, criminal justice and social systems of this nation and contributing to an unprecedented wave of violence and homelessness."
Substance abuse is also disrupting the workplace and driving people to crime, said Dr. Steven A. Schroeder, president of the Johnson Foundation. Half of the men arrested for homicide and violent assaults test positive for drugs, he said.
Mr. Califano, who was President Jimmy Carter's first Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare and is a longtime crusader against smoking, said, "Without an all-out attack on substance abuse and addiction, reforms designed to provide health care for all Americans at a reasonable cost are doomed to failure."
The report said many of the estimated 520,000 deaths each year linked to substance abuse "could be reduced, if not eliminated, by changing people's habits."
Cigarettes were blamed for 419,000 of those premature deaths, it said.
 
Other Findings Cited
 The Brandeis researchers drew their estimates from figures compiled by the National Center for Health Statistics for 1989 and 1990. These were among the report's findings:
*As many as two-thirds of homicides and serious assaults involve alcohol.
*Overall use of alcohol, illegal drugs and cigarettes has declined, but heavy use has not.
*Men are three times more likely than women to be heavy drinkers, and twice as likely to use marijuana frequently.
*By the time they reach the eighth grade, 70 percent of the nation's youths have tried alcohol, 44 percent have smoked cigarettes, 10 percent have tried marijuana and 2 percent have used cocaine.
*Twenty-five percent to 40 percent of all general hospital patients are there for alcoholism-related complications.
A free copy of the report, "Substance Abuse: The Nation's No. 1 Health Problem," can be requested in writing from the Johnson Foundation, Attn. Communications Department, P.O. Box 2316, Princeton, N.J. 08543-2316.

HEADLINE: A Second Term for Mayor Dinkins

 BODY:
At this point in the mayoral election, the cliches of disappointment are getting a real workout: Something must be badly wrong with a system that can't produce candidates better than David Dinkins and Rudolph Giuliani. The real issues are being oversimplified. It doesn't really matter who wins.
The first two statements may apply in this campaign, as they do in most. But it emphatically does matter that voters choose correctly between Mr. Dinkins and Mr. Giuliani. 
 It is not an easy choice, particularly for the swing voters who will determine which of these imperfect candidates will win. Either choice requires a leap of faith -- faith that Mr. Dinkins can govern more effectively, faith that Mr. Giuliani can think more judiciously about the city's problems.
We fully understand why some former Dinkins supporters have drifted to Mr. Giuliani and why others are wavering. His legal background appeals to those who believe Mr. Dinkins has been too relaxed about street crime and government corruption. Mr. Giuliani has made "quality of life" his central campaign theme. New Yorkers always hunger for candidates with a reasoned, coherent program to bring a higher degree of safety, civility and tolerance to everyday life.
But for reasons outlined below, we have concluded that Mr. Giuliani has not made the case for a change at the top. Indeed, he has convinced us that the risks of change are greater than the risks of staying with Mr. Dinkins and pushing him toward a higher standard of governance.
The Mayor is a person of humane intentions, calm temperament and sound judgment. Mr. Giuliani has presented himself as a man of hard attitudes, volatile temperament and variable judgment. He offers to take the city in hand and shake it. After four years on the job, Mr. Dinkins still has the capacity to take the city in hand and heal it.
Whether the Mayor can achieve his potential as a healer depends heavily on whether he understands why this election is so close. The voters are warning him that they want to see more discipline and diligence from him, that they want not only care but a higher order of competence as well.
We believe Mr. Dinkins can meet a loftier standard. His first two years were bumpy, in part because he was overwhelmed by the weight and complexity of the job. He is more at home now, both with the nitty-gritty of budget-making and with important decisions like the appointment of Raymond Kelly as Police Commissioner.
We know Mr. Dinkins's shortcomings. They have been recited so often as to have the feel of folklore. He is disengaged. He is more devoted to the costumes of office -- his tuxedos and dashing tennis togs -- than to the tasks of governing. He caved to the unions and let favoritism toward blacks cripple law enforcement in Crown Heights and at the Korean grocery store.
The real Dinkins record is not perfect, but it is better than this ossified caricature from the discontented. Contrary to his image of disengagement, Mr. Dinkins is among the handful of New Yorkers who understand the city budget. He has complied with the state budget-balancing law in four difficult years, and he has finally started wrestling with the built-in spending increases that produce deficits year after year.
A favorite charge against Mr. Dinkins -- that he failed to deliver as a racial healer -- has been parroted by the tabloids and by former Mayor Ed Koch in his grudge-nursing commentaries. It is an ingenious line of attack because Mr. Dinkins's skill in preventing localized racial flare-ups from becoming citywide conflagrations can be demonstrated only by noting that New York did not become Los Angeles.
What happened in Crown Heights was bad. The police gave the Mayor flawed information. He was far too slow to react. But he did not plunge in and make a bad situation worse, and when he did act, it was in the right direction.
In urban conflicts, damage controllers are appreciated only when they have been replaced by damage creators. The fear about Mr. Giuliani is that he might be such a person. Even the private assurances of Mr. Giuliani's friends that he is not as hot-headed as he used to be are disturbing.
Political leaders need an internal guidance system that allows them to dial down their own emotional temperature when people around them are dialing up theirs. Mr. Dinkins can be maddeningly phlegmatic. But Mr. Giuliani is prone to lurching behavior -- his barnyard language at the 1992 police demonstration, his strong-arm tactics during the insider-trading scandals of the 1980's -- that has to be explained away if we are to preserve faith in his leadership temperament.
After the 1989 election, it was possible to see Mr. Giuliani as a leader for the future. This campaign provided an opportunity for him to show that he had developed a balanced tough-love approach to civic problems. Instead, the vision that emerges is that of a civic Reaganism.
Faced with the most complex urban economy in America, he recommends David Stockman's silver-bullet cure-all of tax cuts that the city cannot afford and, in some cases, cannot even legislate. Louis Farrakhan wants to rent Yankee Stadium? Just say no and never mind the First Amendment. Homelessness? Ninety days and out. Authoritarianism and neglect do not add up to a social policy. There is plenty of tough in Mr. Giuliani's attitude toward the city, but where is the love?
While Mr. Giuliani has failed to offer any enlargement in his politics, there is enough in Mr. Dinkins's record to suggest that he has begun to grasp the breadth and complexity of his task. His economic development plan, while not entirely to our taste, does call for public-private partnerships in areas that can produce new jobs. His community policing initiative has added 6,070 police to the force, and the yearly number of major crimes against people and property has declined from 712,419 to 626,182 since Mr. Dinkins took office.
He has continued to build bridges to religious and ethnic communities even when he knew he would reap a scanty return in votes. He was slow to adopt Andrew Cuomo's creative proposals on homelessness, but he made a good-faith effort to meet an onerous court order demanding overnight housing for everyone. His promising effort to create a network of neighborhood-based health clinics and to expand primary health care coverage for poor New Yorkers is a model of mayoral responsibility.
On this last point, Mr. Dinkins deserves special credit. For over a decade now, there has been a sinister impulse afoot in this society to demonize the homeless, the sick and the poor. It is making itself felt in local politics in the person of candidates who want a coarser, meaner social contract. Under its hard surface, New York has a special place in American history as a citadel of humanitarian concern. Mr. Dinkins's political behavior has honored that history.
Mr. Giuliani has been stalled in the polls for several weeks now, while his strategists have tried one hot-button issue after another. Why has Mr. Giuliani stalled? Why has Mr. Dinkins confounded predictions that he would be 10 points or more out of contention by now?
Our answer is that slowly but surely New Yorkers have realized that this is an election about values. By that standard, one conclusion leaps out: In a choice between two imperfect candidates, Mr. Dinkins is clearly the more worthy.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Requiem for the Supercollider

 BODY:
The death of the Superconducting Supercollider at the hands of Congress last week is a cause for sadness. Not because the huge project was the most important research on today's scientific frontiers -- it clearly wasn't. And not because it would have had an enormous impact on America's technological or economic growth -- those claims were always far-fetched.
But the supercollider was undeniably a worthy scientific project and was indispensable to the continued advance of the esoteric field of high-energy physics. It was science at its most pure and most costly, so fundamental and impractical that only the Federal Government could afford to support it. And now even the Government has concluded that the price is too high. 
 The supercollider was to be the next leap ahead in construction of particle accelerators, the giant machines that are used to study the tiniest particles of matter. It was to be housed in a huge oval tunnel, 54 miles in circumference, beneath the plains of Texas south of Dallas. The machine was designed to accelerate two beams of protons at enormously high speeds in opposite directions. When the protons collided, they would release showers of smaller particles that could be tracked and studied to shed light on the most fundamental forces and constituents of matter in the universe.
The supercollider would have accelerated particles to much higher energy ranges than now possible, in an effort to produce events and particles never before seen. Some of the world's leading physicists deemed it essential to further progress in understanding matter. But Congress was concerned about the mounting costs, which would have reached $11 billion by some estimates.
In a political climate that places great emphasis on deficit reduction, it's hard to argue that the supercollider deserved high priority for preservation. But it's even harder to believe there weren'tless-valuable programs that might have been eliminated. One could start with some of the excess planes, submarines and aircraft carriers still cherished by the Pentagon despite the end of the cold war. Or the annual subsidies of more than $10 billion to farmers. Or the hard-to-justify space station, which is more costly than the supercollider.
The supercollider expired largely because it had a relatively weak constituency and became a very visible symbol of high-cost projects -- right when Congress was looking for ways to demonstrate seriousness about deficit reduction.
The supercollider's death holds warnings for the future. On costly projects like this, it will be critical to enlist other nations as partners. And it will be imperative to project costs accurately from the start, to head off the kind of anger that developed as the supercollider's costs kept rising. The days of a blank check for science, however pathbreaking the research, are clearly over.

HEADLINE: Christopher, Resign

BYLINE: By Frank McCloskey; Frank McCloskey, Democrat of Indiana, is a member of the House Foreign Affairs Committee.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
As a loyal Democrat and supporter of President Clinton, I believe, with regret, that Secretary of State Warren Christopher should resign. He has severely damaged the national interest through failed leadership in difficult situations that have required a firm hand. These crises, in the former Yugoslavia, Somalia, Russia and Haiti, are likely to worsen because of the Administration's flawed policies.
Our Bosnia policy has been an utter failure. Mr. Christopher has vacillated and obfuscated the issue of Serbian aggression. In early February, he defined our strong strategic interests in the region and stated that our response to the war would serve as a test case of how we handled ethnic and minority concerns throughout the world. By June, he was saying we had no vital interests at stake and that our primary goal was to stop the killing. 
 The State Department has pressured the Bosnian parliament to accept a partition agreement that would ratify Serbian aggression, dismember Bosnia and lead to officially sanctioned "ethnic cleansing" and more fighting. Mr. Christopher steadfastly refused to describe Serbian atrocities in Bosnia as genocide. Why?
More than 200,000 Bosnians have been killed, and half of the rest have been driven into exile. More than 380,000 people are in the 18th month of the Sarajevo siege, but Mr. Christopher will not describe this situation as terrorism.
As for Somalia, America has no clear idea what Mr. Christopher believes our interests are and how he believes we should achieve our objectives. I still have no idea why he signed on to Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali's plans to capture Gen. Mohammed Farah Aidid and to construct democratic institutions in Somalia out of thin air.
In a remarkable reversal prompted by public and Congressional pressure, the Administration has embraced the Bush policy toward Somalia: we will withdraw our forces and turn nation-building over to the U.N. Why did 18 Americans have to die?
In Russia, the Administration identifies Boris Yeltsin as the embodiment of democratic reform and is investing all of its faith and aid to Russia in his survival. Given his erratic behavior and his crackdown on his opponents and the press, I gravely doubt that he is a true democrat.
More important, we are encouraging violent ultra-nationalists and secessionists throughout the former Soviet Union, by failing to address Serbian aggression in the Balkans .
In Haiti, we allowed peacekeepers to be turned back by a theatrical display by a few hundred thugs. Mr. Christopher has defined the return of President Jean-Bertrand Aristide as a strategic interest. But as his elastic views of America's interest show, the use of "strategic" can really only refer to President Clinton's short-term domestic political interests.
So while it may have been fair in February for the Administration to suggest that it inherited the crisis in Bosnia, repeating this claim now and adding Somalia and Haiti suggest an expedient denial of responsibility.
Our allies do not see Mr. Christopher as effective internationally or as an adequate protector of U.S. interests. Largely because of his tacit acceptance of Serbian genocide, they do not see him as a spokesman for American values. And this lack of respect can be seen in our own Congress -- on both sides of the aisle.
In a recent editorial, The Economist called Mr. Christopher "the weakest link in Mr. Clinton's trio of foreign policy advisers," and added: "It is not too late to bring in a genuine enthusiast for foreign policy and one who understands, in the most hard-headed way, how the world works. The ideal candidate would be prepared to work out and articulate, not occasionally but regularly and forcefully, how America's principles apply to a given problem, where its interests in the matter lie, and how far it will go to defend them."
Warren Christopher has distinguished himself in other spheres. But if he continues on his present course, he will do further damage to our security and national interests.

HEADLINE: In America;
The Things They Could Have Said

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT

 BODY:
Think of the opportunity that David Dinkins and Rudolph Giuliani had. Imagine how they could have campaigned, the things they could have talked about.
They could have described a vision of New York that would have placed a sense of hope in the path of our growing feelings of alienation and dread. They could have tempered the fears of many residents that New York is in a state of irreversible decline. 
 They could, for example, have talked to us about getting beyond discouragement to deal anew with the problem of homelessness. They could have explained why, after years of effort and the expenditure of millions of dollars, you still find people sleeping in all kinds of weather in our parks, on sidewalks and in doorways, some of them suffering in the shadows of the city's most elegant and expensive residences.
What are the implications of such problems? What can we do about them? How do we prevent them from becoming a permanent state of affairs, a growing municipal affliction, a glimpse of a crippled 21st-century New York?
The candidates could have talked about that.
They could have engaged us in a serious discussion of what it is like to be a child in New York. The city is especially hard on children. It's a place where a boy or a girl can win a science award at school in the morning, visit a world-class museum in the afternoon and then be shaken down for pocket money on the subway on the way home.
How do we enhance those things that are terrific for children and rid ourselves of the rest?
Nearly 40 percent of all children in New York live in poverty. More than 50,000 are in foster care. What can we do for those youngsters, and what kind of impact do their lives have on the rest of us? The candidates could have talked about that.
Most important, the candidates could have asked more of us, the voters. New Yorkers. They could have asked us to make a serious effort, despite our differences in life styles and backgrounds, to focus on the many things we have in common. The fight against crime. The desire for improved schools. The longing for a greater sense of community. They could have appealed to the best in us.
Instead, the candidates aimed low. What we got, in place of a stimulating campaign, was an appropriately absurd campaign symbol, a scrawny rubber chicken.
We can thank the Conservative Party candidate, George Marlin, for this dubious gift. Mr. Giuliani had made it clear that he would not participate in any debate that included Mr. Marlin. So last week, in a televised encounter with Mr. Dinkins and an empty chair, Mr. Marlin highlighted Mr. Giuliani's absence by producing the rubber chicken. Mr. Dinkins was delighted. The next day the Mayor was seen enthusiastically waving a rubber chicken at a campaign stop.
It didn't end there. All week Mr. Giuliani has been answering questions and making jokes about the chicken. On Thursday night, at the Alfred E. Smith Memorial Dinner, which all three candidates attended, Mr. Giuliani was asked what he had said when he spoke to Mr. Marlin.
He replied, "I asked him where he bought the chicken."
And what, Mr. Giuliani was asked, did Mr. Marlin say?
"He said he bought it in Bay Ridge. And he said he bought it on Saturday in Bay Ridge, when I was there, which really hurt a lot."
The most amazing thing about the chicken episode is the realization that it was an improvement over some other aspects of the campaign. We're better off listening to chicken talk, no matter how ludicrous, than to cheap and dangerous attempts to exploit racial or ethnic differences.
It's not too late for the candidates to aim a little higher. They can still debate. They still have an opportunity to level with the voters, to explain that what affects one segment of the population affects us all, and to ask us to pull together in a joint effort to turn the city around.
And they still have time to encourage an honest dialogue, even some friendships, that cut across racial, ethnic and economic lines. It's not impossible. This is not an ungovernable city and it's not a city full of haters.
Mostly it's a city starved for leadership.

THE ARABISTS: The Romance of an American Elite, by Robert D. Kaplan. (Free Press, $24.95.) A thoughtful, balanced view of the inbred State Department specialists whose fluffs (like their dealings with Saddam Hussein) have received more attention than their successes (like the exodus of the Ethiopian Jews).
 
THE COST OF TALENT: How Executives and Professionals Are Paid and How It Affects America, by Derek Bok. (Free Press, $22.95.) Mr. Bok, formerly president of Harvard, examines, documents and analyzes the trends that have given David Letterman an income more than 50 times that of President Clinton.
 
THE CROCODILE BIRD, by Ruth Rendell. (Crown, $22.) A coolly composed allegorical suspense tale (not dependent on a detective) about a girl who accepts her mother's tyranny though seeming to know that the woman is a mad murderer.
 
DAPHNE DU MAURIER: The Secret Life of the Renowned Storyteller, by Margaret Forster. (Doubleday, $25.) An insightful life of the popular author whose resentment at being born female never challenged the social arrangements that depressed the status of women.
 
THE GIRL WHO TROD ON A LOAF, by Kathryn Davis. (Knopf, $23.) A heated, dramatic novel narrated by Francie, an underachieving composer who finds redemption by completing an inherited unfinished opera.
 
THE HOLDER OF THE WORLD, by Bharati Mukherjee. (Knopf, $22.) A woman of today celebrates the life of a woman who lived three centuries ago and across two cultures in this brilliantly conceived and executed novel.
 
MARGUERITE YOURCENAR: Inventing a Life, by Josyane Savigneau. (University of Chicago, $25.) Yourcenar (1903-87), author of "Memoirs of Hadrian," intense, cerebral, fascinated by sexual ambiguity, has found a perfect biographer in the patient, wise, industrious Ms. Savigneau.
 
PRONTO, by Elmore Leonard. (Delacorte, $21.95.) Mr. Leonard's latest antihero, a cheapo operator for the Miami syndicate, flees to Italy, pursued by the Feds and by two quaint thugs who can't keep their minds on their work.
 
REMEMBERING BABYLON, by David Malouf. (Pantheon, $20.) Mr. Malouf's adroit seventh novel confronts a band of settlers in Australia with Gemmy, a boy born white and raised by aborigines; they dread that their own identities might be compromised like his.
 
TRAVELS WITH LIZBETH, by Lars Eighner. (St. Martin's, $19.95.) A writer who until very recently made homelessness his full-time job has found a strikingly unconventional voice and form to deal with life as the literate don't normally live it.
 
THE WARBURGS: The Twentieth-Century Odyssey of a Remarkable Jewish Family, by Ron Chernow. (Random House, $30.) Mr. Chernow's vast Warburg saga follows the fates of a rich, thoroughly secularized German Jewish family betrayed by the nation and culture they loved.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 36; Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 905 words

HEADLINE: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks

BYLINE: By Laurel Graeber

 BODY:

VIRGIN TIME
By Patricia Hampl. Ballantine, $10.
The author journeys, materially and spiritually, to rediscover her Roman Catholic roots. On the way, she finds the need in her life not so much for God as for prayer and the capacity for wonder it requires. "There are wonderful passages in this book, buoyant, full of light," Barbara Grizzuti Harrison said here last year.
THROUGH THE IVORY GATE
By Rita Dove. Vintage Contemporaries, $11.
This first novel by the new Poet Laureate of the United States explores the relationships and memories of Virginia, a young black actress and musician who returns to Akron, Ohio, her hometown, to teach elementary school. Last year our reviewer, Geoff Ryman, said: "It is a happy book, about the pleasures of living. The author has a talent for sanguine observation." Vintage has also published Ms. Dove's SELECTED POEMS ($12), which includes three earlier volumes: "The Yellow House on the Corner," "Museum" and "Thomas and Beulah," which won a Pulitzer Prize in 1987. One critic said, "Her poems exhibit the thrift that Yeats called the sign of a perfected manner." 

ON CLOWNS: The Dictator and the Artist
By Norman Manea. Grove/Atlantic Monthly, $12.
These five essays examine life in Romania under the Ceausescu regime. They illustrate the sheer tedium of the Communist bureaucracy, which the author sees as another expression of the banality of evil. One section is a censor's report on Mr. Manea's work, glossed by the author himself. "The pointless boredom of this report is almost unbelievable," John Bayley said here last year. Mr. Manea also reflects on his experiences in OCTOBER, EIGHT O'CLOCK (Grove/Atlantic Monthly, $12), short stories revealing his past as an adult under the Communist dictatorship and as a child in a Nazi concentration camp. In the same review Mr. Bayley said, "Mr. Ma nea's prose treads the edge of the poetry of nightmare."
IN MY PLACE
By Charlayne Hunter-Gault. Vintage, $11.
The author recalls her years as one of the first two black students ever enrolled at the University of Georgia. Last year our reviewer, Melissa Fay Greene, said this memoir "makes a whole, pure sound, like a musical note rising from that old segregated world."
UNDER THE FIFTH SUN: A Novel of Pancho Villa
By Earl Shorris. Norton, $11.95.
Now back in print, this tale of the Mexican outlaw-turned-revolutionary presents him as a Hispanic Robin Hood. "Mr. Shorris surrounds Villa with the magic of song," Jerome Charyn said here in 1980.
THEIR ANCIENT GLITTERING EYES: Remembering Poets and More Poets
By Donald Hall. Ticknor & Fields, $11.95.
The author captures the spirits of poets who have gone before him, from Robert Frost and T. S. Eliot to Marianne Moore and Ezra Pound. His memoir often underscores the difference between the writer and the work, concluding that the poems must stand for themselves. Last year Michiko Kakutani said in The New York Times that Mr. Hall's criticism is "humanized by the author's sympathy for his subjects' lives."
SELLING OUR SECURITY: The Erosion of America's Assets
By Martin Tolchin and Susan J. Tolchin.
Penguin, $12.50.
Martin Tolchin, a Washington correspondent for The New York Times, and Susan J. Tolchin, a professor of public administration, argue that America, in becoming the champion of foreign investment, has also become its victim. Last year our reviewer, Michael Lewis, took issue with their thesis, but noted that "they have accumulated an enormous amount of evidence that our markets are very open." The Tolchins' 1988 book BUYING INTO AMERICA: How Foreign Money Is Changing the Face of Our Nation (Farragut Publishing, $14.95) has also been reissued, with an introduction addressing recent economic developments. It is "a superb stimulus to further thought on a subject that has attracted surprisingly little debate," David Kuttner said here.
THE AFRICAN
By Harold Courlander. Owl/Holt, $12.95.
First published in 1967, this novel helped inspire Alex Haley, who was sued by the author for plagiarizing "The African" in his book "Roots." (The writers ultimately reached a settlement.) Reissued with a new preface, "The African" tells the story of Hwesuhunu, a young Dahomean boy sold into slavery in America. One critic called it "a novel of tremendous, moving proportions."
TRUE CRIME
By Michael Mewshaw. Fawcett Crest, $5.99.
A writer whose subject is family murders becomes embroiled in a case involving the deaths of his own father and the relatives of a long-lost love. In 1991 our reviewer, Marilyn Stasio, said the novel "shows us how a mesmerizing storyteller works his morbid craft."
LA STORIA: Five Centuries of the Italian American
Experience.
By Jerre Mangione and Ben Morreale.
Harper Perennial, $15.
This history of Italian immigrants spans the period from the Colonies to the present day, touching on subjects from Columbus to the Cuomos. "It is a book that should be read by all Americans interested in what binds us together," Joseph V. Scelsa said here last year.
HERE TO GET MY BABY OUT OF JAIL
By Louise Shivers. Longstreet, $6.95.
In this first novel, set in North Carolina in 1937, a 20-year-old mother who passed from her childhood home to marriage falls in love with her husband's new farmhand. In 1983 our reviewer, David Quammen, praised the book's "focus, freedom from self-indulgence and clarity of purpose."
 LAUREL GRAEBER
