HEADLINE: Sports Wouldn't Be the Same Without the View from a Blimp

BYLINE: By JOYCE JONES

 BODY:
"BLIMP, I like that shot. Hold it." It is a command that Sandy Grossman, the lead CBS sports director, often makes as he selects shots to be broadcast during National Football League games. The command is made to a camera technician who is situated in the blimp's gondola some 1,000 feet above the stadium.
Blimps are a common sight in the skies above New Jersey and much of the rest of the country, and their presence at all manner of sporting events is only expected to increase. 
 Craig Janoff, the director of ABC's "Monday Night Football," said, "Blimps have become tools that provide outstanding visual sensations."
Mr. Grossman was at the Meadowlands recently working with the CBS sportscasters John Madden and Pat Summerall in a broadcast of a Giants game that used shots taken from the Met Life blimp.
Mike Fitzpatrick, the Met Life airship's captain, maneuvered the 194-foot blimp, which also carries a co-pilot and 450 pounds of camera equipment. When aloft, the pilot hears a stream of directions in the right side of his headphones from air traffic controllers. On the left side, he listens to the blimp's camera technician, who shoots pictures of the stadium below and the surrounding area.
During those conversations, "I am asking the pilot to position the blimp so that I can do what the director wants," said Bob Mikkelson, the blimp's camera technician. A microwave transmitter sends the camera's signal to a receiver on the ground, which then feeds the signal live into the production truck, where the shot can be broadcast over the airwaves or kept on videotape for replay.
"When the stadium is rocking with the crowd, you want a big shot of the whole place," Mr. Grossman said. "From a blimp you are able to get a perspective of a sporting event that no other camera can give."
Goodyear has been building blimps and balloons for the military and for its own use since 1917. It first used a blimp as an advertising vehicle in 1925, but it wasn't until 1964 that the company formed a public relations department to oversee the blimp's operation.
In 1960, Goodyear installed a camera in one of its blimps and used the shots to cover a sporting event at the Orange Bowl, the first time shots from a blimp were broadcast on national television. (The company no longer knows what sport was being played that day in Miami.)
The blimp's usefulness as a broadcast tool drastically increased in 1984 when the airships began to be outfitted with a gyrostabilized camera mount that could carry the largest broadcast lens. The mount was introcudes by Winged Vision, Mr. Mikkelson's company. Cameras stationed in blimps can now pick up the numbers on a player's jersey or a golf ball in the grass.
 
'Terrific Overhead Shots'
 At the U.S. Open at the Baltusrol Golf Club in Springfield last June, the blimp's camera was an integral part of ABC's coverage. Dennis Lewin, the senior vice president of production for ABC Sports, said: "Goodyear gave us terrific overhead shots of the course direction. We used the blimp to identify players and their strokes; people enjoyed seeing the Baltusrol course and the surrounding area from the air."
Along with the public's fondness for blimps, Mr. Mikkelson said, "when a crowd sees a blimp over a stadium, it adds a sense of importance to the event."
The blimp gives a sense of place, Mr. Grossman said. "If you are familiar with Giants Stadium, you've seen the sports complex, the Brendan Byrne Arena and the Meadowlands Race Track. But for those who don't know the area, showing this from the air gives it identity, just as do the shots of the bay when covering a game at Candlestick Park in San Francisco."
The blimp also can provide some comic relief. "John Madden has fun with it," Mr. Grossman said of the CBS sportscaster. At one football game when it started to rain, the Fuji blimp started to leave.
"Where's the blimp going?" Mr. Madden is said to have asked as he traced its flight on the chalkboard, something he usually reserves for diagramming a game play.
Even fans' displeasure can be registered from the blimp. Last year, during a particularly bad game for the Giants, Mr. Grossman called for a shot from the blimp of people emptying out of the stadium into the parking lot. "You didn't even have to show the scoreboard to sense their unhappiness."
Eddie Ogden, the public relations manager of one of Goodyear's blimps, the Spirit of Akron, said that Roone Arledge, when he was president of ABC Sports, said that "Monday Night Football" was not only football, but also entertainment. "When we cover an event for one of the networks or cable, we think we are part of the show, not an added concession," Mr. Ogden said.
As the football season progresses, Mr. Janoff said he plans to use the blimp in more game action on "Monday Night Football." He said that "we'll take a chance using its line camera" to cover play-by-play action, and not just use the blimp camera for beauty shots.
 
Eight Large Blimps
 Currently, the number of large blimps in the United States is up to eight. Only two smaller blimps, 130 feet long, operated by Blockbuster Video and the Family Channel, are equipped with cameras and in use for sporting and other events. The smaller blimps are called Lightships, as they are illuminated internally, from nose to tail.
August A. Busch 4th, the vice president of Budweiser Brands, said one of its large airships, Bud One, is extending its bookings east, whereas last year it mainly stayed in California. Another company blimp, Shamu, promotes its four Sea World parks, in Orlando, San Diego, San Antonio and Ora, Ohio.
With only one blimp needed to be part of any particular telecast, who decides which blimp will cover the event?
"It's simply sponsor-driven," said Jim Harrington, a vice president of production at CBS. "Decisions are made by the sales and marketing people based on which blimp's company has bought the most advertising time. The blimp that is chosen is there for economic reasons."
The deal also includes an arrangement with the television and cable companies that the blimp be shown on the air and mentioned by company name. During one such shot, the announcer usually identifies the airship's captain. At one mention per hour, the blimp's sponsor can expect up to 30 seconds of free on-air advertising, which can cost from $50,000 during the regular football season to $800,000 at the Super Bowl.
A Met Life airship captain, Maurice Mylemans, said: "When the camera technician hears the director ask, 'Who's got the blimp?' we know that they're about to show us on camera. We move fast to get the blimp and its logo in the best position for the shot."
 
Always an Objective in Mind
 Tom Riley, Goodyear's manager of airship operations, said, "Whether covering a network affair or flying over the beach, there is an objective in mind for every moment of flight time."
Companies seek to sponsor events that are in keeping with their services or product. "For example, Met Life does not wish to sponsor auto races, racing being a high-risk sport," said Bob Pizzute, director of blimp promotion at Met Life. But it is a venue that appeals to companies like Goodyear and Anheuser-Busch.
Blimps are made of polyester fabric, and its "lifting gas" is nonflammable helium. The blimp's shape is maintained by the internal pressure of the lifting gas. Only licensed commercial pilots may enroll in a training program to fly a blimp, and the program can last as long as six months, largely beause of the unavailability of blimps for training.
Phil Engle, the manager of Teterboro Airport, said Goodyear has a letter of agreement with Teterboro to use its single blimp parking space when a Goodyear blimp is covering an event in the metropolitan area. Goodyear has already reserved Teterboro's space for the 1994 World Cup soccer games.
 
'They Attract a Crowd'
 Linden Airport can also service the large airships. "When the blimps are here, they attract a crowd," said Paul Dudley, the president of Linden Air Services Corporation. Generally, Linden also houses one blimp at a time.
Blimps are usually serviced by a full-time crew of about 25, which includes four pilots, a company representative and crewmen. Ground support vehicles include a bus transporting the crew, a mobile mooring mast and trailers that house maintenance shops. Generally in the fall, airships head south and west, preferring moderate temperatures to operate effectively.
Goodyear owns and operates its three blimps. Several other companies lease blimps from Airship International Limited; the rental fee for a new client averages $300,000 to $400,000 a month. A large airship can cost more than $6 million to build.
The newest blimp to take to the air is Gulf Oil's blue and orange airship, which was launched last June. Steve Rattner, manager of airship operations at Gulf, said the blimp has 97 miles of exterior wiring that produces signs of colored, animated graphics.
As for its schedule, Mr. Rattner said, "There are enough sporting events going on in this country to keep all eight large airships busy every day of the year."

HEADLINE: New Haven Symphony Marks Its Centennial With New Music

BYLINE: By VALERIE CRUICE

 BODY:
IN 1863, when Morris Steinert attempted to organize an orchestra in New Haven, the "woods were not full of musicians who could play upon orchestral instruments," he later recalled.
The first rehearsals were "simply frightful," he said, and generated such noises "as to frighten the horses which were kept in a livery stable next door, and which immediately signified their displeasure by violently kicking against their stalls in rhythm with the scraping of the fiddles, the windy tones of the flutes, the squeaky harmonics emitted from the yellow clarionets." 
 According to Mr. Steinert's "Reminiscences" from 1900, New Haven was the recipient of "a pandemonium of tones that has never been equaled in any cultural city of the globe."
Nevertheless in 1894 -- not long after the New York Philharmonic (1842), the Boston Symphony Orchestra (1881) and the Chicago Symphony (1891) were founded -- Mr. Steinert brought together 60 musicians as the New Haven Symphony.
In 100 years the New Haven Symphony has come a long way from frightening horses. On Jan. 21, the orchestra will perform at Carnegie Hall, where the clarinetist Richard Stoltzman, a Yale School of Music and Symphony alumnus, will be soloist in a concerto by Mozart.
 
A Bruch Concerto
 The orchestra begins its centennial celebration, however, on Tuesday at Woolsey Hall in New Haven with the guest soloist Itzhak Perlman, who will perform Max Bruch's Concerto No. 1 for Violin in G minor. The Bruch concerto was performed by the orchestra during its very first season. Stravinsky's "Greeting Prelude" and Tchaikovsky's Symphony No. 4 in F minor will also be on the program.
Michael Palmer, who was appointed the orchestra's eighth conductor in 1988, will be on the podium Tuesday. (Horacio William Parker, David Stanley Smith, Hugo Hortschak, Richard R. Donovan, Frank Brieff, Erich Kunzel and Murry Sidlin were the earlier conductors.)
What drew Mr. Palmer to New Haven?
"The New Haven Symphony has always been a well-established orchestra with a fine reputation," he said. "It had a solid reputation -- just to have survived as long as it has as well as it has."
 
Personality and Identity
 "What we have now," he continued, "is an orchestra that is well developed artistically and which continues to develop its personality and identity within the repertoire."
Mr. Palmer, who is 48 years old, described that personality as "very warm, communicative but flexible." He explained that the orchestra "can be lean, combined with a precision of ensemble."
Mr. Palmer said he hoped he had given the orchestra more focus. He has worked on what he calls "a unity of approach," to whatever style the musicians are playing. He said the approach results in "the way in which the orchestra enunciates the music and the way it projects the interpretation of that particular work that's being performed.
 
History of Premieres
 Mr. Palmer has a particular task in programming. "The New Haven Symphony has a history of commissioning new works," he said. "We have a responsibility to perform American music. We must keep pace with what is going on across the country."
In 1959 the orchestra performed the premiere of its first commissioned work through the William Inglis Morse trust for music, called "Fragments for the Song of Songs" by John La Montaine. Since that time, through the trust, the orchestra has commissioned and performed the premieres of 16 new compositions.
The tradition continues with a composition by Ezra Laderman, dean of the Yale School of Music, who has been commissioned to compose his eighth symphony for the 100th anniversary season. It will be performed on Jan. 18.
For the 1994-95 season, Jacob Druckman's Piano Concerto is to receive its premiere performance by Emanuel Ax. In the 1995-96 season, Martin Bresnick's Concerto Grosso will feature members of the orchestra. Both Mr. Druckman and Mr. Bresnick are on the faculty of the Yale School of Music.
Such ambitious promotion of contemporary compositions has earned the orchestra the ASCAP award for the New Music Programming in the regional orchestra category for 1980, 1985 and 1986.
 
Raising Eyebrows
 Some new works have raised a few eyebrows, said two of the orchestra's musicians, Sid Rhein, a bassist, and Bill D'Amato, a cellist, both of whom have been with the orchestra since the 1930's. They recalled one piece in particular: "We were scattered all over Woolsey Hall -- down in the basement, up in the balcony, three conductors, two pianos," said Mr. D'Amato, 77. "The looks we got were something like 'Are you kidding?' " Mr. Rhein, also 77, said that it was the most unusual concert he'd ever done, and that it was a "weird composition."
When it comes to guest soloists, however, the symphony has always attracted the best. "There have been no second-rate performers," said Mr. Rhein. Van Cliburn's first stop after becoming the first American pianist to win the Tchaikovsky prize in Moscow was New Haven in 1958. Other guest artists have included Artur Rubenstein, Glenn Gould, Mstislav Rostropovich, to name a few. The violin prodigy Midori played with the orchestra "when she was coming up," Mr. Rhein said.
Programs to reach young audiences have been held since 1932; currently the Symphony offers a six-concert series in Woolsey Hall for 7- to 12-year-olds. A series for preschoolers features exposure to small ensembles and then to the whole orchestra.
For grown-up patrons, in addition to its seven-concert subscription series (which offers informal discussions prior to each concert), the New Haven Symphony has a Saturday Night Pops Series, a Valley Pops Series held in Shelton, Concerts on the Green that are free, summer concerts held throughout the greater New Haven area, Picnic in the Park in June, and the Merrill Lynch Great Performers Series. A biannual competition for artists under the age of 26 (the Marcia Polayes National Young Violinist Competition) provides the winner with an honorarium and the chance to perform with the orchestra.
Despite the activity, musicians and conductor alike expressed the need for greater exposure for the orchestra through recordings and more concerts.
 
Pairs of Concerts
 Their first wish is to give more than one performance of a particular program. "It's frustrating to do only one concert," said Mr. Palmer. "Ultimately we would want to do pairs of concerts in our home hall. If you do pairs, the total number you have reached is going to be greater. In the long run it doesn't make sense economically to do one," he said.
"We spend a lot of money in rehearsal, then we give one concert for all that time," concurred Mr. Rhein.
Part of the problem is lack of financial support from corporations, a challenge arts organizations are facing nationally. While individual contributions have held steady and ticket sales are up, the outreach programs and other projects have dried up. "We've had to cut back," Mr. Palmer said. "The economic problems have affected the orchestra in terms of moving quickly. We've had to make changes in our approach."
But the conductor is upbeat about the future, and his orchestra is enthusiastic about him. "We're anticipating moving into the next century by bringing the sound of the orchestra to a wider region and the country -- to the nation. I'm happy in New Haven, there's a lot of potential here," Mr. Palmer said.
The New Haven Colony Historical Society (114 Whitney Avenue, New Haven; 562-4183) will commemorate the New Haven Symphony's centennial with "100 Years of Music" through Jan. 31. The free exhibition consists of photographs, programs, original scores and other memorabilia.

HEADLINE: New Activism Over Breast Cancer

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER

 BODY:
WHEN Helen M. Ciaffa first felt a lump in her right breast, she ignored it. When a lesion on the breast began to bleed, she tried not to be concerned. When her arm started to enlarge, she bought long-sleeve blouses to cover the swelling.
"I was petrified, but I couldn't deal with it," explained the 72-year-old retired clerical worker from New Rochelle. "Then my husband looked at me one day and said, 'Helen, why don't you just jump out of the window, because you're already killing yourself this way.' " 
 Shortly after, Mrs. Ciaffa sought medical help, and she said recently that she is "coming along well," after 12 radiation treatments and continuing chemotherapy for cancer in her breast, hips and one leg.
From behind her tears, which she said come frequently since her illness, Mrs. Ciaffa had a message for other women. "Go to the doctor right away if you suspect something," she said, "so you don't end up like me."
Many breast-cancer victims, like Mrs. Ciaffa -- who say that early detection is the best defense against the disease -- are quick to point to the following statistics: this year alone, 182,000 women in the country will be diagnosed with the disease, and 46,000 will die from it. Moreover, they say, 1 in 9 women by age 85 will become a breast cancer victim.
 
Searching for Answers
 Armed with those statistics from the American Cancer Society -- and taking a cue from AIDS activists -- breast cancer survivors are pressing Washington to find answers to a disease that to date has no known cause or cure. In Westchester and nationwide, their grass-roots effort is being joined by doctors, husbands and children weary of the statistics and the toll that breast cancer takes on families.
Bette Slutsky, a 53-year-old Hebrew-school teacher from Ossining, is one of those survivors-turned-activists. She has become part of a battalion of victims wearing pink ribbons on their lapels and lobbying Congress and the White House for more money for breast cancer research.
"We've learned that we have to make noise to be heard," Mrs. Slutsky said. "Like the AIDS activists, we need answers too."
Mrs. Slutsky, the mother of two grown children, was diagnosed with breast cancer 10 years ago and had a mastectomy. "I never considered myself a vain woman," she said. "But the first time I looked down and saw that my chest was gone, I was shocked. There was nothing there."
Like many other survivors of breast cancer, Mrs. Slutsky remembered the sense of despair she felt after losing part of her body and the pain of the treatment that followed. She recalled the hair loss from chemotherapy, the kerchiefs she wore during the hot summer months to cover her baldness and feelings of "Why me?"
She also remembered the first time she and her husband, Gary, made love after the surgery, and the bonds between them that grew stronger during the ensuing months, despite the disfigurement and worry about her health, she said.
Mrs. Slutsky is now a co-chairwoman of the local American Cancer Society's Reach to Recovery volunteer unit in White Plains, counseling other women who have been treated for the disease. Reach to Recovery began in 1952 in Manhattan and has since become an extensive network of volunteers who are active in most cancer society chapters worldwide. Doctors often request that the volunteers visit breast cancer patients in the hospital shortly after their surgery.
"We have to ban together to help each other through this," said Debbie Schreibman, the other co-chairwoman of the program and one of 90 Reach to Recovery volunteers working in the county. "I tell other victims that we cannot feel a sense of shame, because this disease is not our fault."
Earlier this month representatives of the Westchester division of the American Cancer Society and the National Breast Cancer Coalition presented Representative Nita M. Lowey, a Democrat from Harrison, with a petition bearing 8,002 signatures. The document, which was delivered to Ms. Lowey's White Plains office, calls on President Clinton to increase aid for breast-cancer research and to insure that his national health-care-reform plan provides access for all women to services for early detection, diagnosis and care of the disease.
 
'No One Knows Why'
 October has been designated Breast Cancer Awareness Month by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke and other officials nationwide. The local petition drive was part of a national effort to collect 2.6 million signatures -- representing the 1.6 million women who have been diagnosed with breast cancer and the 1 million women who have the disease but do not yet know it. In all, 2.8 million signatures were gathered and presented to the President last Monday.
"The incidence of breast cancer has been rising since the 1940's, and no one knows why," Mrs. Lowey wrote to President Clinton recently. "There is no known cause or cure of breast cancer and unlike many other diseases, there is nothing a woman can do to prevent breast cancer. We cannot tolerate this any longer."
Ms. Lowey also told the President that the growing number of women in power is changing the face of politics, and that women will "no longer be bystanders to a debate that affects our very lives."
In Westchester, the incidence of breast cancer from 1984 through 1988, the most recent period for which statistics are available, was 98.4 cases for every 100,000 women, said Faith L. Schottenfeld, a spokeswoman for the State Health Department.
 
Free Legal Counsel
 Statewide, the incidence rate was 93.9 for every 100,000. And in Nassau County, the rate during that four-year period was 111.4. Ms. Schottenfeld said, however, that not just Nassau but other counties in the state had very high rates, with Monroe County of which Rochester is the county seat, for example, reporting 109.8 cases for 100,000 women.
In addition to the American Cancer Society's lobbying efforts, representatives of the legal profession in New York last year founded Judges and Lawyers Breast Cancer Alert to promote awareness of the disease and reach women who may lack access to breast cancer services. Its projects include a training program for volunteers who furnish pro bono legal services to breast cancer patients and their families, along with other outreach efforts.
"For too long, women have suffered in silence," said Judge Sondra Miller, an Appellate Division judge for the Second Division in Brooklyn and White Plains and a founding member of the organization. "Let's face it, if this were a disease that affects penises at the rate that it affects women's breasts, overnight the Pentagon would have been turned into a center for research."
But Dr. Martin G. Wertkin, a surgeon in Tarrytown and the immediate past president of the American Cancer Society's Westchester division, said that many doctors resent some of the advocates' focus on sexist issues surrounding breast cancer.
 
The Risk Factors
 "The anti-male aspect of this does the movement a disservice," he said. "Sure, some male doctors may be cold or seemingly unfeeling, but some female doctors are, too. Basically, what I have seen is an increased awareness and sensitivity among all doctors, and a trend in surgery toward more breast conservation compared with 20 years ago when there was one way to go -- a mastectomy, and that was the end of the discussion."
Dr. Bernard Bernhardt, an oncologist in New Rochelle, said there had been a "profound change from the radical 'mutilectomies' of the past to current surgical methods like lumpectomies that can preserve much of the breast."
Because the causes of breast cancer remain unknown, the State Health Department has published risk factors for the disease. They include:
*A family history of breast cancer, especially on the mother's side, and particularly when it occurred before menopause.
*High social and economic level, especially among Jewish women.
*Early onset of menstruation and late menopause.
*Late age at first childbearing.
*Urban or suburban residence.
*Obesity during post-menopausal years.
*Previous breast disease.
*Advancing age.
The department said that not all women who fit the profile get the disease, and conversely, many who have no known risk factors do contract it.
 
Free Examinations Offered
 Survival rates for women who find and treat breast cancer in its early stages approach 93 percent, compared with an overall 78 percent survival rate for the disease after five years, statistics show.
The County Department of Health is urging all women to take advantage of free breast cancer examinations and instruction in breast self-examination along with low-cost mammograms at several sites this month. (At present, doctors recommend that women have their first mammogram between 38 and 40. After 40, a mammogram is recommended every two years and after 50, yearly.)
Clinics will be held tomorrow at the Warner Library, 121 North Broadway in Tarrytown; Tuesday at the County Health Department's Mount Kisco District Office, 25 Moore Avenue in Mount Kisco; Wednesday at the Port Chester District Office, 11 Rye Ridge Road in Port Chester, and Thursday at the Greenburgh Neighborhood Health Center, 330 Tarrytown Road in Greenburgh.
The numbers to call for more information, to schedule an appointment (although walk-ins are accepted) or for other clinic dates are 593-5100 or 593-5094.
The American Cancer Society maintains a list of mammography clinics accredited by the American College of Radiology and clinics offering reduced-cost mammograms. For more information, the number to call is 949-4800.

HEADLINE: Complex Marriage, to Say the Least

BYLINE: By David S. Reynolds; David S. Reynolds is the author of "Beneath the American Renaissance: The Subversive Imagination in the Age of Emerson and Melville." He is now at work on a book about Walt Whitman and his era.

 BODY:

WITHOUT SIN
The Life and Death of the Oneida Community.
By Spencer Klaw.
Illustrated. 337 pp. New York:
Allen Lane/The Penguin Press. $25. 
THE Oneida Community in upstate New York was one of the most intriguing of the 40-odd utopian communities that sprang up in 19th-century America. Most such communities were short-lived experiments based loosely on the theories of the French socialist Charles Fourier. Oneida, in contrast, lasted over three decades, from 1848 to 1880, and was guided by the idiosyncratic religious views of its founder and leader, John Humphrey Noyes.
Controversial in its day and unduly neglected in ours, the Oneida Community is described skillfully by Spencer Klaw, who makes use of rare documents relating to the community to provide the first full account of it. Mr. Klaw, the author as well of "The New Brahmins: Scientific Life in America," delves into virtually every aspect of life at Oneida, including its most distinctive feature, a communal sexual arrangement known as complex marriage.
As Mr. Klaw explains it, the Vermont-born John Humphrey Noyes, having experienced a conversion during a religious revival in 1831, preached a Perfectionist brand of Christianity according to which he believed he could do no wrong. Noyes became the hub of a group of men and women, eventually numbering about 300, who saw monogamy as impure and group love as the means of ushering in the millennium. They thought God demanded variety in every facet of life, including sex. To overcome what they regarded as the sin of monogamy, they called for the continual change of partners under the supervision of Noyes.
Noyes took advantage of his position as sexual arbiter. Although he was married, his main gratification came from elsewhere. He indoctrinated his followers with the idea of "ascending fellowship," whereby community elders, considered especially godly, led younger believers heavenward by introducing them to what they saw as the holy pleasures of sex. Shortly after puberty, boys and girls were assigned a succession of older love partners. Teen-agers commonly slept with people in their 50's or 60's, though they got to choose partners their own age as time passed. Mr. Klaw cites sources that suggest Noyes often assigned himself 12- and 13-year-old girls.
All the men at Oneida were thought to be linked in divine marriage to all the women. Many community members had two or three different partners a week. To avoid unwanted pregnancies and to insure maximum pleasure for women, the Oneidans practiced coitus reservatus, or, as Noyes called it, male continence -- intercourse without ejaculation. Couples who drifted toward "idolatrous" (that is, monogamous) love or who broke the rule of male continence were chastised publicly at group discussion meetings. Child rearing was also a group matter. Couples could request to have a child, but children lived in separate quarters, apart from their parents, and were raised communally.
Mr. Klaw judiciously sorts out the rewards and the anxieties of these unusual living arrangements. Parents and children sometimes felt the strain of being separated from one another. He gives the affecting example of a mother who in her rare moments alone with her son asked, "Darling, do you love me?" The son recalled later: "I always melted. My marbles and blocks were forgotten. I would reach up and put my arms about her neck. I remember how tightly she held me and how long, as though she would never let me go."
Possessiveness and jealousy inevitably arose among competing sex partners. The problems surrounding complex marriage contributed to the community's demise. Young people, in particular, grew tired of being assigned older lovers they often found undesirable. "I wish," one woman lamented, "it were more popular than it is for the young to love the old, the handsome to love the less so, the educated the less educated, in short, that love might be truly free, permeating and pervading all hearts."
As Mr. Klaw points out, the surprising thing is not that Oneida failed but that it lasted as long as it did. Communal living apparently had its blessings, other than the mixed ones of sexual variety and group parenting. Music, painting and poetry were among the many cultural interests cultivated by the group. Games and sports enlivened everyday life. Work was looked on as a joyous, shared activity. Community leaders put the cooperative spirit to good economic use. They established a variety of businesses, the most successful of which, a tableware company, is today the world's largest manufacturer of stainless steel knives, forks and spoons.
MR. KLAW makes brief comparisons between Oneida and the free-love communities on Long Island and in Berlin Heights, Ohio, where monogamy was banned for secular rather than religious reasons. Such comparisons are suggestive. One wishes Mr. Klaw had expanded on them and had gone on to discuss the social contexts of Oneida in greater detail.
But he gives a vivid picture of Oneida and thus contributes a useful chapter to American cultural history. Not only does he recount shifting developments within the community, but he traces outside responses to it, ranging from the titillated curiosity of tourists who visited it to the moral outrage of puritanical ministers who tried to stamp it out. The latter attitude eventually sealed its fate. In late June 1879, John Humphrey Noyes secretly left for Canada under threats of prosecution by local clergymen. With its leader gone and internal disputes intensifying, the community abandoned complex marriage and emphasized its business interests.
Tourists still visit the imposing three-story brick mansion house at Oneida, where they contemplate fading photographs of men and women who once made an unconventional attempt at creating heaven on earth.

Viacom said it would pay $10 billion to buy Paramount, a package nearly identical to that of QVC, a home-shopping service. [A1.]

HEADLINE: Strong Sports Agency Key in Yankee Saga

BYLINE: By RICHARD SANDOMIR

 BODY:
In 1971, when the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority set out to build its huge entertainment complex in the swamps of East Rutherford, it had one overarching priority: luring the New York Yankees away from the Bronx.
Two decades later, after enticing New York's two professional football teams, a Long Island basketball team and a Denver hockey franchise to the Meadowlands complex, the sports authority is still without its ultimate prize, the nation's most valuable and storied franchise in sports. 
 How long things will remain that way is another matter.
Although Yankees fans are tempted to blame the team's owner, George M. Steinbrenner, for repeated hints that the franchise would abandon the Bronx when the team's lease expires in 2002, and its problems with crime and parking, New York's real enemy is New Jersey.
And while officials of the New Jersey sports empire say they have not made a specific proposal to Mr. Steinbrenner, the agency's history and its not-so-secret desire to have a major-league baseball team are largely responsible for the crusade that Gov. Mario M. Cuomo is waging.
"I don't doubt they've made an offer for a moment," Mr. Cuomo said in an interview last week. "I haven't seen a document. I haven't seen the details. I can't say there's proof. But it's absolutely clear they've been making suggestions for a long time."
To keep the Yankees, Mr. Cuomo has proposed spending $150 million to improve Yankee Stadium, or to build a grandiose $530 million waterfront field (and garage) of dreams on the West Side.
But the plan was not well received by local community groups and some city officials. And yesterday, during a gubernatorial campaign debate, Gov. Jim Florio said of the Yankees: "If they leave the Bronx, they'll come to New Jersey. They're not going anywhere else."
Mr. Cuomo stepped into the Yankees sweepstakes as a surrogate for Mayor David N. Dinkins, who has been in the midst of a difficult re-election campaign. And he insists that despite his personal input, any offer to Mr. Steinbrenner must come from the city. In fact, since the spring, city officials have spent considerable time trying to satisfy Mr. Steinbrenner's complaints about parking, traffic, security and sanitation problems in the Bronx.
The Governor and the Mayor have reason to fret about what the city would lose if the Yankees decamped in New Jersey. Economically, the city Comptroller's office recently estimated that the Yankees generated $151 million in revenue in 1992. Psychically, losing the Yankees to New Jersey would constitute a blow on a scale with the California migration of the Brooklyn Dodgers in 1958.
And politically, Mr. Dinkins and Mr. Cuomo would prefer to be known as the politicians who kept the Yankees from crossing the Hudson, rather than be remembered like Mayor Robert F. Wagner, who lost the Dodgers and the Giants baseball clubs.
Moreover, the bi-state romancing of the Yankees is part of a national fabric of municipalities trying to lure teams or keep the ones they have. Only a few years ago, Illinois had to fight hard to keep the Chicago White Sox from moving to Florida, ultimately building a new stadium. New stadiums have been built or are under construction in Baltimore, Cleveland and the Dallas area.
The New Jersey authority has had an official policy of seeking a baseball team since 1984. It sponsored and lost a referendum vote, 2 to 1, to build a $185 million, taxpayer-supported ball park in 1987, but has never publicly offered anything concrete to Mr. Steinbrenner. Pursuing the Yankees energized the state even before the authority began in 1971. "Our original financing was based on getting the Yankees," said Robert Mulcahy 3d, the authority president.
In fact, the possibility that the Yankees would depart for New Jersey was among the reasons that Mayor John V. Lindsay decided to renovate Yankee Stadium, which was done in 1974 and 1975, when Mr. Lindsay was out of office.
Richard Aurelio, a Deputy Mayor under Mr. Lindsay, recalled how Michael Burke, the ex-Yankees president, had received feelers from New Jersey and New Orleans. "He really wanted the city to fix up Yankee Stadium," Mr. Aurelio said, "because it had spent 25 or 30 million dollars to build Shea Stadium."
Theft of teams is a recurring theme in New York's perception of the authority's successful history. A few years ago, Mr. Mulcahy said he saw former Mayor Edward I. Koch in an elevator. Mr. Koch asked, "What are you going to steal next?"
And last month Vincent Tese, chairman of the state Urban Development Corporation, said, "They steal teams in the dead of night."
Theft, or not, here are four reasons for Mr. Cuomo to worry:
*The New York Giants football team departed Yankee Stadium for a new home named for itself in the Meadowlands in 1976.
*The New York Jets left behind an unsatisfactory lease with New York City and the swirling winds of a deteriorating Shea Stadium in 1984 to cohabit with the Giants in football-only Giants Stadium.
*The New York Nets basketball team left Long Island's Nassau Coliseum to play in the Meadowlands Arena in 1981.
*The New Jersey Devils, the former Colorado Rockies, started playing on the ice of Byrne Meadowlands Arena in 1982.
"We've never stolen any team," Mr. Mulcahy said. "Each team's problems were well-chronicled."
 
Fears of an Offer
Cozy Friendship Feeds Speculation
 There's been no darkness of night about the friendship between Mr. Steinbrenner and Jon Hanson, a member of the sports authority's board, and the state official most closely identified with bringing baseball to New Jersey.
"I've seen them regularly at '21' and the Columbus Club," Mr. Tese said.
Yes, Mr. Hanson said, he has dined with Mr. Steinbrenner. Yes, they have watched Mr. Steinbrenner's horses compete at the Meadowlands Race Track. Yes, they've been to football games together at Giants Stadium.
"Friends get together," Mr. Hanson, a real-estate developer, said recently. "I've been to restaurants with him and I've been to his house."
But if an offer has passed from Mr. Hanson to Mr. Steinbrenner, both have kept the secret very well.
"Having seen and observed them together, I can say that Jon has the confidence and respect of George Steinbrenner," said Peter Levine, a board member. "Jon's relationship to George is equal in importance to his relationship with the authority. Jon will play the key role."
Whether a formal, written proposal has been made may be irrelevant. Sites inside the Meadowlands and two nearby, north and south of the New Jersey Turnpike, are under consideration, as is another in Jersey City. All are well known to Mr. Steinbrenner.
Well known, too, are the fundamentals of a likely bid: a 48,000-seat stadium with the nostalgic appeal of Baltimore's new ball park at Camden Yards; at least 75 high-priced luxury boxes, and guarantees to reimburse Mr. Steinbrenner financially if attendance falls below 2.5 million.
"Is there a plan?" said Mr. Levine, who succeeded Mr. Hanson as chairman for two years. "Of course there is. Jon has been empowered since he was chairman to deliver proposals to George. And discussions with the Yankess have been ongoing. But we're totally pliable and flexible. The plan is an evolving formula which can be tailored to George. It's the real thing."
 
Loss of the Giants
The Courtship And the Conquest
 Despite Mr. Tese's contention that the authority does its work in the dark of the night, the experience of the New York Giants football team suggests otherwise, and points to at least one similarity to the Yankees' situation: the condition of Yankee Stadium. The Giants spent several years mulling a move out of Yankee Stadium, said Wellington Mara, who owns 50 percent of the team. "We'd stagnated there," he said. "There were so many obstructed-view seats. Our waiting list was growing. Late in the baseball season we didn't have a place to work out," because of the Yankees' penchant for being in the World Series.
Bids for the Giants came from Long Island, Connecticut, Westchester and New Jersey. One man, Mr. Mara said, wanted a revolving stadium "so that twice a game, everybody would be at the 50-yard line."
Finally, what cinched the move was the Meadowlands' proximity to New York City -- four miles west of the Lincoln Tunnel.
"All we asked was that the stadium be no less than 70,000," Mr. Mara said, "and no more than 80,000. They made a great effort to please us." They receive 15 percent of the revenues from luxury box rentals.
"We really have the same lease we had in Yankee Stadium, paying 15 percent of our gate receipts," he said, "only here we have a cut of the parking and concessions. Being here is even better than we expected."
 
Dreams of Expansion
How the Authority Shaped a Dynasty
 Mr. Mulcahy, a former chief of staff to Gov. Brendan T. Byrne, has run the authority since 1979 with quiet fervor and foresight that have made it one of the nation's most successful sports and entertainment complexes.
"I've tried to focus the role of the authority on ego, excitement and economic impact," he said, adding that a study found that the authority generates $1 billion in economic impact annually to the state.
In addition to football, racing, hockey and basketball, the Meadowlands complex is used for college football and basketball, the National Horse Show, the Ice Capades, and rock concerts. Next year, World Cup soccer games will be played in the stadium.
Also in the authority's domain are the Monmouth Race Track in Oceanport and the Atlantic City Convention Center, which is being expanded.
"The authority has epitomized New Jersey's renaissance and its ability to go head to head with New York City," said Assemblyman Rodney Frelinghuysen, Republican of Morristown. "It has a reputation for epitomizing what's good about New Jersey."
But all has not been perfect with the authority, particularly its recent financial health. Despite the authority's original goal of snaring a baseball team, horse racing was the cash cow, producing $49.6 million at its peak in 1977. But competition from casino gambling and other entertainment options ravaged racing's bottom line to the point where last year it produced only $14.3 million.
The gloomier financial picture led the authority to refinance its debt nearly two years ago, a move that also allowed for the construction of a new Atlantic City Convention Center and upgrading of Rutgers Stadium.
But the bond measure also, for the first time, obliged the state -- and its taxpayers -- to shoulder about one-third of the annual payments on the bonds issued in the authority's name.
Although the refinancing passed with broad bipartisan support, the vote occurred before Republicans took control of the Legislature.
"The outgoing legislative leaders basically committed the state budget for the next 20-25 years to backing the financial plan," Mr. Frelinghuysen said. "In 1992, we paid $12 million, and in 1993, we'll pay $18 million."
State Sen. Henry McNamara, a Franklin Lakes Republican and a critic of the refinancing, said: "The people voted down a stadium in 1987 because they didn't want to spend taxpayer money. Now they're paying to support the authority."
With the authority's finances revived, how easy would it be to bankroll a new stadium, whose cost is estimated at $250 million? Clearly, it cannot go to the voters, particularly after the rejection of the 1987 referendum, and not in the current climate of hypersensitivity to taxation.
Many financing techniques would be available to sell bonds backed by revenues from lotteries, hotel taxes, venture capital, luxury box sales or proceeds from the state's Casino Reinvestment Development Fund.
Despite all the concern from Governor Cuomo, Mr. Steinbrenner has not joined in the debate over where his team would go next. In a chance encounter at an East Side restaurant with a reporter last week, he refused to give any insight into his plans. Why aren't you talking, George?
"I'm in hiding," he said.
When will you talk?
"After I've seen New York's plan."
When will he decide? Perhaps after Election Day. Perhaps next year. He wouldn't say. But because the Yankees' lease expires in nine years, he has time -- but not much, if he wants to have a new stadium.
The authority's Mr. Levine said: "The bride knows the groom is wealthy and when she says yes, she'll receive the ring and we'll talk about a new address."

GRAPHIC: Photo: One of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's proposals to try to keep the Yankees in New York was a plan to spend $150 million to improve Yankee Stadium. (Lee Romero/The New York Times)(pg. B4)

HEADLINE: Politics Mirrors Diversity's Drive In the Suburbs

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER with JONATHAN RABINOVITZ

 BODY:
For decades Westchester and Nassau Counties have flourished as places of escape. And just as people left behind the frenzied harshness of city life, they also turned their backs on Democratic politics. In this century, Westchester and Nassau have each selected only one Democratic county executive, and Westchester has never had a Democratic district attorney.
But all that could change soon. For the first time in years, both of these Republican strongholds face formidable Democratic challenges for the job of county executive, and Westchester has a tight race for district attorney.
 
Urban-Like Cynicism
 Those contests say as much about the changing character of the suburbs -- the growing ethnic and racial diversity, the faltering economies and a rising urban-like cynicism about politicians -- as they say about the character of the candidates. 
 "Republican strength in the suburbs can no longer be taken for granted just as Democratic strength in the city is no longer assured," said Mitchell L. Moss, director of the Urban Research Center at New York University.
In Westchester, Richard L. Brodsky, a bright, scrappy six-term Assemblyman, is challenging Andrew P. O'Rourke, the avuncular pragmatist who has run the county for 11 years. The campaign has been dominated by debate over the county's sluggish economy and the integrity of its government. In Nassau, Benjamin L. Zwirn, a blunt, sometimes volatile member of Nassau's Board of Supervisors, is attacking Thomas S. Gulotta, that county's executive for the last six years, for having mismanaged the fiscal house.
The challengers' prospects should not be overstated. Mr. O'Rourke and Mr. Gulotta command strong loyalties, can boast of genuine successes, and have the ultimate political advantage: incumbency.
But one reason that Republicans can no longer sit back complacently is that the suburbs are not as homogeneous as they once were believed to be. The Cheeveresque myth of white Protestant gray-suited men who sip martinis before catching the 6:38 home to housewives in Bronxville has evolved into a more motley picture.
The suburbs of the 1990's are older, have many more commuting women and are not as lily white. By 1990, Nassau's white population had declined to 86.7 percent from 91.1 percent while Westchester's dipped to 79.5 percent from 84.2 percent, both in 1980, largely as a result of a doubling of the Hispanic population and a somewhat slower growth in the black population. Both minorities have long supported Democrats.
 
Mirroring a Pattern
 Even the white population is not what it used to be. That two Jewish candidates are challenging both county executives and a Jew is running for Westchester district attorney is a demographic milestone that mirrors, at least a generation later, the pattern in New York City of Jewish politicians supplanting Irish and Italian politicians who had supplanted Protestants.
"The suburbs of today are the urban neighborhoods of yesterday," said Kenneth T. Jackson, a history professor at Columbia University who wrote "Crabgrass Frontier: The Suburbanization of the United States" (Oxford University).
The Republicans have also had to grapple with a halt to the ever growing affluence of both counties and the appearance of enclaves of poverty that have brought along crime, drug abuse, AIDS and other largely unfamiliar problems.
"The Republican Party's ticket to voters was the assurance that Nassau wouldn't be like New York," said Howard Scarrow, a political science professor at the State University of New York at Stony Brook. "When thousands of people moved from New York to Long Island after World War II, they often switched from Democrat to Republican because they didn't want to bring with them New York City and all of its problems. But with Long Island's situation today, that distinction may no longer be so clear."
Both Westchester and Nassau suffered in the recession that followed the 1987 stock market crash, and Nassau sustained an added blow by the shrinkage of the nation's defense industry. Executives who lost their good-as-gold jobs at I.B.M. and Grumman may be transferring much of their resentment to the Republicans.
 
Loss of Jobs
 "The Republican message of tough love may not be as appealing when you're out on the streets," Professor Jackson said.
A refrain of Mr. Brodsky is that Westchester has lost 40,000 jobs since 1989, a figure that Mr. O'Rourke attributes to a statewide recession that cost New York 622,000 jobs. Mr. O'Rourke chooses to emphasize Westchester's still relatively low unemployment rate of 5.7 percent.
Still, in Westchester and Nassau property values have declined, sales-tax collections have fallen, and the need to pay for rising mandated expenses like Medicaid have undercut the Republican promise to keep property taxes low.
Although Mr. O'Rourke has been able to weather the bad economic times without raising taxes in the last two years or making significant job cuts, his counterpart in Nassau has not been so fortunate. Mr. Gulotta had to cut 2,000 government jobs, the lifeblood of the Republicans' patronage machine, just to hold the deficit on the county's $1.07 billion general-fund budget at $119.9 million. Nassau's bonds are now rated BAA, at a little better than junk bonds, while Westchester has kept its AAA rating.
In both places, Republicans have been touched by corruption, belying the rectitude they have sometimes projected as a contrast to shady urban politics.
 
Revelations of Abuses
 In Nassau, a number of party officials in the 1970's and 1980's were found guilty of taking kickbacks. "They have abused the system," said Steve Sabbeth, chairman of the Nassau Democratic Party. "That could be hidden under the rug in good times, but when things become tougher, those abuses hit you between the eyes."
In Westchester, a state commission revealed in 1989 that concessionaires at the county-run Playland Amusement Park in Rye were asked to make $80,000 worth of contributions to the Republican Party. Mr. O'Rourke escaped direct blame, but some Democrats believe he may be hurt by disclosures this year that he recommended his live-in companion and others for jobs with county contractors. A grand jury has cleared him of any conflict-of-interest violations.
Nassau, with 1.3 million people, burgeoned after World War II as transplants from Brooklyn and Queens flocked there to snatch the American dream of a detached house in a safe, tranquil place. They went to villages like Levittown that sprang up overnight with Federal inducements like loans for veterans and subsidized highways.
Westchester, whose older towns had long been bedroom communities for New York City, surged yet again after the 1950's as major corporations like General Foods moved headquarters there along with thousands of executives and white-collar workers. Its population is now 875,000.
New migrants often arrived with a resentment of the liberal policies of the Democratic cities. Others linked up with the dominant Republicans, figuring such an alliance could be useful for obtaining zoning variances and other civic favors. In 1980, Ronald Reagan achieved higher pluralities on Long Island than almost anywhere else.
In Westchester and Nassau, this Republican electoral dominance was aided by party machines with roots in the governing charters both counties received in the 1930's. These charters tailored local governments to make sure the reigning party stayed in power, said Gerald Benjamin, local government director at the Nelson A. Rockefeller Institute of Government.
 
Cracking G.O.P. Monolith
 Nassau's vaunted Republican machine maintained virtual one-party rule through an elaborate patronage apparatus that used government jobs and contracts to gain political contributions and woo voters. Weighted voting on the six-member Board of Supervisors, a system which has since been declared unconstitutional, essentially gave heavily Republican Hempstead a veto over all county legislation.
In Westchester, Mr. Benjamin said, the Republicans filled the district attorney's office with Republican prosecutors, making it virtually impossible for a Democrat to gain sufficient trial publicity to mount a race for district attorney. It is no accident that Michael G. Cherkasky, the Democrat challenging the Republican, Jeanine Pirro, for the district attorney's job held for 25 years by Carl A. Vergari, made his fame as a prosecutor in Manhattan.
But the Republican monolith has begun to crack. In 1989, a Democrat, Mr. Zwirn, became supervisor of the town of North Hempstead for the first time in 73 years. Last year the Republicans lost the county clerk's race and, in a far more worrisome sign, Bill Clinton became the first Democratic Presidential candidate to win Nassau since Lyndon B. Johnson.
In Westchester, Democrats slipped ahead of Republicans in party registration sometime in the 1980's and now have an edge of 181,360 to 157,774. The Republican ratio in Nassau is roughly 3 to 2.
As elsewhere, party labels in both counties have lost their magic and the power of a strong machine has been overwhelmed by the power of television advertising and polls.
"You don't need the organization of a party because you can create your own organization," Professor Scarrow said.
Mr. Gulotta has built an extensive campaign organization independent of the party, and Mr. O'Rourke is said to have something less than a close relationship with his party's chairman, Anthony J. Colavita.
Increasingly, said Lee M. Miringoff, director of Marist College's Institute of Public Opinion, suburbanites, like their city cousins, appear to be concerned with issues like health care that the Democrats have seized upon. Many Republicans, Mr. Brodsky said, disown their party's stance on abortion, approving of greater choice for women.
"They're reachable on issues I consider my issues," Mr. Brodsky said.
Perhaps the most important factor in tightening races this year, say Mr. Moss and Mr. Miringoff, is that incumbents seem to be more vulnerable everywhere. In New York City, the Democratic Mayor, David N. Dinkins, may be on the receiving end, but in the suburbs that mood hurts the Republicans.
"In the suburbs it's the mirror image, but for the same reason," Mr. Miringoff said.
 
LOCAL ELECTIONS: Assessing the Candidates and the Issues
 
WESTCHESTER COUNTY
 
The Candidates:
Andrew P. O'Rourke, 59, Republican, has been County Executive for 11 years. He was raised in Hell Kitchen in Manhattan in a family that received welfare. Mr. O'Rourke he has written two novels and he had been a government official for more than 25 years.
 
Richard L. Brodsky, 47, Democrat and a graduate of the Harvard Law School, has been an assemblyman for six terms and leads the Environmental Conservation Committee. He is a son of a steel engineer from Ardsley and is known in Albany for his quick mind and blunt manner.
 
The Issues:
Mr. Brodsky contends that Mr. O'Rourke is tired and has lost the imagination to revive the slumping economy. He has accused Mr. O'Rourke of running a corrupt administration. Mr. O'Rourke says Mr. Brodsky lacks the temperament to manage people and has called him a hack Albany politician. He faults Albany for taxes and programs that have hurt Westschester and says a loss of 40,000 jobs is part of a statewide recession.
 
NASSAU COUNTY
 
The Candidates:
Thomas S. Gulotta, 50, a Repulican, has been County Executive for six years. The son of a prominent Nassau political family, he has run successfully for office nine times. An impeccable dresser, he prides himself on understanding the suburban mentality.
 
Benjamin L. Zwirn, 42, defied expectations by twice winning the North Hempstead Supervisor race. Temperamental and aggressive, he has redefined what it means to be a suburban Democrat by strongly advocating fiscal restraint.
 
The Issues:
Mr. Zwirn says Mr. Gulotta has presided over the fiscal decline of the county government decline and faults him for high taxes. Mr. Gulotta's ties to the Republic patronage machine, he says, have prevented him from scaling down government. Mr. Gulotta says many economic problems were outside his control and calls Mr. Zwirn a tax-and-spend liberal Democrat.

HEADLINE: Campaign Stop: A periodic report on neighborhood reaction to the mayoral race. -- 4. St. Albans, Queens;
In St. Albans, Black Voters Express Faith in Dinkins, Wariness of Giuliani

BYLINE: By FELICIA R. LEE

 BODY:
When police stepped up patrols recently in St. Albans, Queens, Rodney Williams, a 20-year-old college student, was pleased, believing it would help reduce the selling of crack in the neighborhood.
But Mr. Williams, who in his limited free time likes to hang out on the corner with friends, soon had another perspective. "The guys who live around here, we all know each other, we talk," he said. "The cops say, 'Where do you live?' and 'You've got to get off this corner.' We have all lived here for years." 
 Mr. Williams, who lives with his parents and studies data processing at Queensborough Community College, believes his experience symbolizes the peculiar pressures facing the black middle class. Residents want a greater police presence, but know that blacks, in both tony and struggling neighborhoods, are more often targets of police harassment than whites. A desire for leadership sensitive to the raw intersection of race and class is one reason why many here say they plan to vote for the re-election of David N. Dinkins.
In this neighborhood, a bulwark of the black middle class for more than 30 years, people said they were galvanized by both the fear of Rudolph W. Giuliani's conservatism and their feeling that the Mayor has done the best job he can during bad times for big cities.
 
Dinkins's Empathy
 They are also motivated by racial pride and the feeling that Mr. Dinkins has tried to empathize with their concerns, even though some complain that his voice has been too muted. They said they knew that if the Mayor stood incognito on many street corners, he too would have trouble hailing a taxi because of his race.
Dozens were interviewed for this story; no one said they would vote for Mr. Giuliani. This is still very much Dinkins country, as it was in 1989 when almost all voters here flicked the lever next to this name.
Mr. Dinkins is counting on that kind of support. With a tight race forecast, the Mayor's backers in St. Albans intend to insure a strong turnout by knocking on doors, taking people to the polls and telling friends and others of the urgency of this election.
 
A Bastion of Black Progress
 Much like the election four years ago of the city's first black mayor, this community connotes black progress. Settled around the turn of the century by Irish and English immigrants, blacks began moving in after World War II. By the 1950's, most whites had left, leaving black people as key players in virtually every aspect of life in St. Albans.
Mr. Williams and his neighbors were interviewed in a roughly 19-block area of tidy brick homes and well-tended lawns defined by Baisley and Merrick Boulevards, Leslie Road and 180th Street. They concede that things have not dramatically improved since 99 percent of voters there went for Mr. Dinkins in 1989, but say the Mayor inherited a mess that will take years to make right.
"It's not his fault," said James McCarthy, a retired police detective who has lived across the street from Mr. Williams for 35 years. "This man would have to be a miracle worker to reverse all the decline. The country as a whole is in a downswing."
 
'Both Men Are Good Men'
 "Both men are good men," he said of the mayoral candidates. "Both would do a good job. But race is going to play a part. Naturally, being a black man, I want to see my own person in there.
"I would vote, though, for the person I think would do a better job," Mr. NcCarthy hastened to add. "Giuliani has been a crime fighter, but he doesn't have the political savvy or experience the Mayor has."
The level of education here is higher than the average for New York City or Queens, and household income exceeds the city average by over $15,000. Many people have lived here for more than 30 years. In the hush of one recent Indian summer afternoon, children played in the streets and a man in a Volvo talking on a cellular phone pulled into a nearby driveway.
Most of those interviewed said they believed that Mr. Dinkins kept the peace when Los Angeles exploded and contained the Crown Heights disturbances. They like the Beacon program, which operates schools as community centers. They also like the set-asides for women and minority contractors.
They say the crack problem that invaded St. Albans in the 80's has improved, part of a general decline in crime. At the time of the last mayoral election, this corner of the borough had become the center of the city's crack trade.
Most people still think that property taxes are too high, that unemployment has eased only a bit and that they need better transportation and recreational programs.
Yet these voters say they have faith that in his second term Mr. Dinkins will make things better. Some fear that Mr. Giuliani's election could undermine already fragile race relations and the delicate balance between haves and have-nots.
 
Police Rally Recalled
 In particular, they cite his plans to limit the amount of time homeless families can stay in shelters. They say he pushes law and order, but lacks social welfare programs that could attack crime at its roots. And they point worriedly to Mr. Giuliani's presence at a City Hall police rally last year at which some police officers directed racial slurs at Mr. Dinkins.
"Giuliani never did anything for us but go in front of a bunch of drunk cops who were calling the Mayor of this city names," said Thomas Graham, a 20-year-old cousin of Mr. Williams who lives across the street. "Is that how it's going to be if he becomes mayor?"
Marilyn Jones, who lives on the same block, said she would like to see more recreational centers for her 10-year-old son, Rahsaan. She also worries about crime. Mrs. Jones, who grew up in St. Albans, frets that she has to escort Rahsaan to school and that her car was stolen right in front of her home. Still, she supports Mr. Dinkins and said that some people active in her Catholic church, St. Catherine of Siena, planned to get out the vote for the Mayor.
"I think he's done the best he can do," Mrs. Jones said.
"A lot of the crime areas are in black neighborhoods and a lot of the crime victims are black," she added. "I don't think Giuliani would have as much heart as the Mayor in trying to correct problems."
Bill Scarborough, who has lived in St. Albans for 30 years and heads Community Board 12, said he and many people believe that Mr. Dinkins's color means he is held to a different standard by voters and journalists.
 
'People Want More Cops'
 "A lot of people are tremendously angry about the way he has been treated," Mr. Scarborough said. "There is a sense that has been building since this summer that the Mayor has been under siege by the media. There are people who say he should have done more for Queens, but they support him.
"Certainly, they think this community will fare worse under Giuliani. They think about his actions at the police rally at City Hall, his statement about pushing people out of shelters, his comments about the civilian review board.
"People want more cops," said Mr. Scarborough, the father of two daughters. "There is a large problem with crime, but everyone knows someone who has been subjected to police brutality, so it is a real issue. Giuliani's position on set-asides in city contracts worries people because black entrepreneurs know that for years they have been shut out. When Giuliani talks about the good old days, a lot of us think of the bad old days."
Solomon Goodrich, executive director of the Southern Queens Park Association, said he and supporters will have to "go to every street, every house," to turn such sentiments into votes.
"It's going to be a life-and-death struggle for the soul of New York," Mr. Goodrich said. "Not because Giuliani is white, but because he is a dyed-in-the-wool conservative. Those of us who are committed to the Mayor will have to work 10 times as hard. As well as pointing out our commitment, we have to point out the alternative."
Jerolyn Minter, a retired college professor who lives a block away from Mr. Graham, said she is a big fan of the Mayor's. She said that crime is down and she is an active participant in Increase the Peace, a group established by the Mayor dedicated to defusing confrontations. She said the Mayor took a beating from the press on Crown Heights.
 
Unfair Expectations
 "In no way can we condone the taking of a life," Mrs. Minter said of the Crown Heights disturbances, in which a rabbinical student was killed. "But the press focused in on that one incident and kept calling for increased investigations. My question is, what's behind that push?
"Any nonwhite person in an elective office is going to be expected to be a super person and to do in a shorter period of time things that were never done before," said Mrs. Minter, answering her own question. She has lived in St. Albans for 37 years and raised three sons. "I don't think we as a society allow our elected officials ample time to put through changes."
David V. Hodge, who owns the American Roots art gallery and trophy shop and is executive director of the St. Albans Chamber of Commerce, said he would not hesitate to vote for a Republican if there were a Republican President, because that relationship could enhance the city's fortunes. Mr. Hodge said that Mr. Dinkins has a strong supporter in President Clinton and that Mr. Giuliani lacks business experience.
"Race is no issue when everyone is working," said Mr. Hodge who has lived in St. Albans since 1954 and started his business in his mother's garage. "And race really won't matter in the voting booth. Anyone with any common sense knows who's the best candidate."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Pressure Mounts on Contributions

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The president of the National Association of State Treasurers says there is growing momentum for limiting the acceptance or soliciting of political contributions.
"I think there is going to be public pressure for people to not ask" for contributions, said Lucille Maurer, the State Treasurer of Maryland. 
 But she said she did not expect the association, which has established a task force to study this and other campaign topics, to take a specific position on the issue of accepting contributions from municipal bond underwriters and others who do business with state and local governments.
Instead, she said, public "pressure will be on, and treasurers will ultimately realize that if they accept and ask for contributions, that will give their opponents the opportunity to say, 'See, I don't accept them.' "
For Mrs. Maurer, who has been the Maryland treasurer since 1987, this may be a little easier to say than for many of her colleagues. She is one of the four state treasurers elected by the state legislature and she does not need to collect political contributions.
 
A Shift in Focus
 Yet this disengagement does not preclude her from saying that the public perception of impropriety created by the acceptance of contributions "presents a problem to me."
The focus has shifted to the recipients of contributions since the big Wall Street underwriters endorsed a moratorium on contributions two weeks ago and last week backed a voluntary ban on political contributions to state and local officials and candidates who could award them underwriting business.
Mrs. Maurer's comments, in an interview on Friday, came after her return from a meeting of the Western States Treasurers Association. At the meeting in San Diego, the association adopted a resolution that urges the national group to consider a ban on accepting political contributions as part of its broad look at campaign reform.
At the same meeting, the group also commended California's State Treasurer, Kathleen Brown, for her efforts at campaign finance reform, which included the decision to refuse political contributions from companies and individuals involved in the municipal bond business.
 
A 'Stronger Statement'
 Mrs. Maurer's views and the position taken by the Western group reflect how sentiment on contributions is moving. It does not mean that politicians will begin to refuse contributions across the board. But it shows that the appearance of impropriety, created by the acceptance of contributions from individuals and companies who get business from elected officials, is driving issuers of municipal bonds and underwriters toward positions that they probably would not have considered possible a few months ago.
As Mrs. Maurer noted, the position taken by the Western treasurers' group is a "stronger statement" than the one written in August in response to the proposed rule of the Municipal Securities Rulemaking Board, which is the self-regulating body for municipal dealers.
The board's proposal would ban contributions from municipal dealers that are made in an effort to win underwriting business. After some modifications, the rule is expected to go into effect early next year and will effectively make mandatory the voluntary ban endorsed last week by the Wall Street firms.
 
Disclosure Endorsed
 In response to the rule-making board's proposal, the National Association of State Treasurers endorsed disclosure of campaign contributions as "the basis for monitoring and regulating the relationship between elected public officials and the municipal securities industry."
The association also raised a long list of objections to the ban on political contributions, including conflicts with the First Amendment, problems with equal protection and vagueness.
But the recommendation of the Western group has now taken the treasurers into new territory. "In August this was an emerging rule," Mrs. Maurer said, "and here we are in October and things have moved rather rapidly."
The statement by the Western treasurers also points up another important issue: There are a lot of other problems in the municipal markets beyond political contributions. And as Milton Wells, the director of Federal operations of the National Association of State Treasurers noted, the focus on political contributions may be diverting attention from them.
These include fee splitting, conflicts of interest between financial advisers to an issuer and the bond underwriters who want the business, finders' fees and the use of consultants. Neither the rule-making board's rule nor the voluntary ban endorsed by the Wall Street firms directly addresses these problem areas.
 
Fears About Growth Prompt Bond Selloff
 The selloff on Thursday and Friday in the bond market has pushed the yield on the 30-year bond back to 5.98 percent, renewing the question of whether the rally at the long end of the bond market is over.
The market backed off quickly after the yield on the 30-year bond finally breached 6 percent in early September. But it faltered even faster after the yield was swept to a new 25-year low of 5.78 percent after the Labor Department reported on Oct. 15 that consumer prices were unchanged in September.
The selloff was caused by concern that the economy was picking up momentum in the second half of the year, and fears that the October report on consumer prices would rise as much as four-tenths of 1 percent, although much of that would be caused by seasonal adjustment factors rather than lasting price increases.
What seems to be clear, however, is that the basic picture of the economy is not changing. Growth may be faster, but just about anything would be faster than the 1.3 percent pace in the first half of the year.
 
G.D.P. Report on Thursday
 The first view of the second half of the year will come on Thursday, when the Commerce Department reports the initial reading for the gross domestic product in the third quarter. The market forecasts seem to average slightly less than 3 percent. The forecasts for the fourth quarter are higher, some up to 4 percent.
But even if the economy picks up, tax increases included in the President's deficit-reduction package begin to bite next year, and many economists said they expected growth to slow at the start of the year as a result.
So, there is still a chance for long-term rates to move lower in the months ahead, And, at worst, it appears that long-term interest rates will hold steady in a trading range that could be up to 6.25 percent and down to 5.75 percent.
What seems sure is that the uncertainty about the outlook will make for a lot of volatility. In the last 32 trading days, according to Matthew Alexy, a government trading strategist at CS First Boston Corporation, the price of the long bond has moved three-quarters of a point or more 12 times.
