HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Networks Gain Riches From News Magazines

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE

 BODY:
On Sunday, more Americans turn to "60 Minutes" than any other television show. By Monday, if they haven't had their fill of news magazines, they can turn to "Day One," ABC's newest entrant to the genre. And on Tuesday, there's more with "Dateline NBC"
So it goes throughout the week. Every day except Saturday there is a network news magazine to choose from: "Eye-to-Eye," "Now," "48 Hours," "20/20" and "Prime Time Live." Often indistinguishable from one another, each seeks a niche in an increasingly crowded field. 
 But the accelerating growth of these programs is not just a sign of a hearty appetite by television viewers. It is really a tale of the rich economics that news magazines can deliver for the networks that create them.
"It's like owning your own mint," said Richard Campbell, a professor of communications at the University of Michigan and the author of "60 Minutes and the News: A Mythology for Middle America" (University of Illinois Press, 1991). "There is no question the news magazine phenomenon is almost completely driven by economics and, only somewhat, by a desire to serve the public interest."
 
'Fussy Baby Syndrome'
 This season, eight hours a week of network prime-time programming are devoted to news magazines; two more programs are on the way. This does not include the so-called tabloid TV news magazines that appear on cable channels and respected programs like "Frontline" on PBS.
"I call it the 'fussy baby' syndrome," said Peter Tortorici, an executive vice president at CBS Entertainment. "Once you find what the viewing public likes -- just like finding out what the fussy baby likes to eat -- you keep feeding them that, again and again."
But it's more than viewer demand. News magazines, while not cheap to produce, are often more profitable in the long run than entertainment shows. In a magazine, the network pays to produce the program -- generally $500,000 an episode -- and recoups by selling commercials.
By contrast, the networks pay far higher licensing fees to the Hollywood production companies that make entertainment shows. These fees range from $500,000 to about $2 million an episode for, say, "Northern Exposure" or "Home Improvement."
 
Control Over Costs
 But far more important is the fact that the news magazines, unlike the entertainment shows, are owned by the networks that produce them. This gives the networks better control over costs. When an entertainment show is a hit, its producers typically come back to the network year after year, demanding higher licensing fees.
"With a news magazine show, we control our own destiny," Alan Wurtzel, a senior vice president for news magazines at ABC, said. "We own it. It's ours, and if successful we have a franchise that won't come back and ask for more money."
And when a steady viewing audience and these economics combine, news magazines can give a powerful bottom-line boost to a network.
"Broadcast networks are beginning to realize the enormous earnings potential of news magazines and they are running to them," said Forrest Sawyer, the anchor of ABC's "Day One" news magazine, said. "Even though there are high expenses in starting one of these shows, once you find an audience and people stay, it's a tremendous franchise -- it keeps going like the Energizer rabbit."
 
Legendary Success
 The economic success of "60 Minutes," now in its 25th year, is the stuff of legend. It is the most lucrative program in network history, having made more than $1 billion for CBS. The program generates $50 million to $70 million a year, and in some years has accounted for as much as half of CBS's entire broadcast revenues.
"All of television looked at the enormous success of '60 Minutes' and decided to clone it," said Don Hewitt, the executive producer of the program. "But they're not trying to clone the broadcast quality, just the profit-and-loss statement."
Adding to the rosy economics is the ability of network news operations to recycle their magazines -- repeating segments two or three times a year. The networks also make more money by repackaging the programs and selling them overseas or to cable stations. For instance, "60 Minutes" runs 52 weeks a year, but produces programs for only 36 weeks and recycles the rest, Mr. Hewitt said.
Moreover, CBS airs "60 Minutes" segments on Australian, English and European news magazines. ABC's "20/20" has repackaged some programs for the Discovery Channel on cable. Now that ABC and NBC are starting new cable channels, "they need programs as a way of creating slots to sell ads," Mr. Campbell said.
"Once you own the material, it can work for you," Steve Friedman, a former executive in charge of "Dateline NBC," said. "You can recycle it. You can re-package it in another format."
Magazines also give the networks a way to amortize the costs of news operations and underwrite a stable of producers and correspondents.
"There is no question that the profitability of news magazines helps pay for the rest of the news division and helps the viability of the news operation," said Andrew Heyward, the executive producer of CBS's "Eye-to-Eye with Connie Chung."
The magazines take advantage of the networks' resources around the world. For instance, in a crisis in Russia, a magazine can televise a discussion with a network correspondent there at a marginal additional cost.
News magazines have also displayed a remarkable ability to outlast their entertainment competition. "20/20" has already reached its 15th year, compared with seven years for popular entertainment shows like "The Cosby Show."
No news magazine opened to more ridicule, perhaps, than ABC's "Prime Time Live," for questionable episodes like a live broadcast of a dying tree. But the shows it initially competed against -- "L.A. Law" and "Knot's Landing" -- have faded, while "Prime Time Live" is now a ratings hit. Similarly, "20/20" had trouble initially against "Hill Street Blues."
Yet those responsible for the magazines say there are limitations. Many say there is a dearth of correspondents and producers skilled at working in the longer format of news magazines.
"Like anything else, there are diminishing returns when there are too many," said Mr. Friedman of NBC. "The downside right now is that too many magazines are doing the same stories."
Added Mr. Tortorici of CBS: "Looking at these shows is like looking at real estate in the late 1980's. The market is wild and this might be the time to sell. I think that's the case with news magazines, and that we've already seen the best of their days."

HEADLINE: POLITICAL MEMO;
Ethnic Shifts in Electorate Play Part in the Mayoral Riddle of Who Will Win

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
How can David N. Dinkins possibly win again when his margin over Rudolph W. Giuliani four years ago was less than 50,000 votes and when public opinion polls suggest that Hispanic and white liberal Dinkins voters are defecting?
The most tantalizing mathematical riddle of the New York City mayoral campaign might be answered, in part, by changes in the city's complexion: the proportion of older whites has shrunk; the share of black and Hispanic registered voters appears to have climbed. 
 Just how big a factor this will be remains to be seen. While blacks overwhelmingly favor Mr. Dinkins and many older whites prefer Mr. Giuliani, according to the polls, the key to any election is not only who is registered to vote but also who among the nearly 3.3 million registered voters turns out.
"It's not the kind of thing that creates landslides," Dr. Lee M. Miringoff of the Marist Institute for Public Opinion said of Mr. Dinkins's possible demographic edge among registered voters. "But in a close race, it could be significant by compensating to some degree for the people who voted for Dinkins in 1989 and who now say they're voting for Giuliani."
The Dinkins and Giuliani camps differ not only about how much the electorate has changed since 1989 but also about how much it matters.
"I disagree with the basic premise that the ball game is going to be determined by white flight, if there is such a thing, and by an increase in minority registration," said Raymond B. Harding, the Liberal Party leader and a Giuliani adviser. "The election will be determined by voter turnout, and in terms of intensity Giuliani has it over Dinkins this year."
Strategy aside, Dinkins supporters say the apparent population shift gives the Mayor some of the wiggle room he needs to compensate for expected Democratic defections to Mr. Giuliani.
"If you conclude that no one who voted for Giuliani the last time is voting for Dinkins," said Norman Adler, a Democratic political consultant, "Giuliani still has to offset the outmigration among older whites and a voter registration effort that was conducted in most of the city, but with minorities the bulk of those registered."
Registration drives conducted in conjunction with the Rev. Jesse Jackson's 1984 and 1988 presidential campaigns laid the foundation for Mr. Dinkins's victory four years ago. Gains since then have been less dramatic. But Dr. Miringoff agreed that despite some pockets like the Upper East Side of Manhattan where Republicans aggressively recruited, voters registered within the last year or so have been disproportionately young, black and Hispanic. In polls conducted by the Marist Institute this fall, Mr. Dinkins was leading slightly among people who said they had signed up to vote within the last year.
 
Calculating Defections
 Juggling several variables in what he acknowledges is a very rough calculation, Mr. Adler concludes that for Mr. Giuliani to win, 65,000 voters would have to abandon Mr. Dinkins.
Few analysts dispute that the city is more diverse than ever before. But no one knows precisely how much New York's population has shifted since the late 1980's. Population usually changes more rapidly than the electorate since children and recent immigrants are ineligible to vote. Many Hispanic New Yorkers are not yet citizens, and nearly half the city's native-born black residents are too young. It is also unclear to what degree a voter's economic and social condition can command greater claim on political loyalties than either ethnicity or race.
Extrapolating from the Census Bureau's Current Population Survey, Terry Rosenberg, who directs the population studies unit of the Community Service Society of New York, a nonprofit research and advocacy group for the poor, estimates that in 1988, 52 percent of the city's adult population age 18 and older was non-Hispanic white, 20 percent was black and 22 percent was of Hispanic heritage. Four years later, she found, the proportion of whites had declined to 47 percent while blacks had increased to 24 percent. That the Hispanic share did not also rise she attributed to probable sampling error.
Relying on census results and a survey of individual surnames, Mark Lapidus, a researcher for the Dinkins campaign, reported a similar shift among registered voters -- a universe that seesawed from about 3,180,000 in 1989 to below 3 million two years later and then rebounded to 3,297,000 at last count when the rolls closed earlier this month.
 
Declining Number of Whites
 The proportion of whites among the potential voters dipped from 56 percent to about 53 percent, Mr. Lapidus estimates, while the proportion of blacks inched up from about 28 percent to 29 percent.
During the 1980's the number of white New Yorkers declined by 540,000, according to the 1990 census. If the decline continued at the same rate, the city's white population could have decreased by more than 200,000 in the last four years alone.
A study by Prof. John H. Mollenkopf of the City University of New York Graduate Center, found that the heaviest defections of the normally Democratic vote during the 1989 general election was in Jewish and white Catholic neighborhoods of Brooklyn and Queens.
"It appears that Democratic registration has continued to shift toward the black and Latino parts of New York City," he writes in "New York City in the 1980's: A Social, Economic and Political Atlas" (Simon & Schuster).
"This will favor Mayor Dinkins, although the larger issues of the relative turnout among various groups and which candidate these groups favor will ultimately determine the outcome of the 1993 elections."

HEADLINE: Is the Economy Strengthening? White House Officials, Cautiously, Say Yes

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24

 BODY:
After puzzling for months over why lower interest rates have not produced faster growth, Clinton Administration officials say they are now confident that the economy has turned the corner and is finally on a path of steady recovery.
News this month that showed housing construction finally picking up, business investment strong and consumer spending humming along has convinced President Clinton's economic team that it can shelve new proposals for stimulating the economy. 
 "The anticipated pickup in growth is occurring," said Laura D'Andrea Tyson, chairwoman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers.
 
Cautious Crowing
 Reaching that conclusion -- which is contested by some skeptical economists -- has important consequences for the Administration, both in terms of economic policy and in planning for the 1996 campaign. But this is one piece of good news that the President is being very cautious about spreading.
But unemployment remains relatively high, at 6.7 percent, even as the economy revs up. So even though Mr. Clinton and his advisers contend that the economy is on a respectable 3 percent growth path, aides say the President is reluctant to crow about it for fear that he will sound out of touch with millions of Americans who are unemployed or fear they could receive pink slips this month or next.
President George Bush made that mistake during last year's campaign, Mr. Clinton's advisers remember, and they do not want their man to repeat it.
"There's a real dilemma here," said Gene Sperling, an assistant to the President for economic policy. "The economy is starting to move in the right direction. We think it's good to tell people that, because it helps increase confidence, but when so many people and communities are still hurting, you also don't want to sound out of touch with their plight."
 
Cautious Note
 In his weekly radio address on Saturday, Mr. Clinton sounded a cautiously upbeat note.
"After a long struggle, we are finally seeing signs of hope in our economy," he said. "We have moved to significantly lower our Federal deficit. And now we have the lowest interest rates in 30 years. That's bringing back business investment, housing starts, purchases of expensive capital equipment."
The President added, "We've still got a long way to go," with the nation needing "more jobs that pay living wages."
The stream of good economic news is causing the Administration to rethink some policies. It has quietly shelved proposals for a new stimulus program that would not have required additional spending. One idea had been to speed up military spending that had already been authorized.
 
Trouble in California
 Despite its growing confidence, the Administration is pushing ahead with plans to help California's troubled economy. That state's residents constantly remind Mr. Clinton that they do not think he has done enough to end California's recession and cut its 9.4 percent unemployment rate, and he does not need reminding about California's clout in the 1996 elections.
Early next year the Administration plans to announce a multibillion-dollar program to retrain laid-off workers. And the Administration will certainly promote this as a program that was developed with California in mind, since cuts in Pentagon spending there have devastated many communities. But Mr. Clinton's economic team does not want to appear as if they are favoring California.
With the economy on surer footing in recent weeks, some Administration officials even see clear sailing through 1996, which in theory would give the President strong momentum in that year's campaign. "It looks like we're on the road to growth of 2.5 to 3 percent a year," said one senior Administration economist. "Inflation should remain low. Unemployment is coming down. We're reducing the deficit. That should give us a good record to run on."
 
Is It a Real Recovery?
 Some within the Administration are already thinking of ways to translate statistics about the recovery into campaign slogans for 1996. Ms. Tyson is quick to boast that more private-sector jobs have been created in Mr. Clinton's first nine months in office than in George Bush's four years.
But many outside economists say it is far too early for the Administration to declare victory. "They're right -- things have picked up over the past month or two, but this has happened at least five times since the recession ended in March of 1991," said Lawrence Chimerine, a senior economist with DRI/McGraw-Hill, a consulting firm. "The consensus would be that we've turned the corner, and then things would slow down again."
What has made the Administration far more confident this time around was this month's news that housing starts rose 2.8 percent in September, to their highest level in more than three years. Officials have been pleased that two other areas sensitive to low interest rates -- business investment in equipment and spending on big-ticket items like cars -- have risen strongly, but they were dismayed that housing construction remained flat, despite the lowest long-term interest rates in more than 20 years.
"Housing starts was the piece of the puzzle that was worrying us," said Alan Blinder, a White House economist. "A low-interest-rate strategy to boost the economy fires on three engines. The other two engines have been firing, and now it's good to see housing starts starting to fire up the economy, too."
Mr. Clinton's deficit reduction plan was instrumental in pushing down long-term interest rates, Administration officials say, although many economists argue that the Federal Reserve's success in holding down inflation deserves more credit for the fall in rates. But Mr. Blinder said it would be unwise for the Administration to declare that a strong recovery was here to stay, recognizing that during the current saw-toothed recovery there were numerous false springs and dips.
Indeed, Mr. Clinton's economic team experienced a sobering winter and spring because growth plunged from a robust 5.7 percent in the fall of 1993 -- Mr. Bush's last quarter in office -- to an anemic eight-tenths of 1 percent last winter and 1.9 percent in the spring quarter.
 
Split Interpretations
 In the view of Republicans, there was a simple reason for the drop: American consumers stopped spending because they feared that President Clinton would raise taxes.
"Under President Bush, we had growth of close to 4 percent last year," said John Taylor, a Stanford University professor who was an economic adviser to Mr. Bush. "Then the economy sagged early this year. There were concerns that we would get a tax increase and we did."
Mr. Taylor said the 3 percent growth that the Administration predicted was not terribly impressive. But Administration officials responded that 3 percent growth would be very respectable when exports are weak because of sluggish economies in Europe and Japan and when the deficit-reduction plan is starting to bite.
In an argument over interpreting economic history, Ms. Tyson says the slowdown in the first quarter was inevitable because President Bush sped up military spending late last year to stimulate output, a decision that made a huge drop in such production inevitable early this year. In addition, the Bush Administration reduced tax withholding in the second half of 1992 to speed growth, and that held down growth last spring because it meant lower-than-normal tax refunds.
Now that these bumps are past, the Administration sees growth of around 3 percent in the second half of this year and for all of next year.
"Our reading of the economy suggests a path of low inflation, low interest rates and steady recovery," Ms. Tyson said.

HEADLINE: Chicago Gangs, Extending Turf, Turn to Politics

BYLINE: By DON TERRY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Oct. 24

 BODY:
On a gray afternoon not long ago, Lu Palmer stood in the city's downtown business district watching thousands of young blacks march past, circle City Hall and stall traffic for blocks. They were ostensibly protesting Chicago's troubled school system, but a few also carried signs declaring it was time for another black mayor.
The marchers were as disciplined as an army. Or a street gang. 
 Mr. Palmer, at 71 a veteran of Chicago's black politics, said the scene reminded him of the 1960's and filled him with hope; maybe black Chicago was back on the move, with young lions leading the way.
 
Official View
 Mayor Richard M. Daley saw something else as he watched the same legions, the same jam of traffic and commerce down Clark Street as rush hour began.
The demonstration, he said, was infested with gang members trying to cloak their real agenda in political protest and the rhetoric of empowerment. He doubted they were interested in voting rights or improving education.
Whatever their motivations or affiliations, thousands of young black people have trooped into the Loop on at least three occasions since summer, promising to turn protest into votes and numbers into political power. And the people of Chicago -- especially their elected officials -- have taken notice.
"These guys have extraordinary numbers," Mr. Palmer said. "That's making a lot of politicians, black and white, nervous." Whatever their other flaws, politicians can count, he said.
While not all the marchers were gang members, many were. And both their presence and organizational discipline suggested that the city's black gangs -- or "street organizations" as they prefer to be known -- are moving into politics, just as white ethnic street gangs did generations before them.
 
Voter Registration
 In the last few months, gang members have registered new voters, marched in protests about health care and the school system, conducted voter education classes, backed candidates in school council elections and courted politicians in a failed campaign to win parole for a gang leader who has been in prison for 20 years for murder.
Autry Harrison, the director of a gang intervention program for the Chicago Boys and Girls Club, said: "If you can control that anger that so many kids have, and get young adults focused, then they can be a powerful force for something positive. If we can make the kids politically aware, what's wrong with that? It's much better than them killing each other or innocent people."
While politicizing gangs has been talked about here since at least the 1960's, the idea now appears to be spreading to other cities, including Los Angeles, Cleveland and Kansas City.
In a sign that it may be taking root, political empowerment was a main topic this weekend at the fourth national United in/for Peace Summit, a meeting of gang members that is scheduled to end here on Monday.
But as gangs talk of exchanging bullets for ballots, many people wonder if their cry is sincere or a sinister camouflage for a criminal agenda.
 
'Peace Is Crucial'
 It is probably too early to tell whether Mr. Palmer is right to be hopeful or Mayor Daley's suspicions are justified. But Carl Upchurch, an organizer of a gang peace effort known as the National Urban Peace and Justice Movement, said one thing was clear: "There's no question we're trying to get political power so we can enjoy economic power in this society," he said. "No one is trying to hide that."
Until the fighting in the inner city over drugs and turf and pride is stopped, Mr. Upchurch said, talk of political empowerment will amount to little more than rhetoric. "Peace," he said, "is crucial. Otherwise, nothing else will happen."
Most news reports here of the gang meeting have been negative, and Mayor Daley, Representative Mel Reynolds, aldermen and local organizers have called the peace effort a joke because the gangs have done nothing to stop their 24-hour-a-day drug business.
But the meeting and peace movement have also drawn a number of prominent black politicians and religious leaders, including the Rev. Jesse Jackson; Benjamin F. Chavis Jr., the director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, and Eugene Sawyer, who succeeded Harold Washington as Mayor.
Today the participants gathered at the mosque in Chicago, where Louis Farrakhan, the minister of the Nation of Islam, and Mr. Chavis embraced. Mr. Farrakhan told the audience: "We've had enough of violence. We've had enough of crime."
 
Defending Meeting
 Gang members and neighborhood organizers from Ohio, Pennsylvania and California attended the gang meeting, but most were from Chicago, which drew several local officials.
Alderman Allan Streeter, who is running for Mr. Reynolds seat in Congress, spoke at the meeting about political empowerment. In an interview before his speech, he defended his decision to speak at the meeting, saying: "These young people are not aliens from outer space; they are our sons and daughters. The Daley administration is afraid of these young people who are mobilizing into a political force. It should be."
One organization at the forefront of harnessing the potential power of Chicago's street gangs is 21st Century V.O.T.E, a group that the police say has close ties with the state's largest gang, the Gangster Disciples.
The chairman of the group, Dwayne Harris, a 26-year-old former high school football star, denies any ties with the gang. He said his group had helped to register thousands of voters, including many who were probably gang members. And he said the group was also entering into "negotiations" with Arab and Korean merchants about economic development in Chicago's black neighborhoods.
"Everybody is quick to label us a lost generation," Mr. Harris said. "Well, we're finding ourselves now."
Street gangs have haunted Chicago for generations, and have been used and abused by politicians of many stripes. The Democratic machine used them for years to keep independent candidates at bay. And when the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. came to Chicago in 1966 to battle slum lords and segregated public schools, he enlisted gang members in his cause, preaching nonviolence and voter registration.
 
Recalling King's Effort
 According to a new book about Dr. King's Chicago campaign, "Northern Protest" (Harvard University Press) by James R. Ralph Jr., Dr. King recognized that the gangs represented some of the "strongest grass-roots organizations in the ghetto."
But Dr. King's larger hope for the gangs was to put a stop to their civil warfare. His efforts received mostly negative attention, and he left Chicago with few real successes.
Alderwoman Dorothy Tillman called the new movement to politicize gang members a scam and a front for the Gangster Disciples. Her announced opponent in the 1995 City Council elections is Wallace Bradley, a former member of the Gangster Disciples.
"Dope is still on the corner," Ms. Tillman said. "They haven't told people to stop selling. The kids are being used. They're not really being educated about politics or the system. If that was happening, I'd support it. Right now, these young brothers and sisters are told when to go to demonstrations, what to say, what to do. That's not politics. That's brain washing. That's intimidation."
Far from the gang meeting, two teen-age members of the Gangster Disciples stood in a parking lot, smoking cigarettes. They said the gang had a new code of conduct that made school mandatory because, as one boy put it, "they don't want no illiterate people."
He said that several weeks ago the members were asked to attend a protest march in the Loop to help "get the little kids back in school."
"I didn't go down to march," he said. "I didn't want to miss school. I'm going to get my education and get out of here."

HEADLINE: After Talks, Haitian Aides Hope for a Break in the Impasse

BYLINE: By GARRY PIERRE-PIERRE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Oct. 24

 BODY:
With two American warships visible less than a mile offshore to help enforce an economic embargo against Haiti, Haitian officials expressed cautious optimism today that the army and the Prime Minister would break a stalemate that is blocking the return of the country's ousted President.
Participants in negotiations held on Saturday between Prime Minister Robert Malval and the head of the Haitian armed forces, Lieut. Gen. Raoul Cedras, said the issue of amnesty for military officers remained a stumbling block. The two sides plan to resume the talks on Monday. 
 "They don't have an alternative, but we fear these might be yet dilatory tactics," said a senior aide to Mr. Malval, who spoke on condition of anonymity. "From our side we will make a good-faith effort to test them."
A group of Haitian legislators outlined an 11-point proposal on Saturday in the hope of resolving the crisis that has gripped Haiti since security forces refused to let foreign troops dock here two weeks ago. The troops were to pave the way for the reinstatement of Haiti's first democratically elected President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, who was deposed in a military coup in September 1991.
A senior diplomat, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the United States had decided to keep a minimum of two warships for the next few days near the Port-au-Prince harbor, within Haiti's territorial limits. The goal, he said, was to turn up the pressure on General Cedras to abide by an agreement that he signed in July to let Father Aristide return to power by Oct. 30.
 
Threat of Wider Embargo
 The United Nations has threatened to widen an embargo on fuel and weapons for Haiti to all commercial goods unless General Cedras complies with that agreement, which was signed on Governors Island in New York.
But Haitian lawmakers and other officials said they doubted that Father Aristide could be reinstated by the deadline.
"Aristide is definitely not coming back by Saturday," a Malval aide familiar with the talks said. "It's just impossible to do what is needed in one week."
While Father Aristide has issued an amnesty for the army high command by executive order, lawmakers close to the military said the command was insisting on an act of Parliament to insure that the order would be binding.
Facing the threat of complete economic isolation, a group of Haitian lawmakers proposed Saturday the Parliament simultaneously approve laws separating the police from the army and guaranteeing broad amnesty for officers involved in the 1991 coup.
 
Army and Police Mingle
 Haiti's police and army are mingled to such an extent that the Port-au-Prince police chief, Lieut. Col. Joseph Michel Francois, controls much of the country's heavy weaponry and is considered the most powerful officer in the country.
Mr. Malval is acting as Father Aristide's Prime Minister under the terms of the accord signed in July. If he and General Cedras agree Monday on a plan of action, lawmakers hope to start meeting on Tuesday and to vote on the two measures by Wednesday.
Under the legislators' proposal, the Chamber of Deputies would discuss one law while the Senate was debating the other; each law would then pass to the other chamber, and lawmakers would finally vote on both issues at the same time.
Supporters of Father Aristide want the lawmakers to ratify the law separating the police from the army first, and then take up the law that would guarantee that General Cedras and the soldiers would not be prosecuted.
 
Aristide Wary of Lawmakers
 Father Aristide is wary of the intentions of many of the lawmakers, who were elected on Jan. 18 in military-sponsored voting that was declared illegal by the United Nations. The legislators, meanwhile, have asked Mr. Malval to enlarge his Government to include more pro-military political parties.
[At a news conference in Braintree, Mass., Father Aristide called for the immediate removal of the military leaders who ousted him in 1991. "By the light of the accord we demand their departure," he said.
[ The exiled leader appeared to balk at suggestions that General Cedras's meeting with officials of the Government was a positive sign. "We heard something like that on July 3 on Governors Island," Father Aristide said."]
Diplomats here in Port-au-Prince said they generally supported the lawmakers' proposal because it was in agreement with the accord.
"I don't think we're there yet," Eric Falt, a United Nations spokesman here, said of the legislative proposal. "It's an important first step which gets things moving in the right direction again. It's a Haitian solution, which already involves a large chunk of the players."
Asked if the parliamentary proposal was just another stalling tactic by the military leaders, Dante Caputo, the United Nations special envoy here, replied: "We will see. If it does not become a reality, sanctions will continue."
 
8 Lawmakers Fear to Return
 Questions remain even on whether the Haitian Parliament can get the quorum needed to pass any laws. Four senators and four deputies aligned with Father Aristide are now in the United States and are said to be afraid to return to Haiti because of the disappearance of one of their colleagues here last week.
"They won't gather until they get some security for themselves," a Western diplomat said. "That is the No. 1 obstacle. The underlying problem is establishing security so people can go and do their job. We've had a pretty bad week of terrorism here."
Under the legislators' proposal, once the assembly passed the two measures, General Cedras and Colonel Francois would resign, as required by the accord.
If the two military leaders stepped down, the next move would be for Father Aristide to appoint new commanders and to return to Haiti, which would lead to a lifting of sanctions and open the way for foreign aid.
Although shooting could be heard on Saturday in a middle-class neighborhood, the streets of the capital were calm today. But attaches, as paramilitary police auxiliaries are known, searched cars heading downtown or on roads leading to the suburbs.

HEADLINE: Review/Television;
Losing Jobs and Hope In 'The Great Depression'

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN

 BODY:
Experiences burned into the memories of those who endured America's toughest times are at the heart of "The Great Depression," a gritty seven-hour documentary that begins tonight on PBS. The producers, led by Henry E. Hampton ("Eyes on the Prize"), also make effective use of strong black-and-white newsreel clips from the 1920's and 30's, zesty folk songs and an intelligent narration, but it is the memories that give this history its punch and drive.
The first hour, "A Job at Ford's," focuses on the automobile company that drew tens of thousands of European immigrants, Mexicans and Southern blacks to Detroit after World War I to produce the Model T, then the most popular car in the world. 
 Remarkable overhead shots of the robotic assembly line are accompanied by the refrain of a protest song of the period: "Hurry, hurry, hurry/ Production rush is on." Douglas Fraser, the United Automobile Workers leader, who started in the factory, recalls, "The job controls you."
Henry Ford is presented as a control freak who tried to inflict a horse-and-buggy innocence on workers even while his product and methods of production were making his dream world obsolete. This paternalistic authoritarian, who offered high pay ($5 an hour) and other benefits to those who went uncomplainingly about their jobs, cracked down mercilessly on anyone deemed to be a troublemaker.
As former Ford workers and their children recall painfully, the good days at Ford ended after the 1929 stock market crash. Now the refrain became "Soo-oo-oop, soo-oo-oop/ They give me a bowl of soup." By 1931 people were starving. (There were bright spots: Ford made $30 million in 1930.) Jobless workers in their ethnic enclaves shared the little they had; many Mexicans went back home.
Particular attention is paid to black workers, not with any implication of racism either among employers or employees but by way of drawing belated attention to their considerable presence at Ford's big River Rouge plant. By 1931 Detroit, like other cities, was staggering under the burden of its unemployed, black and white, for whom there seemed to be no hope. A woman, one of eight children of a jobless worker, sums up the general despair: "I felt we weren't going to make it." President Herbert Hoover is shown delivering a passionless Thanksgiving Day speech in the bleak year of 1931, expressing faith that the nation's spiritual life would be enriched by adversity.
As the narrator notes, there was no national relief or unemployment insurance for the laid-off workers and their families, and the scenes of demonstrations bring back the brief period when the American Communist Party was a significant force on the front lines of industrial unionism.
Tonight's second hour of this view from below turns to the desperate plight of farmers, with disproportionate attention to the career of Charles (Pretty Boy) Floyd, the celebrated Oklahoma bank robber. It ends with a dramatic account of the bonus march on Washington by World War I veterans, a near revolutionary moment in the nation's history. Over the next three weeks, the story is carried from the election of Franklin D. Roosevelt and the innovations of the New Deal to the arms buildup for World War II, which finally ended the Depression.
There is no comfort here about America's present economic troubles, but the hard memories that still bring tears from those who were there offer some perspective to those who were not.

HEADLINE: Re-elect Governor Florio

 BODY:
America's politicians are seeking an answer from next week's election in New Jersey. Is it possible to survive after raising taxes? New Jersey, meanwhile, seeks a capable governor. We recommend re-electing the one they have.
In 1990, newly installed Gov. Jim Florio put through the biggest tax increase in the state's history, having said in his campaign that he saw no need for any increase. In light of the prevailing anti-tax sentiment, it was a brave move. And it was absolutely necessary for New Jersey, as it has been for other states and for the Federal Government, Republican supply-side nostrums notwithstanding. The added revenue solved the problems at hand -- balancing the budget while boosting school aid. 
 But in the tax revolt that followed, the Republicans won control of both houses of the Legislature with veto-proof majorities. At that point, Jim Florio became so accommodating -- on many things, but not taxes -- that recent opinion polls indicate people have forgotten how angry they were. That's one skillful politician.
Christine Todd Whitman, the Republican challenger, makes a good impression -- articulate, intelligent, sensitive to popular concerns. But her political skills need honing. Her campaign blunders cast doubt on her credibility as a candidate and her ability as a potential governor.
Mrs. Whitman's candidacy was created by Governor Florio's tax increase. Having almost toppled Senator Bill Bradley in 1990 by hammering at his silence on the Florio package, she was a natural to tackle Mr. Florio on the package itself. But she misfired with a promise to cut the personal income tax by 30 percent, a pledge so extreme and so late in the game that it strained belief. Indeed, she just fed the public's cynicism about politicians.
Mrs. Whitman would also weaken Governor Florio's toughness on gun control. New Jersey has the nation's toughest ban on semiautomatic weapons, thanks to Mr. Florio's courage in taking on the National Rifle Association. When Republicans won control of the Legislature they tried to repeal the ban, but he stopped them cold. Yet Mrs. Whitman wants to modify the ban, and had the poor judgment to make a campaign stop at a gun shop.
For his part, Mr. Florio shows poor judgment in insisting there was nothing wrong in the fact that a small investment firm half-owned by his chief of staff handled an extraordinary volume of state bond dealings. The Governor argues that investigators have not brought charges of anything illegal. True, but the appearance of Wall Street favors for a Florio insider is a bad sign.
Whoever wins will face difficult program cuts, to avoid raising taxes again. Neither candidate has laid out a convincing plan. The state is still feeling the recession more than most; its unemployment rate has risen to 7.9 percent. Recovery won't come easily and it won't come from magic tricks like Mrs. Whitman's incredible tax cut. It needs the experience, determination and doggedness of Jim Florio.

HEADLINE: Congress Defends Religious Freedom

 BODY:
Three years ago the Supreme Court threw away decades of precedent and watered down the religious liberty of all Americans. In a case involving the religious use of peyote by American Indians, the Court declared that states could criminalize all consumption of the substance without considering their laws' impact on the free exercise of religion.
By radically changing the ground rules for deciding claims of religious liberty, the Court alarmed organized religion, civil liberties organizations of all stripes and Senators as different in outlook as Edward Kennedy of Massachusetts and Orrin Hatch of Utah. The House has passed a bill aimed at correcting the situation and now the Senate is expected to pass it overwhelmingly. 
 The Religious Freedom Restoration Act reasserts a broadly accepted American concept of giving wide latitude to religious practices that many might regard as odd or unconventional. The bill deserves passage.
Before 1990, when law and religion collided, the Court had required government to show a compelling interest and to use the least intrusive method of enforcement. For example, a state could not deny unemployment compensation to a Seventh Day Adventist for refusing work on Saturday, her Sabbath. Not every religious claim was honored. The Court never recognized a religious refusal to pay taxes, but in many cases it gave breathing room to individual faith and conscience.
Then suddenly, and unnecessarily, the Court declared in the peyote case that states could enforce generally applicable laws, even if they trampled on serious religious claims, so long as the laws weren't deliberately aimed at religion.
Several unfortunate applications of this new test followed. For example, a general law routinely requiring autopsies in traffic deaths was enforced despite some relatives' claims that their religious beliefs were deeply offended.
The bill, which President Clinton says he will gladly sign, would instruct government not to "burden a person's exercise of religion," even if the "burden" results from a law that is aimed at everyone and not meant to interfere with religious practice -- unless there is a "compelling interest." If religious exercise must be limited, the bill says it must be done in the least restrictive way possible.
With the Restoration Act, Congress asserts its own interest in protecting religious liberty. It's a welcome antidote to the official insensitivity to religion the Court spawned in 1990.

HEADLINE: DIALOGUE: Staten Island Fights City Hall;
Alone, We're Better Off

BYLINE: By Guy V. Molinari; Guy V. Molinari is Staten Island Borough President.

 BODY:
In the 1894 referendum that approved the consolidation of the City of New York, the strongest support -- 78 percent -- came from Staten Island. How times have changed! This Election Day, Staten Islanders will vote on a proposal to ask the State Legislature to let them form a separate city, and I will be voting yes.
In recent years the interests of the people of Staten Island have become lost among the interests of the four larger boroughs. Staten Island has become a dumping ground, literally and figuratively -- first on the list for the most undesirable aspects of city government and last when it comes to desirable services rendered. 
 Although we represent only 5 percent of the city's population, for example, we receive virtually 100 percent of its garbage in our Fresh Kills landfill. Our plea for each borough to carry its fair share of this municipal burden falls on deaf ears. Just two weeks before Election Day, Mayor David Dinkins announced that plans for a sludge-composting plant in Queens would be squashed; meanwhile, plans for an equally unwanted plant on Staten Island move forward.
Or consider the city shelters and housing for the homeless. Right now more than 5,000 people are living in such housing on Staten Island; no more than 100 of them are Staten Islanders.
Clearly, whenever New York City plays politics, Staten Island loses.
When Staten Island is budgeted to receive services, those services are either inadequate or inappropriate. Of the city's 16 public health-care facilities, only a single small one is housed on Staten Island, and it does not offer basic health services. Unlike the other boroughs, Staten Island has no sewer maintenance crew of its own and must wait for a crew from another borough. A "citywide" program to immunize schoolchildren completely bypassed Staten Island.
And when the city does deliver services, it is often at inappropriate levels. It may make sense to have two officers in every police car in Washington Heights; does it make sense in a low-crime area like southern Staten Island? Should the same firefighting policies that apply to Manhattan with its skyscrapers apply to a borough in which the tallest building is nine stories high? Should Board of Education policies like the "rainbow curriculum," drafted to placate special interests in Manhattan, apply to Staten Island, where community standards are so different?
Not only is secession desirable, it is also economically feasible. Staten Island's location, educated work force and high household income make it highly appealing to new businesses. Since 1978 employment on Staten Island has grown more than twice as fast as employment citywide (62.5 percent to 27.1 percent). The island's population is expected to grow 20 percent by the year 2010, with employment growing 23 percent. These figures stand in stark contrast to the city's loss of 350,000 jobs in less than four years. There are no signs that this trend will be reversed, so it seems certain that a heavier tax burden will fall on those who remain.
Much has been said of the risk of big increases in real estate taxes if Staten Island secedes. But if we do not secede, we can certainly expect large increases in all forms of taxes. The Real Property Tax Reform Commission is likely to recommend large increases in property taxes on one- , two- and three-family homes. Seventy percent of our residents own such homes; 30 percent rent. For the rest of the city, practically the reverse is true.
So a big property-tax increase would disproportionately increase the average Staten Islander's tax bill. The only real question is where those tax dollars go and how they will be spent. Will we pay those taxes to a city in decline, a city that virtually ignores our pleas for a fair share? Or will we pay them to a smaller city governed by our friends and neighbors, responsive to our unique needs and priorities, and accountable to the governed?

HEADLINE: Committed to 'New Forestry' in Montana

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Some important facts were ignored in your Oct. 19 front-page article on the Champion International land transaction in Montana and the role of the Plum Creek Timber Company, to which Champion sold 867,000 acres at $300 an acre. 
 One of our fundamental principles is that we must be responsible and prudent stewards of the land if we intend to stay in business for generations to come. Over the last four years, Plum Creek has acted on that principle, becoming a leader in progressive forest management.
Beginning in 1990 we began experimenting with harvest practices modeled after the "new forestry" methods advocated by Dr. Jerry Franklin, a noted professor of ecosystem analysis at the University of Washington. these methods call for retaining valuable timber on the harvest sites to provide habitat for wildlife and to protect water and air quality.
In 1991 we took new forestry one step further, adopting environmental principles to guide all of our foresters and managers. Those principles govern replanting, wildlife management, stream and wetland protection, soil productivity, esthetics and other issues of concern to all of us, including the environmental community.
No company can achieve perfection in the eyes of everyone. But we believe that fairness dictates that our progress should be acknowledged. And it has been. Perhaps the best insight comes from Montanans who follow the company closely. When we announced this transaction, The Missoulian, one of Montana's leading newspapers editorialized:
"Plum Creek deserves more credit than it gets. It has worked to improve its logging practices and it has invested heavily and wisely in its plants and equipment. The most important thing is that the 867,000 acres of forest now owned by Champion would remain in the timber base and be actively managed for timber production."
With most of Plum Creek's present timberland holdings in Montana -- more than 600,000 of our 1.2 million acres -- and almost 1,400 of our 1,700 employees living and working there, our future is inextricably bound to the state's economic well-being. That is why we took the unprecedented step of entering into a 10-year timber supply agreement with Stimson Lumber Company, the purchaser of Champion's mills, to help assure that a significant number of Champion's employees can be hired back by Stimson.
There are many factors involved in the economic future of Montana and other timber states. However, declining timber supply has already left many timber workers unemployed. Appeals of timber sales and changing Federal forest management mandates continue to reduce timber supply available to Champion, Plum Creek and many smaller mill owners in Montana and throughout the region.
 
DONALD D. LELAND
Chairman, Plum Creek Timber Co.
Seattle, Oct. 19, 1993

CORRECTION-DATE: October 26, 1993, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
A letter yesterday from the chairman of Plum Creek Timber Company rendered his name incorrectly. It is David D. Leland, not Donald Leland.

HEADLINE: Kazakh Uses America To Enhance His Stature

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALMATY, Kazakhstan, Oct. 24

 BODY:
The President of Kazakhstan played politics with the United States today and won.
President Nursultan A. Nazarbayev and Secretary of State Warren Christopher were scheduled to sign and celebrate an excruciatingly technical agreement detailing how Kazakhstan would spend $85 million of American aid to dismantle its nuclear weapons. 
 But when Mr. Christopher arrived at Mr. Nazarbayev's office this morning, the Kazakh leader told him to put away his pen. Of course Kazakhstan was willing to sign the agreement, he said, but only at a pomp-filled, face-to-face ceremony with President Clinton.
No matter that the funds will be stalled until after the agreement is signed. The 53-year-old former engineer is eager to look like a first-rank leader, both at home and abroad, and he considers the photo opportunity more important.
 
No Second Fiddle to Russia
 Mr. Nazarbayev delivered his message over a lunch of lamb dumplings and horsemeat pate, and a senior Administration official paraphrased it this way: "We think we've been responsible on the international stage. I don't want to be overlooked. I don't want to be considered an afterthought after Russia and the Ukraine."
Kazakhstan, the former Soviet Union's second-largest republic, is crucial for American security because it has roughly 100 Soviet-era nuclear weapons and the largest Soviet-era nuclear test site on its territory. Russia, Ukraine and Belarus also inherited Soviet nuclear weapons.
The Central Asian country also has one of the largest oil fields outside the Persian Gulf, so important that the San Francisco-based Chevron Corporation is willing to put up 80 percent of the $20 billion capital investment required to develop it. Kazakhstan is also rich in chrome, gold, silver, zinc, lead and iron ore deposits and a major exporter of coal and wheat.
For the moment, however, Kazakhstan is poor, so poor that people line the streets to barter whatever they have -- a single bar of soap, a tin of tea. Its economy shrank 14 percent last year after shrinking 10 percent the year before, while inflation was 2,000 percent in 1992.
 
Quest for Economic Muscle

Mr. Nazarbayev, who began his career as a steelworker and rose through the ranks of the Communist Party, has aggressively sought foreign investment in his stated quest to transform his country into the driving economic force in the former Soviet Union.
That attitude fits nicely with Mr. Clinton's determination to promote American business abroad. To help push private enterprise in Kazakhstan, Mr. Christopher today announced an economic aid package of $140 million.
To encourage the relationship, Mr. Nazarbayev invited Mr. Clinton to Almaty, the Kazakh capital of 1.2 million people nestled at the foot of the Tian Shan Mountains, near the border with China. (A few months ago, the Government of Kazakhstan changed the name from the Russian, Alma-Ata, to its Kazakh form, Almaty. The name means City of Apples.)
After all, Mr. Clinton announced last week that he will visit Boris N. Yeltsin in Moscow in mid-January, just four and a half hours away by plane. To encourage a Clinton visit, Mr. Nazarbayev offered a gesture to prove that unlike his Ukrainian counterpart, President Leonid M. Kravchuk, he did not want to appear to be using his nuclear weapons to gain leverage over the West. Mr. Kravchuk, who promised last year to give up all of Ukraine's nuclear weapons, now says his country might keep some of them.
 
A Non-Nuclear Pledge
 When Mr. Nazarbayev appeared at a joint news conference with Mr. Christopher, he announced that he would ask his Parliament to approve the 1970 treaty to halt the spread of nuclear weapons before the end of the year. Although Kazakhstan had already pledged to adhere to the treaty, Mr. Christopher called that announcement a "very, very important development."
Last year, Kazakhstan signed the Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty known as START-1, which commits it to reduce its strategic nuclear warheads, and Mr. Nazarbayev has pledged to make his country a non-nuclear state.
But he wants to make sure that if he gives up his nuclear weapons, the West in return will help guarantee the security of his million-square-mile country, which borders Russia, China, the Caspian Sea and three of the other Central Asian republics -- Turkmenistan, Uzbekistan and Kyrgyzstan. In one of his meetings with Mr. Christopher, Mr. Nazarbayev spread out a map and described in detail the "dangers" that exist on his border, said one American participant.
Whether Almaty, with its bleak Soviet-style hotels, limited international phone lines and scant taxi service, could handle the American President and the White House press corps is another matter.
 
'Welcome President Rafsanjani'
 But Mr. Nazarbayev knows how to treat a head of state. Iran's President, Hashemi Rafsanjani, flew into town for a three-day visit just hours after Mr. Christopher left, and the main thoroughfares were lined with Iranian flags. In fact, when Mr. Christopher arrived on Saturday night, he was greeted by a huge sign that read, "Welcome President Rafsanjani."
All in all, today was a good day for Mr. Christopher, the smoothest so far in a bumpy, eight-day ride that includes stops in Hungary, the four nuclear powers of the former Soviet Union and Latvia.
En route to Budapest on Wednesday, Mr. Christopher decided not to announce a new initiative on NATO himself. Instead, he ceded the spotlight to Defense Secretary Les Aspin who briefed reporters at a meeting of NATO defense ministers in Germany.
When the message came out muddled, Mr. Christopher's aides admitted that he should have done it himself.
 
Confusion on Foreign Policy
 In Budapest on Thursday, Mr. Christopher was verbally assaulted by a Texas businessman who wanted to know why American foreign policy was in disarray.
On Monday in Kiev, the Ukrainian capital, Mr. Christopher is expected to have a testy meeting with Mr. Kravchuk over his country's failure to ratify START-1 and adhere to the nuclear treaty.
Even today, Mr. Christopher suffered a mild mishap. For the sake of politesse, he violated the first rule of politics: When you're given a hat, never put it on.
The Kazakhs presented Mr. Christopher with an embroidered camel-hair shapan and kalpan, the national coat and hat of Kazakhstan. Mr. Christopher, who was featured in last week's People magazine as one of the best dressed men in America, struggled to retain a statesman-like demeanor and he donned the clothing, quickly whipping the elf-like hat on and off his head.
"We told them no gifts," said one unhappy American diplomat. "They promised no gifts. This was an unwelcome surprise."

CORRECTION-DATE: October 30, 1993, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Monday about Secretary of State Warren Christopher's visit to Eastern Europe and Central Asia mistranslated Almaty, the new official name for the capital of Kazakhstan, a city formerly known by the Russified name Alma-Ata. Almaty means Father of Apples, not City of Apples.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Customized Radio Services Find More Air Time

BYLINE: By ANDREA ADELSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 24

 BODY:
Two companies best known for supplying traffic reports for radio station listeners, Shadow Broadcasting Service Inc. and its larger rival, Metro Networks Inc., are expanding their scope by offering customized news, weather and sports broadcasts to a growing number of radio stations.
Such ventures are unusual in the highly fragmented radio industry. While stations can supplement their own programming with syndicated segments like Casey Kasem's Top 40, Rush Limbaugh's talk show, or ABC News, more topical local information typically had to be produced by each station's news staff.
 
'A Logical Extension'
 Even The Associated Press's broadcast wire, used by more than half of all radio stations, generally carries only regional, national and foreign, not local, news. 
 "We're seeing sharing at the local level the way we've done at the national level," said David Bartlett, the president of the Radio-Television News Directors Association, a trade group in Washington. "The number of stations has doubled in the last 10 years, so we now have mass. It's a logical extension to see it in news."
To make their broadcasts seamless with the station's own, Shadow and Metro let the station dictate how many newscasts it wants, when it wants them, in what tone they are delivered and the mix of local and national news. The service is offered on a barter basis, with Shadow and Metro selling commercial time to advertisers on their own broadcasts.
"We set up the format," said Dave Clark, the program director of KOOJ-FM, a modern country station in Riverside, Calif., which receives eight 3-minute news broadcasts on weekdays from Metro's studio in Los Angeles. "If we want more up, more down, more human interest, they are right on it the next day. They nail it."
Mark Elliott, the program director of KMGX-FM in Granada Hills, Calif., a Shadow news affiliate, said its professional sound and use of San Fernando Valley news helped his station compete. "I'd much rather have this than me doing the news or a jock who tells jokes all morning. He loses credibility doing the news."
The new rivalry between Shadow and Metro is gaining ground because of the deregulation in 1981 that made news coverage by radio stations optional; the liberalization of station ownership rules last year, and a soured economy. When radio revenue began shrinking, so did news operations, particularly at stations with music formats. Jobs in radio news declined 22 percent, to 15,600 in 1992, according to the news directors' group, from the peak in 1990.
Music stations once commonly had two and three-person news divisions. More typical now is a station with one staff member. But a one-person operation can still cost about $100,000 a year in salaries, benefits, wire services and other overhead.
The contract news services try to offer cost savings to affiliates. Shadow offers what it calls "news protection" to stations, insuring coverage of breaking stories after the morning drive and on weekends. Some stations, like WOR-AM in New York, rely on Metro only for overnight news coverage to back up their own daytime news staff.
Lee Marshal, the vice president of news and sports at Shadow, said his service also addressed a common failing of radio news broadcasts; they are often at odds with a station's format. "I can't tell a 16-year-old Megadeth fan about soybean futures. But if I tell him, 'The cost of a date just went up,' then I can get through."
David Saperstein, a former used-car salesman from Baltimore who founded Metro in 1978, agreed. "We're giving listeners of music stations a reason not to leave," he said.
Shadow and Metro traffic broadcasters provide information on hundreds of stations in cities like New York, Boston, Philadelphia and Los Angeles. On the air, both services often remain anonymous.
Metro, based in Houston, has 1,200 traffic affiliates in 50 cities, and 32 news, weather or sports affiliates in 11 cities. In New York, WOR is Metro's only news affiliate, though the service provides traffic to 20 radio and 2 television stations.
Shadow has 186 traffic affiliates in eight cities, and 52 news, weather or sports affiliates in six cities. In New York, Shadow has at least a dozen traffic outlets, five sports outlets, including WINS-AM, and one news outlet, dance station WMXV-FM. The company, based in Philadelphia, is owned by Michael D'Ambrose, Alan Markowitz and Len Lodish.
 
'The Next Rush Limbaugh'
 Industry executives credit Curtis Beckman with pioneering the local radio network concept. Mr. Beckman, a longtime news director of WCCO-AM, founded Radio City Network News of Minneapolis in 1988.
"What I heard on music stations in this marketplace was below-average, inexperienced people reading wire copy," he said. "The people I'm replacing are almost always not journalists, but people who want to be the next Rush Limbaugh."
Critics of contract news services say the services compete for advertising revenue with stations and contribute to the diminution of voices and opinions heard on the radio. John Lynch, the chairman of Noble Broadcasting Inc., which has 16 stations and is based in San Diego, said, "Anyone who tries to rely on them for real news is kidding themselves."
Radio's historical source of news, The Associated Press's broadcast wire, may have the most to lose. "If they put radio news people out of business, that's bad for us," said Jim R. Williams, The A.P.'s vice president and broadcast director.
In June, The Associated Press began offering format-specific copy to music and all-news stations. Mr. Williams denied that the move was a response to the new services.
"The day they are in the pool in Somalia or on the courthouse steps covering a story, then I'll say they're in our business," he said.

HEADLINE: Business Digest

 BODY:

Companies
Sales of domestic cars and light trucks climbed 18.4 percent in mid-October, helped by a rebound by General Motors from earlier production difficulties. Car sales rose 17.4 percent and light truck sales increased 19.8 percent, with the seasonally adjusted annual selling rate for cars at 7.8 million. [Page D1.] 
 Viacom commenced its $10 billion tender offer for Paramount Communications, but the attention was on whether QVC Network would raise its $9.5 billion takeover bid. [D2.]
Bell Atlantic's merger with Tele-Communications will bring together two chief executives -- Raymond Smith and John Malone -- who have more in common than their images suggest. [D1.]
The toughest job at I.B.M. may belong to Nicholas Donofrio, who is trying to halt the decline of the company's mainframe business caused by price cuts and competing technology. [D1.]
Inquiries about the huge Prudential Securities fraud settlement continued to deluge state securities regulators. [D3.]
Surgical Care Affiliates offered to merge with Medical Care America in a stock swap valued at $941 million. [D4.]
Exxon reported record earnings, helped by asset sales and lower overseas tax rates. Ashland also rose, but ARCO fell. [D4.]
Advanced Micro Devices and Microsoft entered a licensing agreement that bolsters Advanced Mico's battle with Intel. [D4.]
Leading airlines cut fares up to 40 percent on domestic routes, matching discounts announced by Northwest Airlines. [D4.]
Boeing reported a 45 percent decline in third-quarter earnings, citing weakness in the airline, military and space businesses. [D5.]
Jurors retired to decide if Goldman, Sachs was guilty of sex discrimination in the dismissal of a female employee. [D7.]
 
The Economy
Market principles do not apply in the health care industry, which is one reason medical costs have so steeply risen and why almost every plan being considered for overhauling the system would try to introduce some basic economic principles. [A1.]
More than 60 nonprofit, consumer, labor and civil rights groups plan to announce an organization intended to broaden public discussion of the national data highway. [D2.]
The Administration favors letting banks operate more freely across state lines, but will not push the issue until other legislation clears Congress, Treasury Secretary Bentsen said. [D9.]
 
International
Japan moved to open its construction industry, which could be a breakthrough in negotiations with the U.S. [D1.]
The French Prime Minister's retreat from cost cutbacks amid the Air France strike sends a signal that he has no stomach for conflict at a time when economic conditions could lead toward the kind of social explosion that shook France 25 years ago. [D3.]
 
Markets
Blue-chip stocks galloped to new highs, but the broader market languished. The Dow gained 24.31 points, to 3,673.61. [D10.]
The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond rose to 6 percent, and prices fell, amid uncertainty over growth and inflation. [D18.]
The dollar moved higher as traders anticipated more cuts in German interest rates. Gold prices fell. [D17.]
Oil prices tumbled again as supplies remained ample heading into the winter. Lumber prices soared. [D17.]
 
 Today's Columns
Wall Street expressed disappointment with the tentative labor accord at G.M. An announcement that the company would take a $950 million charge also bodes ill. Market Place. [D1.]
Ads urging young people not to smoke are being paid for with help from the tobacco industry. Advertising. [D21.]

HEADLINE: Japan Officials Move to Open The Construction Market

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD

DATELINE: TOKYO, Tuesday, Oct. 26

 BODY:
In what could prove to be the first breakthrough in tense trade negotiations between the Clinton Administration and the new Japanese Government, the chief Cabinet secretary announced this morning the outlines of a program for opening Japan's scandal-tainted construction market.
The outlines of the program -- which were negotiated at the end of last week -- were sketchy, and they did not meet some of the basic American demands for concrete actions. But some American officials indicated they would probably be enough to halt the United States from imposing sanctions against Japanese construction companies in the United States because they suggested a commitment to real change. 
 However, the final American response, which is likely to come later this week, remains uncertain.
The deal would be significant since it would indicate an unusual degree of flexibility on both sides. Construction has been one of the most acrimonious areas of disagreement between the United States and Japan for the past seven years.
As the first trade agreement between Tokyo and Washington, it could give some indication of how other deals might be struck.
The "action plan," as it is being called, would make the bidding system more transparent, provide foreign companies equal access to information about projects and strengthen enforcement against collusive bidding practices, which a recent series of scandals have shown to be rampant in Japan. However, the program would only open bidding on projects above a certain size, which was not specified.
Japan faces a Nov. 1 deadline to either meet demands that it permit foreign construction companies, consultants and subcontractors to bid on public works projects on equal terms with Japanese companies, or have the rights of Japanese companies in the United States curbed.
The construction talks are separate from broader trade negotiations between Japan and the United States known as the framework talks. Those talks, which face a January deadline, are currently focused on opening Japan's insurance, auto, auto parts and Government procurement markets.
If the terms of the outline are accepted, officials indicated, they would amount to a down payment and would have to be followed with tangible measures by the time Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa meets President Clinton in January.
The Clinton Administration has been extremely tough in demanding that Japan not just open various markets, but that it guarantee tangible results. This deal, if it goes through, would indicate that the White House is willing to accept less concrete commitments of results.
American officials have said that the flexibility is a product of the fact that Mr. Hosokawa is perceived as a sincere reformer, bent on opening the collusive Japanese economy. But Mr. Hosokawa will remain weak until his Government can pass a long-promised electoral reform bill.
An agreement on the terms announced this morning would give Mr. Hosokawa time to enact that legislation before having to do battle with the powerful lobby that supports the construction industry.
