HEADLINE: Can Whitman Win as the Anti-Florio?

BYLINE: By KIMBERLY J. McLARIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, Oct. 25

 BODY:
If the race for governor of New Jersey were simply a personality contest, Christine Todd Whitman would win hands down. Affable, charming and impressive in person, she is her campaign's second-best asset (the first being Gov. Jim Florio himself). People who know her like her. People who meet her like her. Even people who may not be inclined to vote for her find her a lot easier to talk to than her opponent, a man so naturally guarded he spent a few minutes before the second debate practicing his smile.
But with a week to go before the election, Mrs. Whitman finds herself down in the polls, if gaining quickly, against one of the most harshly vilified governors in New Jersey's history. She has staked her campaign more on anti-Florio sentiment and Republican party doctrine, largely obscuring the woman behind the campaign and leaving many voters with a sense that they still do not know who she is. 
 With Mr. Florio furiously trying to fill that void by painting her as an out-of-touch heiress ill-equipped to manage the state, Mrs. Whitman's challenge has been to give voters more reason to vote for her than the bare fact that she is not Mr. Florio.
"It used to be it was always the nice person who won and the nasty one who lost," said Vernon Noble, an admirer of Mrs. Whitman who served with her on the Somerset County Board of Chosen Freeholders. "You can't put labels like that on people anymore. Now it's the one who works the hardest and gets the best issues and sticks to their guns and makes a point."
 
A Republican From the Cradle
 By now, every voter in New Jersey who has paid any attention knows Mrs. Whitman's history. She was born into one of the state's wealthiest and most politically well-connected families. Her father, the late Webster B. Todd, was a major figure in the national Republican Party, an adviser and friend to President Eisenhower and a builder whose projects included Rockefeller Center. Her mother, the late Eleanor Schley Todd, was a member of the Republican National Committee.
Mrs. Whitman, who is 47, was steeped in Republican philosophy from birth. At age 9 she stood on the dais during Mr. Eisenhower's speech to the Republican National Convention. At age 14, she sold lemonade to raise money for Richard Nixon's 1960 Presidential campaign.
She has held only one elected office, that of Somerset County Freeholder, and one appointed position, that of president of the New Jersey Board of Public Utilities. But her political star rocketed in 1990 when she nearly upset the popular United States Senator Bill Bradley by tarring him with his refusal to comment on the record $2.8 billion tax increase orchestrated by his fellow Democrat, Mr. Florio.
Mrs. Whitman has tried to play upon her relative lack of experience, seeking to portray herself as a political outsider who will clean up the mess created by career politicians in Trenton. "For Jim Florio to call me an amateur is a compliment," she said. "It's true I haven't spent the last 25 or 28 years running for office."
But Mrs. Whitman is politician enough to be personable without ever being personal, to give scripted answers to many questions. Asked whether she likes or despises the rough-and-tumble world of politics, she said: "I like the part of politics that's meeting people. I hate the distortions. I hate the negativism. People really do care about the issues. The part of campaigning I hate is the 30- and 60-second sound bites. I'm not good at it. Maybe that's because I'm a mother and you can't discuss big issues with the kids in 30 and 60 seconds."
Asked whether, as the first woman to run as a major party candidate for governor of New Jersey, her sex should be a campaign issue, she said:
"I don't run on that, but, yes, it is more important that we have more women in positions of authority because they do prioritize differently, they do problem-solve differently. There should be a balance there. But that's not a case for me to make." (And to date, appreciably more women say they favor Mr. Florio.)
 
'I Want to Make A Difference'
 During the Republican primary, Mrs. Whitman defused attacks on her wealth by asserting that her opponents were trying to paint her as a "rich bitch from the hills." But she left the question open: Who is Christie Whitman?
Why does Christine Todd Whitman want to be governor? Why would she place herself and her family in the position of having their tax returns make headlines, their hiring practices examined, their family farm videotaped by Mr. Florio's campaign?
"Because I want to make a difference," she said this week between stops on a three-day bus tour of the state. She was accompanied by several supporters, including her husband, John Whitman, a financier and grandson of a former governor of New York.
"I love this state," Mrs. Whitman said. "The ability to hold that office to make those changes that I think are necessary to make life better here, it's worth it."
This answer may sound like so much boilerplate to jaded voters, but those who know the candidate insist she truly believes that, having lived a privileged life, she is obliged to give back to the community.
"Our parents felt very strongly about politics as a good vehicle to do something for the people of the state," said her sister, Kate Beach, who like many members of Mrs. Whitman's campaign wore a small golden pin that said "Christie, 93."
 
College, Children, Then a Campaign
 Mrs. Whitman began her political career after graduating from Wheaton College in Massachusetts with a degree in government. She went to work for the Federal Office of Economic Opportunity and later the Republican National Committee.
She waited until her two children, Kate, now 16, and Taylor, now 14, were old enough for preschool before seeking elected office, running in 1982 for a seat on the Somerset County Board of Chosen Freeholders.
Mrs. Whitman's fellow freeholders described her as hard-working and goal-oriented. John Kitchen said Mrs. Whitman's drive and determination helped them defeat an incumbent Democrat and former Democratic board member during that first election.
"She is very organized," Mr. Kitchen said. "She did her homework. She didn't let the problems stand in the way of the solutions. I can't see any flaw in the way she governs."
In 1988 Gov. Thomas H. Kean appointed her president of the State Board of Public Utilities, where she oversaw one of the most controversial actions of her career.
Under Mrs. Whitman's leadership, the utilities panel approved a deal that allowed Hackensack Water Company to transfer 290 acres of watershed property to the company's development subsidiary. Local environmental and community groups strongly opposed the transfer.
But the Appellate Division of Superior Court reversed the board's decision after finding that the language of the transfer did allow development of the property under some circumstances. The court also criticized the board for acting without adequate public input. The board approved the transfer at a meeting in January 1990, only two days after it had given public notice of the meeting and four days before Mr. Florio took office.
Carl Golden, a spokesman for Mrs. Whitman, said Mrs. Whitman stands by her vote on the issue.
"Her understanding at the time was that this would keep the land in that kind of protected position and it was on that basis and assurance that she voted," he said.
 
Social Liberal, Fiscal Conservative
 Mrs. Whitman is a moderate Republican, conservative on fiscal issues, liberal on social concerns. Like Ronald Reagan, she says lower taxes will stimulate the economy, and has proposed cutting income taxes in New Jersey 30 percent over three years. She supports abortion rights, as does Mr. Florio. Like Janet Reno, the United States Attorney General, she has questioned the effectiveness of mandatory sentencing laws, although she has moderated that stance by proposing that third-time violent offenders go to prison for life.
Mr. Florio has used her questioning of mandatory sentences to paint Mrs. Whitman as soft on crime, and his own leadership in enacting New Jersey's ban on semiautomatic weapons to tout his toughness on the issue. Mrs. Whitman has replied that his emphasis on guns simplifies the issue without significantly reducing violent crime or addressing its root causes.
"We've got to understand the problems are much more than just crime per se," she said. "The problems are things like, what do we do in our inner cities, how do we keep them from dying, how do we improve the education system and housing? If I grew up in the inner city in one of those high-rise projects, I'd break windows too. What else is there to do?"
Mrs. Whitman's attempt to support mothers on welfare led to the strange sight of a Republican accusing a Democrat of "extreme right-wing radicalism" after Mr. Florio proposed denying benefits to mothers who refuse to identify the fathers of their children.
"What is the Governor's next idea?" asked a statement released by the Whitman campaign. "A program of tattoos for welfare mothers? A badge sewn onto their clothing identifying them as welfare recipients? Creation colonies, like leper colonies, where welfare recipients would be forced to live? How about an involuntary relocation program into camps?"
Mr. Florio leaped upon the statement, calling it insulting to the victims of the Holocaust, and held two news conferences with angry Jewish and black leaders.
 
A Bumpy Campaign Settles Down
 Although it is unclear whether the squabble cost Mrs. Whitman support among Jewish voters, it is indicative of the missteps that have plagued her candidacy and given critics ammunition to argue that a bumpy campaign would produce a bumbling administration. From hiring and firing the man responsible for the infamous Willie Horton advertisement to stating that tens of thousands of dollars were being spent buying Adidas sneakers for inmates, Mrs. Whitman handed Mr. Florio opportunity after opportunity to attack her.
By not taking the initiative to define herself, she allowed Mr. Florio to define her as indecisive, pro-guns and soft on crime.
But over the last week, Mrs. Whitman has managed to steady her campaign. Ed Rollins, the Republican consultant, has taken over daily operations from Mrs. Whitman's brother, Webster B. Todd Jr., and made it clear that he is willing to engage in negative campaigning despite Mrs. Whitman's insistence that it was against her nature. She released her 1990 tax returns returns after months of stalling that allowed Mr. Florio to suggest she was hiding something, then left the Florio campaign scrambling to justify its innuendo.
Her campaign put Mr. Florio on the defensive by filing a complaint with the State Election Law Enforcement Commission accusing Mr. Florio of violating campaign finance laws. Then she turned in a solid performance during the second debate on Tuesday.
Mrs. Whitman said that while she expected Mr. Florio to be a tough campaigner, she was taken aback by how he has chosen to attack her.
Fighting back in the debate Sunday, she interrupted the Governor at one point to say:
"Jim, as a mother, I find that totally insulting. This is what the Governor has done throughout this campaign. He has taken positions of mine, twisted them and tried to create fear tactics."
Still, Mrs. Whitman says she would not have done anything differently.
"I still believe in doing it what I consider to be the right way," she said. "I want to be governor, but the desire to be governor does not consume me. I just won't push it that far."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Casting the Star Roles at Bell Atlantic

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON

 BODY:
Raymond W. Smith, the chief executive of Bell Atlantic, has seen to the cutting of 20,000 jobs. He has confronted his regulators in hearing rooms and the courts, usually winning. And to press John C. Malone to strike a deal for the sale of Tele-Communications Inc., he had an aide spread the word that competing cable companies were eager to sign up.
But it's Mr. Malone they call a prince of darkness. "He has been referred to as Darth Vader outside, in the press," Mr. Smith told a Bell Atlantic executive training class a few days ago. "I have only been referred to as Darth Vader inside." 
 His executives quickly glanced at each other, then roared with laughter.
Bell Atlantic's agreement last week to buy the Tele-Communications cable television company for $33 billion set off speculation about how long Mr. Malone would stay with a local phone company, or how soon he would overthrow Mr. Smith. Mr. Malone has been cast as a multimedia mobster, extracting payments from every rival and cable viewer in the nation. Mr. Smith was just a faceless Baby Bell administrator, as menacing as a 96-pound operator.
 
 
Some Shared Passions
 But the two have far more in common than their images suggest. Their shared passions include corporate economizing, fending off regulators and taking calculated but highly leveraged risks. They hate bureaucracy. They agree that Mr. Malone's position at the new Bell Atlantic -- as billionaire vice chairman, strategist and cable programming boss with five board seats under his control -- will beat the drudgery Mr. Smith faces in running the phone service and the broader corporation.
Their contrasting reputations, however, result in large part from their contrasting approaches to the public. Mr. Malone, the Tele-Communications president, has scant patience for politicians or press, and it shows. In-house, Mr. Smith's temper might be shorter than a speed-dial, but outside he is the consummate diplomat.
An experienced actor, director and playwright in local theater, Mr. Smith is alert to his audience of the moment, able to change roles in an instant. With Mr. Malone out of the spotlight and Mr. Smith taking center stage to explain the combined company's motives and strategy, Mr. Malone could enjoy even more latitude.
"If I know Ray," said Anton Campanella, Bell Atlantic's recently retired president, "Ray will let John Malone be John Malone."
Despite Washington's generally favorable response to the deal, some lawmakers and many competitors quake at that thought. "Malone has not only the control he was able to exercise in the past," said Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum, an Ohio Democrat, "but now he has unlimited financial resources." As chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee's Antitrust Subcommittee, Senator Metzenbaum plans a hearing on the deal tomorrow.
At his own company, mounting political pressure was making it more difficult for Malone to be Malone. With each acquisition or increase in cable fees, more regulators and Congressmen demanded greater public control over what had become the nation's largest cable empire.
Now, Mr. Malone, who is 52, speaks more of changing his visibility than his goals. "The one thing in life I don't want to be is Mr. Outside," he said in an interview. "I don't particularly like the publicity and the hassle." As an escape, he spends his summers sailing off the coast of Maine.
Let others accuse him of wielding unchecked power. Mr. Malone says he actually feels pinched by Tele-Communications, despite a stock market value of $13 billion and borrowing of $10 billion. Mr. Malone's ambitions require the added cash flow of a telephone company that has more than 18 million subscribers. "It's part of growing up to realize you've built more opportunities than you have resources," he said.
 
A Tough-Guy Reputation
 His dossier, long and well known, dates back to his arrival at Tele-Communications, near Denver, in 1972, back when the cable industry existed mainly for remote towns beyond the reach of broadcast signals. Mr. Malone relished the tough-guy reputation he gained in making cable a big business. When Vail, Colo., refused to meet fee demands, the company left viewers with nothing to watch one weekend but the home phone numbers of the mayor and city manager. The city gave in.
Through about 500 acquisitions, Tele-Communications now has about 20 percent of all cable subscribers. Mr. Malone's ability to control access to millions of homes has helped him build a vast network of investments in cable program producers.
For all Ted Turner's braggadocio, he must now clear his actions with Mr. Malone, who sits on his board and controls a 23 percent stake in Turner Broadcasting System. Mr. Turner's hopes of entering the current bidding war for Paramount were reportedly blocked by Mr. Malone.
 
 
Dueling With Viacom
 Mr. Malone's current nemesis is Sumner M. Redstone, chairman of Viacom Inc. Mr. Malone is backing a bid by the QVC Network to break up Viacom's plans for buying Paramount Communications. In an antitrust suit, Viacom has accused Mr. Malone of using "bully boy tactics," and said, "The consumer has paid -- and will continue to pay -- a monopoly tax to John Malone." He dismisses the suit as a petty strategem.
He also remains scornful of government. "If there were just a few guys in Washington who ever had to meet a payroll, who ever had to build a company, we wouldn't be in the situation we're in," he said recently. "Sending me off to settle the company's regulatory issues is not a good move."
Enter Mr. Smith, who has spent his 33-year Bell career dealing profitably with regulators. "They are not bad people," Mr. Smith said in an interview. "They work very hard." Although his company is based in Philadelphia, he has a second set of offices, and another home, in Washington.
Mr. Smith's friendly attention is rewarded. Federal lawmakers, regulators and judges have given Bell Atlantic broad rights to expand into television. At the state level, Mr. Smith has persuaded regulators to watch his prices, not his profits -- increasing the company's incentives to economize and add services.
 
 
Image and a 'Dumpy' Office
 Of all the regional phone companies, regulators have treated Bell Atlantic the best, said Steven R. Yanis, an analyst at Kidder Peabody. "It's not by chance," he said. "They've worked at it."
Mr. Smith is frank about the importance of image. He knew that regulators, shareholders and workers would cheer when in 1991 he turned a planned 50th-floor executive dining room at the Philadelphia headquarters into an employee cafeteria, and gave himself a modest office. "I have that dumpy little office there for symbolic reasons," he said. With no receptionist, his secretary seems to get the equivalent of a daily aerobics class by jumping up repeatedly to see who's buzzing at the floor's locked glass door.
Inside, visitors see a list of 25 cost-saving mandates. No. 24: "Use backs of paper due for recycling for notes, calculations, etc., before recycling."
Mr. Smith greets his guests in an Armani double-breasted suit. But in the presence of a newspaper photographer, or the executive trainees, the jacket comes off and the shirtsleeves are rolled up.
Mr. Smith says he achieved most of his staff reductions through attrition and incentives for employees to leave voluntarily. Although other Baby Bells have cut back as well, Bell Atlantic has become the most efficient, with only 35 employees per 10,000 local telephone lines, compared with the industry average of 40.
Mr. Smith's aides speak of his volcanic impatience. "He gets tremendously exercised over bureaucratic fluff," said Stuart C. Johnson, a group president. Recently, when the company's advertising executives came in to discuss their planning process for publicizing the merger, Mr. Smith bristled. "Forget about the plan," he ordered. "Do the work."
He has never had much regard for bureaucracies -- the military, the Bell System before the breakup -- that value spotless records much more than imagination. Mr. Smith, who is 56, traces his maverick ways to his childhood. In his Pittsburgh parochial school, the nun teaching his second-grade class likened the soul to a white ribbon. "I already had an impure thought," he said with a smirk. "My ribbon was already soiled."
To agitate the Bell Atlantic bureaucracy, he is pursuing a decadelong campaign of motivational seminars and exercises. Posters and signs -- everything from "Be Here Now" to "Empowered to Delight the Customer" -- can make Bell Atlantic seem like a Boy Scout troop taken over by New Age cultists.
Mr. Smith's continuing experience as a writer, director and actor in local theater has enhanced his ability to judge his audience and vary his approach. He studied at night to earn master's degrees in business and in literature. He can recite Chaucer as readily as he can break into song. His favorite plays, like "Rosencrantz and Guildenstern Are Dead," by Tom Stoppard, turn conventional thinking upside down -- in this case, by devoting a whole play to the antics of some marginal characters from "Hamlet."
 
 
Reasons for His Roles
 He makes no apologies for his ability to play roles ranging from conciliatory statesman to relentless taskmaster. "It's not manipulative," he said. "It's a sales skill. If you're selling a concept to a group of scientists, you don't present it the same as you would to a group of schoolchildren."
Having told everyone in the company to write down their worst faults on cards and scold themselves always, he recited his: "I will be more patient and I will listen to your point of view and recognize it."
That is, up to a point. "There's nobody who gets to the top of a big business without a sense of impatience," he added.
But Mr. Malone, as a billion-dollar shareholder on the Bell Atlantic board, might win Mr. Smith's forbearance. And envy.
"I told him if I had a choice of having the exciting new areas to deal with and get a billion dollars," Mr. Smith said, "or all the horsefeathers I have to deal with, I think he got the better deal."
Just the sort of thing Ray Smith must have said to persuade John Malone to sign.

HEADLINE: More Banks Nationwide Are Urged

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration favors giving banks the right to operate more freely across state lines, but has decided not to push the issue until other banking and economic legislation clears Congress, Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen said today.
Current restrictions on interstate banking require banks to create separate subsidiaries to operate in more than one state, a cumbersome and costly deterrent to expansion. 
 In a speech here to the Center for National Policy, a public affairs research institute, Mr. Bentsen said removing these barriers would ease credit nationwide and strengthen banks by unhitching them from the economies of individual states.
The American Bankers Association, the largest industry trade organization, generally welcomed the approach he outlined, but consumer groups expressed reservations.
In a letter to Mr. Bentsen, nine groups said interstate deregulation would harm consumers and communities, especially poorer ones, by allowing deposits to be drained away into loans in other regions. Among those signing the letter were the United States Conference of Mayors, the National League of Cities, Public Citizen, Consumers Union and the Consumer Federation of America.
Several versions of interstate branching legislation are moving through Congress, which has tried and failed to enact such a bill in the past. Administration officials are to testify on Tuesday about their goals for any such bill.
The approach favored by the Administration, Mr. Bentsen said, would allow bank holding companies that now maintain separate operating subsidiaries in more than one state to merge their operations into a single bank with branches in each state, as long as the states permit it. Banks that now operate in only one state would be able to open branches in another, also only if the states agreed.
"This would continue to leave it entirely to the states, and that's a major point, to decide if they don't want out-of-state banks doing business within their borders," he said.
 
What Kind of Legislation?
 It remained unclear whether the Administration favored an approach that would require each state to pass new legislation to join the national system, or one that would require that a state enact a new law if it wanted to opt out of the system.
Mr. Bentsen's remarks were the clearest signal to date that the Administration intends to support broader freedom for banks to operate nationwide, an approach Administration officials believe would make them healthier and increase the availability of credit.
But it also made clear that the Administration does not want other provisions combined with those involving interstate banking, a pattern that has often doomed banking legislation in the past. "Overreaching, polarization, and piling on can only lead to failure," he said.
Two major banking bills are before Congress, one to provide money to complete the cleanup of the savings-and-loan crisis, the other to help financial institutions that focus on lending in poor areas. The Administration does not want either weighed down by interstate banking.
On another topic, Mr. Bentsen said the Administration would act more assertively to open foreign markets to American banks and other financial institutions.
He said negotiators would push this demand in the Uruguay Round of talks under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, and to back this up, it would support legislation before Congress to deny new benefits to financial institutions based in countries that deny open access to Americans. That threat would become more important to foreign financial institutions if, as the Administration intends, banks operating in the United States are granted new powers, like interstate branching.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Clinic Chain Seeks a Deal With a Rival

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM

 BODY:
Surgical Care Affiliates Inc., bidding to build a nationwide network of 146 walk-in surgery centers, said yesterday that it had offered to merge with Medical Care America, a troubled competitor, in a stock swap valued at $941 million.
"The urge to merge continues," said John F. Hindelong, a health care analyst at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. 
 Hospitals and other medical services companies have been wooing partners to gain negotiating strength as they face the regional health alliances that would be a centerpiece of President Clinton's health plan.
Surgical Care Affiliates, based in Nashville, has 55 surgery centers in 21 states; Medical Care America, based in Dallas, has 91 surgery centers and 47 home infusion centers in 32 states. The infusion centers supervise intravenous treatments in the home.
 
Shares Jump 30 Percent
 Medical Care America shares jumped 30 percent yesterday on news of the offer, closing at $24.625, up $5.625 in heavy trading on the New York Stock Exchange. It was the largest percentage gain of the day. Surgical Care Affiliates slipped 87.5 cents, to close at $19 on the Big Board.
Showing little eagerness for the offer, of which it was informed in an Oct. 14 letter from Joel C. Gordon, chairman of Surgical Care Affiliates, Medical Care America said yesterday that its board would respond "in due course."
Mr. Gordon said yesterday he was "disappointed" by the reaction. He hinted he might raise the bid if the Dallas company opened its books.
Surgical Care Affiliates offered to convert each Medical Care share to 1.35 shares of S.C.A. common stock. Medical Care had 36.7 million shares outstanding on June 30.
 
Possibility of a Counteroffer
 Randall S. Huyser at Furman Selz said the proposed merger would be "a good fit," but Mr. Hindelong suggested it might attract a counteroffer from the Columbia Healthcare Corporation, the aquisition-minded hospital chain based in Louisville, Ky.
Columbia already has joint ventures with both Surgical Care Affiliates and Medical Care America, offering "one-stop shopping" to managed-care customers. Columbia Healthcare, awaiting Federal antitrust approval for its planned merger with the HCA-Hospital Corporation, had no comment yesterday on the surgery center offer.
Economy-minded payers often direct patients to surgery centers, which do not keep them overnight and typically have lower overhead and charges than hospitals.
Joyce Albers at CS First Boston said Medical Care America "became a target" after disappointing results in the home infusion business that it acquired 13 months ago in a poorly timed merger with Critical Care America. Insurers that pay for home care were driving down prices. Medical Care's profits faded, sending the Dallas company's shares plunging from the 1992 high of $64.
Growth in surgery center business has also slowed to single digits, Mr. Hindelong said, although the long-term outlook seems relatively strong. Many hospitals have established their own ambulatory surgical units.
Mr. Gordon said he would try to rebuild Medical Care America's troubled home infusion business if the merger wents through. "We cannot get rid of it or sell it for two years," he said, to preserve the tax-free "pooling" accounting advantages in the stock swap.
Bear, Stearns & Company and Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom are advising Surgical Care Affiliates.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Boeing Profit Falls 45.2% As Airlines Stay Weak

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 25

 BODY:
The Boeing Company today reported a 45.2 percent decline in third-quarter earnings, citing continuing weakness in the airline industry and soft military and space business.
Boeing, based in Seattle, said earnings fell to $189 million, or 56 cents a share, from the third quarter last year. Sales fell 25.3 percent, to $5.15 billion. 
 Analysts said the lower results indicated the company had not returned to growth and might not for some time despite a recent decision to retain some workers previously scheduled for layoffs.
"What the results are telling you is the bottom is still some distance off in the future and cannot be identified as yet," said Howard A. Rubel, an analyst with Goldman, Sachs. He said Boeing appeared to be willing to sacrifice some sales to keep profit margins higher. "Boeing would rather hold price rather than rate, so rates will come down while prices remain constant," he said, referring to profit margin rates.
 
Shares Are Lower
 Boeing shares dropped 87.5 cents today to close at $37.375 on the New York Stock Exchange.
Sales and earnings for the fourth quarter, the company said, will be well above the third quarter based on current programs and schedules. Sales for the year are expected to be in the $25.5 billion range. But a trend to lower sales would continue through 1994, the company said.
Production is being slowed to reduce the rate of building 737's to 10 a month, the 757 to 5 a month and the 767 to 3 a month. In early 1994, the 747 production rate will be reduced to three from five a month.
"Economic growth in the major airline traffic markets worldwide continues to be weak, particularly in Western Europe and Japan," Frank A. Shrontz, Boeing's chairman and chief executive, said in a statement. "Consequently, airline industry profitability, although improving in the aggregate, is expected to remain below historical levels in the near term. In this environment, the company continues to review airline requirements and associated production rates for late 1994 and beyond."
Boeing said 142 new orders valued at $9.8 billion were announced by customers during the first nine months, down from 158 aircraft valued at $11.5 billion for the corresponding period last year.
"Although new-order activity in the present environment remains depressed, the company has been successful at maintaining its historical market share," Mr. Shrontz said.

HEADLINE: In a Gritty Town, Hope Outlives the Prosperity

BYLINE: By MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SHAMOKIN, Pa.

 BODY:
Against all odds, pine trees have taken root on the black mountain of coal mining waste that looms above this small city in central Pennsylvania. The people of Shamokin have also put down deep roots, holding fast to a bleak place despite a harsh economic climate. It is a triumph of time over adversity.
By objective measures, Shamokin (pronounced shuh-MO-kin) is a dying town. The coal and textile industries folded up years ago, unemployment rose, and most of the young people fled. 
 A quarter of the 9,200 residents here are over 65, a demographic fact apparent on any street on any weekday, making Shamokin's population the second oldest of any Pennsylvania city's, after Monongahela's. And except for Florida, Pennsylvania has the oldest population in the country, with 15.4 percent of its residents over 65, a fact the state recognizes by spending its lottery revenues on programs for people over 65.
 
A Prison Is Good News
 One of the few bits of good economic news lately was Shamokin's victory over a dozen other communities in the competition for a new state prison. The city sold bonds to build the institution, which opened a year ago just outside of town, and is leasing it back to the state. "Last October we had a job fair for 400 jobs at the prison, and 4,300 to 4,500 people came and applied," said David F. Matash, manager of the Shamokin Job Agency, a state employment office.
It is not clear how much the prison will mean to businesses in Shamokin, since many of the institution's supplies are bought elsewhere. But there are hopes that the utilities installed to serve the prison can make it easier to lure industry to the community.
To visit Shamokin (or any one of dozens of small towns like it) is to see a Pennsylvania a world away from the vitality of Pittsburgh and Philadelphia and just as far removed from the prosperity it once enjoyed from the mines and mills. To visit Shamokin is to be reminded, too, of how the bonds of place and family can sustain a community as it grows old and stares into a bleak future.
During the day, after many of the people of working age have driven to jobs as far away as Harrisburg, 55 miles to the south, or even Philadelphia, 125 miles away, Shamokin looks like a retirement community. But the gathering places are not golf courses but church basements.
 
Getting By, Thank You
 Many of the elderly in Shamokin say they lack for nothing they can't do without. But there are only a half-dozen doctors in town -- too few, the state says, to serve Shamokin and surrounding Northumberland County. The city does not have a pediatrician.
On a recent morning, a dozen elderly women sat around a table in the St. Stephen's Roman Catholic Church basement, peeling potatoes and onions to make pirogi, or dumplings, to sell to benefit the church school.
A 79-year-old widow, Vi Golden, said that on a typical weekday she went to 8 A.M. Mass, then helped out at a nursing home. Dinner is often a spaghetti or chicken plate at church. Her parents immigrated from Poland to work in the mines, and she has lived in Shamokin all her life. Her seven children all moved away to find work. "I do miss them," she said.
Mrs. Golden, who worked in factories and as a cook, retired with no pension and lives on a $517 monthly Social Security check. She lives in a frame house, next to her 87-year-old sister-in-law. "The house needs everything," she said, especially a new furnace.
People dismiss the notion that their city could wither away. They talk about living in homes built by their grandparents and attending churches their families helped build.
Their city is poor: the median household income is $14,500, and 21 percent of its residents live in poverty.
"It is disheartening when our youth have to go elsewhere for employment," said James E. Yurick, a city councilman and carpentry instructor at the regional vocational school. But he added, "I don't look at Shamokin as a dying city, and I don't look at Shamokin as a depressed, older community."
The biggest concern for many people is the Catholic Church's recent proposal to close five of the city's eight churches. "I have a lot of sorrow in my heart with all this talk of church mergers," said Dolores Demas, 63, a secretary at St. Stephen's Church.
Shamokin started as a mining camp in the early 1800's and reached its peak population of 21,200 in 1920. The coal mines gave out in the 1930's, and the textile mills and shoe factories began losing out to foreign mills in the 1970's.
In August, the last of the city's dress makers closed, laying off about 200 workers and pushing the local jobless rate to about 12 percent, compared with 6.7 percent nationally.
The city's biggest employer is the school district, but just outside the city limits, in an industrial park, several large companies employ a total of about 1,000 workers. They build mobile homes, package greeting cards and print tickets for theaters.
After being unemployed most of the last three years, Michael J. Canfield, 31, just started working for one of these companies as a part-time machinist at $9.60 an hour. He said that he had worked in Orlando, Fla., for five years but that he preferred the coal region. "It's more peaceful around here, and people know everybody," he said.
Ms. Demas, the church secretary, says that she and her husband moved away from Shamokin to Baltimore in 1950, so he could find work as a truck driver. They missed Shamokin so much that she recalls the date they were able to come back: July 25, 1986. "We couldn't wait to return," she said.
Shamokin is a sleepy place where people sit for hours on their porches. The most prominent building downtown is an abandoned shoe factory with a copper clock tower and six stories of broken windows. There used to be an empty textile factory across the street, but it recently burned down. The business district has several blocks of small shops, restaurants and medical supply businesses.
 
Pressures From Outside
 Shopping malls 20 miles away have taken their toll. Some Shamokin storefronts are vacant, two clothing stores are closing, and the largest store, J.C. Penney, had only a few customers one recent afternoon. Next door to Penney's, "Sleepless in Seattle" was playing in the only movie theater.
Residential streets, with names like Anthracite, Carbon and Coal, fan off the downtown area, up into the hills whose coal has scarcely been worth mining for decades. The mines and mills were not locally owned, so there are few big houses in town.
But no matter what it looks like, no matter what it is, Shamokin is home to some people. After going to Harvard College and Medical School, Dr. Wayne Miller returned to Shamokin to care for the elderly. They include his grandfather, Robert Evans, a retired miner who has black lung disease.
"I've always enjoyed living here," said Dr. Miller, who is 31 and practices internal medicine. "I grew up here seeing that the medical care was substandard, and I've always planned to come back."
Mr. Evans, who is 81, said he was not surprised by the decision. "We're doing pretty good here," he said.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Rises on Expectation Of More German Rate Cuts

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar moved higher against most major currencies yesterday as traders anticipated more cuts in German interest rates and further improvement in the American economy.
Gold prices fell after rising overseas. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for December delivery settled at $370.50 an ounce, down 80 cents from late Friday. The Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late bid for spot gold of $369.30 an ounce, off 70 cents. 
 Trevor Woodland, chief corporate trader for Harris Trust and Savings Bank in Chicago, said the currency market remained bullish on the dollar after Thursday's cut in two important interest rates by the Bundesbank, Germany's central bank.
The surprise move -- which was intended to prop up the weak German economy -- prompted several other European countries to follow suit last week.
Lower interest rates abroad tend to drive the dollar higher, as investors shift money into dollar-denominated investments to capture higher yields.
At the same time, currency traders were banking on stable to higher interest rates in the United States, Mr. Woodland said.
"The market is looking for some reasonably good numbers for America's gross domestic product for the third quarter," he said. "Some feel it will be in excess of 3 percent" growth.
The Commerce Department is expected to release its third-quarter report on the nation's G.D.P. on Thursday.
In late New York trading, the dollar rose to 1.6855 marks, from 1.6755 marks on Friday. It also rose to 108.58 Japanese yen, from 108.05 yen on Friday.
But the dollar was weaker against the British pound. In New York, sterling was quoted at $1.4790, up from $1.4735.
Other late New York dollar rates compared with late Friday rates, included: 1.4855 Swiss francs, up from 1.4755; 5.8690 French francs, up from 5.8539; 1,616 Italian lire, up from 1,613, and $1.3123 Canadian, up from $1.3043 Canadian.

HEADLINE: GOVERNING TORIES IN CANADA ROUTED BY LIBERAL PARTY

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TORONTO, Tuesday, Oct. 26

 BODY:
The Liberal Party, led by Jean Chretien, a Quebec lawyer and former Cabinet minister, steamrolled to victory in elections Monday that foreshadowed major changes in Canada's political landscape.
The Liberals swept Ontario and the eastern provinces, crushing the Progressive Conservatives, who have led the country for nine years. A preliminary count gave the Liberals 177 seats in the House of Commons, a clear majority of the total of 295, to just 2 for the Conservatives, who had held the majority. 
 "The time has come to put the country back on the right track," Mr. Chretien told cheering supporters early this morning.
Bloc Quebecois took 54 of the 75 Commons seats contested in Quebec. The Bloc, whose main platform is to prepare for Quebec's secession from Canada, is expected to become the official parliamentary opposition.
 
Opposes Secession of Quebec
 "I say to our friends in English Canada that our victory tonight represents a unique occasion to begin a new relationship founded on honesty and respect," the Bloc's leader, Lucien Bouchard, said Monday night.
Although Mr. Chretien, 59, the 18th of 19 children, was born in a paper-mill town in central Quebec where the sentiment for separation is strong, he passionately supports keeping Quebec within Canada.
In western Canada the populist Reform Party, made up chiefly of disaffected Tories, picked up 52 seats, becoming the third-ranking party.
The results could end the political career of the Conservative Prime Minister, Kim Campbell, the first woman to hold the office. She took over last June from Brian Mulroney, who left office with the lowest popularity ratings of any Canadian leader in this century.
 
A Brutal Defeat
 The Tories, with their 2 seats, and the New Democrats, who won 9, both lost their official party status, which requires at least 12 seats. One seat went to an independent.
Never in history has a governing party been so punished.
Ms. Campbell, who lost her seat in Vancouver, said in her concession speech that she accepted the judgment of the people "with disappointment but without reservation." She added with a smile: "I'm glad I didn't sell my car."
In the past, the Liberal Party has had strained relations with the United States. But although Mr. Chretien has criticized the North American Free Trade Agreement and has said he would seek some changes, there have been signs that he would seek some accommodation with Washington.
 
Ties With U.S. Seem Firm
 Although Liberal governments have tended to be more adversarial than the Tories in relations with the United States, Mr. Chretien is unlikely to alter the existing close links between the two countries, analysts said.
The election caught Canadians in a state of enduring petulance, anxious for politicians who could offer help but distrustful of their promises. "There is a fury in the land," said a broadcaster and professor, Keith Spicer, in a national report in 1991. "Canada looks to Canadians like a pessimist's nightmare from hell."
Little has changed since then. Joblessness has been stuck at around 11 percent, or 1.6 million people, and hundreds of thousands of Canadians are on welfare.
One of the few Conservative victories was that of Jean Charest, in Sherbrooke, Quebec. He was the runner-up to Ms. Campbell at the Conservative leadership convention last June.
Mr. Chretien saved his seat in St. Maurice, Quebec, in the Bloc Quebecois surge. Although he ran a low-key campaign, he could not undo his image among many Quebecers as one of those responsible for isolating the province when he served in Pierre Elliott Trudeau's Cabinet and blunting Quebec's demands for more power.
The Bloc also made headway against warnings by the Quebec Premier, Robert Bourassa, and Mr. Trudeau that a victory by the separatists would carve a dangerous faultline in Quebec unity.
There are still hurdles to jump before Quebec goes off on its own. First the provincial separatist party, the Parti Quebecois, must win an election next year. Then a majority of Quebecers must vote "yes" in a referendum; in a referendum on separation in 1980, 60 percent voted "no."
There were a record 2,155 candidates from 14 registered parties running for the 295 seats. Before today's vote, Conservatives held 153 seats, Liberals 79, New Democrats 43 and Bloc Quebecois 8. The Reform Party and the Independent Conservatives each held one. There were 10 vacancies.
Mr. Chretien and President Clinton share a belief in activist government and face similar problems of increasing economic growth and cutting budget deficits. Both are more practical than ideological and hew to the more conservative policies of their parties.
 
'Bad Old Days' Are Over
 "The excellent relations with the United States will continue virtually unchanged," predicted Robert H. Pines, Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for Canada for three years in the Bush Administration and a friend of Mr. Chretien. "There is no going back to the bad old days of the 1970's."
Mr. Pines was referring to the strains that existed under Mr. Trudeau, the last Liberal Prime Minister, an urbane, leftist intellectual whose nationalistic policies on energy and investment provoked a series of crises with Washington.
Still, the Liberal victory could present the Clinton Administration with some new problems with the North American Free Trade Agreement, which would lower tariffs imposed by Canada, the United States and Mexico on one another's goods. Mr. Chretien said during the seven-week campaign that he wanted new talks with Washington to win greater protection for Canadian exporters.
 
What to Do About Nafta
 The trade agreement can be amended after it goes into force, and its provisions are also subject to interpretation by the three governments. Officials in Washington have said they would prefer a Liberal Government to pursue one of these options rather than demand to reopen the original pact, a tactic the Clinton Administration has said it would rebuff.
Robert Rubin, head of the National Economic Council at the White House, said Monday evening that the Administration was confident Canadian concerns could be addressed, but he refused to discuss details.
A Canadian withdrawal from Nafta would have little economic effect on the United States because the two countries already have a separate trade agreement. If Canada rejects Nafta, free trade would remain in effect between Canada and the United States and between Mexico and the United States, but not between Canada and Mexico.
Mr. Chretien, derided by the Tories as "yesterday's man," was able to bring more than 30 years' experience to bear in what even Ms. Campbell agreed was an excellent campaign.
"I'm quite prepared to give Mr. Chretien the gold star," she said last week, after polls showed the Tories falling to fourth place behind the Liberals, Bloc Quebecois and the Reform Party, a western regional party that has attracted disenchanted Tories.
Ms. Campbell, a lawyer and teacher who was elected to the House of Commons for the first time in 1988, made a number of tactical and strategic errors during the campaign. She also had to carry the baggage of nine years of Tory rule under her predecessor, Brian Mulroney, who left office with the lowest popularity rating for any Canadian leader this century.
For Canada's left-leaning New Democrats, the vote was also a disaster. All the party's Ontario seats were lost. A leading member of the party, Bob Rae, is the Premier of Ontario but he has become highly unpopular.
 
Advertisement Gone Awry
 Mr. Chretien sensed early that the key issue was jobs. Ms. Campbell focused initially on the ballooning budget deficit and the need to cut it. But her presentation tended to bog down in details and her points were hard to follow for many Canadians.
Ms. Campbell also stumbled when she appeared in early comments to abandon hope of dramatically reducing unemployment before the end of the century. Another gaffe occurred when she remarked that an election campaign was not the time to discuss Canada's social programs.
A final blow was a series of advertisements taken out by the Tories that appeared to ridicule Mr. Chretien's facial paralysis. Mr. Chretien stood his ground with dignity. "It's true I have a physical defect," he said. "God gave it to me." Ms. Campbell pulled the ads.
Canadians complain that they are over-taxed. Yet there is a federal budget deficit of $35 billion ($27 billion United States), and interest on the mushrooming debt takes an ever larger share of expenditures.
Mr. Chretien wooed voters at least partly with the promise of a $6 billion ($4.5 billion) public-works program to upgrade roads, sewers and bridges. Ms. Campbell was highly critical of the program, asking where the money would come from and what people would do once the funds ran out.

THE GOVERNMENT: Canada is a constitutional monarchy, a self-governing dominion in the British Commonwealth. Queen Elizabeth II of England is also Canada's Queen. She delegates her largely ceremonial powers to the Governor General, Ramon J. Hnatyshyn. Its powers to the Governor General, Ramon J. Hnatyshyn. Its constitution was initially a British statute, the jBritish North America Act of 1867. Until 1982 its amendment required action by the British Parliament. In that year tghe Consitution was "patriated," meaning that Canadians obtained the right to amend the Constitution in Canada. Canada has two official languages, English and French, and two systems of law: Civil Law (in Quebec) and Common Law (in English Canada).
 
YESTERDAY'S VOTE: There were 2,155 candidates running in the 295 districts or ridings from 14 officially registered political parties. Only one member of Parliament is elected for each electoral district, although any number of candidates may run. The candidate with the plurality wins. The constitution requires election of a new House of Commons every five years.
 
WHO VOTES: There ar 18.5 million eligible voters. The total population is 27 million. In the 15 federal elections since 1945, the average turnout rate for voters has been 75.3 percent. The highest turnout rate was 80.6 percent in the 1958 election.

PUB-DATE: October 26, 1993

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 4; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 2252 words

HEADLINE: SWING VOTE SEEMS TO DRIFT TO MAYOR, BUT POLL IS CLOSE

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
Hispanic New Yorkers, women and other vital swing voters appear to have drifted back toward Mayor David N. Dinkins in the last three weeks, but his overall support remains below 50 percent and voters continue to express enduring reservations about him in a close and unpredictable race, the latest New York Times/WCBS-TV News poll shows.
At the same time, Rudolph W. Giuliani's negative ratings on qualities like trustworthiness and leadership have crept up and his positive ratings have slipped a bit, though voters still overwhelmingly view him as the tougher candidate on crime, the No. 1 issue they say they want the next Mayor to address. 
 Just one week before Election Day, a majority of New Yorkers believe both candidates have spent more time attacking each other than explaining what they would do if elected. Four in 10 said Mr. Giuliani has been more responsible for the negative tone while just under one-quarter of voters surveyed blamed the Mayor.
 
Debate as a Requirement
 With little apparent prospect of a face-to-face debate between the two candidates, nearly 60 percent of voters said they should be required to debate, and nearly two-thirds said any debate should include the Conservative Party candidate, George J. Marlin, as Mr. Dinkins has insisted. Mr. Giuliani has refused to debate if Mr. Marlin is included.
Voters were evenly split over a ballot proposal to limit municipal officeholders to two consecutive four-year terms, with 47 percent favoring that idea and 47 percent opposing it.
Over all, the Democratic Mayor holds a slight edge, leading his Republican-Liberal challenger among registered voters 46 percent to 40 percent, which is just within the poll's margin of sampling error of plus or minus 3 percentage points for each candidate. Another 1 percent supported Mr. Marlin -- a drop from past polls, despite his increased exposure in two televised debates with Mr. Dinkins. Two percent said they favored no one and 11 percent were undecided. The telephone poll, taken Wednesday through Sunday, interviewed 1,721 adults, of whom 1,147 said they were registered voters.
In other contests, Assemblyman Alan G. Hevesi, the Democratic nominee for Comptroller, led Herman Badillo, the Republican-Liberal nominee, by 43 percent to 30 percent, while Mark Green, the Democratic candidate for Public Advocate held a commanding lead of 53 percent to 22 percent over Susan D. Alter, the Republican-Liberal candidate.
But there were signs that the mayoral race may be even closer than it seems. When undecided voters were pressed to say which way they were leaning, the contest tightened to 48 to 43, and among those who said they would definitely vote, Mr. Dinkins led 49 to 45. When, following the method used in a 1991 study by the Gallup Organization, the remaining undecided voters were allocated to the candidate of their own race, Mr. Dinkins led 49 to 48.
Moreover, past polls have substantially overstated support for black candidates, and a nationwide study of contests in which black and white candidates faced each other suggests that unless the black candidate holds a lead of 8 percentage points in pre-election polls, chances are he has no lead at all. That is because undecided voters -- most of whom are white -- tend to vote ultimately for the white candidate, instead of splitting evenly between the candidates.
In 1989, late polls showed double- digit leads for Mr. Dinkins, and he ended up defeating Mr. Giuliani by just 2 percentage points.
Still, the poll showed recent trends boding comparatively well for the Mayor. He now leads among Hispanic voters 51 percent to 31 percent, a much better standing than in earlier polls this year but still short of his 2 to 1 advantage among this group in 1989. He leads among women 49 percent to 34 percent, while his overall white support has edged up to 25 percent -- the minimum that Dinkins advisers have long said is necessary to win -- though his support among Jewish voters is hovering just below 25 percent, considerably less than the 35 percent he won in the last election.
By contrast, Mr. Giuliani appears to have stalled in his effort to improve his image with voters since the previous New York Times/WCBS-TV News poll at the beginning of the month, and his negative ratings have risen slightly, while Mr. Dinkins's have held steady, if decidedly mixed, with voters evenly divided over whether the Mayor shows strong qualities of leadership.
 
Criticizing Lapses
 In the last month, a prominent Dinkins supporter has accused Mr. Giuliani of attracting fascist elements, Dinkins campaign commercials have attacked his past equivocation on abortion rights, and Mr. Giuliani has responded by criticizing Mr. Dinkins for a litany of lapses beginning with his failure to file income-tax returns two decades ago.
All that fighting seems to have had an impact. For example, 31 percent of voters now say Mr. Giuliani does not have strong qualities of leadership, compared to 25 percent three weeks ago.
Thirty percent said he does not care about the needs and problems of average New Yorkers, compared to 26 percent three weeks ago, while 52 percent said he does care, down from 58 percent at the start of the month. Among Hispanic voters, 45 percent said Mr. Giuliani cared about the needs and problems of average New Yorkers, down from 58 percent at the beginning of the month, and well below the 73 percent of Hispanic New Yorkers who said Mr. Dinkins cared.
One-third of voters said Mr. Giuliani can be trusted to deal with the city's problems, down from 38 percent, and 50 percent said he might make serious mistakes, up from 46 percent.
The survey found that Mr. Giuliani's supporters are overwhelmingly motivated by their dissatisfaction with Mr. Dinkins, rather than by any attribute of Mr. Giuliani's that they could think of, with 44 percent of Giuliani voters citing unhappiness with the current administration as the main reason for backing him. In contrast, one-quarter of Dinkins voters said they backed him because he was the best man, four times the rate for Mr. Giuliani's supporters.
The poll also suggests that Mr. Giuliani has failed to make stick his charge that the Mayor is responsible for a steady decline in the conditions in the city. Nearly 6 in 10 voters said life has gotten worse in the city in the last four years, but just 15 percent of those who said conditions had worsened held the Mayor "mostly responsible."
Crime and drugs remain New Yorkers' top concern, with about half of voters citing those as the problems they wanted the next Mayor to concentrate on, and half saying the city is less safe than it was four years ago. But it is less clear how that plays out as a campaign issue, since a plurality of voters said they saw more police officers walking in their neighborhoods, nearly two-thirds said they had not seen anyone in their neighborhoods selling drugs and three-quarters said neither they nor anyone in their family had been the victim of a crime in the last year.
In the latest poll this month, black New Yorkers were about 10 percentage points less likely than white and Hispanic residents to say they had been the victim of a crime, breaking past patterns and confounding the statistical reality that blacks are more likely than others to be crime victims. That may suggest that with crime a major issue and the political future of the first black to be the city's Mayor at stake, blacks are reluctant to stress the issue.
Crime remains Mr. Giuliani's most potent issue, with 69 percent of voters saying he is tough enough to deal with it, compared with just 38 percent for the Mayor.
By contrast, the Mayor is perceived as the more caring. For example, 57 percent of white voters say people in their neighborhood would be treated fairly if Mr. Dinkins won re-election, while 56 percent of black voters said people in their neighborhoods would not be treated fairly if Mr. Giuliani won.
 
Looking Toward Turnout
 Bill Lynch, the Mayor's campaign manager, said the poll seemed to vindicate his strategy that core Democratic voters like women and Hispanic New Yorkers would return to the Dinkins camp once the candidates' records and philosophies were compared. But he expressed concern about complacency in drawing voters to the polls, and he plans a busy week of stumping, highlighted by a Thursday visit from President Clinton.
"Where I'm focused now is not on polls but on turning out the vote on Nov. 2," he said. "This helps us to be a little bit more optimistic that where we're headed is the right direction." "
Mr. Giuliani's top strategist, David Garth, said he was not surprised at the poll's findings. "That's the result of negative attacks that painted us unfairly, and a combination of the paid media ads and the free media that corroborated it," he said. "But I think we'll win because there are enough people out there that we can bring together."
While the contest remains volatile, 79 percent of each candidate's supporters said they had made up their minds, compared to 19 percent who said they might yet change their minds, down sharply from the 35 percent of Giuliani supporters who said they might change their minds three weeks ago.
A plurality of voters said that such problems as race relations and the economy would remain about the same whoever won, though the Mayor won slightly higher marks for race relations.
But Mr. Dinkins appeared to have substantially more intense support, with 59 percent of his backers strongly favoring him, compared to just 35 percent of Mr. Giuliani's supporters. Voters were evenly divided on the available candidates, with half expressing satisfaction at the choices and nearly half wishing they had other options.
Fifty-three percent now say President Clinton's suggestion that "too many of us are still to unwilling to vote for people who are different than we are" was not true, while 39 percent said it was true. That contrasts to early this month, just after the President spoke, when voters were evenly divided.
Mayor Edward I. Koch's endorsement of Mr. Giuliani was apparently a wash, with 69 percent of voters saying it would not influence them, while 14 percent said it would make them more likely to pick Mr. Giuliani and another 14 percent said it made them less likely to do so.
As has been true all year, voters' views of the candidates remained starkly polarized along racial lines, with just 18 percent of white voters having an over all favorable opinion of the Mayor and only 3 percent of blacks having a favorable view of Mr. Giuliani.
 
 
 
HOW THE POLL WAS CONDUCTED
 The latest New York Times/WCBS-TV News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Oct. 20 to 24 in all parts of New York City with 1,721 adults, of whom 1,147 said they were registered voters. Interviews were conducted in either English or Spanish.
The sample of telephone exchanges called was selected by a computer from a complete list of city exchanges. The exchanges were chosen so as to assure that each area in the city was represented in proportion to its population. For each exchange, the telephone numbers were formed by random digits, thus permitting access to both listed and unlisted numbers. Within each household one adult was designated by a random procedure to be the respondent for the survey.
The results have been weighted to take account of household size and number of telephone lines into the residence, and to adjust for variations in the sample relating to borough, race, sex, age and education.
In theory, in 19 cases out of 20 the results based on such samples will differ by no more than 3 percentage points in either direction from what would have been obtained by seeking out all adult New Yorkers.
For smaller subgroups the potential sampling error is larger. For example, it is plus or minus 4 percentage points for white registered voters, 6 points for black registered voters, and 8 points for Hispanic registered voters.
In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey of public opinion may introduce other sources of error into the poll. Differences in the wording and order of questions, for instance, can lead to somewhat varying results.
And in a poll conducted more than a week before an election, like this one, there are additional potential difficulties, like dramatic events, debates, or campaign appeals that occur after the interviewing, unusual patterns of voter turnout, and the ultimate decisions made by those voters who were undecided at the time of the poll or who said they might change their mind before Election Day.

HEADLINE: Washington Memo;
Economic Outlaw: American Health Care

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25

 BODY:
In health care today, fundamental principles of the marketplace do not apply.
Prices are not determined by supply and demand or by competition among producers. Comparison shopping is impossible. Greater productivity does not lower costs. 
 Sometimes, in fact, the system works exactly opposite of the way of the normal marketplace. For example, the providers of the service -- doctors and hospitals -- determine how much of their service their customers will buy. Their customers, the patients, can rarely evaluate the quality of the service they are receiving.
This is one reason medical costs are rising out of control -- and one reason almost every plan being considered for overhauling the system would try to introduce some basic economic principles.
Under President Clinton's plan, for instance, most Americans would be offered more choice than they now have about what kind of medical insurance coverage they carry. And competition among insurance companies and comparison shopping by consumers would be theoretically enhanced because most Americans would buy their medical insurance through large cooperatives that would negotiate for the best price and quality.
 
Insurance: Hiding the Costs
 Economists agree that the health care industry can never work entirely according to the rules of the marketplace. Unlike almost every other thing consumers spend money for, good health is priceless; people place no limit on what they will pay.
But economists also agree that medicine does not have to stray as far outside the marketplace as it does now. Here are some examples of how the American health care system operates with almost total disregard for basic economic principles.
The single most important deviation from the normal rules of economics involves the way medical insurance insulates consumers from the cost of the product they are purchasing. Insurance covers more than 90 percent of the hospital charges and more than 75 percent of the doctor bills Americans pay. This is why doctors normally do not post their rates and why patients generally do not take the trouble to find out the cost of treatment in advance.
Other forms of insurance that most people carry protect them against rare, costly occurrences like an automobile accident or a fire. Medical insurance, on the other hand, covers routine expenses. If people's car insurance paid 80 percent of the cost of normal maintenance and repairs, it is a safe bet that their cars would spend more time in the shop.
By the same token, Americans have every incentive to seek additional medical care, even if the benefit they stand to gain is modest compared with the total cost. It is not like deciding whether to take a suit to the cleaners to have a small spot removed or whether to order push-button windows on a new car.
Of course, health insurance is expensive. But mostly the premiums are paid by employers, and workers often have no idea how much they cost. Nor do most workers have any reason to believe that their paychecks would be larger if their medical insurance premiums and coverage were reduced.
Further masking the cost of health care is the fact that insurance premiums are tax-free. So workers often seek more generous insurance with lower deductibles and broader coverage rather than asking for the money in wages.
 
Consumerism
System Impedes Shopping for Value
 In contrast to the way people buy most products and services, they do little comparison shopping for medical treatments. One reason is that because of health insurance money is no object. Another obvious one is that people who are really sick are in no position to shop around.
Perhaps most important, a patient depends on a doctor to decide what treatment is needed. And a patient does not have the information or expertise to evaluate the quality of a doctor or the services being provided, as someone would judge, say, the ability and performance of a barber or even a lawyer.
Generally, a patient does not choose a hospital either; the selection is made by the patient's doctor on the basis of where the doctor practices, not on the basis of the quality of the hospital or the prices it charges.
Comparison shopping is further hindered by the fact that a consumer rarely knows the full range of alternative treatments available or the pluses and minuses of the various treatments.
To illustrate that point, researchers at Dartmouth Medical School tried to determine how patients would respond if they were thoroughly informed about various possible treatments. The researchers found, for example, that when they used videotapes and other techniques to explain carefully the advantages and disadvantages of prostate surgery, the number of patients at the Veterans Administration hospital in White River Junction, Vt., who decided against having such surgery increased significantly.
A study by Abt Associates, a consulting firm, found that doctors who performed and charged for their own radiological tests prescribed such tests at least four times as often and charged higher fees than did doctors who referred their patients to radiologists.
Pharmaceutical companies advertise heavily to persuade doctors to prescribe their products. When the patent expires on a profitable drug, the company owning the patent usually does not reduce the price of the medicine to compete with identical, lower-cost generic drugs that immediately come on the market. Instead, drug companies generally raise the price to pay for more advertising to persuade doctors to keep prescribing their product.
For example, since 1987, according to Senate testimony this year, McNeil Consumer Products Company, a division of Johnson & Johnson, has doubled the average price it charges wholesalers for Tylenol No. 3, a prescription painkiller, even though the generic drug cost one-third as much.
Consumers delegate decision-making authority in many fields other than medicine. For example, they generally rely on a mechanic to determine what work needs to be done on their car. The difference is that in markets other than medicine, there is a limit to what consumers are willing to pay. A mechanic gives a cost estimate in advance, and the customer makes an informed judgment on whether the work is worth the price.
 
Economics
Health Care Defies Laws of the Market
 The fundamental law of the marketplace is that of supply and demand. When the supply of a product exceeds the demand for it, the price should fall. This is the main reason peanut butter costs less than caviar.
But that law does not apply to medicine. If it did, prices would drop and doctors and hospitals would make less money when they were in oversupply. Instead, doctors and hospitals create their own demand.
Studies have repeatedly shown that the level of use of hospital beds in a community is determined largely by how many beds the community has. Clinton Administration officials often cite a study that compared hospital use in Boston and New Haven. Boston has 4.5 hospital beds for each 1,000 people in the area. New Haven has 2.9 beds per 1,000. The rate of hospital admissions are 50 percent higher in Boston than in New Haven. The hospitals in Boston did not reduce their prices; they admitted more patients.
In the same vein, Dr. John E. Wennberg, director of the Center for Evaluative Clinical Sciences at Dartmouth, found a correlation between the number of surgeons in a community and the number of operations performed there. That helped explain why tonsillectomies were performed nine times more often in one Vermont town than in another, and why prostate surgery was four times more likely and hysterectomies three times more likely in some cities than in others.
One industry in which the law of supply and demand is often followed is pharmaceuticals. In one case that has received considerable attention recently, a doctor at the Mayo Clinic discovered that a drug made by Johnson & Johnson that had been used for 30 years as a deworming medicine for sheep at a cost of 6 cents a dose helped reduce the recurrence of colon cancer in people.
The Government and the Mayo Clinic performed all the research at no cost to the manufacturer and determined that the drug, levamisole, was safe and effective for human use. That meant a big rise in demand.
So when Johnson & Johnson marketed the drug for colon cancer, it raised the price a hundredfold, to $6 a dose.
 
Technology
Invention Becomes Mother of Necessity
 In the normal marketplace, new technology is introduced to improve productivity and lower costs. That is what happened, for example, when the steam engine replaced the horse and again when the internal combustion engine replaced steam. But in medicine, new technology seems to lower productivity. It certainly raises costs.
Productivity is usually defined in terms of units of output per worker. It is difficult to measure in medicine because a unit of health care is not so easily identifiable as a unit of a product that comes off an assembly line. But statistics compiled by the American Hospital Association seem to indicate that hospital productivity has dropped in the last decade.
The number of patients admitted to hospitals in the United States fell to 31 million in 1991 from 36 million in 1981, a decline of more than 14 percent. During the same decade, the average length of a hospital stay fell to 7.2 days from 7.6 days. But the number of positions on hospital staffs rose during that period by 17 percent, to 3.5 million from 3 million.
In other industries, technology often displaces workers. There could be many reasons for the decrease in productivity in hospitals, but administrators say new health care technologies have increased the demand for technicians to operate the advanced equipment.
 
The High Cost of Oversupply
 As for cost, new devices that have become parts of day-to-day medicine -- like magnetic resonance imagers, which permit doctors to see abnormalities in the brain, spine and other parts of the body, and lithotripters, which crush kidney stones with sound waves -- are expensive to purchase and operate.
They are made more expensive by the fact that they are in oversupply in many communities. Hospitals and clinics compete to have the latest equipment, often as a matter of prestige and to attract better doctors. The oversupply increases the prices charged for each use of the machine.
Researchers at the National Institutes of Health and at the Food and Drug Administration found, for instance, that the nation has three times more mammography machines than it would if each machine operated at capacity. But the doctors and hospitals that own the machines have not cut prices to attract customers. Instead, they have kept the price higher than necessary for each mammogram so they can amortize the cost of the machine.
Patients often demand that their doctors use the latest techniques. "In most things we buy," said Robert D. Reischauer, director of the Congressional Budget Office and the chief staff economist of Congress, "necessity is the mother of invention. In the health care world, invention is the mother of necessity. Once we discover something, we decide we need it."

SECTION: Section C; Page 15; Column 5; Cultural Desk
