HEADLINE: Met Opera Planning Summer Season In New Jersey in '96

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS

 BODY:
The Metropolitan Opera has signed a letter of intent to make a planned $50 million theater at Waterloo Village in New Jersey its summer home beginning in 1996. The New York Philharmonic and American Ballet Theater, which also have no permanent summer locations, confirmed yesterday they are also in discussions with officials at Waterloo Village.
The plans for the Metropolitan, the Philharmonic and Ballet Theater, which were reported on Sunday in The Star-Ledger, are all contingent on the completion of the theater, to be built about half a mile from Waterloo Village in Allamuchy Mountain State Park, a town restored as a historic village for tourists and arts patrons. 
 "We hope that this will be New Jersey's Tanglewood," said Percival H. E. Leach, the chairman of the Waterloo Center for the Performing Arts, a nonprofit group. Waterloo Village, near Stanhope, N.J., has sponsored smaller arts events and a school of music, about an hour's drive west of Manhattan, since 1976.
Gov. Jim Florio of New Jersey said yesterday that he approved release on Friday of $6 million in Economic Development Authority funds to pay for planning and development studies for the proposed theater, and Mr. Leach said that ground breaking could take place as soon as December. A design for the theater, by the architect Alexander Cooper of Cooper, Robertson & Partners in New York, was made public over the weekend.
 
Private Funds Needed
 The rest of the funds for the project are not in hand. Governor Florio said he supported a $21 million bond issue to help pay for the project, but even if the bond issue is approved, another $23 million in private funds would be needed. Mr. Leach, an interior designer who is a co-founder of Waterloo Village and has been working to build the project for decades, said the money would be supplied by corporate, foundation and individual donors.
In a letter of intent signed last Thursday by Joseph Volpe, the Metropolitan's general manager, the Met agreed to offer fully staged productions regularly at the arts center starting in 1996.
David Reuben, a spokesman for the Met, said that if the arts center were built, the Met would be most likely to perform there in the month of June, and would still keep its international performing commitments during the summer.
 
9,000 Seats Planned
 The theater is to be designed as an open-sided opera house, with a 135-foot-high fly loft, to accommodate set changes. There would be 4,000 covered seats and an additional 5,000 seats outside the theater for those on lawn chairs and blankets.
Mr. Cooper said he hoped the theater could be enclosed by movable panels, similar to the design of the Glimmerglass Opera House in Cooperstown, N.Y. Some opera performers prefer not to sing in unenclosed spaces.
"We feel that the performing-arts center will not only enhance cultural activities in New Jersey," said Governor Florio in an interview yesterday, "but will be an economic benefit to the region as well."
Unlike the possible departure of the New York Yankees to the Meadowlands, the summer flight of three distinguished arts organizations to New Jersey does not seem to pose a cultural threat to New York State. New York already has summer arts programming at Saratoga, and the Met, the Philharmonic and Ballet Theater would not be leaving their regular season homes in Manhattan.
Juanita Scarlett, a spokeswoman for Gov. Mario Cuomo of New York, said yesterday that "I'm sure the Governor would think it's wonderful that the people of New Jersey will be able to enjoy those institutions that make New York the cultural capital of the planet. We show off the Yankees around the country, and these are other superior assets that can help people appreciate all that New York has to offer."
 
A Marriage of Convenience
 Mr. Leach estimated the yearly operating budget for the planned summer series of the Met, the Philharmonic and Ballet Theater to be between $10 million and $15 million, which would be provided by the Waterloo center, not by the companies themselves, he said. The money would come from operating revenues and additional contributions, he said. Marketing studies have shown a strong demand for presentations of such top-caliber companies, he added, especially given the center's proximity to suburban New Jersey, Rockland County and New York City.
If the Waterloo plan is realized, it will be a marriage of convenience. The Met and the Philharmonic have year-round contracts with their artists, and are constantly seeking to expand the number of summer play dates. And the Waterloo project needs big-name talent to attract the kind of fund-raising that will be needed to complete the project.
Deborah Borda, the executive director of the New York Philharmonic, said: "It's been no secret that the Philharmonic has been reconsidering its summer activities. Waterloo looks like a very exciting plan." She said, however, that the Philharmonic, which is one of the few major orchestras that has no regular summer home, was exploring a number of other options besides the Waterloo center, including several in New York City and Westchester County, though she would not specify them.
American Ballet Theater has also not yet made any commitment to perform at Waterloo. "We look forward to it and we hope it's going forward," said Robert Pontarelli, the company's public relations director. "But there is no signed contract and no financial agreement."
Mr. Pontarelli said that if Ballet Theater appeared at Waterloo, "we would perform our regular programs with the full company." Last summer the company did not have a regular engagement after its six-week season at the Metropolitan Opera that ended on June 12.
Mr. Leach said yesterday that the pianist Byron Janis would be the artistic director of the proposed arts center. Mr. Janis said yesterday that the idea of the arts center was "exciting," and expressed confidence that the Philharmonic and Ballet Theater would come to terms with the organization.
In a related matter, the critic and magazine publisher Samuel Lipman said yesterday that he had been discharged as artistic director of the Waterloo Music Festival and School. Since 1985 Mr. Lipman, the publisher of The New Criterion and music critic for Commentary magazine, had been coordinating the programming of the festival, a six-week program of classical music, from July to the second week in August.
Mr. Lipman said he was "quite surprised" to have been dismissed when he received a call yesterday afternoon from Carol Delaire, the administrative director of the Waterloo Festival. Mr. Lipman said he believed the festival school had been a success, and the festival programming "had managed to change the repertory of American music." Mr. Lipman said the festival owed him $11,000 for his services during previous summers, and said he had been told that the festival had no money to continue this summer.
But Mr. Leach denied that Mr. Lipman had been released. "I hope to continue our relationship with Sam," he said, "but I haven't decided in what capacity." He said the festival will be reorganized under the arts-center management under Mr. Janis, and that he hoped Mr. Lipman would "make a contribution."

HEADLINE: PERIPHERALS;
Getting Your Feet Wet In a Sea Called Internet

BYLINE: By L. R. SHANNON

 BODY:
"THE government always discovers a technology after its moment is passing," the economist and author George Gilder says in an interview in the September/October issue of Wired. "It's not going to change with Clinton and Gore. The dog technologies run to Washington, decked out like poodles. The politician is always the dog's best friend."
One of the technologies Vice President Al Gore is pushing is the information superhighway, which will link everyone at home or office to everything else -- movies and television shows, shopping services, electronic mail and huge collections of data -- starting perhaps with the elaborate structure envisioned by Bell Atlantic and Tele-Communications. But the Internet, already linking 10 million to 15 million people in a version of the data superhighway (albeit without movies and shopping), shows, in Mr. Gilder's words, that "to have a very rich fabric of services you don't need a regimented system of control." 
 No one is in charge of the Internet. You do not visit a retail outlet to buy the sign-up software or fill out a card that flutters out of a magazine. Yet the Internet, which grew out of a 1969 Department of Defense contract to connect university, military and defense contractors, keeps growing; no one really knows how much or how fast. Paul Gilster, in "The Internet Navigator: The Essential Guide to Network Exploration for the Individual Dial-Up User" (John Wiley & Sons; $24.95), writes that by 1985, "approximately 100 networks formed the Internet." He continues:
"By 1989, that number had risen to 500. The Network Information Center of the Defense Data Network Information Center found 2,218 networks connected as of January 1990. By June 1991, the National Science Foundation Network Information Center pegged it at close to 4,000, and connections have more than doubled within the last two years. If we extrapolate based on current numbers, the Internet could reach 40 million people by 1995, 100 million by 1998. Its current growth rate is 15 percent monthly."
Most individual users have formal or informal connections to a network linked to the Internet. "Formal" means working for or attending a member company or university; "informal" means having worked for a member or being able to ingratiate oneself with a strategically placed officer. Michael Fraase, in his breezy "The Mac Internet Tour Guide" (Ventana Press; $27.95 with disk), devotes four sections to general instructions "about who to befriend and what arcane terms to utter so you'll sound like a seasoned expert." Commercial on-line services like Compuserve, America Online and Delphi have begun to add Internet links, some limited to sending and receiving electronic mail, others with full service. A host of so-called service providers, providing gateways to the Internet, have also sprung up -- probably three or four hosts if you do not read this first thing in the morning.
Connecting a business to the Internet can cost thousands of dollars, depending on its size; an individual without a real or feigned relationship to a member organization can seek a service provider. Rates are reasonable, considering what the money buys. For instance, the Pipeline, a service provider getting under way in New York City, charges $15 a month for five hours on the Internet and $2 for each additional hour. A $20 fee is good for 20 hours a month, and $35 buys unlimited access.
Without even trying, I have gathered eight new or recently updated books on the Internet. With, say, MCI Mail or Prodigy, you can learn as you go along. The Internet not only deserves preparation, it absolutely demands it. One reason is that, as noted, nobody is in charge. Another is that the Internet prefers to speak UNIX, an unfriendly language in which your address might be "hildyj.chi.il.us." You can get by, as you can in most other foreign countries, by speaking English and learning the UNIX equivalent of "Where is the bathroom, please?" and a few other stock lines. But to be completely comfortable, you will have to be able to say, in UNIX, "It seems to me and to most of my peers, epistemologically speaking, that Forster is flaccid." Ordinary people will applaud Windows and Macintosh software.
 
More Books on Internet
 "Internet: Getting Started" (PTR Prentice Hall; $28), edited by April Marine, Susan Kirkpatrick and Vivian Neou, and "Internet: Mailing Lists" (PTR Prentice Hall; $29), edited by Edward T. L. Hardie and Vivian Neou, have been updated. "The Internet Guide for New Users" (McGraw-Hill; $40 hardcover, $27.95 paperback), by Daniel P. Dern, goes into more detail than the books already mentioned, which can be viewed as an advantage or not. Mr. Dern is also the editor of a new bimonthly magazine, Internet World, $4.95. "Navigating the Internet" (Sams; $24.95), by Mark Gibbs and Richard J. Smith, also gains, or loses, points for comprehensiveness. O'Reilly & Associates of Sebastopol, Calif., publishes both a slim and a fat volume. "Connecting to the Internet" ($15.95), by Susan Estrada, is the first; "The Whole Internet User's Guide and Catalog" ($24.95), by Ed Krol, is the second.

HEADLINE: UKRAINE MISSILES: TERMS ARE TOUGH

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KIEV, Ukraine, Oct. 25

 BODY:
Reflecting the ambivalence and political pressures involved in becoming a non-nuclear state, Ukraine's leaders told Secretary of State Warren Christopher today that they were committed to ridding the country of nuclear weapons, but wanted billions of dollars and pledges of Western military protection to do it.
Even then, Foreign Minister Anatoly Zlenko told reporters at a joint news conference with Mr. Christopher, there was no guarantee that Ukraine's Parliament would approve the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty, as demanded by the United States. 
 "I cannot give you any promises," he said, adding that the decision was in the hands of the Parliament.
For his part, Mr. Christopher said both Mr. Kravchuk and members of the Parliament "gave a clear commitment to me that they desire a non-nuclear furture for Ukraine." But when pressed, Mr. Christopher acknowledged that there was one issue to be resolved: "Timing."
 
Stiffened Its Conditions
 In the last several months, Ukraine, whose missiles and bombers make it the world's third largest nuclear power after the United States and Russia, has stiffened its conditions for destroying them, largely because of a growing pro-nuclear lobby in its Parliament. The United States has responded by trying to moderate Ukraine's behavior by offering it economic incentives, which Mr. Zlenko suggested today were woefully inadequate.
At dinner tonight, Mr. Kravchuk and Mr. Christopher hammered out the final details of a complicated technical agreement that spells out how Ukraine intends to spend $175 million in American funds to begin the dismantling of its nuclear weapons. Mr. Christopher and Mr. Zlenko signed the agreement, the main obstacle in unfreezing the money earmarked for dismantlement.
The United States has also recently pledged to give Ukraine $155 million in economic aid and loan guarantees in the 1994 fiscal year.
But Mr. Zlenko told reporters that Ukraine needed $2.8 billion to dismantle and destroy its nuclear weapons. He also complained about Russia's failure to compensate Ukraine for the highly enriched uranium in the missiles that were sent to Moscow last year, adding that the uranium contained in the weapons still on Ukrainian soil had a commercial value of $5 billion.
 
Praise for Ukrainian
 As part of its strategy to embrace, rather than criticize Ukraine's behavior, Mr. Christopher lauded Mr. Kravchuk, saying he promised today to try to persuade the Parliament to approve both the Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty, known as Start I, and the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty as a package.
Last week Mr. Kravchuk told reporters that Ukraine might want to keep its SS-24's, but today he told Mr. Christopher that he had been misquoted, a senior State Department official said.
Mr. Christopher was so concerned about extracting a clear commitment on nuclear disarmament from Mr. Kravchuk that more than a third of their 55-minute meeting was devoted to the subject, a senior Administration official said. Mr. Christopher told reporters that Mr. Kravchuk assured him that an agreement signed in Lisbon last November in which Ukraine -- along with Russia, Kazakhstan and Belarus -- agreed to become non-nuclear powers "applies to all strategic offensive arms" in Ukraine, including the SS-19's and the SS-24's, the most advanced missiles in the old Soviet arsenal..
Earlier in the day Mr. Christopher met with influential members of Parliament, who rejected his appeal to get rid of all of its long-range nuclear weapons and join the nonproliferation treaty, the 1968 treaty that prohibits the development, maintenance or traffic in nuclear weapons.
Dmytro Pavlychko, who heads the Foreign Relations Committee, said in an interview that the Parliament could ratify Start I as early as next month, but added that the nonproliferation treaty could not be ratified until next year at the earliest, and only then with at least $2 billion to help dismantle Ukraine's nuclear weapons.
Mr. Pavlychko said he told Mr. Christopher that Ukraine must have a formal Western pledge of military protection before the former Soviet republic could dismantle all of its 130 SS-19 missiles under Start I.
"It is not enough for the United States to say, 'I guarantee your security,' and then say goodbye," he said.

HEADLINE: Ukraine's Wasting Nuclear Asset

 BODY:
It's two down and one to go among the republics that inherited nuclear arms when the Soviet Union broke up. Kazakhstan is about to follow Belarus's lead and get rid of its nuclear legacy. That leaves a lone holdout: stubborn Ukraine.
Ukraine has turned its tactical nuclear arms over to Russia for dismantling. And it's removing the warheads from aging SS-19 missiles. But President Leonid Kravchuk, who last year pledged to give up all of Ukraine's arms, now wants to keep some. The ones he has in mind, 46 intercontinental-range SS-24 missiles, were designed to target the U.S., and fly too far to strike most of Russia. 
 Ostensibly, Mr. Kravchuk is driving a hard bargain in an effort to win financial aid from the West. But his eagerness to appease Ukrainian nationalists could be a deal-stopper.
The nationalists see nuclear arms as a symbol of power and don't want to give them up. But nuclear weapons won't put food on the table. They're an expensive distraction from the true threat: the social unrest that's sure to follow if Ukraine's economy collapses. Unless Ukraine is prepared to spend billions it can't afford to pay for the infrastructure to control, re-target and maintain the warheads, they are a wasting asset.
Belarus and Kazakhstan understood that and knew the time had come to cut a deal. Belarus has begun to send its nuclear missiles back to Russia for dismantling. Washington has already provided financial inducements. The U.S. could also help things along by supporting Belarus's bid for a seat on the United Nations Security Council. That would provide an important reminder to Ukraine and others that nuclear arms do not assure a seat at the head table.
Kazakhstan has agreed to sign the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty by year's end. For its troubles it will get $140 million in economic aid and much, much more, like investment to develop its oil and natural gas, $85 million to help dismantle its nuclear arsenal and millions more to clean up the nuclear test site at Semipalatinsk.
Kazakhstan's President, Nursultan Nazarbayev, wants a face-to-face meeting with President Clinton to clinch the deal. President Kravchuk of Ukraine also wants a summit soiree in Washington before facing the electorate back home. But why give him one now? Rewarding Mr. Nazarbayev with a photo opportunity while denying one to Mr. Kravchuk would allow Mr. Clinton to show that the way to win Washington's favors is to disarm.

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
On Civil Respect

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL

 BODY:
In the end, the mayoralty election in New York City will depend on how many New Yorkers vote for civil respect as their first priority.
Civil respect is based on civil liberty. But it goes beyond, to problems that affect our lives and cannot be decided simply by law. Easing these problems depends on the government's respect for the citizens and the citizens' respect for each other -- voluntary or imposed. 
 Civil respect includes some specific freedoms: freedom from street crime and street harassment, freedom from local regulations and taxes that drive business out and turn hamburger-flipping into the career future, freedom from sloppy, inefficient government, freedom from neglect for the mentally wounded, freedom from pushers, freedom from users, freedom from schools that don't teach children and from children who shoot other children.
Civil respect and the quality of democratic life are part of each other, rising or falling together.
During the Dinkins administration the quality of life became worse. We live here, we work here and we know. New Yorkers may not be smarter than the rest of the world, but they are not more stupid.
If polls are really needed, see today's New York Times/WCBS-TV News study. It shows 59 percent of New Yorkers interviewed thought life in the city got worse during the Dinkins years. Quality of life includes the city's economy, race relations, crime and public education. Eight percent thought life was better and thirty percent thought it was just the same.
If most New Yorkers think their lives are worse after one Dinkins term and only 8 percent think they are better off, why are so many thinking of voting for a second, enough to make the race too close to call?
Some like and approve of Mr. Dinkins, very much. Some very much do not like or approve of Rudolph Giuliani. They do not like the idea that he was a prosecutor, or think he was too tough.
Or they do not like the way he tried to prevent his supporters from being sore losers last election night by telling them to be quiet. Save our souls, New Yorkers never heard such terrible language.
Or they think he is a fascist -- a plain anti-Italian lie out of the Dinkins camp. Or white New Yorkers may feel guilty for considering voting against an African-American, a sensation encouraged by President Clinton. That we do not need; New Yorkers can feel guilty at the drop of an autumn leaf.
Black New Yorkers have been hurt, perhaps most, by the drop of the quality of life. But since they will vote overwhelmingly for Mr. Dinkins, they obviously feel that a black Mayor, even one who has not improved their lives, is better than a white one who has not had the chance to try. Such very heavy black preference for black may be understandable, but Mr. Clinton and Mr. Dinkins ought to spare us piety about voting across color lines.
Dinkins people call black-for-black voting a matter of pride. Mr. Giuliani says he does not want the support of voters who would choose him for "pride" of color or ethnicity. Strain an ear: no applause from my friends who would have danced liberal fandangos had Mr. Dinkins said that.
Write off voters who will vote for reasons of race, emotion, bigotry, distaste or party. What's left are those who would vote for a candidate of any party, religion, hue or hair style. Most of them are middle-class, strivers by upbringing.
They are among the majority who say their lives are getting worse. But these New Yorkers often are embarrassed about voting as so many other Americans do, for their economic self-interest. They think of that as selfish. They long for something that would better express their sense of American hope. And there is something better: civil respect.
The phrase has not been used in the campaign, although I hereby release copyright. But my New York ears and stomach tell me that more New Yorkers see that their best interest and the city's are the same -- civil liberty expanded to civil respect, and that one withers without the other.
So I think the election will turn on how many New Yorkers vote on the one major issue. Which candidate will do the most to heighten the quality of life in New York and, by whatever name New Yorkers yearn for it, build civil respect?

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Jordan's Role in Israeli-Palestinian Peace Effort;
To Invigorate Economy

 BODY:

To the Editor:
The Clinton Administration and the international community have correctly recognized that rapid economic development in the West Bank and Gaza is critical to the success of any peace agreement. The Palestine Liberation Organization, Israel, the United States and the West now share the common goals of economic stability and a rapid decrease in unemployment for the Palestinians. To this end the United States is currently organizing donations from the OECD to a multibillion dollar investment fund for projects in the West Bank and Gaza. Planning and implementation of investments will take time. They cannot be expected to create new jobs immediately. In the meantime, an additional, simple mechanism to aid the Palestinians would be a unilateral reduction of tariffs on exports from the West Bank and Gaza. 
 A reduction of tariffs, in addition to the proposed investment fund has several advantages:
(1) The potential impact on the employment and on the general well-being of Palestinians is huge. Low wage rates, together with current high rates of unemployment, imply a comparative advantage for the West Bank and Gaza in labor-intensive industries. Exports will therefore grow in branches such as agriculture and textiles, which require only minimal investment. Thus, many new jobs could be created within months of implementation. (In contrast, much of the investment from the fund will go to infrastructure projects that are not labor intensive and will have lengthy planning stages before they can create many jobs.)
(2) Any country in the world could join as an act of good will with a minimal impact on the local economy. The economies of the West Bank and Gaza are too small to be a threat to any local industry in the West. In the current state of affairs in most world markets, even a full abolition of tariffs would generally create new trade while diverting little existing trade from current exporters of labor intensive goods.
(3) A unilateral reduction in tariffs requires no lengthy trade negotiations. Such a reduction in tariffs by the European Community, the United States and other OECD countries can provide a much needed complement to an investment fund. It will let the market do what it does best -- generate new jobs in response to economic opportunity, while governmental aid can do what governments do best -- provide a sound infrastructure for a better future.
 
ELI BERMAN
DANIEL TSIDDON
Boston, Oct. 18, 1993
 
The writers are, respectively, professor of economics at Boston University and professor of economics at Brown University and Hebrew University of Jerusalem.

HEADLINE: The Family Farm Doesn't Exist Anymore

 BODY:

To the Editor:
After you exposed the economic and political incestuous relationship between the United States Department of Agriculture and corporate agribusiness, which has been destroying our family farm system of agriculture for decades ("Tainted Trade," front-page series, Oct. 10-12), one would have hoped for a more enlightened followup analysis in "The Politics of Food" (editorial, Oct. 16). 
 By denouncing "farmers" as "the nation's richest welfare recipients," you perform not only a grave disservice to the struggling thousands of men, women and children who annually grow and harvest our agricultural bounty, but also you seriously mislead the public as to who really pays and who profits when it comes to the manufacturing of our food supply.
To subscribe to the many corporate agribusiness shibboleths you propound, as Laura B. DeLind, a Michigan State University social anthropologist, argues, makes family farmers readily susceptible to (and firm believers in) agricultural programs, services, technologies and research that promote "efficient," businesslike farm management and production. In turn, strategies of commercial "self-improvement" serve an economic and political system dominated by corporate capital.
"The family farm, like the 'emperor's new clothes,' does not exist," Ms. DeLind argues. "It is a torturous twisting of reality, under the guise of 'conventional wisdom' . . .
"By accommodating all major organizational variation within a single conceptual category, the systematic reasons, particularly the economic and political reasons, for operational differences among farming enterprises are obscured. These latter are built, not on personality, managerial ability or individual effort, the perceived 'quality' of ownership, but on differential control over the processes and resources of production."
As Ms. DeLind concludes: "The category family farm must be pried apart. It must be opened up so that its internal contradictions can be seen, not hidden, and used as a basis for identifying and comparing the relative class positions of producers. This would provide a keener awareness of the structure of agriculture . . .
"In addition, any long-term action to reform the system -- to bring about a more equitable distribution of power and income -- must rest on class-based alliances which cut across the 'family farm' category."
 
A. V. KREBS
Des Moines, Oct. 21, 1993
 
The writer is corporate agribusiness research director of PrairieFire Rural Action.

HEADLINE: Knocked Out by the Freshmen

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25

 BODY:
Perpetually teetering on the edge in Washington's annual budget battles, the superconducting supercollider had managed to survive one brush with death after another like an alley cat with extra spring in its legs.
But the proton smasher lost its ninth life on the House floor last week, the victim of a new generation of politicians whose faith in big science has been shaken by the kind of cost overruns and construction delays that have dogged the supercollider for years. 
 Eighty-one of the 113 freshmen casting votes in the House moved to kill the project, defying the advice of President Clinton and the House leadership of both parties. It was a majority so overwhelming that House leaders could not revive their strategy of last year, which was to go along with the Senate's solid support for the project even after the House voted to kill the project.
Many of the freshmen have challenged the old boy network by which members of Congress vote for each other's projects as an exercise in mutual backscratching that assures their re-elections but also drives up the deficit. The backbenchers have made limited progress, in part because they have been just as meek about tackling automatic spending programs like Medicaid as their elders.
 
Space Station Is Target
 But in the case of the supercollider, those freshmen not representing the construction states of Texas and Louisiana found a cause they could rally against without offending any vital constituency back home. Likewise, the vast majority of House freshmen voted last week to kill the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's $3.7 billion advanced solid rocket motor project, which was designed to enable the space shuttle to carry heavier cargoes at higher altitudes in orbit. And many freshmen now say they are preparing to take aim at the space station next year.
"It was the House freshmen who were the driving force," grumbled Senator J. Bennett Johnston, a Louisiana Democrat who strongly favored the supercollider project. "They are the product of an angry electorate that wants to cut projects and cut perks. Basically, they are at war with the institution of Congress."
To listen to the post-mortems from the proponents and opponents of the project is to hear two different visions of the Government's role in science, and the replacement of the once limitless faith that politicians put in scientists with a view that the wasteful ways of science contractors must be curtailed.
"This new generation of leaders doesn't understand the difference between an expenditure and an investment," complained Representative Robert G. Torricelli, a six-term New Jersey Democrat and who was a supporter of the supercollider on the Committee on Science, Space and Technology. "Listening to the debate, I wondered if this Congress would have invested in the railroads or the early development of aviation. It certainly is not a Congress that would have invested in the space program."
Representative Martin R. Hoke, a Republican freshman from Ohio who is also a member of science panel, voiced a different view. "If we find more basic building blocks of the universe," he said, "it's not going to change the way people live."
 
'Cancer' of Runaway Budget
 He added that the project's runaway budget, the fact that its estimated cost rose from $4.4 billion to more than $11 billion in just over seven years, demonstrated that the supercollider was "reflective of a cancer, the way a lot of these projects get sold in the first place."
"They are sold on the basis of numbers that are fraudulently produced with the contractors knowing that they are able to obtain more money later," he said.
Only 25 years ago, when Americans were more optimistic about their economic future and frightened that the Soviet Union could pull ahead in technology, 5.2 percent of the Federal budget was devoted to nonmilitary scientific research. That figure gradually dwindled to 1.8 percent of the budget last year, as Federal spending on programs like veterans' benefits, Medicaid and Medicare mushroomed, and research spending more or less stagnated.
If all nonmilitary science spending were cut this year, the budget deficit would still climb. But to the freshmen, the supercollider was a ripe symbolic fruit ready for picking. Several put the program on their pet lists for cuts during their election campaigns along with mohair subsidies and House mail franking privileges.
"We are spontaneously as a group against all unnecessary spending, and we were elected on that," said Representative Karen Shepherd, a freshman Utah Democrat. Another Democratic freshman, Representative Blanche M. Lambert of Arkansas, said: "We all campaigned on fiscal responsibility. The bottom line was money."
"There's double-digit unemployment in my district," Ms. Lambert continued, "and this project didn't create any jobs in my district. For all the money, where was the return?"
Congressional supporters of the program knew they had an uphill fight with the incoming freshmen, so Representative Joe Barton, Republican of Texas, sent every one of them extensive literature on the project before they arrived in Washington and invitations to visit Waxahachie to see construction in progress. But only a handful accepted the invitation, and by their own account, few freshmen studied the program as closely as other issues like health care and the North American Free Trade Agreement.
"It's not something I stayed up at night reading about," said Representative Ernest J. Istook Jr., a Republican freshman from Oklahoma who voted against the supercollider. "The decision had to be made on what you can afford to do and what you cannot afford to do."
Representative Sam Coppersmith, a freshman Democrat from Arizona who is a member of the science committee, thought long and hard about the project, and concluded that it did have noteworthy scientific merit. But in the end, he voted against the project, because of the cost overruns.
"There should be some penalty for promising and not performing," he concluded.

CORRECTION-DATE: November 4, 1993, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Science Times on Oct. 26 about the demise of the superconducting supercollider project misspelled the name of the Treasury Secretary. He is Lloyd Bentsen.

HEADLINE: Man in the News;
Canadian With Mandate: Joseph Jacques Jean Chretien

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH

DATELINE: TORONTO, Oct. 26

 BODY:
The Conservative Party derided him as "yesterday's man" because he faithfully served Prime Ministers Lester B. Pearson, Pierre Elliott Trudeau and John N. Turner.
But by placing today's problems in the hands of Jean Chretien, who will become the country's next Prime Minister, Canada's voters said experience must count for something. Among the nation's problems are getting people back to work, adjusting trade relationships and preserving national unity. 
 Voters gave the Liberals a resounding mandate, with 178 seats in the 295-seat House of Commons, up from 79, and slashed the Progressive Conservatives from 153 to 2, the most punishing blow to any governing party in Canadian history. Even the Conservative Prime Minister, Kim Campbell, lost her seat in Vancouver.
But despite a comfortable majority, Mr. Chretien will have to work with a Parliament fractured by regional rivalries. Two regional parties surged in the voting: The separatist Bloc Quebecois won 54 seats and the populist Reform Party, based in Alberta, won 52.
 
Challenge of a Deficit
 But the biggest challenge for the new Government, which is expected to be installed within the next two weeks, is a crushing budget deficit, higher on a per-capita basis than the deficit in the United States. The deficit tightly restricts the maneuvering room for job creation.
"The main constraints on the Government's power are not going to come from a vigorous opposition," said Alasdair McKichan, president of the Retail Council of Canada. "They're going to be coming from the demands of Canada's international creditors."
Pressure from the other direction seems sure to come from Bob White, the head of the 2.2-million-member Canadian Labor Congress, who warned that Mr. Chretien has to make good quickly on his promised $6 billion public works program, which is intended to create up to 120,000 jobs over two years. "He's got the trust of a lot of Canadians based on the economy being the No. 1 issue," said Mr. White. "And if he fails to start addressing that issue, then he'll lose an enormous amount of credibility."
Exporters are worried about Liberal hostility to the North American Free Trade Agreement, which broadens the bilateral agreement with the United States to include Mexico.
Mr. Chretien has said he wants to renegotiate Nafta. But the new leader has never specified what the renegotiation would entail. At this stage no one knows whether it would stymie the deal, though the assessment in Washington is that it would not.
In a sense, Mr. Chretien's position is similar to that of President Clinton last January, when he too was hemmed in by economic constraints on a jobs program, and he too sought improvements in the free trade pact.
 
Mutual Needs
 Still, most analysts say Mr. Chretien will back away from precipitating a crisis with Washington over trade.
Two reasons are cited: First, he needs the support of the business community if his economic initiatives are to work, and fighting Nafta will not win him many business friends. Second, given Canada's export dependence on the United States, Canada would be hurt far more if the tariff walls were to rise again. The United States takes about 75 percent of Canadian exports, and exports are responsible for about a quarter of the Canadian economy.
"Would the Liberals really want to intervene in a complicated process and antagonize the President?" asked Maureen Appel Molot, director of the Norman Paterson School of International Affairs at Carleton Unversity in Ottawa. "I think not. They'll have neither the time nor the inclination."
 
Underestimated by Others
 As the Tories recently discovered, one of Mr. Chretien's strengths is the tendency for others to underestimate him. He cultivates a rough-hewn demeanor, exacerbated by a sometimes awkward use of English, which he did not seriously take up until he was elected to the House of Commons, at 29.
"Maurice Chevalier and I had to practice to keep our French accent in English," he likes to say jokingly. "It has become a kind of trademark."
But the lack of polish in this 59-year-old lawyer from Shawinigan, a mill town 50 miles northeast of Montreal, conceals what Maclean's, the newsweekly, calls a "shrewdness and calculating ambition."
 
A Country Childhood
 Joseph Jacques Jean Chretien, was born Jan. 11, 1934, the 18th of 19 children born to Marie Boisvert Chretien. "In those days," he says, "God decided how many kids people had." His father, Wellie, was a machinist in a paper mill and moonlighted as secretary of the Shawinigan municipality to help send the children to college.
Jean did not do as well as his siblings at school. One of his problems was shyness about a birth defect that had left him deaf in his right ear and distorted his mouth.
During the political campaign, the Tories took out advertisement that seemed to ridicule Mr. Chretien's appearance, but the ads backfired. With great dignity, he told reporters: "It's true I have a physical defect. God gave it to me."
Mr. Chretien's father and grandfather were Liberal Party organizers, and it was from them that Jean developed a taste for politics. "I argued for the Liberals in the poolroom near our home," he recalled in his autobiography. His grandfather, Francois Chretien, had also been Mayor of a small nearby village, St. Etienne des Gres, for 30 years.
The family had always been Liberal, in the free-thinking, anti-clerical, anti-establishment tradition of the 19th century. His pitch was to the working class because the Liberal Party in the Shawinigan of that day was supported by unions and workers.
 
Defeated in 1984
 Defeated in his first bid for leadership of the Liberals in 1984, he returned in 1990 to rally the dispirited party on his terms and at his own pace. Monday's triumph was sweet vindication.
His wife, Aline, told an interviewer for Saturday Night magazine some years ago that her husband had plotted a career that only went upward.
"It was to always advance, to keep moving up," she said. "It was to never stay at the same level, and he hopes that his friends will tell him if he begins slipping."
Mr. Chretien is a Quebecer who has little use for separatism. As a result, the separatists have little use for him.
Lucien Bouchard, who heads Bloc Quebecois, said at one point in the campaign that Mr. Chretien had no business even representing a district in Quebec because of his views. To this, Mr. Chretien hotly replied that he had as much right as Mr. Bouchard.
The two men will have many more face-offs. By virtue of Bloc Quebecois' strength in the new House, Mr. Bouchard is the leader of the official opposition.
Mr. Chretien says Quebecers have wanted to "rewrite history" ever since their ancestors lost the battle of the Plains of Abraham in 1759.
 
Flight of Money and Jobs
 Yet Quebecers, he maintains, end up only paying the price for independence without ever experiencing the euphoria of it. The price is the money and jobs that have left the province in recent years as a result of uncertainty about the future, a price that is likely to continue being paid as the threat of separatism again increases.
"Part of their intense reaction against me," Mr. Chretien said in his autobiography, "came because I had to demystify their great dream."

HEADLINE: Going Private -- A special report;
Mexico Sells Off State Companies, Reaping Trouble as Well as Profit

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MONTERREY, Mexico

 BODY:
When Mexico first said it was going to sell off or shut down its vast network of Government-run businesses, many people were skeptical, thinking they had heard such promises before from third-world governments that ran bloated industrial bureaucracies.
A decade later, Mexico is nearing the end of one of the most sweeping sales of state companies in the world. In all, the Government has sold or dissolved more than 80 percent of the 1,155 businesses it once ran. 
 The sale of the state companies has brought the Government more than $21 billion. Almost all of that went to retire part of the national debt, helping the administration of President Carlos Salinas de Gortari slow inflation from more than 150 percent to below 10 percent and open up the economy to competition and outside investment.
 
400,000 Jobs Are Lost
 The savings on debt payments have also enabled Mexico to spend more on social programs and move ahead with even bolder economic reforms, including negotiation of a North American Free Trade Agreement with the United States.
But there are signs that the privatization program has aggravated many problems instead of easing them. For example, whittling back government industry has cost more than 400,000 jobs since 1983, causing widespread social hardship.
In addition, getting government out of business did not always lead to greater efficiency, more competition or a better life for ordinary Mexicans. In many cases, the new private owners have proved to be just as unresponsive to workers and consumers as the old government bureaucrats.
In recent months, moreover, the privatization program has stumbled because what was being offered did not generate enough interest from investors.
 
A Model, World Bank Says
 The program has been described by the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund as a model for other developing countries, which have not been nearly as successful at pulling out of industries.
However, of the 940 businesses the Government disposed of, far more were closed than sold. Of those sold, the overwhelming majority were through acceptance of private bids, usually from wealthy Mexican investors, rather than through public stock offerings to employees or the public.
Sales did not guarantee success. Mexico's largest shipyard, Astilleros Unidos de Veracruz, was sold with great hopes to Norwegian investors in 1991 but is now nearly bankrupt because of labor disputes and a slowdown in business. Dozens of old sugar mills sold off in the last few years have closed, causing hardships for workers and cane growers alike.
The privatized telephone company is still a sluggish monopoly, with customers waiting a year or more for installation and thousands of lines out of service at any given time.
 
A Few Investors Become Rich
 Doing business with a privatized bank can be a costly nightmare, since the investors who bought them seem intent on recouping their investment in a few years by charging sky-high rates for loans. And the two privatized television stations have done little more than rejigger their old menu of soap operas and sports programs.
Perhaps the deepest disappointment is a common feeling that in selling off what some consider the national patrimony, the Government has favored a few investors, who have become fabulously rich. Instead of paving the way for competition in goods and services, the program has increased competition among the handful of families vying to be Mexico's wealthiest clan.
"The booty of privatization has made multimillionaires of 13 families, while the rest of the population -- some 80 million Mexicans -- has been subjected to the same gradual impoverishment as though they had suffered through a war," a columnist, Alvaro Cepeda Neri, wrote in La Jornada, a leftist Mexico City newspaper.
Luis Rubio, a political scientist in Mexico City, said: "This Government has proved to be a first-class manager of the economy. What it hasn't done is anything to increase competition."
Government officials say that competition, though desirable, was never really their goal. Rather, the priority was efficiency, they say, along with elimination of costly subsidies and debilitating losses.
 
The Program
Some Now Sniff At the Offerings
 For a long time, private investors seemed willing to take a chance and relieve the Government of those responsibilities. But times have changed.
Last month, the sale of a shrimp-exporting company with $250 million in sales, Ocean Garden Products Inc., was abruptly put off because the bids submitted to the Government were too low. The sale of El Nacional, a newspaper that adheres to the line of the long-governing Institutional Revolutionary Party, was dropped for the same reason. And the state-owned oil company, Pemex, scuttled plans to sell secondary petrochemical refineries this year because it did not think it could get a good price.
Government officials say that such stumbling blocks are temporary and that they plan to offer the same companies for sale at the end of this year or early next year after doing a better job of promoting interest among investors. Officials at the San Diego-based Ocean Garden, owned by the Mexican Government, say foreign investors will be allowed to bid this time, and the size of staff at El Nacional has been slashed to reduce costs and make the newspaper a more attractive investment.
"The people love to buy when we have already managed the cleanup," said Mexico's Finance Minister, Pedro Aspe, who is generally credited with the Government's privatization strategy.
Government officials say they must increase productivity as Mexico, the United States and Canada prepare for passage of the North American Free Trade Agreement, which would eliminate most trade barriers between the three countries. Even the main Mexican labor confederation believes that job cutbacks were necessary.
"The whole effort has been good for the economy of the country," said Juan S. Millan Lizarraga, Secretary of Education for the Confederation of Mexican Workers. "There had to be some adjustments in personnel."
"What has been worse," he said, "is the situation of those workers in industries that have been kept by the Government."
Mr. Millan was speaking of Pemex, which has reduced its payroll by 100,000 workers, mostly through early-retirement programs. Like electricity, railroads and other businesses that the Constitution defines as strategic, oil is generally excluded from the privatization program, though Pemex has entered several projects with foreign investors to drill for or refine the petroleum that Mexico still controls.
 
The Buildup
The Empire Grows With Oil Revenues
 The number of state-run businesses in Mexico was comparatively small through 1970. But when the Arab oil embargo of 1973 drove up oil prices and greatly increased Mexico's revenues from its oil, the Government had the money to run hundreds of unprofitable businesses whose main purpose was widely understood to be providing jobs and paychecks regardless of productivity. By 1982 there were 1,155 such entities, including economically insignificant ones like commissions or trust funds set up for specific projects like the 1968 Olympic Games.
Acquiring or setting up such companies proved to be easier than disposing of them. Sale and divestment, called disincorporation, began under President Miguel de la Madrid, who served from 1982 to 1988. Under Mexico's current President, Mr. Salinas, the program evolved into the Government's nearly complete retreat from the private sector.
Taking a leaf from the privatization program introduced by Margaret Thatcher when she was Britain's Prime Minister, Mr. Aspe and other Mexican economists drafted a plan for starting with smaller enterprises and moving gradually to larger and more complicated ones so they could learn from experience.
But officials say they made sure that most of the revenue from the sell-offs went into reducing Mexico's debt rather than budget expenditures.
Mexico managed to slice billions off its debt, but more importantly for economic stability, net debt dropped from more than 70 percent of gross domestic product in 1986 to less than 29 percent today, according to the Bank of Mexico. As a result, interest payments on debt declined considerably, allowing the Government to funnel more money into a national antipoverty program that finances public works projects, gives grants to small businesses and refurbishes schools and community centers.
 
The Balance Sheet
Many Jobs Are Lost With the Sell-Off
 For many Mexicans, privatization has been a mixed blessing. When the project began in 1983, nearly 12,000 people worked at the state's huge Fundidora steel foundry on the outskirts of Monterrey. Ninety miles away in Monclova, the Altos Hornos foundry, also owned by the Government, employed about 24,000.
Founded at the turn of the century, Fundidora was inefficient, technologically outdated and bankrupt when Mexican officials decided to just close it down in 1986. All 12,000 jobs were lost, and today the foundry site is being cleaned up and turned into a park and business center in a $350 million project by the state of Nuevo Leon.
Altos Hornos, set up in the 1940's, had newer equipment and production methods, and despite strikes and other labor protests it was sold to a consortium of private investors in the Monterrey area in 1991. One of Mexico's leading industrial groups, it now employs 10,400 people, fewer than half its former labor force.
Another privatization cited as a success was that of Aeromexico, which at the time of its sale in June 1989 had only 30 percent of the market and was known as "Aeromaybe" because its service was so poor. Today Aeromexico is Mexico's biggest passenger carrier, with a consistent on-time performance. It now owns 55 percent of the carrier Mexicana and, in a turnaround, was part of the consortium that submitted a winning bid for 70 percent of Aeroperu, which was privatized by the Government of Peru.
In 1990 the Government began the privatization of Telefonos de Mexico, or Telmex, which was touted as one of the biggest state-owned companies in the world. But many Mexicans say they cannot tell the difference between the new Telmex and the old, given the difficulties they have reaching an operator, getting a phone installed or upgrading service.
The denationalization of Telmex was the largest and most complex sale of a Government-held enterprise. After selling majority voting rights and a 20.4 percent stake to a consortium for $1.76 billion, the Government sold $3.7 billion in shares to the public in two separate offerings, the only such public tenders to date in the privatization program.
The sale of 18 commercial banks for a combined $11 billion in June 1991 was considered a great success because each bank went for three to four times its book value. But it can still take more than a month to get a check cashed, a major stumbling block for middle-class Mexicans and foreign investors who are used to relying on such services.
Mortgages are just becoming available, interest rates on credit cards and car loans can be 50 percent higher than in the United States and credit of any kind for longer than 10 years is hard to come by.
In the bulk of privatizations, Mexico generally advertises that a company is up for sale, invites bids from private investors and reaches a decision that it says is based not only on price but also on a bidder's ability to assume debt. In sensitive industries like newspapers and broadcasting, foreign investors are limited to minority holdings.
While there have been no big demonstrations against the sell-offs of Government companies like those in Brazil when steel plants were sold, critics here accuse Mexico of giving preferential treatment to certain investors. Government officials have acknowledged working with potential bidders before an important deal, like the sale of the state telephone company and a recent package of television stations, but maintain that the final selection is honest and evenhanded.
Still, some Mexicans seem to have done awfully well by the Government. Carlos Slim Helu, whose Grupo Carso was part of the consortium that submitted the winning bid for a controlling share in Telmex, is now considered one of the richest people in the world.
This year Fortune magazine estimated his wealth at $2.9 billion and ranked him 68th on its list of the world's 101 richest people. Since Mexico has only one telephone line for every 14 people in the country, Mr. Slim and his partners in the consortium, Southwestern Bell and France Telecom, stand to reap huge profits as the communications network expands.
 
The Sacrosanct
Will Mexico Relax Its Hold on Energy?
 Mexico plans to close the disinvestment office this year or early in 1994. With a few exceptions, the 209 remaining state-owned entities are unlikely to be sold. They include schools, hospitals and the national lottery.
In recent weeks the state-owned insurance company and corn-processing plants have been sold. Many people are eager to see what happens when bids come in for the last item on this year's privatization list, the 150,000-customer natural gas distribution system here in Monterrey.
The sale has piqued interest, but not only because of the potential for expanding the network, already one of the largest in the country. The Monterrey gas network is an asset of the national power company, and as such comes close to the "strategic" -- and supposedly inviolate -- Government domain of oil and energy. The Government is allowing bids from foreign companies, and Southern Union Company of Austin, Tex., has shown some interest.
Recently a similar Government test -- a deal to sell part of a new electric generating station, Carbon II, in the state of Coahuila, near the Texas border -- collapsed when the American investor, a subsidiary of SCE Corporation, pulled out.
Mindful of the issue's sensitivity, the Mexican Government seems uncertain when it comes to yielding parts of its state-run energy industry. Mexico's 10-peso bill still bears an image of a refinery, commemorating the nationalization of the sector in 1938 in defiance of American oil companies.
Even a comparatively small deal like the Monterrey gas sale takes on added significance since it is one of the few assets remaining on the privatization list and its sale could ultimately signal a break with protection of a cherished sector.
"There's been a lot of heavy breathing," said George Baker, an energy consultant in Oakland, Calif., who often works in Mexico. "But because of what this entails, the Mexican Government hasn't yet figured it out."

HEADLINE: Capitol Hill Memo;
On Liberties and Libertines: Furor Over Packwood Diary

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26

 BODY:
Every Tuesday, the Senate Democrats and Republicans talk about the great issues of the day in separate private policy luncheons. Today, they talked about sex.
More specifically, the senators discussed Senator Bob Packwood's diary and the Oregon Republican's none-too-subtle suggestion on the Senate floor on Monday that if he was forced to surrender it to the Ethics Committee it could reveal the sexual dalliances of other lawmakers. 
 Senators debated publicly today about unemployment and grazing fees with great confidence and flourish, but they seemed truly confused when it came to the diary.
 
How Thorough Is Good?
 On the one hand, senators said they wanted the Ethics Committee to examine thoroughly the accusations of more than 20 aides, lobbyists and other acquaintances who have accused Mr. Packwood of making unwanted sexual advances over several years. On the other, they expressed concerns that the Senator's civil liberties could be abused by enforcing the committee's demand that he give up all the thousands of pages of his diary to the panel.
And while no senator wanted to appear concerned about what the diary might reveal about himself or another senator, a few expressed displeasure that a colleague was apparently suggesting that he had something on somebody.
This morning, one senator teased Senator Wendell H. Ford of Kentucky, the 69-year-old Democratic whip who is by all accounts a happily married Southern gentleman, that all his sexual secrets were about to be revealed.
But the overall mood all day was dour and edgy, since lawmakers know that sexual indiscretions have not only embarrassed such modern stalwarts as Senator Brock Adams of Washington and Representative Wilbur Mills of Arkansas, or ruined their careers, but colored the reputation of their institution as well.
"This is a monumental issue; this is a monumental discussion," said Senator David H. Pryor, Democrat of Arkansas, who said he was not quite sure what should be done.
The ambivalence of the Senate was more fully expressed by Senator Pete V. Domenici, Republican of New Mexico. "My instincts dictate that we ought to be very careful before we subpoena a private diary of a senator or any witness," he said. "Having said that, I believe we ought to hear the Ethics Committee's reasoning and try to understand the problem."
Others were more coy. "I have to talk to my lawyer," said Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the New York Democrat who usually has an opinion on everything.
 
'Powerful, Personal, Poignant'
 Behind the Republicans' closed door, in what was described as a highly emotional exchange, Mr. Packwood pleaded with his colleagues at lunch that portions of his diary that did not relate to his alleged sexual offenses should be protected as a matter of privacy. After lunch, Senator Alan K. Simpson of Wyoming, the Republican whip, said, "It was a very powerful, personal, poignant meeting."
The Democrats also had a spirited discussion in their luncheon, and several senators who before the session seemed cautious about the release of the entire diary later appeared to be ready to follow the call of the Ethics Committee for full disclosure.
The latest turmoil in the Packwood case was touched off last week, when all six members of the ethics panel decided they needed unfettered access to the diary dating back to 1989 to corroborate or rebut the information they are gleaning from interviewing scores of Packwood associates and women who have accused the senator of sexual abuse.
 
Compromise Is Rejected
 The panel said last Friday that after investigators had examined 20 years' worth of writings, Mr. Packwood suddenly cut off access and declined to provide copies of excerpts the investigators deemed relevant.
The subpoena was issued after Mr. Packwood rejected a compromise agreement to allow a neutral party to review the diary and excise passages that involve his relationships with lawyers and doctors and strictly family matters, the panel said. The committee then said the entire diary "may be relevant and probative."
Mr. Packwood's lawyer, James F. Fitzpatrick, said that the agreement had broken down when the investigators began asking for information that was clearly irrelevant.
The committee asked the full Senate last Thursday to enforce the subpoena in Federal Court. But a consensus appears to have emerged in at least the Republican caucus that Senators George J. Mitchell of Maine, the majority leader, and Bob Dole of Kansas, the minority leader, should work out a compromise on releasing the diary in consultations with Mr. Packwood and the Ethics Committee.
 
Decision Deferred, Happily
 The willingness to put off a decision on the subpoena could cool things off for a few days, but the Oregonian's speech Monday suggested just how far out of control things could get.
Speaking of the diary, Mr. Packwood echoed a warning by his lawyer, saying it included, "an extended affair that one senator had with a member of his staff" and "an affair that a staffer had with a member of the current Congressional Democratic leadership."
As Senator Patty Murray, the Washington Democrat who presided over the session, hoisted an eyebrow, Mr. Packwood continued: "I have no intention of ever using this for blackmail, gray mail, or anything else. But I want the Senate to clearly understand that it is the Ethics Committee that has demanded the production of the pages of the diary upon which is contained the information to which my lawyer made reference."
A senior Republican Senate aide said of the Packwood statement, "You can say the cold war's over, but that was mutually assured Senate destruction."
Mr. Packwood said he has willed the diary to the Oregon Historical Society for release "years" after his death. For more than 25 years, he devoted up to a half-hour every morning to scrawling notes on the events of the day before, mixing ruminations on the issues with personal tidbits and possibly gossip.
Among the items cited specifically by the Senator was a meeting with President Richard M. Nixon over Watergate. On a more personal level, Mr. Packwood described his writing as containing "the hopes and the dreams and the despairs of all of us."

Bryan, the Nevada Democrat who heads the Senate Ethics Committee, spoke to reporters yesterday from an elevator. (Jose R. Lopez/The New York Times) (pg. A16)

HEADLINE: 'Anything Goes' Houston May Go the Limit: Zoning

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOUSTON, Oct. 26

 BODY:
In many American cities, the mental image of the landscape is set by something the city has. Seattle has the Space Needle, St. Louis has the Gateway Arch. Here in Houston, though, even with its famed Astrodome, the urban geography has long been noted for what this city does not have: any zoning regulations whatsoever.
But now Houston, the only major American city without a zoning code, is on the verge of determining whether the time has finally come to impose zoning and, perhaps, inject some modicum of order to the helter-skelter, hodgepodge way that the nation's fourth largest city has evolved and even now continues to grow. 
 So while voters in many cities are going to the polls next Tuesday to pick their mayors, Houstonians are facing a referendum that poses a more fundamental choice over the character of their city. And that means they are debating the quintessential Sun Belt faith, perhaps more pervasive here than anywhere else, that unbridled growth -- anywhere, anytime -- is a good thing.
 
Of Vibrancy and Chaos
 With no ordinances separating residential, business and industrial areas from each other, Houston is full of neighborhoods that mix all three. A cluster of bungalow homes is split by a convenience store, a church is dwarfed by the glass skyscraper next door. Zoning opponents say this has brought a unique vibrancy to Houston, while zoning proponents say it has brought ugly chaos.
A prolonged recession, mounting concerns about unsightly sprawl and a determined drive by zoning advocates have all brought the issue to the fore.
Twice before, in 1948 and again in 1962, after one civic leader called it a Communist plot and another said it would bring "socialized real estate," voters here soundly rejected referendums to impose zoning. And nobody debated zoning much in the freewheeling 1970's and early 1980's, when the doubling and redoubling of world oil prices brought an almost mind-boggling prosperity to much of Houston.
But the collapse of oil prices and the ensuing bust here have clearly brought a measure of sobriety, which many people detect in the reasoned debate over the measure this time around. The vote on Tuesday is expected to be far closer than the other two referendums, and some recent polls show the pro-zoning forces headed for a victory.
"Any time zoning came up before, Houston was always like the perpetual adolescent," said Tim Fleck, editor of The Houston Insider, an influential newsletter on politics and other local issues. "But now people are really asking themselves the question: do we finally settle down and accept the strictures of middle-aged city life, and regulate things, or do we just continue to be the adolescent, partying around and building wherever we can?"
Many people argue that the lack of zoning epitomizes a kind of frontier spirit that made the city great. The biggest newspaper in town, The Houston Chronicle, editorialized against zoning recently, cautioning: "Houston has prospered beyond its fondest dreams without zoning. We will meddle with this success story at our peril."
But others see a definite downside. Maybe you do have the freedom to do anything you want with your home, but so does your neighbor -- like convert it to a tattoo parlor or a chop shop. That kind of thing happens in Houston.
In fact, proponents of the zoning measure say Houston is finally ready to face up to the fact that some things may be more important than the ultimate in free-market economics.
 
Enjoyment of Property
 "The experience of the 70's and 80's has taught us that peaceful enjoyment of property, peaceful enjoyment of a neighborhood, is also a valuable property right," said Jim Greenwood, a City Council member who is a leader of the pro-zoning forces. "It doesn't do much good to make a bunch of money if you have to drive 30 miles to a home where you can enjoy it."
The vote on Tuesday is the product of more than two years of research and mapmaking by a city-appointed panel that has divided the city's 580 square miles into a patchwork of areas zoned for various purposes, as is the norm in many other cities.
In many residential areas, a certain level of commercial activity would be retained, but in others new restrictions would keep out businesses that have drawn the most ire from homeowners, including liquor stores, coin laundries, palm readers and establishments that are politely known as hourly motels.
The outcome of the vote is extremely difficult to predict. A recent poll of 500 likely voters by The Chronicle, said to have a margin of sampling error of plus or minus four percentage points, found that about 43 percent of Houstonians favored zoning, 30 percent were against and 28 percent were unsure.
But even many who expressed a preference said they were confused about the issue, and the anti-zoning forces, which include large developers and small home-based businesses, have put on a blitz of television advertisements. The pro-zoning side has less money to spend but does have the public support of many city officials, including the city's popular Mayor, Bob Lanier, who himself appears headed for an easy re-election on Tuesday.
Virtually all aspects of zoning's impact are subject to bitter debate, including its cost. Barry Klein, executive director of the Houston Property Rights Association, an anti-zoning group, says zoning would hurt thousands of businesses and drive up taxes, while proponents say it would stabilize property values and cause no tax increases.
And there is considerable dissension in minority communities, which by many accounts have the most to gain or lose from zoning. In many wealthy residential neighborhoods, there is a form of de facto zoning known as "deed restrictions," under which those who buy property voluntarily agree not to use it for anything other than a home, knowing that their neighbors have done the same thing. But in many poor or middle-class areas, such restrictions are either nonexistent or too expensive to enforce.
Now, some black ministers who led the fight against zoning 30 years ago out of fear that it would be a tool for segregation, are urging a vote in favor, saying it represents the best way to stabilize neighborhoods and property values. Others are still leery. One group of black ministers argues that the lack of zoning has helped keep Houston from having large ghettoized areas of "poverty and slums."

HEADLINE: $1,000 Coupon Offer at Issue in G.M. Safety Suit

BYLINE: By MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 26

 BODY:
A Federal judge held a hearing today to determine whether the General Motors Corporation should be allowed to settle a suit concerning the safety of 6.3 million pickup trucks by providing owners with $1,000 coupons to buy new G.M. trucks.
The Government opened a formal investigation of the pickups last April after G.M. refused to voluntarily recall and repair them. The company said the trucks were not defective. 
 The trucks have side-mounted gasoline tanks, and the Government has said the design creates a higher risk of fire in collisions from the side. G.M. no longer puts fuel tanks outside a vehicle's protective frame.
Judge William Yohn Jr. of Federal District Court here heard arguments about the proposed settlement, which would settle 23 consolidated class-action suits representing consumers in every states but Texas. Lawyers for General Motors and G.M. truck owners negotiated the agreement on July 20. The trucks at issue are 1973 to 1987 full-size C/K model pickups and their successor R/V models in model years 1988 through 1991. Only 60,000 vehicles are in the latter category.
 
Company Eager to Settle
 A Federal judge in Texas, the state with the highest ownership of the trucks, is scheduled to hold a hearing on Wednesday on the same proposed settlement for Texans. The judges will rule separately sometime soon; if each approves the settlement, other courts would likely use the agreement to resolve 14 additional class-action suits pending against G.M., lawyers involved in the cases said.
Jim Schink, a G.M. lawyer, told Judge Yohn today that the company wanted to settle the case "because we don't want to have an adversarial relationship with our customers."
"The plaintiffs' position shows there is substantial doubt that there is a safety risk," Mr. Schink added.
All that the agreement settles is the potential economic loss of the truck owners in disposing of their vehicles. If it is accepted, the trucks' owners do not lose their rights to sue G.M. for liability or to take part in a recall to repair safety defects.
Still, some consumers and their advocacy groups oppose the settlement because it does not address the Government's safety concerns. But only 11,653 of 5.7 million truck owners who were notified of the settlement by mail have formally criticized or rejected it.
The agreement would provide each truck owner with a $1,000 coupon, which could be used to reduce the final negotiated price of a new pickup or light truck in the 15 months after approval of the settlement. A truck owner or an immediate family member could use the coupon, transfer it with the truck to a new buyer or sell it. If the coupon was sold or given to an unrelated person, its value would drop to $500.
 
Boon for G.M.
 If every owner redeemed the coupon, it would cost G.M. $6.3 billion. But according to a survey conducted for lawyers representing the truck owners, only about $2 billion worth of coupons are likely to be used.
At the same time, marketing experts say that if the agreement is accepted G.M. will turn a lemon into lemonade. The company's profits from new truck sales might be several billion dollars, by some industry estimates.
"It's very clever because the perception is that both the company and the consumer can win," Stephen A. Greyser, a professor of consumer marketing at Harvard Business School, said in an interview.
Ed Lechtzin, G.M.'s director of legal and safety issues, said before the hearing, "We're not defensive about the fact that we might sell more vehicles and that it could very good for the bottom line."
 
Prime-Time Explosion
 The settlement was able to skirt the safety issue, Professor Greyser said, because public concern has sharply declined since last November when NBC broadcast a prime-time "expose" on exploding gas tanks on G.M. pickups. This spring the network acknowledged that its "Dateline NBC" program had rigged a pickup to catch fire in an experimental crash.
In court today, company and consumer lawyers said the $1,000 coupon would offset any decline in the trucks' resale value that could result from negative publicity about the tank design. To date, values have not fallen.
Clarence M. Ditlow, executive director of the Center for Auto Safety, a consumer advocacy organization in Washington, said the case might present the only chance to pressure G.M. into making free repairs on all the trucks. Even if the Government determines that the trucks are defective, by law it can order G.M. to make free repairs only on vehicles made within the previous eight years. Ninety percent of the trucks at issue are older than eight years, and instead of making free repairs, G.M. would only have to notify owners that a defect exists.

HEADLINE: CLINTON SEES WAYS TO REDUCE COSTS

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26

 BODY:
Reaching into a grab bag of leftover campaign promises, President Clinton today introduced legislation and signed executive orders that he said would cut the deficit, curb crime and streamline government.
Mr. Clinton said the proposals could save $10 billion in the next fiscal year by eliminating or reducing wasteful programs while fulfilling his pledge to search for additional cuts in the budget. 
 Administration officials said today that another $22 billion could be cut from government spending over five years. The cuts would be achieved, they said, by eliminating wasteful programs and revamping the procurement process to incorporate new technologies, like allowing bids to be made by computer and thus doing away with some paperwork.
Leon E. Panetta, the director of the Office of Management and Budget, said he expected the Congressional Budget Office to peg the overall savings much lower, closer to $5 billion. But he insisted that the Administration estimates were the correct ones and would allow the President to steer $4 billion to $5 billion of the savings to pay for anticrime legislation, which is pending in the House and Senate.
 
'Keep Our Citizens Safe'
 The President said, "We ought to take some of that money that your Government has been wasting all these years and use it to uphold government's first responsibility, which is to keep our citizens safe here at home."
By investing what Senator John Glenn, Democrat of Ohio, called the "grunt work of government" with the promise of imminent action on issues that the President's pollsters have identified as important, Mr. Clinton hoped to build the case for quick Congressional support.
"I want them to know that, if these cuts aren't passed, I'm going to come back with more cuts," Mr. Clinton said. "And if those aren't passed, I'll come back with still more." He also promised to urge Congress to set aside $5 billion of the savings to pay for the enhancements called for in his anticrime bill.
 
Draws on Gore's Work
 Drawing from the recommendations made by the National Performance Review effort that was headed by Vice President Al Gore, the legislation that was sent to Congress today would achieve its major savings in the following ways:
*Reducing Agriculture Department field offices.
*Ending wool, mohair and honey subsidies. (This measure is essentially being counted twice, since it has already passed both houses and awaits the President's signature.)
*Authorizing managers at the Pentagon to use the proceeds from the sales of recyclable materials.
*Eliminating legal and regulatory restraints to allow open bidding on Medicare claim processing contracts.
"In a larger sense, the steps we are taking here today are also about proving to the American people that we can honestly and seriously deal with the issues that matter most to them and that for too long too many have felt powerless to change," Mr. Clinton said.
 
More Savings Possible?
 But some members of Congress, including Representative Tim Penny, a Minnesota Democrat, contend that the Government could save even more money, and are preparing legislation to that effect.
Mr. Panetta said that the plan Mr. Clinton announced today "more than fulfills that commitment" made in August to members of Congress who asked the Administration to produce additional budget cuts in exchange for support of the President's economic plan.
But he acknowledged that the President's efforts to link the new savings to the anticrime bill could falter if Congress balks at allocating the money or rejects the savings estimates.
