HEADLINE: Electric Rates To Be Frozen By Authority

BYLINE: By TOM REDBURN

 BODY:
The New York State Power Authority, trying to repair its tattered public image and fight off competition from independent energy suppliers, said yesterday that it would freeze electricity rates for the next three years for its government customers in New York City and Westchester County, which could save them as much as $110 million.
The freeze would hold down electricity rates for New York City, the city's subways, suburban commuter rail systems and a number of other government agencies. The action would reduce their bills by roughly 4.5 percent, compared with the increases the Power Authority had previously projected. But some local officials said they did not anticipate that their savings would be as large as the authority announced. 
 The action would not directly affect consumers and businesses, which generally buy electricity from the Consolidated Edison Company, the private utility that serves New York City and Westchester County. But it could, in a modest way, help ease the budget squeeze on local governments and moderate the pressure for fare increases.
"This is one of the most significant rate actions any Power Authority board has ever taken," said Richard M. Flynn, chairman of the authority, which supplies a quarter of the state's electricity, some of it bought from Canada. "We have to beat the competition if we want to keep the customers."
 
'Aggressive Actions'
 Mr. Flynn has been under fire for his use of a state airplane to fly to a weekend home in Rhode Island, for poor management at two nuclear power plants and for efforts to derail attempts by independent companies to supply electricity at lower costs. He portrayed the rate action, one of the few times that the Power Authority has managed to keep rates under control for a sustained period of time, as a sign that the troubled authority is turning the corner.
"We're able to do this because of the aggressive actions we've taken in the past year to cut costs throughout the Power Authority and to revamp our nuclear management and operations," Mr. Flynn said.
In a public-relations barrage accompanying the announcement of the rate freeze, Mr. Flynn rolled out statements of support from Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, Mayor David N. Dinkins, Andrew P. O'Rourke, the Westchester County Executive, and Peter E. Stangl, chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. Most of the cost savings are the result of a $1.1 billion bond refinancing at current lower interest rates, which should cut the borrowing costs of the authority by $370 million over the life of the bonds.
The authority has also reduced its work force by about 200 people and decided to absorb some of the expense of buying additional power to replace the output of its trouble-plagued Indian Point 3 nuclear power plant, which has been shut down since February for repairs. Mr. Flynn said the plant should resume service in early 1994.
Lower costs help make the rate freeze possible. But the fundamental pressure for savings comes from independent power companies that are offering more competition to the power business, which has traditionally been controlled by local and regional monopolies.
"The market has really evolved in recent years," said William F. Squadron, New York City's Commissioner for Telecommunications and Energy. "We had to explore whether there are alternatives."
For example, Sithe Energies, which is building a 1,000-megawatt, gas-fired power plant in upstate New York that is to be finished in 1995, has said it could deliver electricity to the city for about 10 percent less than the Power Authority now charges.
Officials of the company testified before a state legislative committee this month that the authority had tried to kill its project because of the threat that it posed to the authority's James A. FitzPatrick reactor, in Scriba, N.Y., which has a spotty record of reliability and did not run at all last year. But yesterday Mr. Flynn said he was only trying to assure that independent producers, who have been encouraged by Federal legislation guaranteeing them an outlet for their energy, compete on a "level playing field" with existing suppliers.
Mr. Squadron said he welcomed the rate freeze by the authority, saying it was a "very valuable step" that would help bring "stability" to the city's power costs. He said the city's willingness to look for a new source of power was the main factor in prodding the authority to hold down rates.
New York City and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority are by far the largest government customers of the authority, buying almost 20 percent of its output. Last year they spent about $370 million on electricity purchases and an additional $160 million to Con Edison for distribution.
Mr. Flynn said the authority expects the New York City government alone to save $42 million in power costs through 1996. But city officials disputed those figures, saying they anticipate a benefit of only $10.5 million.

HEADLINE: Stocks Stumble in Erratic Trading Session

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY

 BODY:
A day after blue-chip issues roared to new highs, the stock market stumbled through an erratic session yesterday that seemed to raise a question among some analysts: Why can't investors sustain a lengthy autumn rally?
To Michael Metz, chief investment strategist at Oppenheimer & Company, the declines in most stock indicators yesterday may point to renewed anxiety about the health of the economy and the strength of corporate profits. After weeks of setting records, Wall Street may be running out of gas, he said. 
 "The market is foundering and looking for some direction," he said. "It looks tired. There is a new psychology among portfolio managers, where they basically want to reduce their exposure and risk. The market is going to have a downward bias for the next few weeks at a minimum."
 
 
Conference Board Report
 Traders cited two developments that rattled investors yesterday: the Conference Board, a business research group, said its consumer confidence index fell unexpectedly, to 59.4 this month from 63.8 in September. And the strong victory of the Liberal Party in the Canadian election cast new doubt on the fate of the North American Free Trade Agreement.
As a result, the Dow Jones industrial average, which jumped 24.31 points on Monday to a record, fell 1.12 points to 3,672.49. The average had been down nearly 20 points but regained some losses after a small recovery in stocks of large companies whose earnings are sensitive to the economy.
One of the few bright spots in the market was the Dow Jones transportation average, which rose 19.44 points to a record 1,697.15. The previous high was 1,683.08 on April 16.
The transportation average was led by airline stocks like UAL, the parent of United Airlines, up 3 3/8, to 146 5/8; AMR, the parent of American Airlines, up 1 7/8, to 70, and Delta Air Lines, up 1 1/2, to 57 5/8. Analysts said investors seemed to be sensing that the airline industry might be entering a period of stronger earnings.
 
 
Profit Taking
 The industrial average was dragged down by investors who were cashing in on the gains of stocks that did well on Monday, like United Technologies, down 1 1/2, to 62 3/4; Alcoa, down 1 1/8, to 69 5/8, and Eastman Kodak, down 1 1/8, to 57 7/8.
The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks rose slightly, 0.10 point, to 464.30. The American Stock Exchange composite index fell 1.94 points, to 473.64. And the Nasdaq Composite index slumped 4.29 points, to 765.46.
Volume on the Big Board was 284.5 million shares, up from 260.3 million shares on Monday. Once again, declining stocks outnumbered advancers, 1,121 to 908.
Among the strong issues were steel, pollution-control, chemical and automobile stocks. Industries that suffered were banking, software, tobacco and life insurance. Among small stocks, technology and gambling issues, which have ricocheted all over the board in recent weeks, were hard hit.
The most active stock on the Big Board was BankAmerica, which dropped 3/4, to 42 3/8, mirroring the decline in other bank stocks, which appeared to be linked to concern about rising short-term interest rates. Among other heavily traded issues, RJR Nabisco, which said its quarterly net income plunged 58 percent, was unchanged at 5 3/8; General Motors increased 5/8, to 45 3/8.
National Health Labs fell 2 1/4, to 13 1/4, after the Federal Medicare program said it would not pay for two of the company's tests. American Express, which reported sharply higher quarterly profit, declined 1 3/8, to 32 5/8. And Data General was down 1 3/8, to 9 1/4, after it reported a $37.2 million quarterly loss.
Chevron, which announced that its quarterly earnings were down 10 percent, was unchanged at 96 1/4. USX jumped 2 1/2, to 38 1/8, after it reported $36 million in quarterly net income. And Allied Signal dropped 1/8, to 72 3/4, after it said its quarterly earnings rose 24 percent.
I.B.M., which reported a smaller-than-expected quarterly loss, was up 1 3/8, to 46 1/4. And Procter & Gamble gained 1/8, to 52 1/8, after announcing that its quarterly profits increased to 95 cents a share.
On the Nasdaq market, Wall Data fell 1 1/4, to 39. The company said there was a surge of activity because of the expiration of agreements that had prevented its executives from trading until now. And BMC Software dropped 5 3/4, to 51 1/4, after it said its quarterly international sales were weak.

HEADLINE: Senate Bill to Extend Jobless Aid Is Defeated as the G.O.P. Prevails

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26

 BODY:
The Senate voted unexpectedly today to kill an emergency program that gives unemployed Americans an extra 7 to 13 weeks of benefits when their normal six months of checks run out. Legislators later said, however, that they hoped the measure could be reconsidered and passed this week.
Democrats said they planned to negotiate with Republican opponents over the issue that killed the measure: how to find the $1.1 billion needed to pay for the program. 
 The same issue delayed passage of the measure in the House for weeks, beyond the Oct. 2 expiration of the program. The House finally passed the legislation last week.
The bill would extend the emergency program until February. That four-month extension could keep checks coming for a while longer to roughly a million people.
 
Sought to Waive Rule
 Republicans say they support the program but want it financed on a pay-as-you-go basis by raising revenues or making cuts elsewhere in the Federal budget. Congressional budget rules require lawmakers to pay for the emergency program during the fiscal year in which it is approved.
Democrats contend it is impossible to find $1.1 billion in the 1994 budget, and had sought to waive the budget rule and make up the cost over five years. The Senate voted 59 to 38 to grant that request, but the party-line vote fell one short of the 60 required to bypass Senate procedures.
The effort was doomed in the last seconds of the vote when one Republican, Senator Nancy Landon Kassebaum of Kansas, switched from "yea" to "nay."
"When I realized that passage came down to just one vote I changed my vote in the hope that we could work out a way to be more accountable for the costs," she said in a statement.
Even with Senator Kassebaum's defection, Democrats appear to have sufficient strength to pass the jobless benefits extension should it come to the floor again. One strong Democratic supporter who could provide the winning margin, Senator Donald W. Riegle Jr. of Michigan, was absent today.
Regardless of the numbers, Democrats will try to work out a compromise on paying for the benefits in 1994 before bringing the bill back to the Senate floor, said the staff director of the Senate Finance Committee, Lawrence O'Donnell.
Mr. O'Donnell said, "we'll go back and see if there's some financing mechanism that makes this thing more acceptable to more Republicans."
When it was first enacted in 1991, the emergency benefits program was conceived as a temporary, $10-billion balm for a national economic slowdown. It extends the standard 26 weeks of unemployment checks by 13 weeks in the highest-unemployment states -- currently Alaska, California, Rhode Island and West Virginia -- and by seven weeks everywhere else.
Since 1991, Congress has approved the extension three times, at an additional cost of $15 billion. Congressional rules require that the cost of each extension be made up in the year in which it is passed, but until today, Democrats had always mustered the 60 votes needed to bypass the rule, and the White House had always signed the legislation.

HEADLINE: Consumer Confidence Drops

 BODY:
The widely followed Conference Board consumer confidence index fell sharply this month, declining to 59.4 points in October from 63.8 in September. Although the business research group's survey rattled stock investors and knocked the dollar down, economists do not see it as a persuasive sign that consumers are about to retrench.
For one thing, two other respected confidence surveys suggest that consumer spirits -- though far from buoyant -- are rising a bit, not declining. The University of Michigan's index, regarded as a somewhat less volatile gauge than the Conference Board's, perked up in the first half of this month, jumping to 83.1 from 77.9. 
 The ABC/Money Magazine weekly poll also suggests that the mood of consumers has improved this month. That poll shows the mood brighter than at any time since the spring.
More important, consumers have not been acting as depressed about job prospects and the economy in recent weeks as they sounded when they wrote their answers to the Conference Board questionnaires.
So far this month, Johnson Redbook reported, sales by national retail chains have been running 8.2 percent ahead of the comparable period last year. The upswing in the housing market continues, and car dealers report a surge in buying. The Conference Board found car-buying plans more bullish than at any time since May.
All that, Mr. Kelly said, "suggests that retail sales are going to be very strong for October." Peter Schaeffer of Johnson Redbook said he expects a good Christmas.

HEADLINE: U.S. Says Chretien Will Not Undo Nafta

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26

 BODY:
President Clinton and his aides said today that they did not expect that the Liberal Party's victory in Canadian elections would hurt the prospects for approval of the North American Free Trade Agreement or lead to renegotiation of the pact.
"From my point of view, it will have no impact at all," President Clinton said this morning, discounting the Liberal Party's platform plank that called for renegotiation of the accord. "I see no reason to renegotiate the agreement or any grounds or basis for it, and I think we should just go ahead." 
 Several Administration officials said they believe that Jean Chretien, the Liberal Party leader, is more enthusiastic about free trade than others in his party and less interested in renegotiating the pact.
 
Chretien Has the Muscle
 President Clinton, who spoke by telephone with Mr. Chretien this morning, said the Canadian gave him no specific assurances on the trade accord. But, the President added, "nothing occurred in the conversation which made me have any doubt that our course of proceeding is the right course."
A White House official who spoke on condition that he not be identified said, "My sense is that given the scale of Chretien's win, he is going to be under less pressure" to seek renegotiations. A smaller victory margin could have forced the Liberal Party to seek the support of the left-leaning New Democratic Party, which is implacably opposed to the pact.
"What he has been saying is quite moderate," the official said. "What he has been saying is an open-access -- I don't want to say free trade -- but it's a very open-access, moderate agenda."
Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, said Washington opposed any renegotiation.
But at two news conferences and in an interview today, he refused to say whether the United States might be willing to discuss with the Canadians how to interpret the pact. The Administration is currently pursuing similar talks with Mexico on trade in sugar, fruit and vegetables.
 
Well, There Are Other Accords
 Mr. Kantor said he had seen nothing in Mr. Chretien's statements suggesting that he would seek to reopen the pact. "The Canadians have raised no concerns directly with us and so, therefore, there's nothing to renegotiate," he said.
A Canadian withdrawal from the North American Free Trade Agreement would have little economic effect on the United States because the 1988 United States-Canada Free Trade Agreement already covers trade between the two countries.
If Canada withdraws, the United States would still conclude a pact with Mexico, Robert Rubin, the head of the National Economic Council, said last month. Without Canada in Nafta, free trade would be in effect between Canada and the United States and between Mexico and the United States, but not between Canada and Mexico.
The House of Representatives is tentatively scheduled to vote on Nov. 17 on legislation to put the agreement into law; the Senate is likely to vote the following day. President Clinton has been aggressively wooing members of Congress, and met with several Representatives today.
But Representative Sander Levin, a Michigan Democrat and a vocal opponent of the agreement, contended that the wide support in Canada for a party that favored renegotiation reinforced his view that Nafta should be redrawn.
 
Fence-Sitter Leans to the North
 Representative Toby Roth, a Wisconsin Republican who is one of the few undecided members of Congress, expressed concern at the Canadian vote, saying it would influence him and others who have not decided how to vote.
"I think that Nafta was a big issue in the Canadian elections," he said, "and I think that the American politicians have to take that, factor that into their equation as they're making up their mind as to whether to vote for it."
Most Canadian political experts today blamed the crushing defeat of the ruling Progressive Conservative Party mainly on the weak economy and a badly run campaign. They assigned a secondary role to trade concerns and the loss of jobs to the United States.
To bolster the trade pact, the Administration struck a tentative four-part deal with most House and Senate leaders today on how to raise $2.8 billion to cover the lost trade tariffs, worker-retraining programs and a cleanup program along the Mexican border, all facets of Nafta.
 
Covering Nafta's Costs
 Bowing to pressure from conservative Republicans, the Administration agreed to increase the customs inspection fee for arriving passengers by only $1.50, to $6.50, instead of doubling it, to $10, as proposed last week. But $6.50 will cover only the cost of the inspections and no more.
To make up the $2.8 billion, the Administration and Congressional leaders tentatively settled on three accounting maneuvers: requiring companies to send in income-tax deductions from workers' checks more quickly, requiring the Customs Service to use Internal Revenue Service data to discover undervaluation of imported goods subject to tariffs and projecting that the Agriculture Department would spend less to hold up crop prices as sales to Mexico rise.
But the tentative deal was not put in writing because of objections from conservative Republicans. Representative Thomas W. Ewing, an Illinois Republican who organized a revolt by 26 colleagues last week against doubling the $5 customs inspection fee, said he and a dozen allies probably would not vote for the accord if it included even just a $1.50 increase.
The Administration is also preparing to announce as soon as Wednesday that some money for the border cleanup would be used to set up a North American Development Bank to make loans to communities anywhere Nafta might cause job losses, officials said. The announcement is intended to woo legislators from districts far from the border.

HEADLINE: Looking Ahead at Dinkins Cabinet

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER

 BODY:
As he campaigns for a second term, Mayor David N. Dinkins steadfastly refuses to talk about what his second administration would look like, though it is clear at City Hall that he would, if re-elected, probably have to find successors for his two most important aides as well as improve the overall management of his government.
Some senior advisers say Mr. Dinkins thinks that some commissioners may need to be replaced, or, as one put it, that "he's got to tighten up the bolts in some places." Whether Mr. Dinkins, who has long shown a reluctance to dismiss people, would ask for the resignation of some of his less-than-stellar commissioners is a matter of debate within the administration. 
 But his most crucial decisions will likely be how to fill the roles of the two figures who set much of the tone and direction for his administration: First Deputy Mayor Norman Steisel, who friends say is likely to leave government within the next year or so if Mr. Dinkins is re-elected, and Bill Lynch, the Mayor's closest political adviser, who has said often in recent months that he hoped to go to South Africa to advise the African National Congress on the formation of a multiracial government.
The Mayor gives no hint who their replacements might be, but many of his advisers suggest that they would probably set a different tone and personal style.
 
Infighting Is Concern
 Many aides say that the Mayor would have to cut down on the infighting that marred his first four years, including bickering between Mr. Steisel and the head of the Human Resources Administration, Barbara J. Sabol. Some also suggest that Mr. Dinkins should reduce the number of deputy mayors -- there are now six -- to streamline decision-making.
Even before he was elected in 1989, Mr. Dinkins named Nathan Leventhal, a former First Deputy Mayor under Mayor Edward I. Koch, to run his transition. He also promised to make Victor A. Kovner corporation counsel. But this time around, Mr. Dinkins has steered away from all talk about the possible shape of a second administration. "I'm not willing to discuss that at this time," the Mayor said.
Some rising stars are looked on as likely figures of importance if there is a Dinkins second term.
One is Carol O'Cleireacain, who was Finance Commissioner until she was appointed Budget Director in late August. The city's long-term fiscal problems are so severe that the budget will surely be topic A in City Hall next year, whether Mr. Dinkins or Rudolph W. Giuliani, his Republican-Liberal challenger, wins on Tuesday.
Another insider whose role would most likely expand is George B. Daniels, the Mayor's Counsel, who has become a crucial mayoral adviser and whose judgment and temperament is widely admired.
 
Success of Many Women
 Many of the commissioners who have performed well and would be likely candidates to fill openings at the top of the administration are women. Among them, said more than a half-dozen senior mayoral aides, are Emily Lloyd, the Sanitation Commissioner; Betsy Gotbaum, the Parks Commissioner; Catherine M. Abate, the Correction Commissioner, and Ms. O'Cleireacain.
"I know the men will be calling me up howling, but the female commissioners in general have outperformed the men," Mr. Steisel said.
Mr. Steisel, a former Sanitation Commissioner and investment banker, is respected within the administration for his expertise on government and management, but he has also been criticized for a manner that can be abrasive. His successor is likely to have a more collegial style and to make the city's senior administrators work more cohesively, many mayoral advisers said.
Mr. Steisel's successor may also require assurances that he or she will be perceived clearly as Mr. Dinkins's top aide.
While Mr. Lynch and Mr. Steisel have said often that they respect and like each other, their sharply different personal styles and different political and governmental experiences often led to internal clashes, many senior mayoral aides said.
 
No Clear Successor
 Many aides said that if Mr. Steisel did depart, there was no clear-cut successor within the administration.
Among the insiders mentioned as possible candidates are Barry F. Sullivan, the Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development; Fritz W. Alexander 2d, the Deputy Mayor for Public Safety, and Sally Hernandez-Pinero, the chairwoman of the City Housing Authority, who served before that as a Deputy Mayor in the original Dinkins team.
But there are factors that would diminish the likelihood that any of these three would become the next First Deputy Mayor.
Mr. Sullivan, a retired bank executive, is not particularly familiar with many agencies within the huge city government.
Mr. Alexander, who was a judge on the state's highest court, the Court of Appeals, before joining the Dinkins administration, was once the Mayor's law partner and is a close friend. But he might not be willing to make the commitment of time and energy needed to be First Deputy.
And Ms. Hernandez-Pinero left City Hall for the Housing Authority last year because she wanted to spend more time with her children.
The commissioners who are widely perceived as having performed well might be candidates for Mr. Steisel's job, should he depart. In addition to Ms. Lloyd, Ms. Abate, Ms. O'Cleireacain and Ms. Gotbaum, others given high marks included: Carl Weisbrod, the president of the city's Economic Development Corporation; Margaret A. Hamburg, the Health Commissioner; Kenneth J. Knuckles, the Commissioner of General Services, and Raymond W. Kelly, the Police Commissioner.
Among those perceived by many within the administration as having had difficult tenures are Ms. Sabol, the head of the Human Resources Administration; Lucius J. Riccio, the Transportation Commissioner; Hazel N. Dukes, the president of the Offtrack Betting Corporation, and Josephine Nieves, the Commissioner of Employment.

HEADLINE: Christopher Praises Belarus on Nuclear Issue

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO

DATELINE: MINSK, Belarus, Oct. 26

 BODY:
Secretary of State Warren Christopher came to this capital of broad boulevards today and praised its leaders for taking "historic steps" to remove nuclear weapons from their territory.
His message was as much an embrace of Belarus as it was a signal to Ukraine, whose leaders told Mr. Christopher on Monday that they were committed to making their country nuclear-free, but whose Parliament has not yet ratified the Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty or agreed to adhere to the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty. 
 The former Soviet republic of Belarus, by contrast, signed both agreements this year, and has already actively begun to dismantle and destroy its nuclear weapons.
"The United States very highly values the historic steps Belarus has taken to remove nuclear weapons left on its soil by the Soviet Union," Mr. Christopher said at a joint news conference with Stanislav Shushkevich, who holds the positions of both head of state and speaker of the Parliament.
Mr. Christopher said Belarus "serves as a shining example to states around the region" because of actions, which he said have won the "gratitude of the entire world community."
Mr. Christopher also announced that the leaders of Belarus had informed him that they would hold early elections in March, earlier than expected.
Until today, leaders had pledged to hold parliamentary elections, but had not set a deadline. Mr. Christopher called that decision a "sharp acceleration" of the country's movement toward democracy, although a final decision is up to Parliament.
The remnants of the Communist era are evident in Minsk, a city of 1.6 million people where a statue of Lenin still graces Independence Square. A huge white canvas covers a Mount Rushmore-like marble head of Mr. Lenin behind the stage in the auditorium of the former headquarters of the Communist Party.
The Communist Party continues to dominate both the Council of Ministers and the Parliament. And the country has even adopted the Soviet national anthem as its own, minus the words.
One of the most conservative republics under Soviet rule, Belarus is still heavily dependent on Russia, which supplies 70 percent of its imports. But Mr. Shushkevich has fought efforts by Prime Minister Vyachelsav Kebich and Parliament to align his country's foreign policy with Moscow and join a Russian-led defense pact.
Today Mr. Shushkevich thanked the United States for offering help with his country's elections and for proposing a plan that would give Eastern Europe a "partnership" role in NATO.
Although he said that his country was determined to move toward democracy, he added, "The United States should understand why the political reforms and the economic reforms are very slow in this process."
Asked how long it would take to rid his country of nuclear weapons, he said it was "difficult to say," although he added that his country was eager to become nuclear-free.
Belarus has dismantled 9 of its 72 SS-25 missiles under the 1991 Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty and is pledged to speed up the disposal of the others. It has already received $59 million in American aid for dismantling.
In exchange for proceeding with disarmament, Belarus asked earlier this month for a seat on the United Nations Security Council.

HEADLINE: CAMPAIGN TRAIL;
Florio and Whitman Focus on Basic Themes

BYLINE: By KIMBERLY J. McLARIN

DATELINE: BRICK TOWNSHIP, N.J., Oct. 26

 BODY:
It is exactly one week before Election Day and the polls show the race for Governor could be close. But Christine Todd Whitman and Gov. Jim Florio could be vacationing in Hawaii for all the stress the two candidates are showing on the campaign trail.
Appearing remarkably relaxed and confident, both candidates crisscrossed the state today, returning to their core audiences to shore up support and dropping in on lunchtime crowds to lobby for last-minute votes. 
 Mr. Florio had only two events for the day, while Mrs. Whitman sandwiched two small events around a television and a radio interview.
Traditionally, candidates in the closing innings try to hone in on a theme. Florio has chosen to emphasize his role in the state ban on assault weapons. But Mrs. Whitman tried out various pitches today on several widely varying fields.
Her day began with a visit to the state headquarters of the American Automobile Association in Robbinsville, where she addressed about 30 staff members and slung a few barbs at Mr. Florio.
"He has no defense for the past or vision for the future," she told the small gathering, which was nearly matched in number by a horde of reporters. "We need to hear what he is going to do. He won't answer because he doesn't know."
Spending lunchtime at a food court in Trenton, she ate a slice of cheese pizza and waded through a crowd of state workers on their lunch break, shaking hands and holding animated talks on everything from her tax-cut plan to infant mortality.
By the afternoon, Mrs. Whitman was in New York City for interviews on CNN and on the Bob Grant talk show on WABC radio.
Mr. Florio, a man renowned for his intensity, began the day schmoozing and laughing with an elderly group in Brick Township, Ocean County. Mr. Florio introduced his wife, Lucinda, gave his standard line about her being his "better two-thirds" and told a story about how the couple was walking in a parade in Trenton a few days ago when someone in the crowd spotted Mrs. Florio and called out, "Hey, there's Whitman."
"If folks in this state would think Mrs. Whitman and myself would hold hands and walk down the street, anything can happen," he said.
Later, during a news conference in Clifton, Mr. Florio continued trying to link Mrs. Whitman to the National Rifle Association. He accused Mrs. Whitman of trying to hide N.R.A. support for her candidacy and handed out what he said were copies of a newsletter put out by the Association of New Jersey Rifle and Pistol Clubs, an N.R.A. affiliate organization. The newsletter said that the group's executive association had voted to endorse Mrs. Whitman.
Mr. Florio said that if Mrs. Whitman were elected, she would work to dismantle the state ban on semiautomatic weapons. Mrs. Whitman has said she will support the law, but has also said she favors removing certain weapons from the ban and believes that gun owners who owned semiautomatic weapons before the ban should be allowed to keep them.
Mary Warren, a member of the rifle and pistol club association's executive board, said the group recommended Mrs. Whitman to its membership but did not endorse her.
Carl Golden, a spokesman for Mrs. Whitman, said Mrs. Whitman never sought or received an official endorsement from the association.
"They put out something in their newsletter, but that does not constitute an endorsement," Mr. Golden said. "I know the Governor is struggling mightily to turn it into one because it's the only issue he's got."
When reminded that he once accepted contributions from the N.R.A before being elected Governor, Mr. Florio said, "That goes to the very heart of who it is that's willing to stand up when something is wrong."
 
Black G.O.P. Assails Florio
 Today, the African-American Republican Coalition held a rally to criticize Mr. Florio for his record on issues affecting black residents. The coalition released a report that said African-Americans were worse off now than before Mr. Florio took office in the areas of education, welfare, health and unemployment.
"Governor Florio had three and a half years to make a difference for the African-Americans in this state," said Assemblywoman Priscilla B. Anderson, a Republican from Camden. "The facts show he hasn't really helped us at all."
 
Bellwether (Long Hair Extra)
 Come election season, everyone is a pollster. High schools take straw polls among their students. The elderly pass out little slips of paper before bingo. If Weekly Reader can do it, why not Mike Sutlovich?
Mr. Sutlovich, a barber in Hackensack, polled his customers last October and found that Bill Clinton was running just enough ahead of President Bush to win. This year, Mr. Sutlovich held a seven-week poll that ended last Friday and found Mr. Florio ahead of Mrs. Whitman, 733 to 685.
His analysis?
"People around here, they feel like they don't have much of a choice, that they're being forced to choose between the lesser of two evils," he said.
"Two years ago, I couldn't even mention Florio's name in here; people would get mad," he said. "Between tax hikes and this and that, I stood a better chance of getting re-elected governor myself."
But as angry as voters are with Mr. Florio, many do not consider Mrs. Whitman sincere or capable, he said.
"They say, 'Hey, she hires illegal immigrants, what kind of respect does she have for the working stiff?' " he said. "Other people say Christine here, she can't manage her own campaign. How is she going to manage the state?"

HEADLINE: On the Trail of Voter Vindication;
Florio Campaigns on the Value of Taking Tough Medicine

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, Oct. 26

 BODY:
They have become known as the Recession Governors, the executives of big industrial states who inherited budgets and payrolls that were bloated by the boom years of the 1980's and revenues that are starved by the lean times that came with the 1990's. And the first among them in office, and the first to face a review by the voters, is Jim Florio of New Jersey,
"We were first across the barbed wire," the Governor said recently, choosing a grim simile of trench warfare, to describe the politics of governing in a recession. 
 As Mr. Florio's re-election campaign against Christine Todd Whitman enters its final days, keeping those other governors in mind seems to be the key to understanding his claim for a second term. Mr. Florio returns time and again to his argument that while others postponed the harsh truths of recession budget-making, New Jersey swallowed a stinging dose of higher taxes early on -- medicine that will eventually, he says, produce a long-term cure.
Mrs. Whitman and others may point to the turmoil that followed the defining act of his administration, the $2.8 billion in new taxes Mr. Florio rammed through the Legislature during his first months in office. They may note the voter backlash that followed, the early wars and icy truce with Republican legislators who rode the tax backlash to a veto-proof majorities two years later, and the barely concealed bitterness of many Democrats whose legislative careers were ended in that campaign.
 
Comparison to California
 But to questions about these events, Mr. Florio turns for vindication to the experiences of governors who tried to finesse the recession, keeping their heads down, avoiding new taxes, praying for a recovery.
"Three and a half years ago California and New Jersey faced the same problems," he said in a recent interview, ticking off details -- rising costs, shrinking revenues, yawning deficits. "Today, New Jersey's bonds are rated double-A plus, California is junk."
From higher bond ratings Mr. Florio proceeds to lower borrowing costs, which affords more money for job training and industrial development, which produce more new jobs for a state that has lost 200,000 of them since he became governor, and so on -- stepping from program to program, fact to fact, drawing a skein of inevitability around his policies.
 
Fifteen Previous Campaigns
 This is Mr. Florio's 16th campaign in 24 years as a politician, which is not to count the one that won him the student council presidency at Trenton State College in 1962. To each, winning and losing, he has brought the same dogged reliance on the facts as he sees them and the same hard-scrabble style that he gained on his way out of the near poverty of his Brooklyn childhood to the national spotlight of his latest race.
By all accounts, Tuesday's vote will be as closely watched in the White House as in the dozens of other state houses where governorships will be up for grabs next fall. The question is, will a campaign style that is more attack than explanation be enough vindicate the governor?
Watching Mr. Florio on the stump, one of many inconsistencies in his style becomes clear. He is an incumbent governor with a considerable record in office, an encyclopedic command of its detail and a lawyer's ability to defend that record. Yet Mr. Florio has clearly preferred to fight the campaign on Mrs. Whitman's record than on his own.
So Mr. Florio steadfastly refuses to forecast his plans for his next term, should he win one, beyond saying that he plans to press on with the economic development programs already in motion. Pushed to say if he saw any problems ahead, like the continued budget deficits that seem to be in many economic forecasts, he said with evident peevishness, "If I saw any problems, I'd be talking about them."
 
Spending the Political Coin
 Yet Mr. Florio's record is arguably one of considerable achievement, and one purchased with the true coin of politics, his popularity, said Carl Van Horn, a Rutgers University professor and former head of planning for Mr. Florio.
"Most governors save their real battles until the second term, but Florio has clearly left a legacy already," Mr. Van Horn said. "He was dealing with real problems that are everywhere in this country, and he didn't wait until they got worse. In Florida, Lawton Chiles said he wouldn't raise taxes until he had made all possible cuts. A year later his popularity is down around 20 percent, and then he raised taxes. You could ask, who got it right?"
Little of the commotion of Mr. Florio's first term could have been predicted from his campaign against James A. Courter, a Republican and, like Mr. Florio, a United States Representative.
Mr. Florio devoted most of his time to the shoot-the-wounded style of campaigning that he, along with other Democrats, developed after watching George Bush crush Michael A. Dukakis with negative campaigning in the previous year's Presidential race. It was Mr. Florio's third try for the governorship, following a failed attempt for the nomination in 1977 and a narrow loss to Thomas H. Kean four years later, and he won by 540,000 votes.
 
Dropping the Budget Shoe
 When Mr. Florio delivered his inaugural address on Jan. 16, 1990, his words contained no forecast of the storm that would soon enfold his cause. Instead he reviewed the themes from his campaign, illustrated with poignant vignettes of citizens he met on the campaign: automobile insurance reform, gun controls, worker re-training, appointment of an environmental prosecutor. There was no mention of new taxes, or of sacrifice.
But a month later, his treasurer and current campaign aide, Douglas Berman, declared that the fiscal year 1990 budget that Mr. Florio inherited from Governor Kean was, with five months to go, some $600 million out of balance. These days, Mr. Florio often cites the arts groups and farm groups who demonstrated against him then, as he went to work cutting their programs, as if their anger were proof of his budget-cutting diligence.
In mid-March, Mr. Florio dropped the other shoe, his 1990-91 budget, which called for a doubling of the income tax rate for upper-income New Jerseyans, a one-cent increase on a sales tax to be expanded to apply to a wider range of goods, and numerous smaller levies on business expenses, from telephone calls to purchases of heavy trucks. Total annual yield: $2.8 billion.
With his tax increase, Mr. Florio put in motion a system in which the state collects vastly more money and redistributes it back to the communities according to need. It amounted to a fundamental reorganization of the way taxes are collected and services are financed, a moving away from the previous fragmented system of local taxes, under which rich communities did well and poor ones starved.
 
A Crisis Atmosphere
 Instead of sending his department heads before appropriations committees to defend his plan, Mr. Florio developed a focused strategy to keep Republicans and tax-shy Democrats in the Democrat-dominated legislature on a tight rein. He sent only Mr. Berman to defend the budget, arguing that the rest of the cabinet was too green to speak authoritatively.
"I'd been in Trenton for 10 years then, and it was the first time I'd seen it done that way," said Garabed (Chuck) Haytaian, now the Republican Speaker of the Assembly. "No one talked to us, no one collaborated, it was just pushed through in three weeks."
David Kehler, president of the Public Affairs Research Institute of New Jersey, a nonpartisan think tank and government watchdog group, concurred.
"Florio had a legislative strategy but he didn't have a public strategy to build public support for these things," he said. "His staff ran the tax increases through in a kind of crisis atmosphere - 'There's no time to debate, let's move on this.' "
In contrast, two other recession governors, John Engler of Michigan and Robert P. Casey of Pennsylvania, have since brought similar tax-shifting proposals before their lawmakers, only to see them defeated, Mr. Kehler said.
"So it was a legislative success for Florio, but it produced a massacre," he added.
 
Hitting Rock Bottom
 Most of the new taxes began biting quickly but the offsetting decline in the rate of property tax growth did not register for a year or more, and many voters, particularly those lower middle-income residents who stood to benefit from the Florio plan, rose in near revolt. The anti-tax crusade was skillfully abetted by gun owners and the National Rifle Association, which was gearing up for an attempted repeal of a strict gun control law Mr. Florio had successfully pushed for in late 1990.
Reporters began reaching for the Fahrenheit scale as a trope for the governor's below-freezing, and still falling, popularity rating. And when the polls closed on election day in November 1991, 32 Democrats had been defeated, and the Republicans had won 85 of the legislature's 120 seats and veto-proof majorities in both houses.
"It was very difficult," Mr. Florio said recently, looking back at the days when his administration hit rock bottom. "I suspect there are not a lot of people who could have gone through the last 3 1/2 years without crawling into a fetal position."
In the first 12 months of the new Assembly, Mr. Florio's veto was overridden 12 times, compared to three veto overrides in the previous 40 years. The Republicans rolled back the penny increase in the sales tax and overruled the governor's budget and enacted their own spending plan, one that cut spending from the previous year's level for the first time anyone could remember.
 
A Move to Bipartisanship
 Yet the Republican majority also began to feel the responsibilities of governing. When the cut in the sales tax brought the layoffs of thousands of state workers, Mr. Florio blamed the Republicans. When the budget cut resulted in higher prescription costs for elderly patients, the governor directed complaints to the legislature.
And in a victory, this spring, of immense importance to Mr. Florio's prestige, the Senate misread the popular feeling for gun control and was forced to back down on one of its leadership's first campaign pledge, to end the Governor's ban on certain semiautomatic firearms.
Meanwhile Mr. Florio brought in a new, less contentious top staff, including M. Robert DeCotiis as chief counsel, a man who, many Republicans concede, was skillful at soothing Republican feathers and at building a spirit of cooperation. More legislation rolled through in a bipartisan spirit, with each side happily claiming credit -- a tightening of welfare eligibility, election law changes, new coastal zone protections, the decontrol of prices at hospitals in the state.
Approaching what is probably his last try -- Governors in New Jersey are limited to two terms -- at an office he has coveted for 15 years, Mr. Florio feels that time has vindicated him.
"Somebody has to run the state," he said to explain his fierce style, "even if it takes a long time to cut through the noise and get to where people finally start to say, 'Oh, O.K. -- I see now.' "

HEADLINE: Weicker Plans to Offer Bill To Limit Handgun Ownership

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Oct. 26

 BODY:
Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. said today that he plans to draft legislation that would virtually ban the private ownership of handguns in Connecticut.
"It's time we stepped out on the issue," Mr. Weicker said. 
 "This isn't something unique to Connecticut. It's a national disease and it comes under the guise of people's -- quote -- rights," he said. "Well, believe me, the United States isn't in 1993 what it was in 1776. And we recognize it in every other phase of our life, and it's time we recognize it as far as weapons go."
Mr. Weicker first floated the idea of the handgun ban on Monday, but he said then that he was not certain if he would submit such a proposal to the General Assembly.
Today he said he plans to meet with legislative leaders and representatives of gun-lobbying groups to discuss the legislation before presenting it to the General Assembly in February.
 
Sees Shift in Opinion
 Mr. Weicker said he wants to ban the private ownership of all handguns, with the exception of those used by law-enforcement officials, the military, collectors and private security companies.
He acknowledged that the prospects for such a sweeping ban are not strong, but he said he believes that public sentiment is shifting in that direction. He also played down opposition from gun lobbyists.
"I'm not going to accept any more slogans," he said. "People are getting killed every which way in this state, as they are in states and cities across the nation -- we've never seen such unparalleled violence."
Mr. Weicker said that the state did not have enough money or police officers to deter crime and that such underlying social problems as unemployment, lack of health care and inadequate educational opportunities must be addressed before the state can ever hope to see the crime rate go down.
"Will the people of this state continue to permit the proliferation of handguns in the hands of anybody and everybody that wants to have them -- an instrument which has only one purpose, which is to maim or kill a human being? It's as simple as that. That is the purpose of a handgun," he said. "Or has the time come to get these weapons off the street?"
In June the state legislature passed a ban on the sale of about 60 semiautomatic guns deemed to be assault weapons. A coalition of gun owners, supported by the National Rifle Association and the Second Amendment Foundation, is challenging the ban in court.

HEADLINE: G.M. Tells Plant It Will Delay Date Of Closing

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON

 BODY:
General Motors gave its car assembly plant in North Tarrytown, N.Y., a brief reprieve yesterday, saying it would continue operating as much as a year beyond its scheduled 1995 closing date.
But G.M. said that it still planned to close the plant as soon as full production of a 1996 mini-van model began elsewhere, and that employment at North Tarrytown until then would depend on sales of the Chevrolet Lumina, Oldsmobile Silhouette and Pontiac Transport mini-vans assembled there. 
 News of the delayed closing came as a relief to G.M. workers, shops and restaurants near the plant and to state and local officials who are trying to find a new use for the 95-acre site along the Hudson River. But most took the company at its word that it would still close the plant, which built its first automobiles in 1900 and is Westchester County's largest remaining factory.
"It's good news in that 2,000 people are going to be employed there for a year beyond when we thought they would," said Susan Glass, a spokeswoman for New York State's Commissioner of Economic Development, Vincent Tese. But, she said, the state has shifted its efforts from trying to persuade G.M. to stay to mediating talks between the company and the village on a departure package.
 
Cleanup a Goal
 The Mayor of North Tarrytown, Sean Tracy, said, "We see this as a reprieve for the business community in the village for another year or two, to allow them to prepare themselves for a new customer base."
In the meantime, Mr. Tracy said, the village's lawyers are working on a departure package proposed by General Motors. The village's primary goal is to make sure that G.M. cleans up the huge industrial site, so that the land will be attractive to buyers.
"This site is so important to the future of our community, we can't just whistle past the cemetery in the hope that G.M. might stay," he said.
G.M.'s announcement in February 1992 that it would close the North Tarrytown plant in 1995 stunned state, local and union officials, who had made large concessions to keep the factory open. Under a 10-year agreement that began in 1985, the state, county and village had provided incentives valued at $140 million.
 
Seeing Delay as Victory
 In 1987, Local 664 of the United Auto Workers had agreed to a contract that eliminated most job classifications in an effort to provide G.M. a modern and efficient shop floor.
Yesterday the president of Local 664, Donald C. Martino, saw the delayed closing as a victory, because it would keep the plant in operation until the next round of union talks with G.M. in 1996.
"I kept saying we'd never close in '95, while G.M. was saying it wouldn't change its decision," Mr. Martino said. "Everybody wrote us off, but the workers here kept building a world-class quality van. It depends on sales, of course, but sales are picking up, so maybe we can win a concession in '96 and stay open."
Margaret Holmes, a spokeswoman for G.M.'s midsize car division in Warren, Mich., said the North Tarrytown plant would stay open into the 1996 model year so that G.M. would maintain a presence in the mini-van market until its new 1996 model "accelerates to full production."
"This does not, however, change General Motors' plans to cease operations at North Tarrytown after the existing vehicle is replaced by the new mini-van," she said.
The number of jobs at the plant, which stood at 3,450 in February 1992 but fell to 2,150 six months later when G.M. eliminated the second shift in response to disappointing sales, "will depend on the orders we get from our customers," she said.
The threat of closing has hung over the assembly plant, G.M.'s oldest, since the 1970's. Its expensive retooling in the 1980's to build a new line of mini-vans was seen as a great victory, but tied its future to the success of models that havenot sold well. Now employees and the businesses that serve them are again hoping for the best.
"We've always been under the gun, and this extends the stem of hope for us," said Jimmy Carter, a U.A.W. attendance representative who has worked at the plant for 30 years. "The van is starting to sell, and we're putting in nine-hour days and every other Saturday. This is the best work force in the world."
Karen Eannacomi, an hourly worker, said: "Everybody's happy, and some people think this means the plant will stay open. I'm not sure of that, but the longer we stay here, the better it is for everybody. It gives us another year to plan the future."
Rick Tucci, a Pinkerton security guard assigned to the plant, said: "I think it's great if it stays open. Basically, if they're not here, I'm not here."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Calm Over Trade Pact's Prospects

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The victory of the Liberal Party in Canada's election on Monday has again put the spotlight on the future of the North American Free Trade Agreement. The next Prime Minister, Jean Chretien, has said he wants to renegotiate the agreement to protect some Canadian exporters.
The possible objections from Canada provide an opportunity to ask what will happen in the bond market if the United States Congress rejects the agreement with Mexico. A leading opponent of the agreement, David E. Bonior, a Democrat of Michigan, said yesterday that just 10 more votes were needed to get the 218 votes to defeat the trade pact. Congress is scheduled to vote on it on Nov. 17. 
 Some analysts argue that the bond market will sell off if the agreement is defeated, even though a defeat will not have a significant impact on economic growth or inflation in the near term.
"Nafta is an important symbol of American willingness to continue to be part of the world," said Neal M. Soss, chief economist at at CS First Boston. "Defeat would be a very bearish symbol. The instant market reaction would be negative and it would also call into question President Clinton's ability to get other things done in the future, especially on deficit reduction."
Robert V. DiClemente, an economist at Salomon Brothers, agreed about the symbolic importance of the agreement, adding that its defeat would raise doubts about moving ahead with other efforts, like the still-stalled negotiations to open world markets under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.
"Free trade and open borders for money and goods are a tremendously disinflationary force, and anything that disrupts that will raise questions about the larger effort," he said.
But Mr. DiClemente was not sure how much the bond market would be affected by a Congressional defeat of the free-trade pact because the immediate impact on inflation and growth would not be significant. "I think it would cause a ripple," he said. "I don't know if it would be enough in itself to dominate a day's trading or start a trend."
Robert Dederick, chief economist at the Northern Trust Company in Chicago, said the Congressional vote on the agreement would probably have little impact. "The big effect of this is political," he said. "I don't view it as something that will affect the market significantly one way or another."
 
Treasury Market
 Prices of Treasury bonds and notes inched higher after falling for three consecutive days. Because traders and investors are so uncertain about the course of the economy and inflation, each new piece of economic news is watched closely.
Yesterday's report on consumer confidence turned out to be a surprise on the positive side for the market: that is, the report was weaker than expected. The Conference Board consumer confidence index for October was 59.4, down from a revised 63.8 in September. Most analysts had been expecting an increase to around 65. The news helped bolster prices early in the day.
The market also received a lift in the afternoon from a weaker-than-expected report on department store sales for the first three weeks of October.
In secondary trading, the price of the 30-year bond was up 7/32 of a point, while the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, fell to 5.98 percent from 6 percent the day before. The yield on the Treasury's three-year note was at 4.16 percent, down from 4.16 percent.
The announcement that the Treasury would sell $26.8 billion in three- and six-month bills next week pushed the discount rates on both securities higher. The rate on the three-month bill was 3.07 percent, up from 3.03 percent.
In the Treasury market, the auction of $16.5 billion of two-year Treasury notes went as expected. The notes were auctioned at the high yield of 3.94 percent. That is the same rate as at the end of trading Monday and is the same as the yield at the auction in September. In late trading in the when-issued market, the yield on the newly auctioned notes was at 3.92 percent, a reflection of demand after the auction and a signal that the dealers who bought them at the auction are probably happy with the auction results.
The Treasury will auction $11 billion of five-year notes today. In late trading in the when-issued market, the yield was 4.78 percent, down from 4.81 percent Monday.
 
Sweden's Bonds
 Sweden offered its first floating- rate global issue. A global issue can be traded simultaneously in markets around the world.
The $1 billion issue, with Lehman Brothers and J. P. Morgan Securities as joint lead managers, will have an interest rate that will change every quarter. The rate will be the London interbank offered rate minus 9 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point. The first rate will be set just before settlement, which is Nov. 15. Based on yesterday's rate, the interest would be about 3.35 percent.
Bradley H. Jack, the head of the debt syndicate at Lehman Brothers, said the floating-rate market for debt issued by governments was not very active in the United States. So to make this deal attractive to American investors, it was done globally. This means that American investors can sell the bonds in Europe or Asia, where the markets for these issues are more active. About 25 percent of the deal was done in the United States, with 40 percent in Europe and 35 percent in Asia.
 
Corporate Bonds
 In the corporate market, the New York Telephone Company, a subsidiary of the Nynex Corporation, priced $400 million of debt securities yesterday, joining dozens of companies that have refinanced high-interest debt to take advantage of lower interest rates.
So far this year, American companies have sold more than $346.1 billion of bonds, mainly to refinance outstanding debt. American companies redeemed a record $74 billion in corporate bonds during the first eight months of this year, Fitch Investors Service Inc. said.
New York Telephone sold its bonds through two competitive pricings, with $150 million of 5 5/8 percent noncallable notes due in 2003 awarded to Morgan Stanley & Company and priced at 98.403 to yield 5.838 percent, or about 43 basis points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity.
The telephone company also sold $250 million of 6.70 percent debentures due in 2023 at 97.606 to yield 6.89 percent through Salomon Brothers. Underwriters said the 30-year debentures were callable in 20 years and rated A-2 by Moody's Investors Service and A by Standard & Poor's and Duff & Phelps.
 
Municipal Bonds
 In the municipal market, the City of Los Angeles sold $390.7 million of waste-water system revenue bonds through competitive bidding, awarding the issue to Morgan Stanley. The maximum yield was 5.37 percent for an issue due in 2021, followed by 5.32 percent for a bond due in 2019, 5.31 percent in 2017 and 5.20 percent in 2014. For shorter maturity serial bonds, yields ranged from 2.75 percent in 1994 to 4.10 percent in 1998, 4.75 percent in 2003, 5.2015 percent in 2008 and 5.25 percent in 2010.
Because the bonds are insured by the Financial Guaranty Insurance Company for interest and principle payments, they are rated triple-A by Moody's and Standard & Poor's.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Consumer Confidence Drop Causes Dollar to Weaken

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar generally weakened yesterday, hurt by news of falling consumer confidence in the economy. But it gained against the Canadian dollar after Canadians overwhelmingly voted the Conservatives out of power.
In late New York trading, the dollar fell to 108.35 Japanese yen, from 108.58 yen on Monday. It also slipped to 1.6805 marks, from 1.6855 marks. Still, the dollar rose to $1.3169 (Canadian), from $1.3123 (Canadian). 
 Gold prices were mostly lower. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for December delivery settled at $370.30 an ounce, off 20 cents from late Monday. The Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late bid for spot gold at $369.30 an ounce, unchanged from Monday.
 
 
Conference Board Report
 A report by the Conference Board business research group that showed that consumer faith in the economy fell this month set the tone for a selloff in the dollar, currency strategists said.
The monthly report said many American consumers expected their own finances to worsen in coming months. That was construed as a sign of economic weakness that would tend to make the dollar's value worth less.
"It looks like the dollar has run out of steam on its aggressive move" upward, said Stephen Flanagan, a vice president at Paine Webber in New York.
Gillie Augeri, a vice president and chief dealer at Shawmut Bank in Connecticut, said the decline partly reflected investor profit taking on the dollar's recent strength. "If you wanted to take profits, this was an excellent day to take them," he said. "You had an excellent excuse to sell."
The notable exception to the dollar's weakness was its surge against the Canadian dollar. On Monday, Canadian voters overwhelmingly voted out the governing Progressive Conservative Party in favor of the Liberal challengers. The uncertainty of how the Liberals may change Canada's economic policies was a major reason for the move out of Canadian dollars.
"When you think about it and you're an investor and looking at Canada at this point it must be kind of scary," Mr. Augeri said.
The British pound, meanwhile, rose to $1.4795 in New York, up from $1.4790 late Monday.

HEADLINE: Books of The Times;
The Minstrel Tradition: Not Just a Racist Relic

BYLINE: By MARGO JEFFERSON

 BODY:
Love and Theft
Blackface Minstrelsy and The American Working Class
By Eric Lott
314 pages. Oxford University Press. $24.95.
 Of course the recent blackface colboration between Ted Danson and Whoopi Goldberg at the Friars Club knocked Somalia off the front page: culture wars on the home front leave no civilians untouched. Entertainment and politics are both about power, and entertainment is a lot more fun.
All of which is at the heart of Eric Lott's terrifically smart and unexpectedly timely study of blackface minstrelsy. Rightly, he sees it as a crucial source for, and form of, popular culture. It was big business. It was a riot of ethnic and regional styles. And it was a psychic map that traced and exposed its fans' curiosity about the boundaries between races, classes and sexes. 
 Blackface minstrelsy was an American descendant of commedia dell'arte and an American cousin of English music hall. At its baldest, Mr. Lott writes, it was "an established 19th-century theatrical practice, principally of the urban North, in which white men caricatured blacks for sport and profit," assuring themselves of their racial superiority in the process. More complexly, these caricatures were stoked by fascination as well as derision. The gestures, voices, songs and dances borrowed from blacks or imagined to be black, he goes on, were "less a sign of absolute white power and control than of panic, anxiety, terror and pleasure." Imitation always implies admiration of some kind.
Put this all together and you have the form that gave rise to vaudeville and rock, Billy Crystal and Howard Stern, Al Jolson and Michael Bolton, "Saturday Night Live" and "In Living Color." And, given that its stars were all men, many of whom specialized in playing women (mainly viragos and wenches) onstage, it can be said that it paved the way for the mainstream cross-dressing of Milton Berle, Jonathan Winters, Flip Wilson and RuPaul (who, I'm told, attended the Goldberg roast dressed in a nun's habit).
Minstrelsy ruled the American stage during the 1830's, 40's and 50's, playing to an economically and socially distraught country. The industrial North and its wage labor was pitted against the agrarian South and its slave labor. Immigrants were at odds with those longtime citizens who considered themselves the "real" Americans. Economic changes sent women into the workplace and jobless men back to the home. The anti-slavery movement was gearing up, as was the struggle for women's suffrage. Minstrelsy's first audiences largely comprised working-class men who were at the center of these crises and felt at the mercy of them.
The first successful minstrel was a song-and-dance man named T. D. Rice, who, according to The Atlantic Monthly, was sauntering down a Cincinnati street one day in 1830 when he heard a voice singing: "Turn about an' wheel about an' do jis so/An' ebery time I turn about I jump Jim Crow." The voice belonged to "a Negro stage-driver lolling lazily on the box of his vehicle," and Rice was enchanted. "As a national or 'race' illustration, behind the footlights, might not 'Jim Crow' and a black face tickle the fancy of pit and circle . . .? Out of the suggestion leaped the determination."
Mr. Lott is at his best tracking the ways in which a "national illustration" -- a figure, like Uncle Sam, meant to embody a nation's identity -- became a "race illustration." Black Jim Crow, thanks to slavery, embodied a nation's identity crisis. The key to this transformation lies in the unruly power of comedy, as this telling quote from Freud makes clear: "The discovery that one has it in one's power to make someone else comic opens the way to an undreamt-of yield of comic pleasure and is the origin of a highly developed technique." And the power to make other people comic is linked to the power to make one's own fears and uncertainties comic.
Minstrelsy did just that. It began with black makeup and pseudo-plantation songs, dances and stories. It extended itself to mocking and ambivalent commentary on abolition, suffrage, political corruption, city life, country life and westward expansion. It made burlesque out of Shakespeare, ballet and the manners of the nouveau riche. It assimilated the passionate melodrama of "Uncle Tom's Cabin." It produced ballads, polkas, jigs and the syncopated predecessors of ragtime. And it accommodated, without removing the blackface, Irish, German, Italian and Yiddish accents.
The beat goes on, and minstrelsy puts on new masks with every generation. Mr. Lott cites Elvis Presley's now-legendary blackface turns without makeup: what would he make of Chuck Berry's forays into whiteface? (Mr. Berry sounds like a rockabilly redneck in "Johnny B. Goode" and a bemused sitcom father in "School Days.") Irish, Italian or Yiddish accents have been replaced by Puerto Rican, Polish and Russian ones.
And if rock videos are any indication, Asians are the new exotics of choice. They exude "Last Emperor" lust and mystery in Janet Jackson's "If I Was Your Girl." They exude technocratic lust and mystery in Madonna's "Rain." And, as the jazz musicians behind the black rappers in Digable Planets' "Cool Like Dat," they signify the ultra-hip, just as black jazz musicians used to signify it when they played behind white poets.
Mr. Lott is a professor of American studies at the University of Virginia, and he is so alert to minstrelsy's multiple impulses and strategies that I would like him to pursue them into the 20th century. But I want him to do so in a language that refuses to hide behind the mask of academic theory. Phrases like "the signifying chain linking working men to Bowery amusements" or the "inescapable synecdoches of plantation, factory and home" are deadly at this point. And the endless chain of quotes from like-minded scholars, reads, as Mr. Lott notes trenchantly in another context, "like a self-serving roll call of brand names." Every field, from American studies to journalism, has a standardized language. But it is up to scholars and writers to take the best of this and discard the rest. Mr. Lott has a mind of his own. Why not find a voice, too?

GRAPHIC: Photo: Tom Cogill (Oxford University Press)

SECTION: Section A; Page 22; Column 4; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 679 words

HEADLINE: China Makes Trade Pact for Americas Urgent;
Rethink the Agreement

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Giving in to the pie-in-sky hopes expressed by supporters of the North American Free Trade Agreement is not what I would expect of William Safire. "Laughter After Nafta" (column, Oct. 21) is no joking matter for tens of thousands of American workers on unemployment lines today or heading toward them in the future. 
 Mr. Safire's willingness to throw some people out of work now to help our kids get better jobs tomorrow is disingenuous. The trade agreement will not lose any jobs for economists or political columnists, but it will accelerate the outflow of factory and craft-worker jobs that have been sliding south to the sweatshops along our border with Mexico and eastward to Taiwan and other offshore factories.
What are the jobs that will benefit tomorrow's workers to which Mr. Safire alludes? Does he expect our unemployed and underemployed workers to wait two or three generations, or forever, for Mexican and other Southern Hemisphere laborers to turn into big ticket consumers?
As our economy is significantly driven by middle-income consumer purchases, the outflight of jobs to Mexico can only serve to shrink our pool of workers with discretionary income to spend. It's already happen
ing. What economic quid pro quo will Mexico supply, and how long will it take to generate?
With unemployment at record highs, particularly for minority youngsters, the United States neither today nor tomorrow can afford the price of providing improved income to Mexican workers and also to the run-away United States industries enjoying low-cost labor rates. We cannot reasonably expect all the next generation of Americans to be highly skilled technical-professional class employees. We can't expect all future workers to be college educated.
The United States will always need assembly, semiskilled and unskilled workers. How can we keep these jobs within our borders with the trade agreeement sending them south?
The trade agreement does not answer America's need for work opportunities today or tomorrow, and realistically, it certainly does not guarantee an evolving middle class south of the border. Mexico's population is one of the fastest growing in the world. And the free trade treaty will not provide jobs equal to this exponentially exploding birthrate.
Mr. Safire also envisions a North American marketplace 370 million strong to keep Europe and Asia from "ganging up." Predictions for a Europe as an implacable economic entity have been set on their ear lately by the unwillingness of members of the European Community to give up enough monetary sovereignty, cultural independence or border control to make such a competitive monolith an impending threat to our economy.
We have yet to see Asia evolve as a solidified economic force aimed at North America. The Asian countries are tough enough competitors separately. But the competition among China, Japan, Korea and a half-dozen smaller Pacific countries is too dynamic to foresee a unified economic community rising out of the East.
We will have to rethink the North American Free Trade Agreement and possibly redraft it to conform to the realities of a United States in need of more work. We certainly cannot think of our country as an island economy unto itself. But it is also adjusting to a hemorrhage of industrial jobs and is still without a program for keeping its workers employed. The trade agreement will not help solve these needs.
Things to do within our borders include tax credits to businesses, small and large, that invest in job-producing research and development, and create training programs, along with increased Federal aid for cities and states filtered through the private sector to help rebuild our crumbling infrastructure or prepare displaced workers for new opportunities. These and not a stronger Mexican economy are more likely solutions to cure the defects of our displaced manufacturing economy. Otherwise the last laugh heard will be Mexico's.
 
ALEC ANDREW PORTE
Minneapolis, Oct. 22, 1993
The writer is a marketing consultant.

HEADLINE: China Makes Trade Pact for Americas Urgent

 BODY:
To the Editor:
A few days ago I returned from a trip to China. I would like to send a few select members of the House of Representatives over there to take a look at what's happening. China's overwhelming infrastructure and industrial development ambitions are clearly beyond its pocketbook. Vast new projects, like Shanghai's huge new city complex of Pudong stand partly developed with most of the work being done by manual labor. 
 Meanwhile, the dilemma of Western investment institutions isn't whether or not to invest in China, but only how to get money into the market. Pending an equity market with some stability, and the introduction of acceptable legal protection for investors, most Western capital wishing to participate in China's growth will continue to flow to the markets of other countries in China's economic orbit. One day soon, probably with Hong Kong as the facade, China will appear a respectable recipient to these institutions.
The giant sucking sound heard by representatives opposed to the North American Free Trade Agreement comes not from south of our border; it comes from the East. Western capital is and will be used to build the industries that employ Chinese, not Western, workers. The primary beneficiaries of the Chinese worker's increased spending power will not be the West, but other Asian countries.
How shortsighted the House will be if it does not approve the North American Free Trade Agreement. We must get on with building one large, powerful North and South American industrial and economic bloc in which our capital is invested to improve Western living conditions. The Chinese will not buy United States cars; Mexicans do.
 
AUDREY A. CURTIS
Westport, Conn., Oct. 21, 1993

HEADLINE: Redrawing the Map in Canada

 BODY:
The Liberal Party landslide in the Canadian elections was more like an avalanche. The Progressive Conservatives, who ruled for the past nine years, took the worst pasting ever for a governing party; they lost 151 seats and will have only 2 in the new Parliament. Meanwhile, two new regional parties scored huge gains. It's a new political era for America's biggest trading partner and closest ally.
Jean Chretien, the Liberals' leader who now becomes prime minister, is a career politician, well known by his service in nine cabinet posts and comfortably familiar to the hierarchy of U.S. power and politics. He's no Pierre Trudeau -- the last Liberal Prime Minister, outspoken and flamboyant. But like Mr. Trudeau, he hails from Quebec and is firmly opposed to Quebec separatism. 
 The Liberals' sweep -- they won 30 more than half of the 295 seats -- was striking in itself, but no more so than the sudden emergence of two parties with no nationwide following. All three parties' gains could be traced in large measure to the overwhelming unpopularity of former Prime Minister Brian Mulroney's Conservatives.
Mr. Mulroney was scraping bottom in public opinion polls when he quit last spring. The principal factors in his collapse were Canada's weak economy, unpopular taxes and job losses attributed to the free-trade pact he made with Washington.
Mr. Chretien makes a point of saying he has no interest in going fishing with the U.S. President, as Mr. Mulroney did with President Bush, lest he end up as the fish. He also talks broadly of wanting better terms for Canada in its free-trade agreements with the U.S. and Mexico. It remains to be seen what he means, and how much of that talk was campaign rhetoric. But his principal pledge was to create jobs with a quick dose of public works; given Canada's budget deficit, that will be difficult.
The two regional parties can't outvote him in Parliament, but will pose a constant reminder of the country's divisions. Most Liberal seats are in the East. The three-year-old Bloc Quebecois exists only in Quebec, mainly to fight for sovereignty. The Reform Party, founded six years ago, is a Western reaction to domination by Ontario and Quebec; more conservative than the Conservatives, it targets government spending and immigrants.
The Bloc Quebecois will be the "official opposition" in the new Parliament, having placed second with 54 seats; the Reform Party got 52. Symbolically, the Bloc's leader, Lucien Bouchard, declares his commitment to separation by saying he won't move to the Ottawa mansion provided for the head of the opposition.
But substantively, Mr. Bouchard said on election night that his party was ready to "tackle the most urgent tasks of Canada," namely economic revival. "Our goal is not to rend the fabric" of Canada's institutions, he said -- in English.
Canada's voters have made one thing clear: They want no more of the Conservatives for now. But by splitting their support between East and West, English and French, they have mapped out a fractious political landscape.

CORRECTION-DATE: October 29, 1993, Friday

 CORRECTION:
Wednesday's editorial on the Canadian elections misidentified the last Prime Minister from the Liberal Party. He was John Turner, who held the office for less than 11 weeks in 1984, not Pierre Trudeau.
