HEADLINE: U.S. CANCELS A PLAN TO BEGIN SANCTIONS AFTER JAPAN ACTS

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration today canceled plans to impose trade sanctions next Monday against Japan after Tokyo agreed to open its public sector construction market to international competition.
Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, announced this morning that the Administration would not proceed with the sanctions, at least for now, because the Japanese Government had promised to eliminate the practice of restricting the bidding on construction contracts to a few companies. The sanctions would have barred Japanese companies from bidding on some Federal construction projects. 
 The century-old Japanese restrictions have long been a sore point with American construction companies. Irritation over them has intensified in the last decade, as Japan embarked on an extensive program to build better roads, airports and other public works. Ending the restrictions would eliminate a persistent source of friction between the two countries.
 
A 'Historic' Move
 "This move today by the Japanese Government is welcome, it is important, it is significant, and it's historic," Mr. Kantor said.
The Japanese plan to end restrictions had only a few details today. Mr. Kantor said the Administration was still prepared to impose sanctions if the Japanese Government did not provide further details of its plan and carry it out by Jan. 20. But he played down this possibility, saying that the Japanese plan, "indicates for the first time that the Government of Japan is determined to bring about important reforms in its public sector construction market, including improved access for all foreign firms."
The Japanese decision to change the Government contracting procedures is more the result of domestic political changes in Japan than any response to the threat of American sanctions, said Seiichiro Noboru, the top economics official at the Japanese Embassy here.
Bribery of Japanese Government officials by local construction companies contributed to the downfall of the Liberal Democratic Party this summer and its replacement by a coalition of seven parties championing deregulation and other changes. Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa has set up a special council of senior politicians to draft by late December a detailed overhaul of Government construction contracting practices.
By moving the American deadline to January, Mr. Kantor accommodated the Japanese schedule.
Tokyo has agreed to provide further details at next month's meeting in Seattle, where President Clinton is scheduled to discuss trade and investment issues with Mr. Hosokawa and a dozen other heads of state from countries with Pacific Ocean coastlines, Mr. Kantor said.
The Japanese plan accepted by Mr. Kantor today also called for Tokyo to bar bids by companies convicted of bribery, improve enforcement of its anti-monopoly law and establish objective, published standards for bidding and contracting procedures. All of these steps could limit the discretion of the powerful bureaucrats at the Japanese Construction Ministry, who have successfully resisted previous American efforts to open the Japanese construction market.
 
Senator Backs Plan
 Senator Frank H. Murkowski, the Alaska Republican who has pushed successive administrations for seven years to open the Japanese construction market, said today that the Japanese plan was vague in some places but still ambitious enough to justify the postponement of sanctions. "I think they've accomplished something," he said.
Mr. Murkowski said his concerns centered on the Japanese pledge to apply the changes to all contracts above a certain value, without specifying a value. The value must be set low enough to cover contracts for American architectural and engineering companies, and not just big contracts that include a lot of earthmoving and other work performed locally in Japan, the Senator said.
Charles E. Hawkins, a senior vice president for Associated Builders and Contractors, an American industry group based in Washington, said he was cautiously optimistic that the Japanese offer would make a difference, but wanted to see the details. A Japanese agreement in the late 1980's to open the bidding for the construction of the Kansai International Airport at Osaka initially seemed like a big concession to the United States, but the fine print of that deal later prevented American companies from winning more than a tiny fraction of the contracts for the project, he said.
American companies are interested in Japan because, "you look around the world and it's the one area where there's a lot of construction going on," said Kenneth H. Fraelich, the executive vice president of marketing and strategic business development at AEG Westinghouse Transportation Systems Inc., which tried unsuccessfully to sell a mass-transit system to the Kansai airport project.
"Our business there we couldn't double or triple right now because it's zero," he said, adding that the latest Japanese offer, "is a very encouraging announcement if they do what they say."
 
Size of Problem Debated
 For years, the United States and Japan have been unable to agree even on the size of the problem. According to Japanese Embassy figures, American companies won $330 million of public sector contracts in Japan last year, while Japanese companies won $325 million in contracts in the United States. But Commerce Department figures show that American companies won only $189 million of a $700 billion Japanese market last year, while Japanese companies took $1.5 billion of the $425 billion American market.
Some American construction industry executives contend that even the Commerce Department figures understate the disparity because Japanese companies have bought large stakes in many American construction businesses, while American companies have had trouble investing in their Japanese rivals.

HEADLINE: Puerto Rico Takes Lead With School Vouchers, And Feels the Arrows

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN JUAN, P.R., Oct. 26

 BODY:
As the rest of the nation continues to debate using school vouchers, Puerto Rico is plunging ahead with a month-old experimental voucher program that has already provoked threats of an islandwide teachers' strike as early as next week.
The legislation, passed on Sept. 3, is intended to "expand the options of parents and students with regard to the selection of schools," said Education Secretary Jose Arsenio Torres, and to "offer economic incentives to public schools to improve their course offerings." 
 Under the plan, parents who participate receive a government credit of $1,500 per child. They can then transfer the credit to the public or private school of their choice.
"We have taken this radical step because we have a sick school system," Mr. Torres said in an interview here this morning. "Our costs have been getting higher and higher, registration has been dropping, the dropout rate has been climbing and the achievement level falling. The people want change, and we are giving it to them."
 
Opposition From Teachers
 But the plan has met with intense resistance from three unions representing the 46,000 teachers in the commonwealth. The teachers are demanding the dismissal of Mr. Torres and a halt to what they call the "privatization" of public education. Two of the unions have authorized a strike and the third has scheduled a strike vote for next Saturday; if it passes, as seems likely, union leaders say a strike could begin Nov. 1.
"Every dollar spent on vouchers is a dollar taken away from the public schools," said Jose Eligio Velez, president of the Teachers' Association of Puerto Rico, which with more than 27,000 members is the largest of the three unions. "There have never been enough dollars to attend the needs of the public schools, and this will only drain even further what is available."
While Puerto Rico has more than doubled its spending on education in the last decade, to $1.5 billion, the commonwealth, which has a population of 3.6 million, still spends only $1,987 per pupil, compared with a mainland average of $5,245.
Several states are also considering school voucher programs, which were supported by the Reagan and Bush Administrations, and voters in California will decide next week whether to use such a system there. The Clinton Administration is opposed to voucher programs.
 
$1,500 Grants Available
 Under the Puerto Rican plan, qualified students from second grade through high school are to receive a $1,500 grant at the start of each school year, a significant sum where the annual per capita income is $6,500, less than half that of the states. The grants can be used at any public or private school willing to enroll them. An initial fund of $10 million was established for the current school year, but that amount will expand to $30 million by 1997, when the commonwealth's Legislature is scheduled to review the program.
Because the voucher plan became law just days before classes began, only 1,716 of the island's more than 650,000 students have thus far used vouchers to change schools. According to commonwealth statistics, 1,121 students have transferred from one public school to another, 302 have moved from public schools to private schools and 293 have left private schools to enroll in public schools.
Leaders of the teachers' unions portray the voucher legislation, sponsored by Gov. Pedro Rossello, as beneficial only to the wealthy, because the poor are presumed to be not able to afford private school tuition. But Mr. Torres and other supporters of the program point to the movement of students from private to public schools, and within the public school system, as proof that the plan has broader appeal.
"There is no reason to fear a great exodus or a privatization of the schools," said the Rev. Jose A. Basols, outgoing president of the Puerto Rico Association of Private Education and director of Colegio Ponceno, one of the best-known private schools on the island. "They are battling ghosts."
 
School-Based Management
 Only families with an income of less than $18,000 a year are eligible to make use of the vouchers. The cutoff will exclude many families that send their children to private schools, but will include a vast majority of families with students in public schools. In addition, students cannot claim a voucher if they transfer from one private school to another, and no more than 50 percent of the students enrolled at any private school can be voucher recipients.
The government's voucher program is central to a broader and even more controversial educational decentralization plan intended to install school-based management, now in place in some school districts on the mainland.
Of Puerto Rico's 1,650 public schools, 40 are being run by teacher-parent councils under legislation passed last June, with 50 more designated to adopt the system in January and the rest scheduled to follow over the next five years.
The three main teachers' unions oppose that change, too. "We do not believe that the councils are prepared or qualified to evaluate or select teachers," said Renan Soto, president of the Teachers' Federation of Puerto Rico. "We are also worried about the powers the councils will have in a country that is as highly politicized as ours."
 
Union Interests Cited
 But supporters of the voucher and community school programs say the unions are thinking not of the welfare of students but of their political muscle. "The unions see this as a threat to their interests and do not want to lose their power," Father Basols said. "They don't understand that this is a great opportunity to improve the schools."
The National Education Association has sent 11 organizers here to help its local affiliate, the Teachers Association of Puerto Rico, in organizing a strike and explaining the teachers' cause to the public. The national group has also authorized $100,000 for assistance to teachers here, including radio advertisements and leaflets, and has said it will grant interest-free loans of $500 to members who join a strike.
Teachers' unions here have also taken the issue to court, contending that the law violates both the Puerto Rico Constitution and a 1990 statute governing the education system. That law makes it illegal to "use public funds or property to sustain schools and educational institutions that are not of the state."
But Justice Secretary Pedro Pierluisi testified recently that "research into both local and Federal law showed there were no constitutional obstacles" to the program. He and other state officials maintain that because the vouchers are issued to the families of students, not to the schools they attend, the prohibition does not apply.
 
Praise From a Parent
 At the 40 schools that have already been turned over to community control, like the Dr. Francisco Hernandez Gaetan Elementary School here, a public school, parents and teachers say they need a voucher program if they are to succeed. While some teachers at some community schools elsewhere have complained of a heavier workload with no pay increase, parents and teachers here said vouchers are a way to strengthen their neighborhood school
"I'm going to stay here no matter what happens," said Miguel Casilla Rivera, a sanitation worker whose four children attend the school. "I like what the teachers are doing, I like having a voice in the decisions, and my children feel at home here. So I see no reason to go somewhere else" once he obtains vouchers.
The school is already making changes to be more competitive. Its teacher-parent council will offer free after-school courses in music and art, and it hopes to organize a computer education course with money raised from local businesses.
"We believe the voucher program is going to benefit us because we will be able to offer more services," said the school's principal, Luz Hernandez. "Our parents are committed to this school, so we think we will have more money to spend on books and equipment and materials."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Teachers opposed to the new school voucher plan in Puerto Rico demonstrating last week outside the Education Department in San Juan. (Cindy Karp for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: CLINTON'S HEALTH PLAN: The Overview;
CONGRESS IS GIVEN CLINTON PROPOSAL FOR HEALTH CARE

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 27

 BODY:
After nine months of brainstorming and politicking, President Clinton delivered to Congress today a 240,000-word proposal for universal health insurance. It represents the most complex, detailed legislative blueprint devised by any President.
The document provides scores of details that were not available in White House documents or speeches by Administration officials over the last nine months. 
 The final legislative proposal revises earlier versions of the President's package, in an effort to control costs and to satisfy the hundreds of political constituencies that are already doing battle over the issue, on which Mr. Clinton has staked his Presidency.
 
Ready to Compromise
 In the Capitol, under the gaze of statues of figures from America's past, Mr. Clinton declared that the United States was "choking on a health care system that is not working." He and his wife, Hillary, summoned Congress to join them in a historic mission to guarantee comprehensive health insurance coverage for all Americans.
His voice rising and his fists pumping, Mr. Clinton demanded that Congress pass a bill by the end of next year. He offered to compromise on most matters, saying, "I want to reiterate what I have said so many times: I have no pride of authorship, nor do I wish this to be a partisan endeavor or victory." But he also said, "When it is over, we must have achieved comprehensive health care security for all Americans, or the endeavor will not have been worth the effort."
Republicans and Democrats alike predict that Congress will make substantial changes in the health care system next year. But members of both parties said today that Mr. Clinton's proposal would be substantially revised on Capitol Hill and that the legislation ultimately enacted would be more modest.
 
Signaling Flexibility
 Like her husband, Mrs. Clinton signaled flexibility, a willingness to jettison almost any element of the White House plan except the goal of providing a comprehensive package of health benefits to all Americans. "We have literally no pride of authorship on many of the details and technical aspects" of the bill, she said.
Mrs. Clinton asked for bipartisan cooperation. In that spirit, her husband praised President Richard M. Nixon as well as Presidents Franklin D. Roosevelt and Harry S. Truman for trying to provide health insurance coverage for more people.
Mrs. Clinton told Congress today, "This will be an opportunity for all of us to work together, to go beyond politics as usual, to make it clear to the American people that this President and this Congress hear them and are committed to solving their problems in a very real way."
But at the ceremony at the Capitol the Republican leaders of both houses, Representative Robert H. Michel of Illinois and Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, warned that the legislative process would be difficult.
"There are substantive and profound policy differences" between the President and Republicans, Mr. Michel said. "The real differences cannot be glossed over," he added, asserting that Mr. Clinton would take the nation "on an uncharted course of government-run medicine."
Mr. Dole said, "Turning over one-seventh of our economy to the United States Government is an idea that has many Americans -- Republicans and Democrats -- very concerned."
Also attending the ceremony was Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House Democratic leader, who has spent much of his career trying to control health costs. He described the Clinton plan as the "most complete work product that I have ever seen, and I think anybody here has ever seen" from a President.
On the other hand, Representative Charles W. Stenholm, a conservative Democrat from Texas, said later, "It's a little bit more expensive and a little more government than the American people can get excited about."
 
'It Seems Bewildering'
 Mr. Clinton's vision of health care overhaul, blending free-market competition with Federal regulation, has always sounded a bit complicated. People reading the full text of his proposal today were left with a bewildering sense of the immense complexity of the proposal.
Anticipating this concern, Mr. Clinton said, "When we debate something that the Administration recommends or something some of you recommend, and it seems bewildering in its complexity, I ask that it be compared against what we have now, because none of us could devise a system more complex, more burdensome, more administratively costly than the one we have now."
Dozens of details, including these, emerged from the text of Mr. Clinton's proposed bill, which will not be formally introduced in Congress for several days:
*Abortion would be covered like other services deemed medically necessary and appropriate. But the proposed legislation includes a "conscience clause," stating that doctors and hospitals need not perform procedures to which they object because of religious belief or moral conviction.
*Health insurance purchasing groups known as regional health alliances would be responsible for collecting all the premiums owed by consumers and businesses. In addition, states would have to insure that the amounts are indeed paid. But the bill does not say how this goal would be achieved, or who would be financially responsible if the payments fell short.
*The Federal Government would put intense pressure on states to set up alliances guaranteeing health coverage for all state residents by Jan. 1, 1998. If a state did not meet that deadline, the Secretary of Health and Human Services could withhold Federal money and take direct action to set up and operate the alliances.
*A new agency, the National Health Board, would set a health budget for the nation and would regulate most private health insurance premiums. There would be "no administrative or judicial review of any determination" by the board on these questions.
*Starting in 2003, workers would owe Federal income tax on any employer-provided health benefits that exceed the standard package of benefits defined by Federal law. Currently, health benefits are not counted as income.
*The Federal Government would review the prices charged for new drugs that represent a significant advance over existing drugs, and it would publish its findings. Elderly and disabled people on Medicare would get a new benefit covering the cost of prescription drugs. To qualify for this program, drug makers would have to give the Government a discount of at least 17 percent off the average retail price of their old drugs.
 
Regional Alliances
 The amount of discounts on new drugs would be subject to negotiation with the Government. Federal officials could deny Medicare coverage for a new drug if the Government and the manufacturer could not agree on the discounts.
Under the Clinton plan, most Americans would get health insurance coverage through the regional alliances. A company with more than 5,000 full-time employees could operate its own health insurance program outside the alliances. People working at company headquarters would be in the corporate health plan.
Employees of a big company working in another state at an office with fewer than 100 employees could join the local alliance in that state.
There has been much debate about the role of these alliances, which under Mr. Clinton's proposal could be either private not-for-profit corporations or state government agencies. The alliances could set fee schedules for doctors who charge a separate fee for each service performed.
In a last-minute adjustment to placate doctors, the White House decided that physicians may conduct "collective negotiations" with the regional alliances, even though Federal antitrust laws would ordinarily prohibit such collective action to set fees.
Doctors said they needed this exemption from the antitrust laws to balance the economic power of the alliances. A typical alliance would be buying health care for hundreds of thousands or millions of consumers.
 
Creating New Agencies
 The Administration assumes that most Americans will enroll in health maintenance organizations or similar networks of doctors and hospitals, which provide comprehensive coverage in return for premiums set in advance. Under the Clinton proposal, all health plans, including H.M.O.'s, would have to give consumers an opportunity to use doctors who did not participate in the plan. Consumers would generally have to pay more if they used a doctor or a hospital outside the network.
Under Mr. Clinton's proposal, consumers who believe they have been improperly denied medical services or payments could file a protest with a "complaint review office." Each state would have to establish such an office. A consumer dissatisfied with the state's decision could appeal to a new Federal agency, the Federal Health Plan Review Board, and from there to a Federal appeals court and to the Supreme Court.
This scheme is intended to limit the number of claims getting into Federal court. But some lawyers predict that there will be a flood of lawsuits by people trying to enforce the new right to health care envisioned by Mr. Clinton.
The President made changes in his proposal to attract support from conservative Democrats and Republicans in Congress. But some changes annoyed liberal Democrats.
Some Democrats were upset over a provision to limit Federal spending on subsidies for low-income workers. "I think it undermines the credibility of the Administration's promise of universal coverage, insurance that will always be there, because it won't be there if they run out of money," Representative Henry A. Waxman, Democrat of California, said.
Mr. Waxman heads the Energy and Commerce Subcommittee on Health and is the architect of a half-dozen laws that expanded Medicaid to serve millions of pregnant women and young children in the last decade.
 
Backing From Catholic Group
 The American College of Physicians, the American Academy of Family Physicians and the Catholic Health Association, representing Roman Catholic hospitals, hailed the President's call for universal health coverage.
But drug makers and biotechnology companies asserted that the Clinton plan would discourage investment in research to find cures for AIDS, cancer and other deadly diseases.
Lisa J. Raines, vice president of the Genzyme Corporation, said tonight: "We are deeply disappointed that, after dozens of meetings, members of the Administration still do not understand that Federal review of new drug prices would have a devastating impact on the biotechnology industry. It's tantamount to price control. We have found that Congress has a deeper understanding of this issue."
 
Arriving at Creating a Consensus
 Mr. Clinton said his proposal would provide much more coverage of preventive services than is usually found in private health insurance plans. It would, for example, pay for immunizations, Pap smears, cholesterol screening, mammograms, blood tests and periodic medical examinations, all according to a schedule prescribed by the Government.
The White House said tonight that it had lined up 31 senators and 43 House members to co-sponsor the President's plan. But the list includes critics like Mr. Waxman and Representative Pete Stark, Democrat of California, who want to make major changes in the Clinton proposal.
While many lawmakers disagree with specific details of the President's proposal, Mr. Clinton does appear to have forged a consensus in favor of action on this issue.
"Partial or incremental approaches are no longer options," said John E. Curley Jr., president of the Catholic Health Association. "Because of President Clinton's leadership, health care reform will now be seriously debated in the public policy arena for the first time in more than a decade."

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Clinton delivering his Health Security Plan to Congress as his wife, Hillary, looked on. (Agence France-Presse) (pg. A24)
 
Charts: "How Much, How Soon"
 The Clinton health care plan lays out a rought timetable, subject to delays in passage by Congress.
 
1994: The Administration hopes Congress will pass the plan in spring or summer; a more cautious assessment is that Congress will not act until fall.
 
1995-1997: Transitional period during which states would establish health care programs for their citizens.
 
Jan. 1, 1998: Deadline by which all states must have their plans approved and all Americans - except illegal aliens - would be guaranteed health coverage.
 
2001: Mental health and dental benefits would be expanded.
 
"How the Plan Has Changed"
In its broad outlines, President Clinton's health care plan remains unchanged from the version he unveiled in a speech to Congress on Sept. 22. But it is a plan of daunting complexity, and many details have been revised since then in an effortto reduce opposition.
 
SUMMARY
 
UNIVERSAL COVERAGE
 
Coverage for all Americans, regardless of medical or employment status.
 
A guaranteed package of benefits including free preventive care.
 
A choice of three kinds of health plans: traditional fee-for-service, Health Maintenance Organizations ad plans that combine the two. Medicaid recipients will receive the standard package.
 
REVISIONS
 
Expected date of universal coverage delayed by a year, to Jan. 1, 1988.
 
More generous coverage of mamograms and of dental care for children.
 
Extra services for children now in Medicaid.
 
Federal Trade Commission is given sweeping new powers to regulate insurerss.
 
All health plans, including H.M.O.'s, must offer patients the option to seek care from any physician, even if at additional cost.
 
HEALTH ALLIANCES
 
Insurance would be administered through pools, called health alliances, meant to concentrate the purchasing power of consumers.
 
Generally there will be one alliance for each state or region; in addition, companies with more than 5,000 employees will have the option of creating their own corporate alliances.
 
The alliances will negotiate with health providers and offer consumers a choice of plans, along with information on their cost and quality.
 
REVISIONS
 
Alliances cannot limit the number of fee-for-service plans; they may reject health plans only for failure to meet state standards of quality and care or if their budgets exceed the average of others in the area by 20 percent.
 
Reduces administrative obstacles for any state that wants to create a single-payer system.
 
COST OF COVERAGE
 
Businesses would pay at least 80 percent of the cost of premiums for the employees. Employees would pay the remainder, with the cost varying according to how expensive a plan they choose.
 
Out of pocket expenses would be higher for those choose not to join an H.M.O.
 
Cost to small businesses and to poor individuals would be subsidized. Caps would limit the cost for business, ranging from 3.5 percent for small companies to 7.9 percent for larger ones.
 
REVISIONS
 
The amount low-income workers would have to pay for premiums would be capped at 3.9 percent of income. And businesses with up to 75 workers would be eligible for subsidies. But an overall cap would be placed on the combined subsidies for both.
 
Companies that benefit from Government subsidies for premiums for early retirees will be asked to rebate some of the savings.
 
COST CONTROL
 
Insurance premiums would be limited, to bring increase in health costs in line with general inflation rate over five years.
 
A national health board would set national and regional budgets.
 
REVISIONS
 
National health board to be part of the executive branch, not independent.
 
Estimate of Federal savings reduced to $60 billion from $91 billion

HEADLINE: Dinkins Uplift, Giuliani Grit: 2 Advertising Schools Battle

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT

 BODY:
David N. Dinkins opened his television advertising campaign with a "Heartbeat of America"-style commercial complete with rousing music. Rudolph W. Giuliani began with a grainy, low-key ad that looked as if it had absorbed its grittiness from the streets of New York.
Next, the Dinkins campaign broadcast advertisements extolling the Mayor's accomplishments in warm, lofty images. The Giuliani campaign came back with ads featuring ordinary people.
 
Clash Between Ad Styles
 Then Mr. Dinkins attacked with negative ads, accusing Mr. Giuliani of fighting against "everything we stand for." The Giuliani campaign countered with the candidate's wife charging the Mayor with race-baiting. 
 The back and forth may seem to be spontaneous -- the product of this particular mayoral race at this particular time -- but in an important sense it has little to do with the candidates involved, or even with the city they are seeking to lead. Rather, it is a clash between two different styles of political advertising: that favored by Mr. Dinkins's consultants, David Doak and Bob Shrum, and that favored by Mr. Giuliani's consultant, David Garth.
In campaign after campaign, Mr. Doak and Mr. Shrum, who work only for Democratic candidates, and Mr. Garth, who has worked for candidates of both parties, have refined their styles so that now it is possible to describe an ad -- as their competitors often do -- as "characteristic Doak and Shrum" or "typical David Garth."
The Doak and Shrum style is characterized on the one hand by lush, rhetorically rich positive ads and scathing negatives. Mr. Garth's ads are typified by a low-budget, "5 o'Clock News" look and by lots of written information. And in the New York City mayoral campaign, both groups of consultants have run campaigns that are as true to their own styles as they are to the candidates they represent.
Indeed, comparing the consultants' advertisements for the mayoral campaign with advertisements they did for other candidates, it is possible to find not only broad patterns, but also specific scenes and images repeated from one campaign to the next.
In 1990, for example, Mr. Doak and Mr. Shrum ran the re-election campaign for Gov. Robert P. Casey of Pennsylvania. The opening campaign ad showed Governor Casey taking the oath of office, then leading a meeting at a conference table.
 
Improvisations on a Theme
 Similarly, the advertisement that began Mr. Dinkins's re-election campaign opened with the Mayor taking the oath of office, then leading a meeting at a conference table.
"He intervened to save Sharon Steel, brought in Ford Electronics and the new J & L structural plant," the narrator said in the Casey ad.
"He's balanced four budgets, cut waste and, in a recession, saved jobs by persuading companies like CBS and Prudential to stay in New York City," the narrator said in the Dinkins ad.
Like improvisations on a theme, sometimes a phrase from one campaign reappears in a slightly modified form in another. In 1987, for instance, Mr. Doak and Mr. Shrum ran the media campaign for Mayor Art Agnos of San Francisco. Mr. Agnos's mailings used the slogan "One City, One Future, One Message." This year, Mr. Dinkins's advertisements carry the tag line "One City, One Future."
Mr. Garth has borrowed even more heavily from his previous campaigns in his ads for Mr. Giuliani.
 
Like Specter, Like Giuliani
 Last year, for instance, Mr. Garth ran the re-election campaign for Senator Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania. A series of ads showed ordinary Pennsylvanians -- veterans, Navy yard workers and retirees -- talking about how the Senator had helped them out. As they spoke, various facts and statistics appeared on the screen. Most of Mr. Giuliani's ads have featured ordinary New Yorkers -- a baker, a restaurant worker, a mother -- bemoaning the sad state of the city while damning figures scroll across the screen.
When Mr. Specter was attacked on television by his opponent, Lynn H. Yeakel, his campaign answered with an ad in which Teresa Heinz, the widow of Senator John Heinz, chastised her for dirty campaigning. When Mr. Guiliani was attacked by the Mayor, his campaign responded with an ad featuring his wife, Donna Hanover Giuliani, chastising the Mayor for the same thing.
Stylistically, it would be hard to find two consulting firms that run more dissimilar campaigns than Doak, Shrum, Harris, Carrier, Devine, based in Washington, and the Garth Group, based in Manhattan.
Ads by Mr. Doak and Mr. Shrum typically have what are known in the business as high production values. They are shot on film, even though it is more expensive than video; this gives them a rich, warm look. And they are drenched in atmospherics -- music, reverberating voices, Kennedy-esque oratory.
 
Not Hesitant About Attacking
 "People like to be optimistic," Mr. Doak said about the style. "The stuff has to look good, especially when you're dealing with your candidate."
At the same time, Mr. Doak and Mr. Shrum are not at all hesitant about using negative ads, and have created several advertisements that stand out for their ferocity. These include one used against Ann Richards in the Texas gubernatorial primary that implied that she had used drugs while an elected official.
In contrast, Mr. Garth's ad campaigns invariably have a newsy feel. They are shot on videotape, which gives them a flat look. They always feature real people and lots of text on the screen. Mr. Garth refused to discuss his advertising style, but people who have worked with him say he feels that the writing gives viewers a sense that the ads have substance.
Mr. Garth, too, has produced some famous negative ads, including one for Ed Koch's gubernatorial campaign that asked viewers to name one thing Mario M. Cuomo had done as Lieutenant Governor while a clock ticked menacingly in the background. Some of his ads for Mr. Giuliani have been scathing as well, particularly one that attacked Mr. Dinkins for mishandling everything from his income taxes to the Crown Heights disturbances. But Mr. Garth is not known as a particularly effective negative campaigner, and he generally relies on more informational, statistics-crammed ads.
Among political consultants of both parties there seems to be a general sense that Mr. Doak and Mr. Shrum's style, combining stirring positive ads with threatening negative ones, has served the Mayor well. But several consultants questioned whether Mr. Garth's style is appropriate for Mr. Giuliani's political needs.
"Garth has expended a lot of capital getting you to like Rudy, and that hurt," said Stuart Stevens, a Republican consultant. "It's not something Garth is good at." Some consultants suggested that Mr. Garth had made a mistake by using video, which has a cool, distant look, to try to make Mr. Guiliani seem warm. His latest ad features Mr. Giuliani's mother, Helen, praising her son.

Giuliani by David Garth, who used ordinary people and text to deliver messages on the issues. (pg. B8)

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Utility Bonds Hit by Rating Threat

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Utility bonds took a beating yesterday after the Standard & Poor's Corporation announced that several companies were facing a credit rating downgrading and that the outlook for a third of the industry was being switched from stable to negative.
The announcement by S.& P. threatened to push the bonds of some electric companies from investment grade status into noninvestment grade, or junk bond, status. And the selling was especially focused on companies that are already at the bottom of the investment grade rankings. 
 Many money managers cannot hold old bonds that are below investment grade, so a lot of the selling was done to get rid of the bonds before a possible rating downgrade, said Geoffery Kurinsky, a senior vice president at Massachusetts Financial Services, a money manager in Boston. He said some of the companies, like the Cleveland Electric Illuminating Company, were already priced as if they had been lowered to junk bond status.
 
 
Long Island Lighting
 The bonds of the Long Island Lighting Company have been falling for several weeks, but they dropped even further yesterday. The Long Island utility was in the group that had its outlook changed from stable to negative and has a triple B rating, just a notch above the bottom of the investment grade category.
For example, the price of Lilco's 7.125 percent bond due June 1, 2005, was off by about three-quarters of a point. The spread between the yield on the Lilco bond and that of comparable Treasury securities, a closely watched measure of performance, widened to about 130 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, from about 105 basis points several weeks ago and about 120 basis points on Tuesday, Mr. Kurinsky said.
The bonds of Cleveland Electric dropped even more sharply, with the price of the 9 percent bond due in July 2023 off about three full points. The spread between the yield on the Cleveland Electric bond and the comparable Treasury bond jumped about 30 to 220 basis points. The Cleveland Electric bond has a triple B-minus rating, which is the bottom of the investment grade category; the company was one of those put on credit watch with the probability that it will be downgraded after further review.
Curtis Moulton, an S.& P. industry analyst who did the study, said, "We see the business risk for the industry increasing, and because of that the rating outlook for a lot of companies has changed."
He said the main reason for the change in the outlook was growing competitive pressures. But the companies also face slow earnings growth, environmental cost pressures and the costs of operating or decommissioning nuclear plants.
 
 
Treasury Market
 Treasury prices fell yesterday as traders and investors awaited today's release of the first report on the pace of economic growth in the third quarter.
The Commerce Department's data on the gross domestic product in the three months ended Sept. 30 will begin to answer questions about how much faster the economy is growing in the second half of the year after an anemic pace of 1.3 percent for the first six months.
The recent selloff in the market, which has pushed the yield on the 30-year bond back to 6 percent, is a reflection of fears that the economy will be strong enough to put upward pressure on consumer prices. Rising inflation is the nemesis of the bond market because it erodes the fixed rates of return from bonds and notes.
 The average forecast for the G.D.P., according to Market News Service, is 2.8 percent. Most economists seem to agree that consumer spending will be in the 4 percent range. The disputes that make the range of forecasts run from around 2 percent to 3.5 percent are over exports, inventories, Government spending and capital spending.
But even as this number is released, the focus will shift to the status of the economy in the current fourth quarter, where economists generally feel that automobile production and sales are helping push up growth a little more, to an annual rate of around 4 percent, or even higher. The strong 10-day automobile sales reported earlier this week have reinforced that view.
In trading yesterday, the price of the 30-year bond was down 8/32 of a point as the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 6 percent from 5.98 percent Tuesday.
The Commerce Department report that orders for durable goods, like cars, appliances, computers, airplanes and military equipment, rose seven-tenths of 1 percent in September, contributed to some of the selling. The increase was more than the average forecast of two-tenths of 1 percent expected on Wall Street.
 
 
Military Spending
 Excluding military industry and commercial aircraft orders, everything else was up. But excluding these two categories can present a skewed picture of the economy. The Government cutback in military spending is one of the major drags on the economy right now. And the aircraft industry is one of the country's major export industries.
The market seemed to overlook the fact that the backlog of unfilled durable-goods orders continued to decline, falling 1 percent. Most economists say there will not be sustainable gains in manufacturing until that backlog begins to grow, so the decline could indicate that the pace of growth cannot pick up that much in the near future.
Although the Treasury auction of $11 billion of five-year notes went well, it did not give the market a boost. The high yield in the single-price auction was 4.81 percent, down from the 4.83 percent last month. But in late trading in the when-issued market, the yield had popped up to 4.84 percent, reflecting the souring of sentiment in the late afternoon.

HEADLINE: Dow Drops 7.83 Points, Closing at 3,664.66

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY

 BODY:
The economic news was encouraging yesterday, but investors apparently needed a little more convincing. They sent confused signals in a fragmented stock market, bidding up small companies while shunning some industrial powerhouses that might be expected to profit from a spurt in the recovery.
Despite the Government's announcement that September durable- goods orders rose, blue-chip stocks in the Dow Jones industrial average gave up more of the gains of Monday, when the index hit a new high. Other indexes were only slightly stronger, though the Nasdaq composite rose sharply, lifted by technology issues. 
 Traders said investors seemed hesitant because quarterly earnings reports were generally mixed and because they were awaiting the Government's announcement today of third-quarter data on the gross domestic product, which should shed more light on the direction of the economy.
The blue-chip issues also seemed to be hit by profit taking and a rise in interest rates in the bond market, which tends to cause investors to move funds from stocks to fixed-income securities.
 
Nasdaq Jumps 6.42 Points
 The Nasdaq composite index, which had been sluggish recently after reaching new records earlier in the month, jumped 6.42 points to 771.88. It was led by Apple Computer, up 2, to 31 3/4, Intel, up 3/4, to 64 1/2, Dell Computer, up 7/8, to 20 3/8, and Newbridge Networks, up 1 7/8, to 62 1/2.
These issues often perform well in the fourth quarter, when technology companies typically have their strongest sales. "These stocks are going to be a major driver for Nasdaq," said Claudia Mott, director of small capitalization research at Prudential Securities.
On the New York Stock Exchange, the Dow industrial average fell 7.83 points to 3,664.66. Among slipping Dow components were stocks whose earnings are sensitive to the economy, like Allied Signal, down 1 7/8, to 70 7/8, Alcoa, off 1 1/8, to 68 1/2, and Minnesota Mining & Manufacturing, which fell 1 5/8, to 103 1/2, after announcing slightly lower quarterly income.
The Dow Jones transportation average, which reached a new high on Tuesday, again hit a record, increasing 1.50 points to 1,698.65. The Standard & Poor's Index of 500 stocks rose 0.31 point to 464.61. And the American Stock Exchange composite index was up 1.42 points to 475.06.
Big Board volume was 279.8 million shares, down from 284.5 million shares on Tuesday. Advancing stocks outnumbered decliners, 1,031 to 971.
Ford Motor was the second-most active issue on the New York Stock Exchange, rising 5/8, to 60 3/8, after the company reported sharply higher quarterly earnings. General Motors increased 1 1/2, to 46 7/8. Paramount Communications, the target of a takeover battle, was up 2, to 81.
UST dropped 3 3/8, to 24 3/4. Anheuser-Busch fell 1/2, to 47 5/8, after reporting a quarterly loss. Du Pont, which also announced a loss, declined 1/2 to 46 1/2. Timberland shot up 7, to 77, after announcing strong earnings.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
ICN Pharmaceuticals offers a double bet for investors.

BYLINE: By Joshua Mills

 BODY:
INVESTING in ICN Pharmaceuticals Inc., currently the object of a proxy struggle between its incumbent management and Rafi M. Khan, a California stockbroker, is sort of like betting the daily double at the local race track. As where horses (or dogs) are concerned, the gamble does not pay off unless the bettor correctly picks the winners of two consecutive races.
In the first half of this particular double, investors are being asked to bet that bullets and bombs will give way to partnership and that United Nations sanctions will turn into trade alliances. The second half is a bet that the Food and Drug Administration will approve ICN's antiviral drug, ribavirin, as a treatment for hepatitis C. 
 A number of commentators, like Joseph Morgan, M.D., publisher of Dr. Morgan's Medical Stock Commentary, conclude that ICN is a risky but potentially rewarding bet. Dr. Morgan suggests that ICN is well positioned to take advantage of eventual economic revival in Eastern Europe and the former Soviet republics and that ribavirin is well on its way to approval. ICN shares closed yesterday at $11.125, down 12.5 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange.
ICN, based in Costa Mesa, Calif., was founded and is led by Milan Panic, a Serbian emigre and the former Prime Minister of Yugoslavia, and last year it did more than 59 percent of its business in Yugoslavia -- whose business climate these days is not even as hospitable as Antarctica's.
The local problems are devastating to business operations. The Yugoslav dinar was devalued five times last year, making supplies much more expensive; the currency problems cost ICN's Yugoslav operations about $48 million. Inflation, which in February reached an annual rate of 26,000 percent, is now about 100,000 percent, said Keith Crane, an economist with Planecon, a research and consulting firm in Washington that specializes in Eastern Europe and the former Soviet republics.
Price controls on drugs were imposed last year, which "inhibited ICN Galenika's prior practice of increasing prices to keep up with inflation," ICN noted in its annual report. ICN has a 43 percent stake in SPI Pharmaceuticals, which in turn owns 75 percent of ICN Galenika, a Yugoslav pharmaceutical manufacturer.
The sanctions imposed on Yugoslavia, which now consists of Serbia and Montenegro, exempt certain medical supplies that ICN Galenika makes. But gaining the exemptions requires licenses from the United Nations for each transaction, and the administrative burden has hurt ICN, which purchases many raw materials for its drug manufacturing outside Yugoslavia.
As ICN noted in its annual report, "While the impact of sanctions, price controls and devaluations on future sales and net income cannot be determined with certainty, they may, under the present political and economic environment, result in an adverse impact in the future."
Mr. Crane of Planecon said there was "no cause for optimism about the region's economy." Even if a peace is reached, he suggested, "the United States and Western Europe are not going to be quick to repeal the embargo because of revulsion with the Serbian Government."
And if the political bet is not too long a shot, what about the other half of the double -- the F.D.A. approval of ribavirin? The drug "is having a new day in the sun," an ICN spokesman, Jack Sholl, said yesterday, describing its "late-stage development for approval as a hepatitis C treatment," an endorsement by the American Academy of Pediatrics as a treatment for infant respiratory diseases and its presence in 44 countries for use in treating a total of eight diseases.
 The F.D.A. review process often lasts several years. Drugs that do well in early stages, when tests are conducted on first a dozen, then perhaps a hundred people, often falter in the home stretch, during what the F.D.A. calls Phase 3 -- which involves perhaps a thousand people at dozens of sites. The roadside to F.D.A. approval is littered with the debris of drug makers whose stocks boomed on optimism in the early stages of the approval process, only to break down and crash -- like the Cetus Corporation, whose Interleukin-2 was not approved by the F.D.A.

HEADLINE: Catholic Bishops Proposing Active U.S. Policy Abroad

BYLINE: By PETER STEINFELS

 BODY:
The nation's Roman Catholic bishops have drafted a statement calling for a more active American role on the world stage, including supporting the United Nations, expanding foreign aid and, when necessary, using military force for interventions intended to rescue people from hunger or mass violence.
Now in draft form, the statement is meant to commemorate the 10th anniversary of the bishops' 1983 pastoral letter on nuclear arms, which stirred intense public debate because it ran counter to the Reagan Administration's emphasis on a build-up of nuclear weapons. 
 The new document, which will be submitted for amendments and a vote at the bishops' meeting Nov. 15-18 in Washington, also appears to challenge what the bishops say is an radically altered political climate.
"After the cold war, there has emerged an understandable but dangerous temptation to turn inward, to focus only on domestic needs and to ignore global responsibilities," the statement reads. "This is not an option for believers in a universal church or for citizens in the world's most powerful nation."
 
No Movement, but a Reflex
 Archbishop John R. Roach of St. Paul and Minneapolis, who heads the bishops' committee on international policy and helped draft the document, said that the bishops did not see the growth of an isolationist ideology like the one in the United States before World War II, but rather "an involuntary reflex" that risked "withdrawing more and more from any involvement overseas."
The bishops sensed this drift, he said, in public anxiety over American actions in Somalia and Bosnia as well as in the public's "enormous preoccupation, and a legitimate one, with what's going on at home, whether health care reform or the economy."
Unlike the 1983 document, the present statement is not meant to be a full-scale pastoral letter, which usually sets forth authoritative church teaching. By contrast, the drafters called this statement "a set of more modest reflections" that do not "provide definitive answers to the key policy questions of this moment."
 
Some Broad Principles
 Nonetheless, the statement proposes priorities for American policy makers, and it offers guiding moral principles for complex issues like the use of economic sanctions, the rights of nationalities to self-determination and military interventions.
This statement is not likely to curtail the wide range of opinion on international issues among Catholics, both in the pews and in the pulpits. But it can become a widely known base line for discussions within and outside the church.
Looking back at the 1983 letter, for instance, the bishops wrote that it "led to spirited debate and constructive dialogue in our dioceses and parishes, and has been widely used in schools, colleges and universities, the armed forces and research institutes."
The new document clearly reflects the bishops' wrestling with moral issues posed by the war in the Persian Gulf, the break-up of Yugoslavia, the intervention in Somalia and the stalemate in Haiti.
The bishops voice special distress, for example, at the wave of conflicts rooted in nationalistic rivalries, especially when these are reinforced by religious differences. "Every child murdered, every town 'cleansed,' every hatred uttered in the name of religion is a crime against God," they write.
But they warn against responding to conflicts with a religious dimension by stripping religious forces of their social roles or "even by repressing so-called fundamentalist movements, especially in the Islamic world." Such efforts are apt to backfire, distracting attention from political, economic and ideological factors in the conflicts, the bishops say.
Demands for self-determination by ethnic or religious groups often reflect valid concerns, the statement says, but these can frequently be met by guarantees of minority rights and other measures short of establishing independent states.
The statement agonizes over the use of economic sanctions, which the bishops supported against Iraq, Serbia, Haiti and South Africa, but which they recognize often work the greater hardships on innocent people rather than on the politically powerful.
Sanctions, they conclude, remain "an effective alternative to war" but also a "blunt instrument" to "be used sparingly and with restraint."
Referring to the situations in Haiti, Bosnia, Liberia, Iraq, Somalia and Sudan, the bishops take up the debate about intervention by foreign governments or international organizations in the internal affairs of states. "The principles of sovereignty and nonintervention may be overridden only in exceptional circumstances, notably in the cases of genocide or when whole populations are threatened by aggression or anarchy," the bishops say.
While nonmilitary forms of intervention should take priority, "military intervention may sometimes be justified to insure that starving children can be fed or that whole populations will not be slaughtered," the bishops say.
But they emphasize that intervention should be limited to "clearly defined humanitarian objectives," should be "multilateral, under the auspices of the United Nations," when possible, and should remain part of broader efforts to strengthen international law and institutions.
 
Support for Foreign Aid
 Strengthening international institutions, especially the United Nations, is a major theme. "Perhaps no challenge is more urgent or more complex than that of improving the United Nations' ability to reduce conflict in the world," the bishops write, adding that "at a minimum, the United States must pay in full its U.N. assessments."
The statement also stresses the moral obligation of returning attention to issues of economic development and the plight of poor nations. The bishops are critical of the reduction of assistance for economic development in American foreign aid and say that in contrast to other industrialized nations, "we continue to rank near the bottom in terms of the share of our economy devoted to development assistance."
The committee that drafted the statement included influential church leaders like Joseph Cardinal Bernardin of Chicago and Roger Cardinal Mahony of Los Angeles as well as Archbishop Roach and Bishop James Malone of Youngstown, Ohio, both former presidents of the National Conference of Catholic Bishops.
Before drafting the statement, the committee held session not only with other church leaders but also with foreign policy leaders like General Colin L. Powell, then chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, and Alvaro de Soto, the senior political adviser to United Nations Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali.
The 1983 pastoral letter affirmed the validity of both the early Christian emphasis on nonviolence and the later, dominant teaching that under certain stringent conditions warfare can sometimes be morally justified.
That letter said the two traditions complemented and corrected one another, but it did not resolve the tension between them. The same tension runs through the current statement, with the bishops acknowledging the power of nonviolent resistance in bringing down Communist regimes but also endorsing the right of political authorities "as a last resort to employ limited force to rescue the innocent and establish justice."

HEADLINE: Regional Configuration Gets Pro Football Team

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHARLOTTE, N.C., Oct. 27

 BODY:
The Carolina Panthers will do, but if the owners of the National Football League's newest franchise really want to get the name right, they might try something more descriptive, like the Carolina Post-Urban Regional Configuration.
To be sure, urban policy was not exactly Topic A today in this town. From the exultant "TOUCHDOWN!" across the top of The Charlotte Observer, to James Laughlin's hawking cassettes of his "Carolina Rally Song," to the hand-scrawled "Carolina Panthers -- A Reality" triumphantly tacked to Uptown Donnie's hot dog stand, the only subject was the N.F.L.'s anointing of Charlotte on Tuesday as the home of the league's 29th franchise. 
 In a town with a particularly pronounced strain of the South's veneration of go-go hustle and self-promotion, the euphoria was no surprise. But with sports as much dollars and demographics as muscle and mud, Charlotte's victory over better known cities like Baltimore and St. Louis is a revealing window onto a nation whose center of gravity is moving South and whose old notions of what a city is are often as out of date as a leather helmet.
 
On the Map, but Where?
 Still sometimes confused with Charleston to the south or Charlottesville to the north, Charlotte may still be a place few people can place on a map. The new football franchise is a reminder of how different the cities that now snare professional teams can be from the older cities that used to get them.
And with its conspicuous economic success in recent years, its flood of newcomers, its sprawling market area of medium-sized cities running from Durham, N.C., to Columbia, S.C., Charlotte is a city in the new mold.
"When Charlotte talks about being part of a market with 10 million people within 150 square miles, it's not really a statistical sleight of hand or a rhetorical flourish," said David Goldfield, an urban historian at the University of North Carolina at Charlotte. "It's really a historical truth. Other cities increasingly are marketing themselves as regional entities, but for us there's a particular historical truth to it."
From the stores hawking merchandise for a team so far without players or stadium, the live television coverage of the return of the Carolina delegation that courted the N.F.L. owners in Chicago and the celebrations downtown, one might think the millennium had arrived, not football. But then, the possibility of seeing huge men pound on each other each Sunday sometimes seemed the least of the excitement.
 
'To the First Tier'
 "This is probably as big an event as there's been in our history in terms of just elevating us to the first tier of American cities," Mayor Richard Vinroot exulted after Charlotte was picked over four rivals.
"If you saw the National Basketball Association playoffs, you had Larry Johnson with 'Charlotte' across his big chest, standing there on national TV on Sunday afternoon, next to Patrick Ewing with 'New York' on his chest. Everybody knows New York, of course, and all of a sudden, there's Charlotte."
Charlotte has not exactly come from nowhere. The city was incorporated in 1768 and named for Queen Charlotte, the wife of King George 3d of England. It grew first with gold, then with cotton, then with textiles, toiling in Atlanta's shadow for most of this century.
But with a booming economy based on banking and a diversified service and manufacturing base, Charlotte has blossomed in the past two decades to become the nation's third-leading banking center. The city grew by 25.5 percent from 1980 to 1990, to 396,000 people. Its metropolitan area grew by almost 20 percent, to 1.1 million.
 
Numbers Aren't Everything
 Still, neither figure makes Charlotte a powerhouse. It is now the 34th-largest metropolitan area, between Buffalo-Niagara Falls and Providence-Pawtucket, and the 35th-largest city, between St. Louis and Atlanta.
What persuaded the N.F.L. was a marketing area that includes most of the Carolinas. Marketing studies developed by Rand McNally and used to promote Charlotte indicate that, using a basic trading area that includes surrounding counties, Charlotte ranks 28th nationally. Using an expanded unit definition that takes in 134 counties, Charlotte ranked sixth in size. And, in fact, the euphoria about the football franchise spread throughout the Carolinas.
"We are ecstatic," said Dick Blouse, executive director of the Greenville Chamber of Commerce in South Carolina. "We don't view this as a Charlotte team, but a regional team."
In Clemson, S.C., where the team will play its first year at Clemson University's "Death Valley," interest in the team is already so high that customers lined up at the Mr. Knickerbocker sporting goods store this morning to buy Panthers' paraphernalia. The store manager, David Spearman, said he had to turn them away because his shipment had not arrived.
"It's like living through an earthquake this morning," he said.
Much of the distinctive nature of the Carolinas is a product of history, specifically a textile industry that created a host of medium-sized cities through the Carolinas rather than one urban center with Charlotte at the central distribution point.
"Charlotte has always conceived itself as being the economic capital of the two Carolinas," said Dan Morrill, a history professor at the University of North Carolina at Charlotte. "This is nothing new."
What is new is the degree to which population and job growth are coming to cities like Charlotte and other medium-sized cities, particularly those in the South like Nashville; Tampa and Orlando in Florida or Greenville-Spartanburg in South Carolina. In the 1990 census, of the 20 fastest-growing metropolitan areas with more than a million people, 19 were in the South and West.
There were a few dissenters here today. "I would hate to say that whether a city has a damn football team has anything to do with whether it's a world-class city," said Bob Raiford, a local radio commentator who terms himself a curmudgeon at large.
Football aside, Charlotte has problems, like a soaring crime rate, not much different from those in bigger cities. And even some admirers of Charlotte say that, football or no, it is bigger on squeaky-clean enthusiasm and leafy neighborhoods than urban excitement. "Some people say New York is a city that never sleeps," said Professor Goldfield. "Charlotte may be a city that never wakes. But it's a nice place to live."
But snaring the N.F.L. franchise with an innovative plan for private construction of a stadium, on top of the success of the N.B.A.'s Hornets, has most people here soaring.
"When we first set out to seek the N.B.A., people sort of laughed at us," said Mr. Vinroot. "One pundit said, 'The only franchise you'll get is a new McDonald's.' Well, we proved them wrong. Now, there is, I think, a feeling of self-confidence that's almost scary."

HEADLINE: Chretien Says He Wants Changes in Trade Accord

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TORONTO, Oct. 27

 BODY:
Fresh from the stunning triumph of his Liberal party in Canada's general elections, Prime Minister-designate Jean Chretien said today that he wants changes in the North American Free Trade Agreement and may not implement the pact without them.
Although he insisted at a news conference in Ottawa that Canada did not want to intervene in the debate over trade legislation in the United States, his comments complicated the task of passage and appeared to put him into conflict with President Clinton. 
 Mr. Clinton told reporters in Washington on Tuesday that he saw "no reason to renegotiate the agreement." President Carlos Salinas de Gortari of Mexico also opposes renegotiation.
Over 15 years, Nafta is intended to create a single $7 trillion-a-year market covering 360 million consumers in Canada, the United States and Mexico.
Mr. Chretien's remarks created consternation in Washington, with officials saying some members of Congress would refuse to vote for the agreement if there were a possibility it might be changed later. "We get the sense that many Congressmen will use Chretien's comments as an excuse" to oppose the pact, one official said.
But Representative Bill Richardson, a New Mexico Democrat who favors the pact and is a chief deputy majority whip, said Mr. Chretien's position "has not affected our vote count -- that's the truth."
He added that if Mr. Chretien revived talks on the pact before Congress votes in mid-November, "that will hurt us." Noting that Mr. Chretien had said he would not take any action until he had appointed his Cabinet, Mr. Richardson said, "My hope is he will wait in appointing his ministers."
Still uncertain is whether Canadian demands can be dealt with as side issues or whether they will lead to counterdemands in Mexico and the United States that would reopen the entire agreement.
Elaborating on the Liberal position for the first time, Mr. Chretien said he would press for changes to protect Canadian energy reserves and to define rules on unfair subsidies and unfairly low prices for exports.
Canadians have asked for such definitions because, they say, American charges that Canada unfairly subsidizes exports of steel, pork, lumber and other products are arbitrary.
Washington has demands of its own, including abandonment of provisions in the four-year-old Canada-United States trade accord that protect Canadian books, films and other cultural industries from full competition.
Mr. Chretien made his comments in response to reporters' questions; they were not part of a formal declaration by the new Government, which will not be installed for 9 or 10 days.
Mr. Chretien and Mr. Clinton, who spoke by telephone on Tuesday, have scheduled a meeting to discuss the problem on Nov. 19 in Seattle, during an Asian-Pacific Economic Cooperation conference.
Although the Liberal Party platform had called for renegotiation, there has always been a question how hard the case would be pressed once the party was in power.
Liberals had fought free trade in the 1988 elections and are divided over Nafta today. The left wing wants to scrap the deal. Moderates fear that if it does not go forward, Canada will find itself isolated and economically impaired. Mr. Chretien is in the camp of the moderates, but he is anxious to prevent any ruptures within the party.
He also emphasized today: "I will do my best to have very good relations with the United States and Mexico."
The Canadian legislation to put Nafta into force was passed by Parliament under the Progressive Conservative Government, which was soundly beaten at the polls Monday. But Mr. Chretien said it would not become law until he proclaimed it.
Mr. Chretien said his first task as Canada's 20th Prime Minister would be to create jobs -- as was also promised in the Liberal platform. "My first priority will be definitely to work on the economy," he said. "That is the reason why we won the election."
He is expected to announce shortly a $6 billion public-works program to create up to 120,000 jobs over two years.

HEADLINE: U.S. MAY TIGHTEN EMBARGO ON HAITI

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

 BODY:
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 --
With efforts to restore Haiti's elected President stymied, President Clinton's top foreign policy advisers met today to consider a complete economic embargo against the poor Caribbean nation.
But they took no action, and it was not clear when they would meet again. 
 Administration officials said the advisers were considering a French proposal for a worldwide economic embargo on Haiti. The proposal is being circulated among members of the UNited Nations Security Council.
 
Deadline Played Down
 Under an agreement negotiated in July, Haiti's military government is required to cede power to the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, the President ousted in a 1991 coup, by Saturday. But President Clinton's advisers played down the importance of the deadline, and they did not say when stiffer sanctions might go into effect.
"We are not pressing for additional sanctions at this time," the United States representative to the United Nations, Madeleine K. Albright, said in New York.
A United Nations embargo enforced by a flotilla of American, Canadian and French warships, was imposed against Haiti on Oct. 16 and went into effect just before midnight on Oct. 18. But that only covers oil products and weapons.
The French proposal calls for a blockade against Haiti that would prevent virtually all commerce from flowing into and out of what is already the poorest country in the Western Hemisphere.
 
Assets of Military Frozen
 Earlier this month, in an effort to go beyond the oil and weapons embargo, the Clinton Administration unilaterally froze the assets of Haitian military leaders and their supporters. But the meeting today appeared to be the first in which the Administration formally considered a complete embargo.
The Administration received a copy of the French proposal this morning, one Presidential foreign policy adviser said. "What it does is to point in the direction of increasing the bite of sanctions, and that's a good thing."
The draft resolution would permit imports of goods deemed necessary for basic humanitarian needs and would allow the Government of the exiled President, Father Aristide, to request exemptions on a case-by-case basis. Otherwise, all commerce between Haiti and the outside world would be banned.
Among the factors Administration officials say among they are weighing in considering whether to push for new sanctions is whether they will be able to get a consensus among Security Council members. They would also have to weigh the position of Father Aristide on a wide-ranging embargo. The exiled President is scheduled to addressed the United Nations General Assembly on Thursday.
Clinton Administration officials said they hoped that the reimposition of the limited embargo will force Haiti's military and police rulers to step aside as required by an agreement signed at Governors Island in New York in July and allow the return of Father Aristide, who was deposed in a military coup two years ago.
 
Aristide Seeks More Pressure
 Father Aristide and his supporters have been calling for stepped-up economic pressure on the military leaders and their supporters since it became clear in recent weeks that the leader of Haiti's armed forces, Lieut. Gen. Raoul Cedras, would not step down as scheduled on Oct. 15.
But even some who say they back Father Aristide's return say they worry that such a draconian economic measures would further impoverish an already desperately poor country.
"We may succeed in making Haiti more democratic, but we are also risking the spread of contagious diseases, deforestation and total economic collapse," said Rep. Robert G. Torricelli, a New Jersey Democrat who is chairman of a subcommitee on Western Hemisphere Affairs.
Administration officials said the discussions of tighter sanctions were in the "preliminary stage," and that the draft text of a new United Nation resolution on sanctions was being circulated among members of the Security Council.
Already there are signs that the limited embargo is increasing hardships in Haiti. Officials from CARE, one of the largest relief agencies operating in the country, said that they would have to cut back their activities in the next 48 hours because of a shortage of fuel to deliver food into the countryside.
"Fuel supplies are becoming rapidly depleted, which means we're going to have to curtail operations," said Hope Rosenberg, a communications officer for CARE in New York. "We're feeding 600,000a day, roughly 10 per cent of the population. So if if we have to curtail that, a lot of people will suffer."
As the Administration moved to turn up pressure on Haiti's military and police rulers, Secretary of State Warren Christopher renewed calls today for Father Aristide to broaden his government to include more political parties.
Speaking to reporters during a stop in Riga, Latvia, Mr. Christopher said that the Administration accepted the idea that additional people could be recruited to serve in Father Aristide's Government.
"It's important to assure the return of President Aristide will achieve harmony and tranquility," Mr. Christopher said.
