HEADLINE: CAMPAIGN TRAIL;
Giuliani Says He'd Fill Posts on Basis of Merit

BYLINE: By CATHERINE S. MANEGOLD

 BODY:
Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday accused Mayor David N. Dinkins of making appointments based primarily on race and ethnicity, and said that as mayor, he would make all appointments based on merit, "irrespective of race, religion, ethnic background and sexual orientation."
At a news conference at his headquarters at 415 Madison Avenue, near 50th Street, he suggested that the Mayor was preoccupied with diversity and had made decisions at the expense of general competence. 
 "Right now in the city administration it appears as if the principal reason why people are selected is symbolic," Mr. Giuliani said. "The principal reason is to create a representative government, rather than to select the most talented person. Many people have observed, not just this candidate -- even newspapers that endorsed David Dinkins -- that the quality of the people around David Dinkins is not what it should be."
Though Mr. Giuliani has spoken at other occasions recently of the need for the "empowerment" of various minority groups, he said yesterday that he would seek the most qualified people, while also reaching out to New York's many communities..
Leah Johnson, a spokeswoman for the Dinkins campaign, said of Mr. Giuliani's comments: "It is sad and surprising that a person running for mayor of New York City is going to put down or deride a commitment to diversity and excellence. That is in keeping with his belief that the police force should not reside in New York City and be more representative of the people that it protects, and it goes along with his desire to dismantle the 20 percent target program for minority and women's business enterprises that the Mayor had sought to create."
At his news conference, Mr. Giuliani welcomed the endorsement of Andrew S. Fisher, a Democrat who was legal adviser to Mayor Abraham D. Beame. Mr. Fisher is chairman of the Brooklyn Economic Development Corporation and headed the Brooklyn Bar Association in 1989. But his record was blemished in 1990, when he pleaded guilty to failing to pay state income taxes in 1986 and 1987.
 
Opening Schools at Night
 Speaking at Alexander Berger Junior High School in the Bronx, Mr. Dinkins announced yesterday a plan to open at least half of the city's schools at night in an eight-month trial program to expand the number of schools available for community groups and youth programs.
Mr. Dinkins was joined by Tipper Gore, the wife of Vice President Al Gore. "I am here because I deeply believe in Mayor Dinkins and the direction in which he is taking your city," Mrs. Gore said.
Many of Mr. Dinkins's proposals, like increasing police officers deployed in the public schools, have been unveiled in earlier speeches. Yesterday he said there would be no fee for using the schools in the evening as long as the group is committed to community service.
Richard L. Murphy, the city's Commissioner of Youth Services, said the cost of the trial program in about 500 schools would be between $2 million and $3 million. But he said savings within the budget can cover the cost.
The Mayor also received an endorsement yesterday from James Brady, former press secretary for President Ronald Reagan. Speaking at John Jay College, Mr. Brady, who was injured in an assassination attempt on President Reagan, praised Mr. Dinkins as a "strong consistent voice for gun control."
 
And the Bills Go On
 Win or lose, Mayor Dinkins's campaign will have some sizable bills to pay after Nov. 2. But so will Mr. Dinkins himself.
The Mayor has still not paid the lawyer who represented him during 1990 city and Federal investigations into a stock transaction that came to light during the 1989 mayoral race. Aides to Mr. Dinkins said the bill was for about $200,000.
Harold Ickes, Mr. Dinkins's campaign counsel, said the Mayor intends to repay the bill "in a reasonable time after the election." The unpaid bill was reported yesterday in New York Newsday.
"He really hasn't focused on it because he's been raising money for this campaign," Mr. Ickes said. He said the legal fees were Mr. Dinkins's personal expense and would not be paid by his campaign.
Charles A. Stillman, the lawyer who represented Mr. Dinkins, said he completed his services to the Mayor by 1992 but did not send a final bill to him until earlier this year.
Asked why his office waited a year to send the bill, Mr. Stillman said: "This is not some major New York law firm with a business manager and office manager. We're just not focused on those things as much as others were. There was no calculated reason for it. That's just when it got sent out."
Mr. Stillman said his Manhattan-based firm, Stillman, Friedman & Shaw, does no work for the city and was not showing favoritism to the Mayor in its billing practices.
"Accommodations for individuals stuck with substantial legal fees are not unusual," he said. "I've treated David Dinkins absolutely the same as all other clients."
 
A Statistical Tie
 A poll released yesterday by The New York Post and WNYW-TV showed that the mayoral race remains too close to call, with no sign of significant change in the numbers.
The survey of 400 registered voters showed Mayor Dinkins leading with 46 percent over his Republican-Liberal challenger, Mr. Giuliani, who had the support of 40 percent of the respondents. The Mayor's slight lead, reflected in other recent polls, was within the survey's margin of sampling error of plus or minus 5 percentage points, making the race essentially a statistical tie.
The poll indicated a tightening of the race for comptroller between Assemblyman Alan G. Hevesi, the Democratic candidate, and Herman Badillo, the Republican-Liberal nominee. Mr. Hevesi, who had held a wide lead over Mr. Badillo, had the support of 42 percent in the poll, compared with 35 percent for Mr. Badillo. Nineteen percent of the voters polled said they were undecided.
A poll released on Tuesday by New York Newsday/WABC-TV showed the candidates for comptroller tied at 40 percent each. But a New York Times/WCBS-TV poll released the same day showed Mr. Hevesi leading 43 percent to 30 percent.
 
A 'Reverse Freedom Ride'
 More than three decades after freedom riders rolled into the South to promote integration and voting rights, a new generation of freedom riders is on the road. They still pack into buses but have reversed their course. Yesterday they arrived in New York City from places like Alabama and Mississippi.
Their mission is to get people in poor neighborhoods to vote on Tuesday. "It's a reverse freedom ride," said Crystal Poole of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, the drive's sponsor.

HEADLINE: CLINTON'S HEALTH PLAN: Financing the Plan;
The Difference 6 Weeks Make: Revisions in Costs

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 27

 BODY:
The biggest differences between the health care plan President Clinton invited Congress to ponder six weeks ago and the bill he offered today are financial, reflecting an effort to avoid a repetition of the huge cost increases that have characterized Medicare since its was enacted in 1965.
The changes were meant to reassure likely supporters of the bill who were suspicious of the plan's financial underpinnings, and they brought one quick and important change of tune. Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the New York Democrat who heads the Senate Finance Committee and who called the first version of the proposal "fantasy," said today, "I'm much more satisfied." 
 The three main changes are to assume that inflation will rise 3.5 percent annually through the year 2000, instead of the previously assumed 2.7 percent; to increase an allowance for unexpected subsidy costs from $30 billion to $45 billion, and, most of all, to define the program as a "capped entitlement."
That definition means Congress would have to take a vote on what to do if costs outran estimates. With Medicare and Social Security, by contrast, the Government pays cost overruns automatically.
Leon E. Panetta, director of the White House Office of Management and Budget, said that he personally believed that the new steps were needed and that he had pushed for them. Health care estimates, no matter how carefully drawn, are hardly certain forecasts, he said, adding, "We've just seen too many unpredictable results in health care."
 
Fears About Ceiling
 The changes announced today, like many others, were a consequence of the unusual consultative approach the Administration took in laying a rough draft of the plan before Congress and inviting criticism. Many of the critics wanted to be allies, and nothing bothered them more than the comparison with Medicare, the health care plan for the elderly. Its costs exploded because of unanticipated increases in health care prices and because elderly people went to their doctors more often than anyone expected.
Representative Steny H. Hoyer of Maryland, chairman of the House Democratic caucus, said today that he had asked for a study of just how Medicare cost estimates had gone wrong over the years.
"All of us are concerned about making sure that we're not doing something that looks good, that is good, but wrecks all of our grandchildren," Mr. Hoyer said of the health care bill.
In its first year, the Medicare program cost $6.5 billion; by 1992 it had soared to $132 billion.
But the effort to reassure some lawmakers unsettled others. Representative Pete Stark, the California Democrat who leads the House Ways and Means subcommittee on health, for example, said he feared that the spending cap presented a possibility that there would not be enough money for discounted insurance for the poor or for subsidies to help small businesses buy health insurance. At the same time, he said, there was no limit on the benefits that corporations would get when the Government assumed their responsibilities for health care for early retirees.
The Administration was wary of this political problem, too. Deputy Treasury Secretary Roger C. Altman said at a White House briefing, "It is most unlikely that ceiling will be reached," an argument other officials were making to any Democrat who would listen.
In emphasizing the Administration's conservative approach, Ken Thorpe, a deputy assistant secretary of Health and Human Services, told reporters on Capitol Hill that whenever the Administration was confronted with differing estimates for what health-care premiums would be, it routinely selected the higher set of estimates.
President Clinton himself stressed the same theme of fiscal caution. He told Senators and Representatives assembled in Statuary Hall at the Capitol: "We have tried to be as conservative as we could here in making sure that we have not over-claimed for cost savings or overestimated how small the cost of things will be. Therefore, I think we have in our plan put more money in than it will cost to implement this plan. But better to be wrong on that side than the other side."
Those words were welcome, but most lawmakers said they wanted time to study the proposed legislation in detail.
Even Mr. Moynihan's commitment was not absolute. After receiving his own briefing Tuesday from Hillary Rodham Clinton and Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen, the Senator said: "The Administration says their numbers are the best we can do just now. We know they are subject to change. We know there are vast uncertainties."
Mr. Panetta agreed, saying that the Administration would keep its cost estimates up to date as it got more information. But he said that in health care, "We do not have the kind of accurate fix" available in other areas of the economy.
Other Administration officials, who spoke on the condition that they not be identified by name, said that when the program was fully phased in, it would increase health care spending by $60 billion to $65 billion, not counting the savings that would be achieved through the program. This increased spending would result from the greater demand for services that comes from providing coverage to people who are now uninsured or underinsured.

HEADLINE: Cablevision To Purchase TV Systems

 BODY:
Cablevision Systems Corporation, which is considered a prime target in the takeover wave sweeping the communications industry, turned the tables on speculators yesterday and announced that it would buy an additional three cable television systems for $463 million.
By acquiring the three systems from Sutton Capital Associates Inc., Cablevision will pick up an additional 176,000 subscribers in areas adjacent to the systems it already operates. 
 The company, based in Woodbury, L.I., currently has 2.1 milion subscribers and is the fourth-largest cable operator in the country. Two of the new systems are in New Jersey; the third is in Framingham, Mass.
Charles F. Dolan, chairman of Cablevision, said last night that he had been working on the purchase of the three systems for "a very long time" and that they were consistent with the company's long-standing growth strategy.
"These are systems where we already have a considerable number of subscribers," he said. "This gives us economies of scale and programming opportunities."
Based on the $463 million purchase price, Cablevision is paying more than $2,600 per subscriber for the systems.
The deal was announced after the stock market closed yesterday. Earlier, Cablevision's stock ended at $68, up $1.75, on the American Stock Exchange.
The deal hardly puts an end to takeover fever, however. Industry executives say that Time Warner Inc. and U S West remain actively interested in buying Cablevision as part of their effort to build advanced networks around the country. Southwestern Bell Corporation and Bellsouth Corporation have also been rumored bidders.
Many analysts say Cablevision will almost certainly be sold to someone, because the company has built up clusters of cable systems in good markets.
Under its deal with Sutton Capital, Cablevision is acquiring Monmouth Cablevision, which has about 115,000 subscribers in 31 central New Jersey communities, and Riverview Cablevision, with 45,000 subscribers in Hoboken, West New York, Weehawken and two other communities in Hudson County. And in Massachusetts, it is acquiring Framingham Cablevision, with about 16,300 subscribers.

HEADLINE: Candidates Debate Budget in Battle for Westchester Executive

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SCARSDALE, N.Y., Oct. 27

 BODY:
As the race for Westchester County Executive enters its final days, even a strictly controlled League of Women Voters forum can turn into a rough-and-tumble debate, the incumbent, Andrew P. O'Rourke, and his challenger, state Assemblyman Richard L. Brodsky, showed here tonight.
Given no time for opening statements and restricted to answering issue-oriented questions posed by the League and members of the audience, Mr. Brodsky, a Democrat from Greenburgh, quickly turned his comments on his opponent, suggesting that the solution to nearly every problem in Westchester lay in replacing its chief executive. 
 Mr. O'Rourke, first elected to the post in 1981, cited his administration's actions and then turned to his familiar theme: that Mr. Brodsky was part of a do-nothing state government in Albany.
Given 90 seconds to respond to the first question, how to contain costs while providing needed services, Mr. O'Rourke began: "Cost containment means doing what we're doing right now in Westchester County. We have held the tax-levy increase to zero for the past three years. My budget for '94 comes out tomorrow and again it will be a frozen, zero tax-levy increase budget."
 
Horse Leaving the Barn
 But Mr. Brodsky began, "I listen to the County Executive talk about cost containment as something he is deeply engaged in with some sense of watching a horse leave the barn and the door being closed behind it. Since Andy O'Rourke became County Executive 11 years ago, property taxes are up 124 percent, larger than other counties in the area, larger than local governments, larger than local school districts."
Beyond the attacks and assignments of blame, of course, lies a county of 870,000 people that faces growing problems of the sort that many of its residents moved from New York City to escape, and a recession that has hit hard at white-collar employment in the county.
Mr. Brodsky is trying to provide an alternative for people who are feeling that Westchester can't afford all that it once could, including a big county government. "For Westchester to remain the same, we're going to have to change the government," he said.
Provoking groans and laughter from the audience, Mr. Brodsky repeatedly cited his editorial-page endorsement on Tuesday by the Westchester-Gannett Newspapers, which had endorsed Mr. O'Rourke in 1989, when Mr. Brodsky first challenged him. More than anything, the editorial suggested that Mr. O'Rourke had been in office too long, and that fresh leadership was needed.
 
Speaking of an Editorial
 But Mr. O'Rourke won friendlier laughter from the audience with his own references to his opponent's reliance on an editorial to speak for him. And while constantly jabbing at Mr. Brodsky, he also used his incumbency to cite specific ways his administration had acted on affordable housing, cutting costs and working with New York City on protecting the water supply that the county shares with it.
Both candidates said they opposed the county government's having the power to force affordable housing on communities that resist it. In a county that is under a consent order to provide more affordable housing in middle-class communities, and where the issue has been a bitter one in cities like Yonkers and smaller suburbs, both men said the county had to work with local governments.
And asked for alternatives to the multibillion-dollar filtration plant that the Federal Government may order New York City to build for its water supply, both said the reservoir system should be in the hands of a state or quasi-independent agency, rather than the city's.
Mr. O'Rourke, however, said that if the filtration plant were needed, Westchester should go along and pay its share of the cost.
 
Reducing Fat or Services
 One member of the audience asked how the candidates would cut costs within the county government. Mr. O'Rourke said the key was reducing duplication among various levels of government while examining the best way to provide every service.
Mr. Brodsky, who was attacked repeatedly by the Republican as a big spender, said he was prepared to reduce services. "There ought not to be duplication, but the fact of the matter is that saving money for people will require the downsizing of the government and may require less services than I would otherwise wish to recommend or provide."

HEADLINE: Haig Scorns U.S. for Its Tough China Policy

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEIJING, Oct. 27

 BODY:
Sitting in one of the skyscraper hotels that signifies China's economic ascent, former Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. was seething about American policy toward China.
Visiting Beijing early this month to introduce the new president of the United Technologies Corporation to the Chinese leadership, Mr. Haig argued that Washington was about to lose China again by driving the next generation of Chinese leaders toward "jingoism" and "anti-Americanism." 
 "How dare we go around telling the rest of the world" that they must live up to American standards on human rights, he demanded. "I think the time has come to take a different tack here. And Tiananmen is a long way behind us."
His hotel is a few miles east of Tiananmen Square, where thousands of pro-democracy demonstrators fled the onslaught of the June 4, 1989, military crackdown, a night that left hundreds if not thousands dead.
With President Clinton meeting the Chinese Communist Party leader, Jiang Zemin, in Seattle next month, the question of whether and how to move American-Chinese relations into a new era is likely to be answered soon.
Exactly where the relationship can move is tricky business, however, and advocates on all sides of the policy issues are maneuvering for influence.
The greatest restriction to movement may have come from Mr. Clinton himself. In May he laid down a daunting challenge to the Chinese leadership when he signed an executive order extending China's most favored nation trading privileges for another year, but insisting that in that time China show "consistent overall progress" in its human rights record.
A number of China specialists worry that this schedule may be too short and internal pressures too great. paramount leader, Deng Xiaoping, 89, is in declining health, and the prospect of Mr. Deng's death has rendered his potential successors more cautious than ever about undertaking change. Any leader who could be said to have bent to America's will might be vulnerable in any power struggle after Mr. Deng's death.
Moving United States-China relations away from the annual Congressional wrangle over renewal of China's trade status, with its emphasis on human rights, is an idea shared by a number of businessmen and diplomats who are coming to China to participate in China's economic boom.
This view is also shared by China specialists like Kenneth Lieberthal at the University of Michigan, who have begun to advocate that the United States "should stop punishing China for the massacre of demonstrators in Tiananmen Square" because China is simply too big and too important to isolate indefinitely.
 
The Japan Card
 Mr. Haig lowers his voice to give the geo-strategic underpinning to his argument. In the future, he said, the only way to protect Asia from the kind of Japan "that we don't want to see" is to build a strong relationship with China.
Since the United States already has a strong relationship with Japan, an equally strong American-Chinese relationship will be complementary, he argued. Keeping these future Asian superpowers balanced "is the greatest safeguard against regional uncertainty and instability," Mr. Haig said.
And what would become of human rights policy?
"We would espouse our values, but we should do it by example, not by pedantry," he replies.
Not far from Mr. Haig's hotel suite, a recently released political prisoner provided some contrast.
The prisoner was held for more than two years in solitary confinement and thought for a time that he had lost his mind in isolation. His health is broken, his life shattered by his pamphleteering for democracy in 1989. He asked that his name not be used.
After listening to a description of Mr. Haig's view, he said that keeping up the pressure on the Chinese leadership to respect human rights has been one of the greatest influences on its behavior.
"It would be very sad if the United States changed its policy in this way," he said.

HEADLINE: Durable-Goods Orders Up for a Second Month

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 27

 BODY:
More evidence that the economy is shifting into higher gear emerged today as orders for long-lived factory goods posted a second straight increase in September, the first back-to-back advance in nearly a year.
While the September rise for durable goods was just seven-tenths of 1 percent, after a revised 2.6 percent gain in August, analysts said the Commerce Department report reflected surprisingly strong performance. The orders total was held down by plunging military and aviation business, but, because of the long time between placing orders and actually producing such goods, that category has relatively little bearing on immediate economic prospects. 
 Economists were particularly heartened by the breadth of the gains and the fact that a widely followed subcategory, orders for civilian capital goods other than aircraft, surged 3.4 percent after a 1.8 percent gain in August.
 
'Beginning to Have Some Life'
 "It's pretty encouraging," said Sung Won Sohn, chief economist for the Norwest Corporation in Minneapolis. "The manufacturing segment of the economy is beginning to have some life."
Today's report also showed that shipments of manufactured goods climbed 1.9 percent last month, to $137 billion, the highest level on record. Shipments in all major industry groups advanced.
This, analysts said, reflected heavy orders placed early in the year after a booming final quarter of 1992. Then, the economy grew at an annual rate of 5.7 percent before slumping to an average of less than 1.5 percent during the first half of 1993. The department is to publish its first estimate of third-quarter gross domestic product on Thursday, with economists expecting growth of about 2.75 percent.
"This is another indication that we're coming out of the slump we had during the spring and summer," Dave Orr, chief economist for the First Union National Bank, in Charlotte, N.C., said of today's figures. He expressed some concern about the decline in unfilled orders, which fell for the seventh straight month to the lowest point since June 1988. But, he said, the stronger and more numerous upbeat elements of the report "better fit the trend."
The biggest orders gains were posted by electronic and other electrical equipment, up 3 percent after falling nearly that much in August, and industrial machinery and equipment, up 2.5 percent. Primary metals advanced 2.4 percent. The only major decline was in transportation equipment, which tumbled 1.8 percent.
Sales of cars and houses have been among the strongest economic indicators recently despite continuing consumer apprehension about jobs. Low interest rates have aided both sectors. Companies, meanwhile, are buying new equipment.
"The industrial sector is picking up steam," Donald H. Straszheim, chief economist at Merrill Lynch, said. "The durable goods report is consistent with other recent data that show the U.S. economy accelerating during the second half of 1993."
Orders last month totaled $132.79 billion on a seasonally adjusted basis, 9.3 percent above the September 1992 level. For the year to date, orders are running 8.3 percent ahead of the comparable 1992 period.
Over all, orders for durables have advanced in three of the latest four months. With transportation excluded, the gain was 1.5 percent for September, the fourth consecutive month with a gain of more than 1 percent, according to Laurence H. Meyer & Associates of St. Louis.
Shipments, today's report showed, have similarly advanced in three of the latest four months, with the September level 9.1 percent above that of September 1992.
Unfilled orders, a predictive indicator, fell 1 percent last month to $428.76 billion, the 26th decline in the past 31 months. With transportation excluded, however, the decline was a negligible one-tenth of 1 percent.
Perhaps the most important element of today's report, Michael P. Niemira of Mitsubishi Bank said, was that nonmilitary orders rose for the second straight month -- nine-tenths of 1 percent in September and 3.3 percent, after revision, in August.
This broke a pattern all year in which every month had reversed course from the preceding one. The performance pointed, Mr. Niemira said, to "building momentum."

GRAPHIC: Graph: "Durable-Goods Orders" tracks manufacturers' total new orders for durable goods, seasonally adjusted, since April 1992. (Source: Commerce Department)

HEADLINE: A Race of TV Images: Framing the Debate

BYLINE: By JON NORDHEIMER

 BODY:
Perhaps the most interesting television advertisement in New Jersey's crowded political season has little to do with the main attraction, the race for governor.
It is a spot that urges the re-election of William L. Gormley, a Republican State Senator from Atlantic City, and it is almost entirely devoted to a visual of him paddling about in the rough ocean surf in a kayak. The last image shows the 46-year old candidate on the beach in his bathing suit, looking, from what might be interpreted as a deliberate backside angle, like something of a hunk. 
 Mr. Gormley, who finished fourth in the 1989 Republican primary for governor, laughs off allusions to "beefcake" that the ad has encouraged. It was, he says, merely an inviting way to carry a serious message about his work to improve the economy and build schools.
The point is that the art of selling a candidate on television still depends on visuals, visuals, visuals -- however remote they are from the real issues.
Some of the ads for Christine Todd Whitman, the Republican candidate for governor, tried to dump all the problems of the long recession at the door of Gov. Jim Florio and his $2.8 billion tax plan. Others argued that Mrs. Whitman would broadly cut taxes while the Democrats could not be trusted to refrain from raising them again. For both themes, many of the visuals were static images of shuttered factories with broken windows.
 
Assaulting the Public
 Meanwhile, Mr. Florio's ads were shooting up the screen with chattering assault weapons.
Neil Upmeyer, president of the Center for the Analysis of Public Issues at Princeton, says the Democrats so far are the winners in the battle of the ads, and the assault weapon is why.
"Assault weapons have very little to do with the kind of crime most voters fear in this state," he noted. "The handgun is what threatens most people. But the image of the assault weapon is so much stronger and memorable."
Not only were the assault weapon ads effective, in the judgment of Mr. Upmeyer and others. They were also out there early.
The Florio campaign began running spots shortly after Labor Day that attacked Mrs. Whitman on issues like her reservations about aspects of the assault weapon ban and drunken-driving laws. At the time, some Republican insiders gloated that the Democrats had made a strategic mistake: By spending heavily on television in September in a state with campaign spending limits, the Florio camp risked running short of money later in the campaign.
 
Negative, Without Nastiness
 The Democrats' ads had framed the debate, however, and Mrs. Whitman was forced to spend a lot of time explaining her positions on assault weapons, drunken driving and welfare reform.
"The Florio people did a superb job through their ads of strengthening the very soft lead they started the campaign with," said Dr. Jerome Aumente, director of the Journalism Resources Institute at Rutgers University.
The TV ads may have turned negative but never in the nasty style of previous campaigns.
Mr. Upmeyer and others suspect that Mr. Florio and his campaign adviser, James Carville, were prepared to get as mean as necessary. But when a variety of polls showed them comfortably ahead, the Florio team never had to make that decision.
 
Falling Short
 There is fairly widespread, even bipartisan, agreement that Mrs. Whitman's television commercials failed her in two ways.
*They did little to counter the Florio camp's unrelenting campaign to portray Mrs. Whitman as a hunt-country dilettante out of touch with ordinary people.
*They failed to inspire confidence in Mrs. Whitman. Her biggest target was Mr. Florio's shaky credibility, But her own credibility got no boost from ads trying to sell the voters on her promise to come up with a broad tax cut.
And the Florio team was swift to capitalize on criticism of her tax plan.
"Especially effective was their quick response to challenge the Whitman tax cut package and damage her credibility," Dr. Aumente of Rutgers said. "Her ads mentioned trivial things she would cut out of the budget -- like sneakers for prisoners and the Governor's helicopter -- that just didn't add up to the kind of savings needed to allow her tax cuts.
Roger Bodman, a Republican lobbyist, said he felt Mrs. Whitman's most effective ad appeared on radio, not television.
"It's the one where her daughter defends her with a great deal of passion," said Mr. Bodman, who serves as a political analyst on the New Jersey Network.
 
Subject of Referendum
 He agreed that the Florio campaign had largely succeeded in defining Mrs. Whitman for the public before the paid media campaign got under way in earnest.
"I felt if the Republican campaign was to be successful it had to be fought on the ground that the election was a referendum on Jim Florio," he said. "Instead it has been turned into a referendum on Christie Whitman. That's not necessarily bad but it shows the effectiveness of the Florio campaign to turn things around like that."
Jim McQueeny, a Democratic consultant, said the Whitman campaign was so severely hurt by the tax cut promise that her most recent commercials barely mention it.
"Her ads attack Florio for most of the state's economic ills, but she never gets around to explaining what her alternatives would be," said Mr. McQueeny, who also serves as a political analyst for NJN.
Mr. Upmeyer of the Center for the Analysis of Public Issues said he felt the biggest weakness in the Whitman media campaign was that it relied too much on anti-Florio sentiment and never generated enough good will to make her own economic pronouncements believable.
"If the ads can help establish her as a highly regarded and credible candidate, people would listen to what she had to say on important economic issues. That never happened."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Ford Reports a $463 Million Profit for 3d Quarter

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Oct. 27

 BODY:
With profits in the United States at their highest level for the period since 1988, the Ford Motor Company today posted third-quarter earnings of $463 million, in contrast to a loss of $272 million during the quarter last year.
While Ford's stock surged immediately after the announcement, it receded a bit after Wall Street analysts looked more closely at the numbers. In addition to a one-time favorable tax adjustment of $140 million, Ford's profits were buoyed by sales in Latin America, a market that some analysts consider too volatile to support investors' hopes for future prosperity. Other analysts worried that Ford was continuing to cut the profit margins on its vehicles too fine. 
 In the the end, Ford stock closed on the New York Stock Exchange at $60.375, up 62.5 cents, a record closing price. It was the most active issue on the Big Board, with more than five million shares traded.
 
 
Higher Truck Sales
 The company cited cost cuts and improved truck sales as important contributors to its profitable quarter. Excluding the tax benefit, Ford's American operations earned $163 million, compared with a loss of $260 million a year ago.
Over all, Ford's earnings came to 79 cents a share, or 51 cents once the tax adjustment was excluded. For the quarter, worldwide sales and revenue were $24.5 billion, up $1.2 billion from the third quarter last year.
The Chrysler Corporation reported record third-quarter earnings of $372 million at midmonth, excluding a similar tax adjustment. The General Motors Corporation is expected to report a loss on Thursday.
At Ford, strength in North and South America was not enough to offset continued losses in Europe. Before income taxes, Ford's worldwide automotive operations lost $206 million for the quarter, compared with a total loss of $927 million a year ago.
Today's report also provided insight into Ford's long-term strategy. Analysts have long puzzled over why Ford, which has gained almost six points of market share since 1981, and now has 5 of the 10 top-selling vehicles in America, is not more profitable. One answer, the company indicated today, is that Ford is purchasing market share through its high marketing budget, which pays for rebates and other financial incentives for customers, like low lease rates.
"We have been spending at high levels, but we think the net benefit is clearly worth it," said David N. McCammon, Ford's vice president for finance and treasurer. "In the short run, with the economy weak and total overall demand having to be induced by a certain amount of marketing expense, we aren't making the sort of profits that we'd like to in the long run. But the opportunity to do that in the long run is enhanced."
Once the recovery gathers strength and the car and light-truck market swells to normal boom levels of more than 15 million vehicles a year, he said, Ford, which held 25.4 percent of the total American market for the 1993 model year, will be in a position to cash in.
 
 
The Cost of 'Safe Products'
 Already, Ford has lowered sales incentives on its vehicles. The average incentive for the third quarter was $865, compared with $1,065 in the period a year earlier, Mr. McCammon said. But he said marketing costs for the quarter were 11 percent of total revenue in North America, which works out to about $1.5 billion. When Ford was making big profits in the late 1980's, he said, marketing costs were closer to 6 percent.
Those high marketing costs worry some analysts. "Chrysler has products that people will pay full price for, but Ford ever since 1985 has been introducing safe products that people will buy if the price is right," said Ron Glantz, an analyst with Dean Witter in San Francisco.
In Europe, where Ford's new Mondeo sedan is drawing customers, losses declined slightly, and company officials said the slack European market may be improving.
Ford lost $217 million in Europe in the third quarter, compared with $285 million last year. Separately, Jaguar, the English luxury car builder owned by Ford, lost $108 million, compared with $135 million a year ago. Jaguar's loss included a $65 million charge against earnings for moving a sheet-metal-stamping operation.
Ford's finance arm, the Ford Motor Credit Company, reported record third-quarter earnings of $275 million, up 14 percent from $241 million a year earlier.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Cancellation of Sanctions Buoys Dollar Against Yen

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar rose against the Japanese yen yesterday as the currency markets focused on Japan's economic weakness and the Clinton Administration's cancellation of planned trade sanctions against Japan. The dollar finished mixed against other currencies.
In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 108.69 yen, up from 108.35 yen on Tuesday. 
 Gold edged higher. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for December delivery gained 40 cents, to $370.70 an ounce. The Republic National Bank of New York quoted the spot price of gold at $369.30 an ounce, unchanged from Tuesday.
The dollar's move against the yen yesterday "was largely a function of progress in U.S. trade talks," said David de Rosa, a Swiss Bank Corporation director in New York.
Mickey Kantor, President Clinton's trade representative, said on Tuesday that the United States would not impose sanctions against Japan next week as the Japanese authorities had agreed to open public-sector construction jobs to international bidding.
Currency traders said the yen had also been hurt by the tumbling Tokyo stock market. The Nikkei index of 225 issues closed below the 20,000 level for the first time since July 28. "The market is principally concerned about the economic weakness in Japan," said Belal Khan, a senior dealer at the New York branch of the Bank of Tokyo.
The yen had sharply risen against the dollar for much of this year on the market's perception that the Clinton Administration was pushing for a strong yen to reduce the trade deficit with Japan. A strengthened yen tends to make Japanese exports more expensive, and imports into Japan cheaper. The defusing, at least for now, of Japanese-American trade tensions is seen as a sign that any "strong yen" policy will not be pursued from Washington.
Most European currencies fluctuated in a narrow range against the dollar yesterday, as traders waited for today's report on the American gross domestic product for the third quarter. They said strong figures would push up the dollar's value, and further the impression that the United States economy is growing faster than most other major economies.
In New York, the dollar was quoted at 1.6810 German marks, up from 1.6805 marks on Tuesday.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Coffee Prices Rise Sharply On Market Moves by Brazil

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Coffee futures prices rallied strongly yesterday as Brazil, the world's largest producer, raised the money to buy beans and withhold them from the market.
In a double dose of supportive news, Brazil also announced that its October coffee exports were less than half of what traders had expected. 
 "It's a pretty bullish framework, especially when you consider that coffee is still at one of the lowest prices we've seen in the past 20 years," said Sandra Kaul, an analyst at Smith Barney Shearson Inc.
On the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in New York, green coffee beans for December delivery settled at 76.35 cents a pound, 1.65 cents above Tuesday's close and 2.65 cents above the day's low of 73.70 cents.
The market heated up late in the session as rumors spread that the Brazilian Government had secured financing to join other leading coffee-producing countries in a plan to withhold 20 percent of their planned October-June exports to bolster prices.
Brazil's absence from the withholding plan had driven coffee prices lower since Oct. 1, when the international price-support effort began.
Brazil confirmed the rumors after the close, saying it would buy 135,000 132-pound bags of coffee, possibly starting as early as tomorrow, to help meet the withholding quota for the month of October. That would mean Brazilian exports of less than 700,000 bags of coffee this month instead of the two million bags analysts had expected.
"That is more bullish than any story about Brazil going in and buying coffee," said Judy Ganes, an analyst at Merrill Lynch. But, she cautioned, "one month's figures aren't necessarily indicative of what's to come."
In other commodity trading, silver futures rose sharply. Silver for December delivery jumped 6.2 cents an ounce, to $4.469, on the Commodity Exchange in New York.
Some analysts attributed the strength to optimism about the economy fostered by a Government report that orders to American factories for big-ticket goods increased in September for the third time in four months.
Elsewhere, energy futures rose modestly on the New York Mercantile Exchange in quiet trading. Light crude oil for December delivery rose 11 cents, to $17.65 a barrel.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
The earnings gap grows, within professions and among them.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
IN 1990 the average take-home of the partners in the law firm of Cravath, Swaine & Moore exceeded the total salaries of all nine members of the Supreme Court. Chief executives of the Fortune 500 did pretty well that year, too, netting an average of $1.4 million -- roughly 40 times the average for public school teachers.
O.K., O.K, it is getting harder to work up a lather over such familiar outrages. But the source of these numbers, Derek Bok's new book, "The Cost of Talent," (The Free Press) offers more than a rehash of the old stuff. 
 Rather than focusing on the pay gap between the skilled and unskilled workers, the former president of Harvard and dean of its law school hones in on the divergence in pay among professionals, a subject just beginning to capture the attention of labor economists. And while Mr. Bok is better at describing the consequences than the cure, the phenomenon (and the book) are disturbing.
Wages, economists have been telling each other for decades, are determined by the value an extra worker can bring to the job. Thus if one more burger flipper adds $6 an hour to Wendy's revenues, while one more software engineer adds $30 an hour to Intel's, the software specialist will earn five times as much.
Simple as it sounds (and as hard to prove), marginal productivity theory is still more or less the state of the science of wage determination and income distribution. Indeed, virtually all the explanations for the current blue collar-white collar gap turn on this potent idea from classical economic theory.
But what seems to answer a question as old as Marx in comparing the lot of skilled workers with that of the proletariat does not hold up very well in explaining why, say, auto executives earn more than nuclear chemists. Nor does it touch the issue of why the earnings gaps within professions as well as among them have grown so much in the last two decades.
Mr. Bok, a lawyer who knows his economics, is happy to amplify. "We're talking about unique services," he argues, where there "is an imbalance of information between professionals and the people who employ them."
It is hard enough to figure whom to hire or what to pay them if the work is merely important -- say, tax accounting. It is even harder when the professional typically works as part of a group -- say, the second assistant to the director of personnel. And when it is a matter of life or death, the information vacuum looms as black as outer space. "Can you imagine someone looking for the lowest-cost heart surgeon, even if insurance didn't pay?" Mr. Bok asks.
One apparent consequence, which Robert Frank of Cornell and Philip Cook of Duke University have labeled the "winner take all" phenomenon, is a broadening of the star system beyond sports and entertainment that leads to an ever-smaller number of professionals grabbing an ever-increasing share of the pie. And it is apparently reinforced by the psychology of career choices that have much in common with the lure of high-stakes gambling: People make decisions about education and employment based on small chances of gigantic payoffs -- what they might earn if they, say, bat .320 for the Dodgers or become partners in Goldman, Sachs.
Mr. Bok raises the specter of deeper social and economic losses. One worry is that the most talented are systematically forsaking key professions, like teaching and government service, that do deliver personal security but never deliver a big financial hit. America, he notes, has more than twice as many lawyers as it did in 1970. And education majors who become career high school teachers have College Board scores a full hundred points below those who never teach at all.
Another worry is the loss of loyalty to employers, the bond beyond money that makes organizations more productive than a collection of individuals looking out for No. 1. Still another, is the "whole different feeling of leader to group": If the million-dollar boss is seen as merely the luckiest or most ruthless bee in the hive, capitalism is in trouble.
What to do? Mr. Bok is bearish on the idea that corporate directors can be galvanized to pay senior executives according to merit. "Look who appoints the corporate directors," he points out, "it's hardly a free market." In the end, Mr. Bok suggests, the only real solution is to persuade the culture to renounce the philosophy that he who dies with the most toys wins.
The other approach (embodied in this year's deficit reduction package) is to use government to handicap financial outcomes. While there is considerable skepticism about the capacity or desirability of taxing the super-successful more heavily, it remains the fix of choice for those who do not think there are other choices. "The world wouldn't collapse," allows Frank Levy of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, "if you increased taxes at the top."

HEADLINE: Essay;
Ally for Sale

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
She's intelligent, personable and articulate. Turkey's new Prime Minister, Tansu Ciller, an economist trained in the United States, wowed 'em on television and in private meetings here on her recent visit to America.
Unfortunately, the central message that she and her advisers brought to the White House was unworthy of the proud Turkish people. 
 It's this: The cutoff of the oil pipeline to Iraq, part of the world's sanctions on Saddam Hussein, is costing Turkey billions. Mrs. Ciller wants the U.S., as the chief Desert Stormer, to arrange to recompense Turkey for this cost.
Otherwise -- and here's the zinger that shows how little this Turkish Government understands alliances -- Turkey might just not extend its agreement to permit its airfields and supply routes to be used to protect and feed Iraqi Kurds in our Operation Provide Comfort.
Though not presented as a quid pro quo, the point was blunt: Pay us the money, and we let you keep on preventing Saddam Hussein from slaughtering the Kurds beginning to build an autonomous democracy on the dictator's land.
That goes beyond realpolitik to real blackmail. But an ally whose cooperation is for sale is available for alliance to a higher bidder, and other nations know that. Relationships that rely on immediate mutual back-scratching never become "special."
In her hard sell, the Turkish Prime Minister went further. Saddam, she told one and all, is growing more popular in Iraq day by day. The sanctions aren't working. She wants to do business with him, and never mind the regional threat.
President Clinton and his advisers did not express irritation at being presented with a big bill for continued parking in Turkish airports. That's because Turkey is the secular Muslim nation that stands in contrast to Iran's fanatic fundamentalism, and those two models are battling for the future of the Turkic-speaking nations along Russia's southern rim.
We need Turkey for a related reason: The Russian reformers are in danger of creating a Yeltsin-Grachev regime. The Russian President, in debt for his political existence to the chief of the armed forces, is letting the former Red Army reach into the former Soviet empire to re-establish Moscow's control, ostensibly to enforce order or to protect Russian "near-abroads."
Turkey's stability would be vital if Containment II comes to pass. But an alliance is a two-way street; Turkey's leaders are as worried as we are about a resurgence of Moscow imperialism.
Underlying Mrs. Ciller's programmed pleas for appeasement of Saddam is her own military's decision to escalate the crackdown on the P.K.K. -- terrorist Kurds in Turkey who demand instant independence.
One Turk in six is a Kurd; the great majority want to live as citizens of Turkey, free to express their Kurdish cultural heritage and speak their own language. But the shortsighted army leaders, by overreacting to the terrorists; by suppressing the Kurdish identity of all Turkish Kurds; by raiding Kurdish villages in Iraq while restraining hot pursuit of the P.K.K. in Syria, Iran or Armenia -- are making the classic mistake of driving moderates into the radical camp.
The democratically elected Prime Minister Ciller, mindful of past army takeovers, told me determinedly: "There will be no more coups in Turkey." Let's hope not; but as Kurds and their supporters see it, Ankara's military has already taken control of this Government's Kurdish policy. Mrs. Ciller's recent predecessors were harder for the Turkish Army leaders to push around.
Strange, how this ancient, homeless Kurdish people -- 20 million in a half-dozen countries -- is again at the nexus of geostrategy. The Turks worry that if the Iraqi Kurds build a democratic state, Turkish Kurds may want the same, so Turkey sends us an intolerable bill for helping save Iraqi Kurds from genocide.
Wrong. If Mrs. Ciller reverses course and helps Iraqi Kurds achieve prosperous autonomy -- and by so doing encourages their ethnic brethren to be loyal Kurdish Turks -- the first female Turkish Prime Minister will be remembered not as a clumsy ally-for-sale but as a new Ataturk.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

SECTION: Section B; Page 8; Column 1; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 1758 words

HEADLINE: Next Mayor Faces Expensive Challenges on Basic Services and Repairs

SERIES: Mayoral Agenda: 5. Infrastructure -- A periodic report on key issues facing the election winner.

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:

The Series So Far
Previous stories in the Mayoral Agenda series focused on the city budget, Sept. 27; social services, Oct. 2; crime, Oct. 11, and the economy, Oct. 18.
Whoever is elected mayor on Tuesday will face expensive problems that have yet to surface as major campaign issues. 
 They are the housekeeping questions: taking out the garbage, keeping the drinking water clean, fixing the bridges and improving the subways.
Mayor David N. Dinkins spoke last week before an audience of construction officials and said his administration had improved New York's infrastructure and would do more. But outside experts complain that neither candidate has sufficiently discussed issues that could involve the expenditure of hundreds of millions of taxpayer dollars and affect the quality of life of all New Yorkers.
On several issues, the men express similar views and differ only on pace and methodology. For instance, numerous subway improvements have been stalled over a decision by the Dinkins administration to withhold $100 million of the city's contribution to the needed construction. The administration isn't against the improvements; it simply contends that alternative financing sources exist. The camp of Mr. Dinkins's opponent, Rudolph W. Giuliani, says the money could be made available if the city's capital budget is reorganized.
Hardly the stuff of political drama, but important to hundreds of thousands of New Yorkers.
Here are details on some of the various infrastructure challenges that will face the next administration:
Intermittently, the city's bridges are falling apart. The last major closure was in July 1992, when engineers found a beam on the Manhattan Bridge that had rusted through and had to keep subway trains off while repairs were made. There are many smaller instances; last week engineers closed a ramp from Third Avenue to the Gowanus Expressway in Brooklyn.
City Hall said last month that 56.4 percent of the city's bridges are structurally deficient, which does not mean that they are unsafe but that they need repairs. The number in 1991 was 55 percent, and the projection for next year is 56.3 percent.
"We're doing component repair, fixing the part that's broken," said Lisa Daglian, a spokeswoman for the city's Department of Transportation. "While we're doing that, some of the older parts are wearing down."
That deterioration means that periodic closings are likely in the future and could have tremendous cost. The East River bridges have more than 1,000 maintenance items waiting, and the impact of a major failure could be staggering.
 
Repair Jobs Tripled
 Lucius J. Riccio, the Transportation Commissioner, said the city is making progress, tripling the number of bridge repair jobs undertaken in the last four years, compared with the prior four years. Painting, he said, is now on an 8- to 10-year cycle, rather than once very 30 to 40 years. But it will take time to show results, he said.
Samuel I. Schwartz was chief engineer and first deputy transportation commissioner for the city until 1990 and is now head of the Infrastructure Institute at Cooper Union. He said an independent study he commissioned while still with the city showed that the bridges could be kept in good maintenance for $150 million a year, much of it for simple things like paint. But currently, he said, the city spends far more, about $400 million, because it must replace rusted steel that was left unpainted.
"The painting program to a large extent has been halted because of the lead crisis," he said. "Any paint was good for the bridges. Graffiti were good. That's what protected us through the 1970's. Now it's fighting an uphill battle."
 
Finding a Place for Garbage
 New York is using up its space for garbage.
Once there were landfills in every borough, but now a fleet of barges carries almost all the city's household trash to Fresh Kills on Staten Island. That is a problem for two reasons.
Staten Island will probably vote in a referendum next month to pursue secession from New York City. City Hall's official position is that the city will not break up, and that even if it does, the remaining four boroughs will still own Fresh Kills. But privately they are less sure.
And whatever happens politically, Fresh Kills is approaching physical limits. If everything goes right, Fresh Kills could last until about 2030. That assumes that incinerators are built soon; recycling takes off, and the Federal Government continues to guarantee the interstate transportation of garbage and trash. It also assumes the garbage pile on Staten Island can be built as steep as the city plans, making it one of the highest peaks on the East Coast, three times the height of the Statue of Liberty.
On the other hand, if all those things go wrong, Fresh Kills could be full in 10 years, less than three mayoral elections away. If that were to happen, it is not clear where the city could dump its garbage locally.
 
The Recycling Program
 The Dinkins administration, with some dissent from environmentalists, says that recycling is going well. It is slogging toward building incinerators.
Mr. Giuliani says he believes that the city's recycling program could be improved. Earlier this week, he proposed a one-year moratorium on incineration, which some environmentalists believe creates dangerous air pollutants and ash disposal problems.
Emily Lloyd, the Commissioner of Sanitation, said that of cities with populations exceeding one million, only New York collects for recycling from all homes, requires recycling and enforces the rules, or regulates recycling of commercial wastes. New York is more successful at diverting material for recycling than any other big city, she said.
Mr. Giuliani's position, said his issues director, Mr. Schwartz, is that if the city ran the Department of Sanitation better and had a better contract with the sanitation union, more resources would be available to press forward with recycling, reducing the amount that has to be incinerated.
New York, almost alone among big cities, does not filter most of its water. But whether it can keep doing so is unclear.
The Federal Environmental Protection Agency wants all cities to filter their water, believing that step generally is necessary to meet Federal standards for drinking water.
Earlier this year, the E.P.A. gave New York a temporary exemption. It must rule again by the end of this year.
The Dinkins administration has argued that it will not need filtration if it can protect its large reservoirs in upstate New York by controlling activities in their 2,000-square-mile watersheds. The city would like to buy some parcels of land and enforce regulations on septic systems in other parts.
The city also could either order upstate communities to improve their sewage treatment plants -- as it is allowed to do under state laws -- or pay for the upgrading itself at a cost of hundreds of millions of dollars, a cost likely to be passed onto water rate-payers.
The alternative, according to city officials, is to spend up to $8 billion in building treatment plants, and then $300 million a year to run them. Federal officials think the price might be a lot lower. But the plants are not capable of filtering out certain chemicals, like oil, that can only be kept out by watershed protection.
While this is a decision to be made by Federal officials, not the next Mayor, the vigor and skill with which watershed protection is pursued will probably influence the outcome. Mr. Giuliani's campaign says the Dinkins approach is correct, but that it got off to a late start and is not moving fast enough.
 
Repairing the Subways
 Earlier this year the State Legislature approved a $9.6 billion, five-year capital program for the city's subways, but then the city announced that it was reducing its contribution from $205 million a year to $105 million. The city said that the difference would be made up by money from the Municipal Assistance Corporation, but the Metropolitan Transportation Authority said that it is already counting on that money, and that the result of the city's decision would be to cut the budget by half a billion dollars.
In May, the transportation authority said that as a result it would defer rebuilding 28 subway stations, including the one on the C and D lines at 161st Street in the Bronx that serves Yankee Stadium; the IND 50th Street/Rockefeller Center station, the 72d Street IRT station, and most of the Times Square station in Manhattan, the Queensboro Plaza station and the Main Street station in Flushing, Queens, and six stations on Staten Island.
Reconstruction of the Franklin Avenue shuttle was also deferred, as were design work on the Second Avenue subway and work on transit police district offices and subway repair shops.
The deferral of work raises some safety issues -- for instance, the Oct. 7 subway collision in Brooklyn, blamed on motorman error, possibly would not have happened with an automated signal system. But another concern is the need to combat a general sense of deterioration.
 
'Gateways to Service'
 Alan F. Kiepper, president of the Transit Authority, said in a letter to the chairman of the transportation authority in May, "We find these setbacks most unfortunate because the station environments represent our 'gateways to service,' in that they present our customers with both their first and last impressions of our system."
Joseph G. Rappaport of the Straphangers Campaign, a riders' advocacy group, was more blunt. "You'll see all sorts of stations that desperately need attention continue to decay," he said. "Some stations that need better lighting to fight crime will continue to be dim."
"You've got to have a revived transit system to make the city work," he said.
Mr. Giuliani supports restoring the $100 million a year, according to Mr. Schwartz, who said the money would be available if the city's capital program could be reorganized, with changes in state law to allow more efficient contracting on city projects.
First Deputy Mayor Norman Steisel said the money the city had intended to use for capital was taken instead by the State Legislature for holding down the fare. The city has been cheated out of bridge toll revenues and surpluses accumulated by suburban rail lines, he said.
Whatever the financing problems, a solution would probably be appreciated by city residents. "Dinkins and Giuliani don't see how sexy fixing up a subway station can be," Mr. Rappaport said.

HEADLINE: FLURRY OF ATTACKS AS RACE FOR MAYOR IS NEARING AN END

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
A visit from the President, a flurry of broadcast appearances and saturation-strength television commercials propelled the New York City mayoral campaign toward its final weekend yesterday as Mayor David N. Dinkins rolled into high-geared attack and Rudolph W. Giuliani made more tempered appeals to liberal swing voters.
With polls showing the race too close to call but voters' unfavorable impressions of Mr. Giuliani edging upward from the Mayor's past broadsides, Mr. Dinkins unleashed his harshest commercial of the campaign, using footage of Mr. Giuliani's epithet-spiked speech to a rowdy police rally near City Hall last year and condemning him for excessive zeal as United States Attorney in Manhattan. 
 For his part, Mr. Giuliani mixed apparent confidence with the acknowledgment that his voter support seems to suffer when he is too much on the offensive, and he steered away from direct attacks on Mr. Dinkins.
 
A Giuliani Endorsement
 Mr. Giuliani's new ads feature an endorsement from the Rev. Dr. John E. Brandon, a Harlem minister and former head of the city's Human Rights Commission, who says the Republican-Liberal nominee "will bring us together around the issues of the economy, supporting small businesses and lifting people out of poverty" and "will be fair with everybody, bringing people together and not separating them."
In an appearance on WCBS-TV last night, Mr. Giuliani took some pains to soften his earlier suggestion that the city should try to bar Louis Farrakhan from speaking at Yankee Stadium -- a stance that was considered to have hurt him with liberals. The program was to have been a debate, but Mr. Dinkins skipped it because the station refused to include the Conservative Party candidate, George J. Marlin, as the Mayor wished. [Page B2.]
 
A Postponed Appearance
 "He has a right, unfortunately, from the point of view of the sensibilities of people, but fortunately for the First Amendment, he has a right to express that viewpoint," Mr. Giuliani said of Mr. Farrakhan's appearance, originally proposed for this weekend but since postponed. "And I would protect Farrakhan to the same extent as I'd protect someone that I agree with."
In reminding New York voters of Mr. Giuliani's speech at the police rally, Mr. Dinkins used an issue that politicians had been predicting he would invoke, suggesting that the Mayor intends to leave no hot button unpushed between now and Election Day.
He also began broadcasting another ad repeating past criticisms of Mr. Giuliani for once opposing abortion rights before unequivocally backing them four years ago, and painting the Republican-Liberal candidate's proposals for reshaping city government as cold-hearted. A third commercial cites the endorsement of the Mayor by newspapers ranging from The Village Voice to The Forward, a newspaper aimed at Jewish readers.
Together, the Mayor's twilight rally with President Clinton at a Queens union hall, an emotional gathering with the Rev. Jesse Jackson, former Mayor Andrew Young of Atlanta and other members of the clergy at City Hall, new endorsements and street stumping in which each candidate sniped at the other from a distance marked the beginning of the end of their long battle.
"It's easier to be a good President for New York City and New York State if you have a good partner in City Hall and the statehouse," Mr. Clinton told a cheering crowd of 800 unionists and Democrats at the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers hall in Flushing in his second visit there of this campaign.
Referring to the procession of national Democrats who have endorsed the Mayor, he said: "We may not have the vote in New York, but we have a stake in New York. How can America do well if New York State and New York City don't do well?"
The Mayor, speaking in an unusually blunt and forceful style, again framed the contest as a partisan battle royal, insisting that "it's time to turn back the broken politics of blame and shame, of code words and cold indifference."
Later, in an hourlong appearance of his own on WCBS-AM radio, the Mayor defended his insistence on including Mr. Marlin in the debates, saying, "There's not a question Rudy Giuliani could dream up that would measure up to the superior questions from the press corps that I've faced for four years."
Mr. Giuliani, campaigning at a center for the elderly in Astoria and other stops in Queens, dismissed Mr. Dinkins's gaining of support from the President and celebrities like Barbra Streisand, saying, "He's got to go Hollywood because he's in very bad shape."
But perhaps none of the activity was more intense or potentially influential than the candidates' new commercials, which are now on the air so often that an average viewer will see each of the three Dinkins ads three times. The Giuliani ads include one with him talking with minority students at Bishop Loughlin Memorial High School in Brooklyn, his alma mater.
 
Raising Questions
 Campaign officials said Mr. Dinkins planned to spend about half a million dollars on television time between now and Tuesday, and Mr. Giuliani somewhat more, though neither camp would disclose precise figures.
Robert Shrum, a mayoral media adviser, said the new ads raised more questions about Mr. Giuliani's record, in keeping with the campaign's longstanding strategy.
"We take nothing for granted; we have never intended to take anything for granted," he said. "We're simply showing Mr. Giuliani and how he has behaved in some times when he was under pressure. His entire campaign has turned into an apology for his past record, of saying, 'I didn't quite do it that way.' In fact, I think his explanations have never helped him much."
 
Viewed as Distortion
 Mr. Giuliani countered that the Dinkins ads -- especially one that claims he has proposed "city job cuts that would decimate services for senior citizens" -- grossly distorted his views and that the Mayor himself had initially proposed cuts in programs for the elderly earlier this year.
"In the last days of the campaign, unfortunately in this campaign even in the early days, sometimes when people get desperate they spread a lot of false rumors and they try to frighten people," Mr. Giuliani said.
Seeking to counter the potential impact of former Mayor Edward I. Koch's endorsement of Mr. Giuliani, nearly a dozen former city officials who served under Mr. Koch came to City Hall yesterday to endorse Mr. Dinkins. One who did not come but was listed as a Dinkins supporter was Bess Myerson, the former Miss America and friend of Mr. Koch, whom Mr. Giuliani unsucessfully prosecuted on charges of trying to improperly influence the judge presiding over her lover's divorce.
 
A Difficult Job
 "The Dinkins mayoralty now clearly exhibits the seasoned strength needed to lead us," said Nathan Leventhal, the president of Lincoln Center who was a deputy mayor under Mr. Koch and director of Mr. Dinkins's transition to office four years ago. "Having served in government, we know how difficult the job can be," he said.
Others who spoke included Benjamin Ward, the former police commissioner, who criticized Mr. Giuliani for his participation in the raucous demonstration by the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association.
"The police brass and most of the police in this city are still embarrassed by what went on on these steps," he said. "And we know it will take perhaps several years for us to get over the reputation that the police union with the help of Rudy Giuliani caused. It put us in a bad light in police circles all over the country."

HEADLINE: His Brain 'Aching,' Clinton Tries A Soft Touch to Push Health Plan

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL

 BODY:
A day after delivering his health care proposal to Congress, President Clinton yesterday moved to humanize the complicated universal health insurance plan that he said he had studied "until my brain aches."
Setting aside the fist-pounding oratory that he used in his address to Congressional leaders on Wednesday, Mr. Clinton adopted a confessional tone. Instead of trolling for votes from potentially skeptical lawmakers, Mr. Clinton used his public appearances to shore up the base of popular support for his plan. 
 In his address to an audience of dignitaries, medical students, professors and administrators at Johns Hopkins University in Baltimore, Mr. Clinton emphasized his roots as the son of a nurse from a rural region of the country and his wife's longtime interest in children's health. And he described his effort as a personal battle to restructure a health care system that he said "Rube Goldberg in his wildest dreams could not have designed."
 
'Enormous Ramifications'
 "This is a human problem," Mr. Clinton said. "But you must understand that it has enormous ramifications for all the other aspects of your nation's life."
In a speech in Manhattan last night to business executives, Mr. Clinton also stressed the need for building public support for the North American Free Trade Agreemtn. The President called for the executives to ask their employees to persuade members of Congress to support the pact as well.
In his speech to the business leaders' conference, sponsored by The Wall Street Journal at the Waldorf-Astoria, Mr. Clinton said many wavering Democrats could be persuaded to support the pact -- if they could be convinced that the vote would not be unpopular with their constituents.
"I think if there were no recorded votes we could ratify Nafta tomorrow," Mr. Clinton said.
A lot of members on the fence "just want some other real voters to tell them to vote for it," the President said.
After several weeks in which troublesome foreign affairs have dominated his time, Mr. Clinton today happily returned to his domestic agenda.
 
Ovations for Mrs. Clinton
 Hillary Rodham Clinton, who joined her husband on the trip, received two standing ovations in Baltimore before she even spoke. She said the plan, which she had a major role in shaping, is intended "to preserve what is right and works about the American health care system, but, finally, to fix what is wrong."
The White House had been searching for a receptive audience to address once Mr. Clinton came up with the polished version of his health care plan. Johns Hopkins was apparently chosen because Mrs. Clinton was warmly received there last June, when she spoke about health care costs.
 
Violence and Health Care
 The location was also chosen to allow Mr. Clinton to drive home the theme he has been promoting recently, linking efforts to control crime and violence with health care. The East Baltimore campus of the university's medical school is home to an overburdened emergency room that treats many victims of violent crime.
"We have some group behaviors in this country that are imposing intolerable burdens on the health care system," Mr. Clinton said. "We must recognize every time another kid takes another assault weapon onto another dark street and commits another random drive-by shooting and sends another child to the Johns Hopkins emergency room, that adds to the cost of health care."
"It is a human tragedy," Mr. Clinton added. "It is also the dumbest thing that we can permit to continue to go on for our long-term economic growth."
On the trade agreement, Mr. Clinton renewed a theme he has spent several weeks developing, arguing that those who oppose the pact were worried about the jobs they had already lost rather than any jobs that would be lost in the future.
 
'Flypaper' for Emotions
 The agreement, which would lower trade barriers between the United States, Canada and Mexico, could succeed if disgruntled Americans who are worried about their futures can be convinced that the Federal Government will follow through on its promise to retrain workers for other work, he said.
The opposition to the pact is fueled by the profound sense of insecurity the last few years of recession have given the American worker, he said.
"What happened today in America is we have a whole lot of people who have dealt with this, not very well, who feel that they have worked hard and played by the rules, and who now are the seedbed of resentment welling up against Nafta," he said. "Not because of anything that's in Nafta, but because it is the flypaper that's catching all the emotions."
The first Congressional votes on the trade pact are scheduled for Nov. 17.
