HEADLINE: Trade Pact Passage May Hinge on Mexican Sugar

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Oct. 28

 BODY:
After years of discussion, the prospects for free trade in North America may hinge on this arcane question: Will Mexicans decide to sweeten their soft drinks with corn syrup instead of sugar, and then try to export the extra sugar north?
As the United States Congress prepares to vote on the North American Free Trade Agreement next month, Mexico is coming under heavy pressure from American lobbyists, legislators and Government officials to promise in writing that the sugar will not be shipped north. 
 In the balance are a dozen or more members of the House of Representatives who might then be willing to vote for the agreement, possibly insuring its passage.
Mexican soft-drink makers dismiss as unfounded the fears among American sugar producers that, like their counterparts in the United States and other countries, the Mexicans might switch to so-called high fructose sweeteners.
 
No Renegotiation, Mexico Says
 Soft-drink makers in Mexico say that the country's famous sweet tooth is likely to prove more powerful than the incentive they might have to turn from costly refined sugar to the less expensive corn sweeteners.
American sugar producers say, however, that such a switch would enable Mexico to flood the highly protected United States sugar market with the sugar it had left over.
The Government of President Carlos Salinas de Gortari says it would be unthinkable to renegotiate the trade deal it reached with the United States and Canada more than a year ago. But with the fight over the accord shaping up as a vote-by-vote struggle in which the Clinton Administration admittedly remains behind, some Congressional leaders say a Mexican compromise on the issue could be crucial.
"There are more votes that would come to the agreement if we could do something about sugar than all the other issues combined," said Representative Jim Kolbe, an Arizona Republican who is a leading supporter of the agreement.
Supporters of the agreement say they do not yet have the 218 votes they need to win its passage. Officials say at least 12 members from Northern states that grow sugar beets and Southern states that grow sugar cane might support the pact if the sugar issue is resolved in their favor.
 
Side Deal Called Possible
 The tussle illustrates how the agreement's fortunes are depending on last-minute deals among lawmakers. Another such deal was made on Wednesday, for instance, when Mexican and American officials announced the creation of a special development bank for small business and other projects along the border to obtain the vote of Representative Esteban E. Torres, the California Democrat who has been pushing for the bank.
Proponents of that deal now hope that Mr. Torres can deliver half a dozen votes for the accord.
Two Mexican officials said that despite their Government's tough public stance against the possibility of revising the agreement, some sort of side deal on sugar might well be in the offing. "You are not going to see it for another couple of weeks, but we are not going to lose everything because of a little problem of sugar," one said.
 
Fears of More Demands
 The danger that Mexican and United States officials see in such a compromise is that it would encourage demands for changes by other American industries that fear Mexican imports, including citrus growers, glass producers and appliance manufacturers.
But the political muscle of American sugar beet and sugar cane producers is legendary, since they have preserved sharp limits on foreign imports that keep American sugar prices high.
Under the terms of the trade accord, the quota of 7,258 metric tons of sugar that Mexico is now allowed to export to the United States would rise to 25,000 tons six years after of the pact goes into effect. The quota would disappear entirely after 15 years.
But the accord says that if Mexico can produce more sugar than it consumes for two consecutive years, it can start shipping as much sugar to the United States as it wants as quickly as seven years after the agreement takes effect.
A wholesale switch to corn sweeteners in Mexican soft drinks would mean under the current terms that Mexico could ship as much sugar north as now enters the United States from the entire rest of the sugar-producing world.
According to a study last fall by the United States Department of Agriculture, the Mexican soft-drink industry used 1.3 million metric tons of sugar in 1991, and the amount continues to grow. The United States sugar quota for all foreign imports this year was 1.2 million metric tons.
In a letter on Tuesday, Senator John B. Breaux, a Louisiana Democrat who is a leader in the Congress on sugar matters, urged Mr. Salinas to accept a formal "clarification" of the trade pact so that Mexico could not export sugar to the United States without actually producing more than it now uses.
And at a meeting with Senator Breaux and House leaders on Friday, at least a dozen representatives indicated that they might vote for the trade pact if such a clarification were made, three people familiar with what happened at the meeting said.
For the moment, Mexico's sugar industry does not appear to be much of a match in the political maneuvering for its American counterpart.
Nearly four years after the Government began selling off its network of sugar mills to private investors, many of the operations are still antiquated and inefficient. Mexico's own sugar imports declined after a bumper harvest this year. But they are expected to rise again next year as stocks are depleted, and to continue rising as the domestic sugar market grows.
Many of the privatized mills went to soft-drink bottlers. That ownership and Mexicans' taste for things sugary, officials say, make it unlikely that soft-drink companies will switch from sugar anytime soon. Mexican soft-drink bottlers generally agree, even though the high-fructose corn sweeteners will get less expensive as the Mexican tariffs on them fall under another provision of the trade pact.
 
Experimenting With Raw Sugar
 In an interview today, Weldon H. Johnson, the president of the Coca-Cola's Latin American Group, said the company's Mexican bottlers were experimenting with a possible switch. But he said it would be from refined sugar to treated raw sugar.
"Our analysis shows that treated raw sugar has the same economics as the high-fructose corn syrup everyone is talking about," he said.
Yet while Mexico agreed in the trade pact to other demands of the American sugar lobby -- most important, Mexico will raise its wholesale sugar prices to American levels -- one Mexican negotiator who spoke on the condition he not be identified said Mexico had fought to keep corn syrup out of the equation. He said that this was done to leave open the possibility that Mexico could export any surplus arising from a switch to corn syrup and that at least one Mexican bottler had explored such a move.

HEADLINE: Pentagon Plans Shift in War on Drug Traffickers

BYLINE: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER

 BODY:
The Defense Department announced a modest shift yesterday away from its ineffective and heavily criticized attempts at intercepting drugs to a greater emphasis on helping countries in Latin America attack the major drug trafficking organizations. But drug experts said the change was likely to have little effect on the flow of illegal drugs into the United States.
Brian E. Sheridan, the Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense for Drug Enforcement Policy and Support, said the military planned to cut spending on the interception of drugs, which now accounts for 71 percent of its $1.17 billion anti-drug budget, by 6 to 11 percentage points. It intends to increase spending on training and equipment for countries that grow, refine and export illegal drugs to 16 percent, up by 5 percentage points. 
 The biggest impact on the military's anti-drug programs, which have repeatedly been criticized in Congress and by independent drug experts as among the country's most expensive and least effective anti-drug efforts, is being brought about by Congress.
Pentagon officials said Congress was likely to cut the overall military anti-drug budget by as much as $250 million, or nearly double what the Pentagon had recommended after an internal review.
Some drug experts said the Pentagon shift represented little change from that of the Bush Administration and pointed out that in making the announcement today, the Clinton Administration failed to address the main issue of debate: how much of the proposed $13.1 billion annual drug budget should be devoted to law enforcement and how much to rehabilitation and other health measures.
The Clinton Administration's budget allocates about 65 percent to law enforcement and 35 percent to health measures, or about the same as the last Bush budget. Members of Congress and many drug experts have been urging a substantial increase for treatment, and some have suggested a 50-50 split.
The Administration issued a national drug strategy last week that emphasized health issues. But the strategy was widely criticized by Democrats as well as Republicans and independent experts for not giving any indication of how spending would be apportioned.
Drug experts questioned the fundamental direction of the Pentagon's shift, saying corruption and a lack of enthusiasm for tackling the drug problem in some Latin American countries made putting more money into them an extremely questionable enterprise.
Colombia has been the most cooperative by far in helping the United States achieve its goals in Latin America, they said, and it has focused almost entirely on quelling the domestic violence of drug gangs rather than on trying to destroy their ability to produce and ship drugs.
"They're taking money out of interdiction, which is good" said Peter Reuter, the director of drug policy research at the Rand Corporation. "But they're moving it to an area that I think is even less promising: helping governments that don't want to be helped."
Mr. Reuter characterized the Pentagon's changes as "minor programmatic changes of the kind that go on every year without pronouncement."
 
Futile but Morally Essential
 Rensselaer Lee 3d, a consultant on international drug issues and the author of "White Labyrinth: Cocaine and Political Power," said he regarded attempts at fighting drugs abroad and at intercepting drug shipments as futile but morally essential. "We have to show that we care, that we're taking a stand," he said.
Mr. Sheridan said the assistance to Latin American countries would probably include increases in the number of United States Army Special Forces training teams and perhaps more radar equipment to help the countries track smugglers' planes. Drug Enforcement Administration officials say the radar sites are ineffective and should be shut down.
Mr. Sheridan said the Pentagon also planned to provide more intelligence information to the Latin American governments and to step up assistance in planning anti-drug investigations and raids. He emphasized that American forces would not be accompanying Latin American police and military units on operations.
To cope with a reduced total budget of $900 million to $950 million, Mr. Sheridan said the Defense Department was replacing some of its larger warships -- cruisers and destroyers -- on patrol in the Caribbean with smaller vessels that had been used to monitor Soviet submarines.

HEADLINE: A Verdict on Kevorkian: Their Kind of Neighbor

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ROYAL OAK, Mich., Oct. 27

 BODY:
Most everyone here in his hometown seems to like the man they call Dr. Death, Jack Kevorkian, the thoughtful, neighborly retired pathologist.
He got the nickname decades ago as an iconoclastic medical resident interested in unusual experimentation. But its current connotation of necromantic celebrity is rooted in his more recent mercy-suicide crusade, which, his neighbors are noting, he dared to bring right into his own small walk-up apartment last week in helping a sick and agonized woman from Ann Arbor kill herself right there, next to Mr. B's Pub on South Main Street. 
 "I'm definitely for it, but we have to discuss this issue better," said Carroll Harris, the concerned manager of Mr. B's busy, yuppie restaurant scene, who watched the coroner's workers carry out 72-year-old Merian R. Frederick in a body bag, the 19th suffering patient to be assisted to die by Dr. Kevorkian since 1990. "We shouldn't have a woman who goes into his apartment to die with a million reporters around the building. She could have died in a hospital with dignity."
Other neighbors, even in fondly supporting the 65-year-old ascetically styled doctor, complain of his "bizarre" flair for lethal Rube Goldberg devices and for sometimes seedy surroundings in his one-man crusade, particularly the 20-year-old Volkswagen van used as the site for fatal events until it was seized as evidence.
 
No Debating the Dignity
 But inside Dr. Kevorkian's simple apartment last week, there was no debating the dignity of the event of Mrs. Frederick's parting in the eyes of the Rev. Ken Phifer, who knew her well across 14 years and counseled and supported her in her final decision, attending his parishioner to the end.
"My experience is when people have reached a certain point of desperation, the surroundings are of no moment at all to them; they matter only to survivors," he said, describing a long and painful siege of neural degeneration suffered by Mrs. Frederick, his friend and parish leader at the First Unitarian Universalist Church of Ann Arbor.
Without disclosing details of the case, subject now to criminal investigation, the minister stressed that Dr. Kevorkian had supplied merely a "technical dimension" to the woman's own careful, heartfelt spiritual decision that, deprived of speech and mobility by the painful Lou Gehrig's disease, she could choose to end her life.
 
Not Subtle Enough?
 Here on South Main Street, Dr. Kevorkian is described as a simple, friendly figure of a neighbor and a visionary of sorts. His style is more debated than is his goal of suicide assistance.
"He kind of rubs it in your face," said Jesse Cundiff, a sympathizer nonetheless and a 53-year native of this Detroit suburb, where a boom of youth-focused economic resurgence has made it California-looking with cappuccino bars and boutiques along South Main Street. This coincidental touch of Bohemia does little harm to Dr. Kevorkian's pursuit of his cause in the name of evolutionary self-determination.
"But if he would be kind of subtle, I don't think he would have all this trouble," Mr. Cundiff said of pending charges and investigations. It is a legal mare's nest in which prosecutors in the adjoining jurisdictions of Wayne and Oakland Counties are proceeding, respectively, with considerable philosophical reservation in some killings and decided zeal in others, under a new state law tailored by frustrated, perplexed critics to stop Dr. Kevorkian. The new law forbids physician-assisted suicide and provides for a four-year prison term.
With at least three cases pending under the new law, the suicide crusader, whose medical license has already been revoked, seems finally heading for some climactic court confrontation and possible jail time, perhaps within days. Characteristically, he is welcoming this as a new chance to dramatize his cause.
 
Critics See Quirks
 "This is what I have waited for," he exulted at this possible climax after Mrs. Frederick's death. He has since fallen silent as his lawyer, Geoffrey N. Fieger, pursues court stratagems.
As they attempt to bring him to ground, critics contend there has long been a quirkiness to Dr. Kevorkian's career. They focus on some of his earlier proposals to do medical experiments on condemned prisoners at the time of execution, to see widespread transplant of their organs and to make use of fresh cadaver blood on the battlefield. But Dr. Kevorkian's many friends here mark him as one of a kind and right on course in a crusade that reflects his own taste for nonconformity amid life's impingements.
"We all love him at the library," said Lori Boden, a worker at the Royal Oak public library that Dr. Kevorkian frequents a block east of his apartment.
She said the memory of the death agony of her own mother to leukemia, with conventional medical techniques at a loss to help, made a mockery of the criticism of the doctor's unconventionality.
 
Survivors Are Grateful
 Survivors of the people Dr. Kevorkian assisted echo this, saying the only dignity worth anything to a dying person is the retention of volition, however terminal, and the cessation of pointless agony. "Jack is very aware of people's status, their suffering and dignity," insisted Heidi Fernandez, whose fiance, Thomas Hyde, died with Dr. Kevorkian's assistance in August after he was rapidly muted to a life of paralysis and pain by Lou Gehrig's disease.
"I loved Tom so, and didn't want him to go," Ms. Fernandez said. "But when the writing's on the wall, if someone makes a decision to end a life of pain and suffering, I don't see what the big problem is."
Opinion polls suggest that almost two-thirds of the public might accept well-regulated physician-assisted suicide. "Yeah, but I think there's an element of 'yes, but not in my town,' " said Donald J. Walby, the owner of a local paint store who likes his neighbor, Dr. Kevorkian, but does not appreciate the notoriety he brings to Royal Oak.
"Having the latest one die right upstairs in his own apartment -- that was really pressing the issue," said Mr. Walby, who has been in business since 1936 and readily admits personal affection for Dr. Kevorkian.
 
Doesn't Mind the Jokes
 Friends say Dr. Kevorkian is plain enough to enjoy some of the many jokes about his grim dealings. "He laughed when I told him about the Dr. Kevorkian doll," said Dawn Haselhuhn, founder of a group of local supporters she says can gather by the scores at a moment's notice to counter-balance outside protesters. "You pull the doll's string and it passes gas to you," Ms. Haselhuhn said, referring to Dr. Kevorkian's relying lately on carbon monoxide inhalation devices as his terminal technique.
Ms. Fernandez, who made the issue her own public advocacy cause after the death of Mr. Hyde, her fiance, said Dr. Kevorkian was embarrassed when she praised him "as the Thomas Edison of medicine." He once described himself thusly: "When they call me a pioneer they're wrong. I'm a person at the right time when the mores are changing."
Proponents are pleading with society to look beyond the immediate circumstances of his style and focus on the principle he is raising. "Look, every time I think of wheeling my Tom up to that crusty old V.W. van of Jack's, I could croak," Ms. Fernandez said, recalling the death of her man inside the tattered vehicle. 'But I still know that it doesn't detract one bit from the final peace Tom sought and got with Jack's help."

Frederick, 72, from Jack Kevorkian's home next door. (Peter Yates for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: ISRAEL SEEKS DEAL WITH QATAR ON GAS

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, Oct. 28

 BODY:
Israeli officials say they have held secret negotiations with the tiny Persian Gulf emirate of Qatar on a multibillion-dollar project to bring natural gas to Israel and then export it across the Mediterranean to Europe.
The officials say they could sign an agreement by early December. But Qatar's Oil Minister denied today that a deal was in the making, calling reports of an imminent breakthrough "unrealistic and based on illogical assumption." The Qatari news agency quoted him as saying economic relations are not possible while the Arab boycott against Israel remains intact. 
 While it was not clear through the thicket of contradictory statements whether a deal was on or off, there was little doubt that the Israelis have had contacts with representatives of a land that, like most Arab countries, had been off-limits to them for decades.
Foreign Minister Shimon Peres met secretly with his Qatari counterpart in New York last month, and several weeks ago an official from Mr. Peres's ministry went to Qatar to discuss economic and political relations. In addition, Energy Minister Moshe Shahal is reported to have met in Israel with a group of Qatari energy specialists and businessmen, one of three such delegations that came here last month.
 
Contacts With Arabs Expand
 Israel's contacts with the Muslim world in general have expanded in the six weeks since it signed an agreement with the Palestine Liberation Organization on introducing Palestinian self-rule to the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. Right after the signing ceremony, Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin made the first public visit by an Israeli leader to Morocco, and two weeks ago he capped a trip to China with a surprise stopover in Indonesia, the most populous Muslim country. That same week, Deputy Foreign Minister Yossi Beilin became the highest-ranking Israeli official to visit Tunisia.
While none of those contacts have led to formal relations, they suggest to Israeli officials that genuine change is in the air and that diplomatic and business links with Arab countries, once unthinkable, are now at least imaginable and perhaps within reach.
The project under discussion with Qatar, the Israelis say, would involve shipping liquefied natural gas in tankers from the Persian Gulf to the southern Israeli port of Eilat, on the Gulf of Aqaba. Gas would then be carried by a still-to-be-built pipeline from Eilat to an Israeli port on the Mediterranean, either Ashdod or Ashkelon, and from there much of it would be exported to Europe by way of still another pipeline that would be constructed under the Mediterranean to Greece.
The fate of the project, officials here say, depends on feasibility studies that are in progress and that they say are being paid for by Qatar, whose 250,000 people have one of the world's highest per capita incomes because of oil and gas revenues.
Mr. Shahal said several days ago that Israel would soon sign a natural-gas contract with a Persian Gulf country. He did not identify the country, but other officials said that it was Qatar and that an agreement was expected by the first week or two of December. They put the cost of the project at $2 billion or more, and said it would supply Israel with gas for 25 years.
 
Effect of Remarks Feared
 After Mr. Shahal spoke out on Israel's negotiations in the Persian Gulf, other officials here expressed concern that his public remarks may have killed the hoped-for deal with Qatar. An article today in the newspaper Yediot Ahronot said that, indeed, the Qataris had gone back on their intention to sign an agreement.
But the remarks attributed to the Qatari Oil Minister, Abdallah Bin Hamad Alattiya, suggested that a joint venture with Israel was never realistic. Other Arab oil officials also dismissed the project as prohibitively expensive and improbable both technically and politically, given Qatar's size and need to follow the lead of much larger gulf governments like Saudi Arabia and Iran.
"It's one of these euphoric thoughts that went along with the making of the peace process in the Middle East, not a real project," said an Arab oil minister who did not want to be identified.
Despite these demurrals, Israeli officials insisted that the project was real and could still be carried out.

HEADLINE: Trial Begins in Berlin for Iranian Charged in Dissident's Death

BYLINE: By STEPHEN KINZER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BERLIN, Oct. 28

 BODY:
A reputed agent of the Iranian secret police and four accused accomplices went on trial today for the murder of a leading Iranian dissident last year.
Federal prosecutors say Iran ordered the killing of the dissident, Sadegh Sharafkandi, who with three aides was cut down in a hail of gunfire at a Berlin restaurant. A guilty verdict would be a triumph for political and human rights groups that have charged Iran with sponsoring an international terror campaign against its opponents. 
 Since 1987, more than a dozen opponents of the Iranian Government have been murdered in European cities. The trial that opened in Berlin today was the first case in which alleged killers have been charged with having acted on orders from Teheran.
Iran has denied involvement in the killings.
The trial opened against the background of growing controversy over a visit by the chief of the Iranian secret service, Ali Fallahian, to Bonn this month. American and British officials publicly criticized Germany for receiving Mr. Fallahian, and several members of Parliament are demanding an investigation of contacts between the German and Iranian secret services.
 
Predecessor Also Slain
 In the trial that opened today, prosecutors have accused Kazem Darabi, a 34-year-old Iranian who has lived in Berlin since 1980, of hiring four Lebanese to help him kill Mr. Sharafkandi, who was secretary general of the Iranian Democratic Party of Kurdistan. Mr. Sharafkandi's predecessor was shot to death in Vienna in 1989.
The case had already attracted international attention because of prosecutors' efforts to link the killers directly to the Iranian Government, but it took another twist with Mr. Fallahian's arrival in Bonn three weeks ago. He was received there by Chancellor Helmut Kohl's principal adviser on secret services, Bernd Schmidbauer.
Their meeting provoked a series of angry newspaper editorials and speeches by members of Parliament, as well as unusually direct criticism from Washington and London. Critics said that Germany seemed to be negotiating with a man widely viewed as a dangerous world terrorist.
According to reports in the German press, Mr. Fallahian and Mr. Schmidbauer may have discussed a deal under which the accused killers now on trial in Berlin would be freed or given lenient treatment. In exchange, the Iranians were said to have offered to free several Germans being held in Iran.
 
Israeli Flier Also Mentioned
 Some accounts said Mr. Fallahian had also raised the possibility of releasing Ron Arad, an Israeli air force navigator believed to be held by pro-Iranian forces in Lebanon, and lifting the death sentence issued by Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini and confirmed by the present Iranian Government against the novelist Salman Rushdie.
Upon his return to Teheran, according to the Iranian news agency IRNA, Mr. Fallahian expressed "satisfaction on the current information cooperation between Iran and Germany." Two days later, a leading German businessman in Iran, Gerhard Bachmann, was arrested and charged with espionage and other crimes.
At a news conference in Bonn today, members of the German and European Parliaments called for Mr. Schmidbauer's resignation. They said his meeting with Mr. Fallahian violated a European Community ruling that no member should improve its ties to Iran until the death sentence against Mr. Rushdie was lifted.
 
Criticism Rebuffed
 Mr. Schmidbauer, who visited Iran last year, has refused to give details of his meeting with Mr. Fallahian.
"The Government intends to continue holding humanitarian talks with Iran within the framework of a critical exchange of opinions, despite unjustified criticism," Mr. Schmidbauer said. He said Iran "wants to cooperate with Germany on disarmament and against drug trafficking and terrorism."
A senior federal law enforcement official, Volker Foertsch, last week confirmed reports that the German and Iranian secret services had cooperated in the past.
Germany is by far Iran's largest trading partner. German companies sold more than $5 billion worth of goods and services in Iran last year, and the Government has sought to maintain good ties with Iranian leaders.
"The mullahs have identified Germany as the weak member of the Western alliance," asserted Jamshid Watandoust, an Iranian exile leader who lives here. "They see Germany as an economic giant and political dwarf that is willing to do anything that will mean more business."

HEADLINE: Campaign Waltz May Cost County Executive, Critics Say

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 28

 BODY:
Andrew P. O'Rourke appears to be waltzing toward the close of his re-election campaign, sometimes literally so.
The other day the Westchester County Executive, a burly, silver-haired grandfather who projects a cultivated affability, showed up at a Golden Harvest Dance for 1,000 elderly people and waltzed and tangoed a half-dozen women across the floor to Swing Era tunes like "Sentimental Journey." With a carefree air, he showed off the terpsichorean wiles his four sisters taught him when they were growing up on welfare in Manhattan's Hell's Kitchen and aspired toward what Mr. O'Rourke calls "polite society." 
 His Cheshire-cat grin bespoke a man who believes he has not been badly bruised in this campaign because he feels most voters think he has managed the county well and kept their taxes stable. But his Democratic critics say that self-confidence masks an inattentiveness and inertia that will cost Mr. O'Rourke dearly on Election Day.
Richard L. Brodsky, his 47-year-old Democratic challenger, argues that property taxes have more than doubled during 11 years of O'Rourke rule, that Mr. O'Rourke has wasted money on patronage and sweetheart deals for Republicans and that he has been idle while the county's economy lost 40,000 jobs. He says Mr. O'Rourke is running this year only because he lost a promised Federal judgeship with the election of a Democratic President.
Still, Mr. Brodsky's battle remains uphill because Mr. O'Rourke has the advantage of running affluent Westchester, a place that most residents consider congenial for raising families and where county government seems to get little of their scrutiny. Mr. O'Rourke is also an incumbent in a place where television's preoccupation with the politics of New York City makes it difficult for challengers to become known.
 
Charm and a Sense of Humor
 Mr. Brodsky has suggested the county's attractiveness can blind residents to their leaders' peccadilloes, arguing in a recent debate that Westchester remains livable "in spite of its government, not because of its government." But Mr. O'Rourke blithely retorted: "It's a great place because you have a great county government."
Charm is one of Mr. O'Rourke's greatest assets, supporters and opponents agree. His humor is more self-effacing than vindictive. He has a quiverful of disarming anecdotes. And he falls back on a childlike puzzlement when anyone accuses him of wrongdoing. He avoids harsh personal attacks, sharpening the contrast with Mr. Brodsky's flinty edge.
Some, like Alfred B. DelBello, Mr. O'Rourke's Democratic predecessor and fellow alumnus of Yonkers politics, think Mr. O'Rourke is too much the showman.
"Andy likes politics and likes the public aspect of it, but he never did like and doesn't apply himself to the job of administrator," he said.
With Democrats boasting a 23,500 edge in registration, Mr. O'Rourke must win over moderate and conservative Democrats, the kind who voted for a Republican like Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato.
"Andy's record appeals to them because they're concerned about welfare, crime, taxes and spending," said Peter W. Delaney, Mr. O'Rourke's campaign manager.
Indeed, Dr. Anthony Cupaiuolo, director of the Michaelian Institute for Public Policy and Management at Pace University, detects a reluctance on Mr. O'Rourke's part to emphasize his Republican affiliation just as he detects an effort by Mr. Brodsky, in this staid county, to sidestep traditional Democratic positions.
 
Stricter Welfare Rules
 Mr. O'Rourke and even opponents like Mr. DelBello rank a toughening in the county's welfare procedures as perhaps Mr. O'Rourke's most signal accomplishment. Mr. O'Rourke says that by compelling recipients to work or learn skills and monitoring their diligence, he has saved the county millions of dollars and put 2,600 people to work in the last year. The number of aid-to-dependent-children cases is expected to rise, however, from 11,751 in 1992 to a projected 13,490 next year although the number of home relief cases is expected to fall from 6,513 to 5,497.
Mr. Brodsky argues that Mr. O'Rourke is taking credit for a welfare revisions mandated by the state, and more liberal critics say Mr. O'Rourke has hardened the lives of deserving poor. But Mr. O'Rourke, citing his own welfare background after his widowed mother became blind, argues that his motives have been compassionate.
"It's an uncomfortable feeling to be on the public dole, and from a human feeling we should get people off," he said.
 
The Housing Issue
 He has proceeded somewhat more gingerly on the more explosive issue of housing for low- and moderate-income families, with the specter it raises for some white suburbanites of an influx of poor minorities and urban-style problems.
"I'm not here to integrate communities," Mr. O'Rourke said in an interview. "I'm here to build affordable housing. People understand we're getting more minorities in Westchester. They must be taken care of, and the basic right of any citizen is a decent place in which to live."
Mr. O'Rourke, who beat Mr. Brodsky by 6 percentage points four years ago and dismisses him as a hack politician, is trying to convince voters that he has kept the faith by stabilizing taxes for the last two years and through next year.
 
Moral Backbone Questioned
 But his critics say he does not have the moral spine required of a leader given a $1.2 billion budget and 10,000 people to manage. Mr. O'Rourke has admitted that he recommended the woman he lives with, Flora Lowe, for a job with the county's health insurer and that he asked officials of the medical school that runs the county hospital to seek a doctor's slot for his son-in-law and a school admission for his daughter Alice.
This week Mr. O'Rourke lost the endorsements of the editorial pages of The New York Times and Gannett Suburban Newspapers, both of which backed him in 1989. Voters, the Gannett chain said, no longer tolerate "in-your face patronage and cynical influence peddling."
Mr. O'Rourke took the news with the same cheery mien that he seems to lose only when opponents attack his personal life. "Thank you for being here on my birthday," he told reporters at a news conference on Tuesday, his 60th birthday. "I already got a singing telegram from Gannett."
A graduate of Fordham University's law school, Mr. O'Rourke ambled into politics as a fledgling Yonkers lawyer looking for clients. He chose a Republican club, he once said, because it had regular meetings and the Democrats did not.
He started out as a Yonkers councilman, moved up to the county legislature and was chairman of that Republican-dominated body when Mr. DelBello was elected lieutenant governor in 1982 and the county legislature got to pick a successor -- Mr. O'Rourke. Outside that office, the highlight of his career was a quixotic bid for governor in 1986.
In the heady days of the mid-1980's, Mr. O'Rourke spent liberally, and property taxes have risen from $147 million in 1983 to $329 million this year, a 124 percent increase. A not insignificant share of that increase was spent on housing the county's exploding homeless population, which stands at 3,300.
Mr. O'Rourke also rebuilt the county's civic center, expanded its airport and medical center, built a new jail and recycling center, and created such amenities as a bus system that daily transports 400 disabled people to doctors or shopping centers.
He says that by avoiding deficits he has retained Westchester's AAA bond rating, and he takes credit for keeping unemployment at 5.7 percent during a recession in the Northeast. He shrugs off accusations of ethical blindness, pointing out that District Attorney Carl A. Vergari found he had broken no laws.
"The whole thing I went through proves that I never took advantage of the public trust," Mr. O'Rourke said.
Mr. O'Rourke has three grown children by his wife, Alice, from whom he has been separated since 1987. As painful as the hiring disclosures was the scrutiny of his family life. The separation from his wife, he had to confide, so alienated his daughters that he was not even aware that one, Aileen, was working for a law firm doing county business.
He is an aficionado of military history and, while in office, wrote two adventure novels, "The Red Banner Mutiny" and "Hawkwood," both published by Bantam Books.
"I think most people think the government is running well," he says. "And if they think it's not, then it's time for a change."

HEADLINE: Senate Approves Jobless Aid But Attaches Two Conditions

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28

 BODY:
The Senate voted today to renew a two-year-old program that grants up to 13 extra weeks of checks to jobless workers who exhaust their normal unemployment benefits. But the Senate did so only after tacking conditions to the renewal that confounded its prospects in the House.
The measure now goes to a House-Senate conference, where lawmakers from both chambers will try to agree on a version of the bill that each side can pass and send to the White House. 
 No new recipients have been added to the emergency unemployment benefits program since it expired on Oct. 2, and none can be added until the House and Senate reach agreement.
Unemployed workers are normally entitled to six months of benefits, and about 60,000 people exhaust those 26 weeks of checks every month.
 
Threats of Filibuster
 Congress voted an emergency extension of that 26-week period in November 1991, and has renewed the extra benefits three times since. The bill now before Congress would prolong the emergency program of additional benefits for four months, to next February, at a cost of $1.1 billion.
Lawmakers in both parties generally say they support the four-month extension, but Republicans have balked at its generosity and at the Democrats' unwillingness to pay for it by making cuts elsewhere in the 1994 budget. The House passed a version of the extension last week, but the Senate's first attempt to pass it, on Wednesday, was strangled by Republican threats of a filibuster.
Today, the Senate voted, 76 to 20, to approve the bill, but only after Republicans attached two amendments.
 
Federal Job Cuts
 The first amendment, proposed by Senator Phil Gramm, Republican of Texas, and approved by 82 to 14, would carve into law a White House proposal to reduce the Federal workforce by 252,000 employees.
The second amendment, sponsored by Senator Hank Brown, Republican of Colorado, would deny additional unemployment checks to any jobless worker who reported a taxable income last year of more than $120,000. It passed by a vote of 52 to 43.
By any Federal yardstick, the effect of that proposal would be minuscule, denying benefits only to about 26,500 workers and saving the Government about $2 million. But it sticks in the craw of many Democrats, to whom unemployment checks are a benefit that should be available to everyone.
The bill would grant an additional seven weeks of unemployment benefits to jobless workers in every state with an unemployment rate below 9 percent. In states with jobless rates above 9 percent workers would receive an extra 13 weeks of benefits.

HEADLINE: U.S. Judge Rules Council Lines In Bridgeport Violate Rights Act

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Oct. 28

 BODY:
Less than a week before Election Day, a Federal judge has ruled that a Bridgeport City Council district map drawn this year violates the Federal Voting Rights Act and the United States Constitution and must be redrafted.
The judge ordered that municipal elections proceed next Tuesday, to avoid throwing the city government into chaos, but established strict timetable requiring a new map within 60 days, and a special election within 120 days to replace the winners of next week's contests. 
 The judge, Peter C. Dorsey, ruling in a case filed by the Connecticut Civil Liberties Union and the N.A.A.C.P., said that although black and Hispanic residents represent more than 50 percent of Bridgeport's population, council district lines have diluted minority voting strength by dividing neighborhoods. The 20-member council has 4 black members and 1 Hispanic member.
 
Intent Doesn't Matter
 "The issue is not whether a discriminatory purpose caused the present districts," Judge Dorsey said in his order. But the facts, he said, are undisputable. "The white predominance in Bridgeport elections has continued."
Lawyers for the two groups said it was the first case ever filed in Connecticut using the Voting Rights Act, which has primarily been used in the South to increase black representation. They said that the decision, while it sets no precedents for other jurisdictions, will probably be used to pressure other Connecticut cities, including New London and Meriden, in a state in which minorities are said to be underrepresented.
"It is our intention to try and bring more of these challenges in Connecticut," said Samuel L. Walters, an assistant general counsel to the N.A.A.C.P., which has filed previous suits in New York under the Voting Rights Act, including a case under way in the town of Niagara Falls.
For Connecticut's largest city, Judge Dorsey's order, signed on Wednesday, is just one more travail. In recent years the city has brushed with bankruptcy, battled drug gangs, and tried without success to bring in casino gambling to rebuild the economy.
The City Attorney, Mark T. Anastasi, said it was a victory that elections would take place at all, and said that no decision about an appeal or any other action would be made until after Election Day. But other local and state officials said the deadlines might be impossible to meet.
The 20 City Council members elected next week will be inaugurated on Dec. 1, almost 30 days into the 60-day period for drawing a new map. Several Council members said today that they thought that only the districts changed by the new map would have to hold special elections, a prospect that could complicate negotiations further as new members battle to retain their district lines to avoid having to run again.
"It cannot be done in this timetable," said State Senator Alvin W. Penn, a former councilman who now represents the city in Hartford. "There are too many questions."
 
5 New Districts
 Judge Dorsey, without specifying how it should be done, ordered the city to create two new districts in which a majority of the voters are black, two new districts with a Hispanic majority and one in which the total of black and Hispanic voters constitutes a majority.
One white council member, Michael J. Marella Jr., whose district was changed this year to include more blacks, said he was not thinking past Tuesday.
"We'll just keep going, then we'll take the bull by the horns and see what happens after that," he said. In any case, he said he believed there could be a silver lining for some candidates next Tuesday.
"If they lose, this gives them an opportunity to run again," he said.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Cox to Form a Tiger Fund

 BODY:
Archibald Cox Jr., former chief of CS First Boston, said yesterday that he had joined the Tiger Management Corporation, where he will be head of a new fund investing in companies in China, Southeast Asia, Latin America and Eastern Europe.
As chairman of the new Tiger International Fund, Mr. Cox will start by helping raise money from investors and be responsible for investing up to $1 billion in companies in those markets. He plans to live in Hong Kong to be close to China, the fund's major field of operations. Tiger International will invest directly in companies and projects for which there is no way of investing through publicly traded stocks or bonds. 
 "In these markets it is hard to find enough publicly traded stocks to invest large amounts of money," said John A. Griffin, president of Tiger Management. "You could readily invest $100 million in a power plant or container port in China, but to buy $100 million of stock in China is impossible. Their capital markets are not yet developed enough."
Despite the lack of well developed markets, Mr. Cox said he was confident that "Asia will be the place of greatest economic growth and best performing markets in the 1990's."
He declined to say whether the new fund might match the 32 percent annual return posted by the Tiger Management Corporation since 1980, but added, "We would not be doing it if we did not think that there will be exceptional returns which would be hard to achieve through normal portfolio investments in Western Europe or the United States."
Mr. Cox said the fund expects generally to have partners, including local partners, in its investments. These could take several years to bear fruit, but will not be limited to long-term infrastructure projects.
The new venture comes three months after Mr. Cox resigned as chief executive at First Boston, which he joined in 1990.

HEADLINE: Developer Wins Project To Revitalize Atlantic City

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 28

 BODY:
The company that has developed such urban centers as Harborplace in Baltimore and the South Street Seaport in New York today won the nod to turn 20 square blocks of this shabby resort city into a $520 million hotel-retail-entertainment complex.
The selection of the Rouse Company of Columbia, Md., is a step toward making the city less dependent on its casinos and developing it as a broader vacation and convention destination. The choice of Rouse still must be ratified by the board of directors of the Casino Reinvestment Development Authority at a meeting scheduled for Nov. 8. 
 The first part of the effort to build a tourist corridor to link the Boardwalk with downtown Atlantic City will include a non-casino hotel run by Doubletree Hotels Corporation with financing by Caesars Boardwalk Regency Corporation. The hotel would serve as the flagship for a new $254 million convention center.
"This urban entertainment center is designed to attract family and non-gaming tourists to Atlantic City and create year-round attractions for both domestic and international visitors," said Nicholas Amato, head of the development authority.
 
7,500 Jobs Foreseen
 The corridor project, which Mr. Amato said would create about 1,500 permanent jobs and 6,000 construction jobs, is also expected to include a multimedia entertainment center, restaurants and local and national retail stores.
"There are those around who say, 'What's going to happen to Atlantic City?' This is our answer," Mayor James Whelan said.
Rouse officials said today that the company, which has assets worth $4 billion, is committed to using local workers, vendors and developers throughout the estimated five-year project.
Bob Minutoli, Rouse senior vice president, said the company also had a strong commitment to affirmative action, and would exceed state and local mandates for using minority- and women-owned companies.
The project will be financed partly with bonds from the development authority, which collects 1.25 percent of gross casino revenues for development projects statewide, revenue from the $2 casino parking fee and contributions from other state agencies, said Dennis Lower, the authority's associate deputy director.
The balance, about $270 million, is to come from the sale of private bonds. Doubletree and Caesars were leveraging $35 million to bring $50 million to the project, Mr. Lower said.

HEADLINE: Fairchild Plans to Convert Plant Into a Shopping Mall

BYLINE: By JOHN T. McQUISTON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: EAST FARMINGDALE, L.I., Oct. 28

 BODY:
The Fairchild Corporation announced plans today to redevelop the abandoned 80-acre aircraft plant from which thousands of fighter planes rolled off the assembly line during World War II. The company described it as one of the largest military conversion projects on Long Island.
The cavernous hangars, loading docks and graffiti-covered office complex will be torn down and replaced by a shopping mall with three major retailers and scores of specialty stores. 
 The Fairchild plant, once one of Long Island's biggest factories with 5,000 employees, is in the center of the Island on Route 110, a busy industrial-commercial corridor running along the Suffolk-Nassau border. The plant closed in 1983.
The project will cost between $80 million and $100 million, and the money will come from Fairchild, said Jeffrey J. Steiner, chairman and chief executive of the multinational corporation, which has worldwide real estate and manufacturing interests and annual sales of $1.5 billion.
Mr. Steiner, who announced the plans in Hangar 17, the size of three football fields, said he hoped not only to generate thousands of construction and retail jobs, but also to generate taxes for the Town of Babylon and Suffolk County.
Environmental problems that have blocked past development efforts on the old industrial site apparently have been resolved, said Richard H. Schaffer, supervisor of the Town of Babylon. He said an agreement between Fairchild, Babylon and New York State would allow Fairchild to designate an area in the southeast corner of the property as a state Superfund cleanup site, with Fairchild assuming responsibility for the cleanup.
Mr. Steiner said Fairchild had chosen Peter L. Levine, commissioner of the Meadowlands Sports Complex in New Jersey and president of Levcom, which specializes in building and operating shopping centers, as the developer of the Fairchild project.
"This old plant represents what's great about this county, while at the same time what's hurting the country," Mr. Levine said. "It was once a place of great pride and should be again."
He described the 80 acres as "the finest available, large site in all of Long Island."
"It sits in the center of the Nassau-Suffolk market place, and from a demographics viewpoint, is strong," he said. Levcom and Fairchild officials hope that an economic upsurge in the late 1990's will enable industrial development on the other half of the Fairchild site, with an emphasis on research and development.
Most World War II pilots learned to fly using Fairchild's single-engine trainer, the PT-19. Many Air Force pilots then flew Fairchild's P-43 and P-47 single-engine fighter planes. From 1950 to 1954, Fairchild produced the F-84 Thunderjet, a single-engine fighter, followed by the F-105, and most recently the A-10, an air-support craft used during the Persian Gulf war.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
XEROX CORP. (N)

 BODY:
The Xerox Corporation said yesterday that third-quarter net income rose 24 percent, exceeding the expectations of industry analysts and buoying the company's shares.
Xerox stock rose $5.75, to $76.375, on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. 
 Xerox shares had declined slightly earlier in the week, as analysts said investors anticipated the company's third-quarter results would be as lackluster as in the first half, when slow economies and a reorganization of its sales force cut into profits.
Instead, Xerox said its earnings had improved as equipment sales increased after two quarters of decline. A cost-cutting drive trimmed expenses by $72 million in the period. Those cuts included 600 more jobs, trimming employment at the company, based in Stamford, Conn., by 1,800 since Jan. 1. Xerox's domestic employees account for about half the company's global work force of 97,500.
"The company had a bang-up third quarter, a quarter which should have been a problem," said B. Alex Henderson, an imaging analyst at Prudential Securities.
Mr. Henderson had expected Xerox to show a 20 percent decline in operating profits and a 3 percent decline in revenue in the period, because of the company's exposure to currency fluctuations and poor sales in Europe.
In Brazil, where Xerox sold $1 billion worth of products like copiers and printers last year, high inflation led to a foreign exchange loss of $55 million in the period. In the comparable period a year ago, Xerox had no Brazilian currency charges.
"For the balance of the year, the European and Brazilian economic environments will remain difficult, and competitive pricing and currency will continue to put pressure on earnings," Paul A. Allaire, the chairman and chief executive of Xerox, said in a statement yesterday.
To focus on its document processing business, Xerox has over the last year sold pieces of its financial services business. Its insurance operations are on the block now.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar's Rally Is Cut Short In Selloff by Europe's Banks

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The dollar retreated against most currencies yesterday after selling by European central banks ended an early rally.
In late trading in New York, the dollar was quoted at 1.6740 German marks, down from 1.6800 marks on Wednesday. It also fell to 108.17 Japanese yen, from 108.69 yen. 
 Gold prices slipped. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for December delivery fell 50 cents, to $370.20 an ounce.
The dollar rallied early yesterday after the Commerce Department released its preliminary estimate showing United States third-quarter gross domestic product rose by 2.8 percent. Excluding the effect of flooding in the Midwest and droughts in the Southwestern United States, the G.D.P. would have grown by 3.4 percent in the quarter, the report said.
Even though the report was in line with expectations, dealers took the news as a confirmation of the new, rosier view of the United States economy and a good reason to buy dollars.
"The figures were pretty much as we, and the market, expected and on the whole you could not ask for a better set of numbers," said Jane Edwards, an international economist at Lehman Brothers in London.
But the dollar's rally was short-lived, a result dealers blamed on the aggressive sales of dollars for marks by the Bundesbank of Germany and other European central banks.
 
Shoring Up Reserves
 Several European central banks, most notably the Bank of France, still must pay back to the Bundesbank the marks used in early August to buy local currencies that tumbled after the European Monetary System was rejiggered.
The Bundesbank also may have bought marks to shore up its own reserves, but dealers speculated that the bank may have been concerned about the mark's weakness against the dollar after cuts in German interest rates last week.
The dollar also eased against the yen in late trading in New York, but ended above the lows touched in Tokyo after the American economist C. Fred Bergsten set off panic selling when he said United States policy favored a dollar at 100 to 110 yen.
"The market in Tokyo is much more sensitive to it," Belal Khan, a senior dealer at the Bank of Tokyo in New York, said of Mr. Bergsten's comments. United States dealers said it was unclear how much influence Mr. Bergsten, who is the director of the private Institute for Internatinal Economics, had with the White House.
The British pound finished in New York at $1.4895, up from $1.4805 on Wednesday.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
A ski resort company is poised to benefit from a sport's rebound.

BYLINE: By Robert Hurtado

 BODY:
DESPITE a recent rejuvenation of the ski business, there are still many resorts that face hard times and are considered prime acquisition candidates for the stronger operators. And few resorts are liquid enough to take advantage of the rich opportunities.
According to some Wall Street professionals, investors angling to profit from this should consider an enterprise like S-K-I Ltd., a publicly traded company in Killington, Vt., that has deep enough pockets to do some buying. 
 "The ski industry has recovered from a spate of unusually mild winters and the recent recession, which combined to stall growth," Robert Mains, an analyst with the First Albany Corporation, said. "Cash-strapped and teetering on bankruptcy, some financially weaker ski resorts will sell out to the better capitalized operators who are poised to make attractively priced acquisitions in this period of industry consolidation."
Industry experts said operators of ski resorts shared many of the same headaches of real estate investors who bought properties in the late 1980's at heavily marked-up prices and now cannot make ends meet. It did not help that the Japanese, in their quest to own prime American real estate, bought at least six big ski resorts and helped to drive up property values.
Declining property values have wiped out investors' equity, and in some cases put the debt obligations of these owners at a premium to the value of the resort. The cash flows from the ski resorts never materialized, making it nearly impossible to service the debt. "These are the conditions that lead to fire sales," Mr. Beja said.
Financially strong and cash rich, S-K-I Ltd. is viewed by some market players as a natural beneficiary of any industry consolidation. The company operates three ski areas, Killington and Mount Snow in Vermont and Bear Mountain in California, and is well regarded in the industry for its ability to take on new properties and enhance their value, according to some analysts.
David M. Basoco, an analyst with Chesapeake Research, said that by any valuation, the stock appeared cheap, since it had been trading at less than 13 times this year's earnings estimate.
Conditions are clearly improving for acquisitions. Indeed, S-K-I last week signed a purchase agreement with a small resort adjacent to its Killington property. But the company has not acquired a big property since 1988, when it bought the California operation.
The company said recently that over the longer term, it would pursue opportunities to add diversity to its revenue base and reinforce profit margins, and it was ready to take advantage of those opportunities when they emerged.
Joel Tillinghast, a portfolio manager with Fidelity Investments in Boston, said he favored S-K-I on the fundamentals.
"Management has done an excellent job of making money rather consistently in a business that is highly seasonal and weather dependent," he said. He pointed to S-K-I's ability to stay in the black in the bad years, as well as the good, chalking up 33 years of profitability in the process. Over the last 20 years, the company has recorded 16 percent compounded growth in equity and 15 percent compounded revenue growth.
One trick to its success has been to reduce its dependency on natural snow by manufacturing its own. To maintain its competitive edge, S-K-I has upgraded its ski operations with spending on new chairlifts, improved trails and other amenities.
At the same time, it has always been strong on cost control. Variable costs, like a part-time staff, are monitored and adjusted to remain synchronized with the business conditions.
For the fiscal year that ended on July 31, S-K-I reported earnings of 77 cents a share, on revenues of $98 million, compared with 65 cents a share, on revenues of $89 million a year ago. Value Line expects the company to earn about 90 cents a share in fiscal 1994.
S-K-I stock fell 50 cents, to $12.25, in Nasdaq trading yesterday.

HEADLINE: Review/Dance;
The Taylor, In Wedding Of Darkness And Light

BYLINE: By JENNIFER DUNNING

 BODY:
Paul Taylor is famous for bright-looking dances with a dark underside. But Mr. Taylor has never merged the two quite so inseparably as in "A Field of Grass," presented by the Paul Taylor Dance Company in a world premiere on Wednesday night at City Center. An evocation of six songs by Harry Nilsson from the late 1960's and early 70's, the dance begins on an insidiously goofy note. Why, one wonders, is Mr. Taylor bothering to plunk a grinning dancer center stage, seated in a lotus position and dragging on a cigarette, to the accompaniment of this tepid musical soup?
Very gradually, as "A Field of Grass" moves from one song through another, Mr. Taylor creates a landscape filled with green, sun, a soft breeze and gamboling youngsters in bell-bottom jeans. As gradually, the dancers' bodies tauten. Tall, threatening city buildings seem to have sprung up across earth that one recognizes as tinged with blood. The sun comes out again from behind thin storm clouds at the end. But it shines down on games forbidden in the time that the songs establish and the dance suggests. 
 A good deal of the power of "A Field of Grass" is attributable to the subtlety with which Jennifer Tipton dims, hardens and brightens the light in which the dance takes place. The songs grow darker, too, in a teasing sort of way. And Mr. Taylor has found the perfect interpreter in Patrick Corbin, a dancer who looks amusingly like a model happy-go-lucky boy next door in everything he dances.
It isn't just the sweet wholeheartedness of his smile and his sunny blondness. Mr. Corbin, as he has proved increasingly with each successive year in the Taylor company, is a dancer for all seasons. So buoyant he looks as if a feather could knock him off course, Mr. Corbin is in reality a dancer of impressive strength, resiliency and nuanced physicality. It is hard to imagine anyone else dancing this crucial role, though he is accompanied by two lithe male dancers and a quartet of charmingly sassy females.
But in the end this is Mr. Taylor's deceptively low-keyed triumph. The skipping, ground-skimming dancers of the first song, "Mother Nature's Son," become robots who spurt into brief flights of free flight in the ritualistic "Rainmaker," their limbs locked into bayonet-sharp angles. The lovers look a little lost in "I Guess the Lord Must Be in New York City." They sidle and jive gently to a syncopated beat in "Daybreak," bodies pressing close in a tight conga line.
The group dance Mr. Taylor has set to "Spaceman" is one of his most chilling, its melee of flying bodies ending with Mr. Corbin's convulsive apparent death. Then it's back to calm, though an uneasy one, in "The Puppy Song." Everyone has a right to a friend of one's own, Mr. Nilsson sings, a friend who will be accepted everywhere. The time of the songs suggests the overt racial segregation of America in the 1960's. But the seven dancers swing through a continuous change of partners, arms around each other, often in same-sex couples. A slightly battered-seeming Mr. Corbin is still smiling. The dancers look happy. The effect, however, is subversive.
The fine cast of "A Field of Grass" was completed by Hernando Cortez, Richard Chen See, Sandra Stone, Caryn Heilman, Rachel Berman Benz and Denise Roberts, who stands out for her piquant dancing. Santo Loquasto's costumes suggest rather than announce their period, much in the manner of the songs.
It was good to see "Snow White" return to the Taylor repertory. David Gropman's ingeniously stripped-down theater-within-a-theater was as charming as ever. And Mr. Taylor's good-humored retelling of the story avoids the kind of acid comic high jinks that sometimes sink his funny dances. Francie Huber was delightful in the title role, all sappy Disney smiles and touching affection for her dwarfs. Elie Chaib is perfect as the hunched and slithering Queen and as the most stolid of princes.
Karla Wolfangle was the self-polishing, slightly tart Bad Apple. The lumbering, high-flying dwarfs -- only five for what Mr. Taylor has described as an economy production -- were played with great charm by Joao Mauricio, David Grenke, Andrew Asnes, Thomas Patrick and Edward Talton-Jackson. Mr. Taylor should next choreograph a dance for Bottom and his friends.
The program was completed by two of Mr. Taylor's most popular music visualizations, the gooey-sweet "Arden Court" and the pungent "Esplanade." Watching these dances, one marvels yet again at the ingenuity of the ways Mr. Taylor moves his dancers on and off the stage. Standing out in the compelling crowd of dancers were a twinkling Ms. Benz, the genial and accomplished Mr. Mauricio and, dancing only in "Arden Court," the stylish Mr. Talton-Jackson and Angela Vaillancourt, a big, easy, generous-spirited new Taylor dancer.

HEADLINE: 88 Picassos Lead Fall Auction Parade

BYLINE: By CAROL VOGEL

 BODY:
IN the next two weeks, the attention of the New York art world shifts away from the galleries and the museums and toward the auction houses during the fall sales of Impressionist, modern and contemporary art. This twice-a-year ritual, some of the best free theater in town, offers a variety of entertainment this season. Among the offerings, which go on view this weekend at the auction houses, are everything from the experimental to revivals, as paintings, sculptures and drawings with estimates totaling more than $207 million appear for the art market's autumn pulse-taking.
The usual pre-auction anxiety is evident as collectors, dealers and experts from all over the world flock to Sotheby's and Christie's to see works by artists ranging from Picasso and Renoir to Gorky and Hockney. Just how the market will fare in these economic times is the question everyone is asking. While this fall's auction catalogues are much leaner than those of the boom years in the 1980's, and the atmosphere is noticeably sadder, the experts who put the sales together are also far wiser. 
 "It's been hard getting good material," said Christopher Burge, the president of Christie's in New York. "But we both came through at the last minute," he added, speaking of his own auction house and its rival, Sotheby's.
Persuading collectors to sell choice artworks has been a struggle for everyone in the auction business for the last two years; people still prefer to hold on to their art, if they can, until the market shows a definite upturn. But that's only one part of the problem. Pricing is another. "We've made a conscious effort to keep estimates down," Mr. Burge said, adding that he believed prices would be back to where they were in the first half of 1988.
While more big-ticket paintings -- those expected to bring more than $2 million -- are up for sale than in recent seasons, these aren't what everyone's talking about. Instead, all eyes will be on Sotheby's sale of 88 Picassos on Thursday. The works date from 1899 to 1972 and range from multi-million-dollar paintings like "Women and Children at the Seashore" (1932), estimated at $2.5 million to $3.5 million, to small drawings like "Six Studies: Still Lifes, Figures and Landscapes" (mid-1920's), expected to sell for $8,000 to $10,000.
The collection was formed by Stanley J. Seeger, an American living in Switzerland who has been buying Picasso's work since 1980 and now wants to sell so he can start other collections. This is a highly personal group of Picassos reflecting one man's taste. Mr. Seeger bought all but four of the works at auctions in New York or London.
Putting so many Picassos on the block in the same evening is risky, especially given the delicate state of the market. Some experts say Sotheby's is courting trouble. Many auctiongoers are still haunted by last May's sales, when 16 Warhols were auctioned within 24 hours and only 2 were purchased. (Curiously, this season there are no Warhols for sale at either Sotheby's or Christie's; experts say neither house was offered any.)
David Nash, who heads Sotheby's department of Impressionist and modern paintings, said: "At first I was worried about selling so many Picassos at once. But the feedback we've been getting is very positive. Some people feel the sale might stimulate the market because there is such an enormous range. There's something for everyone."
And each has been priced to sell. In many cases, works have been estimated at far less than Mr. Seeger originally paid for them. For example, he bought "Study for the Actor and Two Profiles of Fernande" (1904-05) for $742,500 at Sotheby's in New York in May 1992. It is now expected to bring only $300,000 to $400,000. "Reclining Woman" (1932), which Mr. Seeger bought at Sotheby's in London in 1988 for $1.17 million, is back on the market with an estimate of $600,000 to $800,000. "The Faun Among the Branches" (1946), purchased at Sotheby's in London four years ago for $374,220, is now expected to bring $100,000 to $150,000.
Works that Mr. Seeger bought earlier, however, have estimates far above their original prices. "Glass, Bouquet, Guitar and Bottle" (1919), which he bought 12 years ago for $792,000 at Sotheby's in London, is now estimated at $2.5 million to $3.5 million. "Playing Cards, Package of Tobacco, Bottle and Glass" (1914), for which Mr. Seeger paid $495,000 at Sotheby's in London in 1981, now has an estimate of $1.5 million to $2 million, while "Women and Children by the Sea" (1932), for which he paid $810,000 at Christie's in New York 10 years ago, is being offered for $2.5 million to $3.5 million. "At the end of the day he'll probably break even," Mr. Nash said.
 
'Not Just Browsing'
 There are four Picassos in Christie's sale of Impressionist and modern art on Tuesday, but Michael Findlay, the senior director of Impressionist and modern paintings, said he didn't think that would be a problem. "Because of the chronology of the sales, it's unlikely that our Picassos will be affected," he said. "They will be offered first; each is from a different decade in the artist's career, and they come with reasonable estimates."
Christie's sale focuses on several star works by other artists. Among them is Renoir's "Motherhood or a Woman Nursing Her Son" (1886). The painting, which shows the painter's mistress, Aline Charigot, nursing their child, is considered choice because the artist rarely created a work on this scale that was at the same time an intimate glimpse of his own family. While Christie's catalogue doesn't give an estimate, the auction house said the work might fetch about $8 million. The last time this painting was at auction was in 1988, when it was sold at Sotheby's in New York for $8.8 million. "The market is at 1988 levels," Mr. Findlay said of the current offering, "and this is lower than it sold for, which makes it quite reasonable."
Also at Christie's is Degas's "Dancers Taking a Bow (The Ballerinas)," from 1885. "It's not that typical at this stage in his career for Degas to have done a luminous pastel, and he rarely painted ballerinas on the stage," Mr. Findlay said. "They were usually resting in the wings."
Mr. Findlay said prospective buyers had expressed interest in the Degas and Renoir. "The market as a whole is gathering steady speed," he said. "Collectors these days are calling to look at very specific things. They're not just browsing."
Sotheby's sale of Impressionist and modern art on Wednesday is also geared for the serious collector. The most notable work, by far, is a colorful Matisse cutout, "The Wine Press" from 1951, which Mr. Nash said could bring about $10 million. "Cutouts are extremely rare," he explained. "The last big one at auction was in 1966."
The work, which was included in the Museum of Modern Art's giant Matisse retrospective last year, has generated interest from American museums as well as private collectors. "We've seen growing confidence in the market," Mr. Nash said. "Since last fall, each sale has done better and better, and people are feeling more secure."
 
Continuing Struggles
 But this upbeat mood is not reflected in the market for contemporary art, which is still struggling to crawl out of the doldrums. Offerings are slim at both houses, although each has several strong works.
At Christie's sale on Nov. 9, there is Gorky's "Year After Year" (1947), which is being sold by Gifford Phillips, a New York collector and a trustee of the Museum of Modern Art. Beautifully colored, the lush abstract painting is full of symbolic images. While Christie's has not provided an exact estimate, it says the painting may bring $3 million to $4 million.
Another important work in the Christie's sale is an untitled Cy Twombly work from 1969, a blackboard painting with spiraling scrawls in chalk on a gray background. "In the height of the market, this would have brought upwards of $3 million," said Diane Upright, who heads Christie's contemporary-art department. This season the auction house hopes it will bring $1.8 million to $2.2 million.
"The painterly quality is powerful, and it comes with a good price," Ms. Upright said. "Grand old pieces bring out grand old collectors. But happily, we are also seeing a lot of potential new buyers, mostly Americans."
 
Safety and No Saatchi
 Sotheby's contemporary sale on Nov. 10 has been put together with specific buyers in mind. "It's a safe sale; we haven't stuck our neck out," said Lucy Mitchell-Innes, the head of the contemporary-art department at Sotheby's worldwide. "Every work has been carefully curated to match pieces to known buyers."
The absence of Charles Saatchi, the London-based advertising magnate who has been a steady seller at Sotheby's for two years, is apparent. But even without him, the auction house has managed to obtain a few prime works. Among the stars are David Hockney's "California Art Collector" (1964), estimated at $600,000 to $800,000, and a 14-foot-tall Calder standing mobile from 1960 called "Constellation," expected to fetch $500,000 to $700,000.
There is also a strong group of Minimalist works, including Donald Judd's first wall progression (1964), estimated at $60,000 to $80,000, and "Several," a 1965 sculpture by Eva Hesse, expected to bring $350,000 to $450,000. (Mr. Hockney, Calder and Ms. Hesse are all artists whose work has done well at auction recently.)
Besides the safe quality of the sale, there are other telltale signs of tough times. Sprinkled throughout Sotheby's catalogue are works by artists including Mr. Twombly, Ellsworth Kelly and Frank Stella that are clearly distress-sale merchandise. Each is marked "Property of the F.D.I.C., as Receiver of First City Bank, Houston."
Sotheby's has also kept its contemporary works priced in the $50,000-to-$750,000 range; the auction house's experts said this was the range with which collectors have indicated they feel comfortable. "The sale shows a definite change from last year, a move away from being heavily weighted toward Abstract Expressionist and Color Field artists, to the next generation, namely Minimalist, Conceptualist and Neo-Expressionist," Ms. Mitchell-Innes said.
Her colleague Anthony Grant, who heads Sotheby's department of contemporary art in New York, added that the response to this fall's offerings had been positive. "There is no shortage of buyers for top quality," he said. "But anything less than first-rate is a real problem. These days, there's simply no urgency to buy."

HEADLINE: Sports of the Times;
Iraq Saves World Cup For the U.S.

BYLINE: By GEORGE VECSEY

 BODY:
THE nation of Iraq did one huge favor for the United States yesterday. It saved this soccer-deprived republic from even the remote threat that the 1994 World Cup would have been whisked to a real soccer power. I doubt that the Iraqis were very happy about that side effect of their 2-2 tie with Japan, which meant neither nation qualified for the 1994 cup.
The Iraqis would have been a great story: a nomad team forced to play only road games because of the troubles in their homeland. They were in the same condition in the 1986 World Cup in Mexico when I interviewed them in their hotel in Toluca, and the goalkeeper gave me a keychain with Saddam Hussein's photo in color. During the Gulf war in 1991, I went scrounging around for that souvenir, but I couldn't find it. 
 Some fans would have adopted the Iraqis as underdogs. America loves an underdog. But the United States may never have seen the World Cup if the United States State Department had kept any Iraqi players from entering.
"We're going to deal with the issue if it comes up," said David Johnson, a spokesman for the State Department, which must be celebrating now that South Korea and Saudi Arabia have qualified on the playing fields of Qatar.
The precedent for stopping athletes from an unfriendly country was set last summer when the United States kept athletes from Libya out of the World University Games in Buffalo. The United States is currently taking part in an international economic embargo against Iraq, and just might have made it difficult for Iraq to take part in the 1994 World Cup, even though President Reagan put it in writing in 1987 that all qualifying teams would be helped with entrance requirements.
In the wake of the Gulf war and the World Trade Center bombing, the State Department surely has legitimate concerns about internal security. But even threatening to keep athletes out of the world's most important sports tournament is a major policy step. As we saw in 1980 and 1984, athletes are the easiest hostages to failed politics.
The implied threat from the State Department ought to frighten the organizers from Atlanta, who have been awarded the 1996 Summer Games. As it happened, Billy Payne, the president of the Atlanta committee, was in New York yesterday. The former Georgia football player looked like he was high-stepping it through the old rubber-tire exercise as he distanced himself from other sports events.
"We shouldn't necessarily panic," Payne said. "The Olympic Games are not the World University Games or the World Cup. The Olympic Games are all about bringing people together, to bring about peace. You do not have that unmistakable mandate in other events."
Actually, soccer authorities say they make this a better world by unfurling yellow Fair Play banners and telling young players not to kick each other in the shins. And even if some Americans haven't figured it out yet, the World Cup is very big. Basically, the world shuts down for a month every four years.
I've been around the friendly folks from FIFA, world soccer's governing body. I don't think they would have been amused by the State Department playing games with passports of Iraqi players. In Zurich, the home office of soccer, a deal is considered a deal.
I happen to believe FIFA would have given the United States a few days to declare its intentions about Iraq, and then FIFA might have moved the 1994 World Cup to Germany, to Japan, surely not to England with its sociopathic fans, but possibly to Italy, home of the best cappuccino and the best soccer league in the world.
The Azzurri, the Blues, the national players of Italy, have no lock on the 1994 cup. If Italy loses to Portugal in Milan on the night of Nov. 17, it will probably not qualify, which would be social and economic disaster for millions of fans in the New York area, who are counting on Italy to play three, four, five games at the Meadowlands.
In my not-totally unrealistic scenario, the lads from Iraq were going to cause the 1994 cup to go straight back to the scene of the delightful 1990 World Cup. Of course, some Italian officials are otherwise detained, as the saying goes, during the current political scandals, but the games could have gone on.
One more goal by Iraq yesterday and my wife and I could have reclaimed "our" lovely flat over the two trattorias, and I could have covered most of the games on a $300 Italrail pass. Giddy fans from Norway and Cameroon and Bolivia and Mexico would have marched through train stations in Italy, waving flags, singing anthems.
Real soccer. Real soccer fans. Real soccer stadiums. Real soccer country. But I guess the United States will be interesting, now that its good pals from Iraq have saved the World Cup.
